fields.headline: Extracts from the report
fields.trailText: "Everything points to the fact that a doctor with the sinister and macabre motivation of Harold Shipman is a once in a lifetime occurrence."
fields.body:
"Everything points to the fact that a doctor with the sinister and macabre motivation of Harold Shipman is a once in a lifetime occurrence."

Professor Liam Donaldson, chief medical officer

Key findings
 Shipman issued a total of 521 death certificates, 499 while he worked in Hyde. The highest number issued by any other Hyde practitioner in the audit was 210.
 A comparison between Shipman and others shows that he issued 297 excess death certifcates. Of these, 236 patients died at home - the vast majority women over 65-years-old.
 The excess death certificates were evident from the beginning of his practice in Hyde.

Analysing the cremation forms
The following trends were revealed among Shipman's deceased patients:
 Death was more likely to occur in the afternoon
 The cause of death was certified as heart conditions, stroke or old age
 Mode of death described as syncope or collapse
 Shipman was likely to be present at the death of his patients while relatives and carers often absent.

The medical records
"Typically, Shipman records attending the patient within one day of death and finding vague symptoms or signs. In such circumstances, he frequently indicates a 'watch and wait' management plan by using the lettes 'tluk' - to let us know if the condition deteriorates. Case 502 is a typical example:

(Day before death) 'h/o vertigo. Falls to 150/100 r leg ? weak ? plantar left all ok stemetil sachets tluk if alters.'

(Day of death) 'o/e - dead. Neighbour saw at 1400 ok found 1500 in bed dead cva bp'

"Shipman's records of deaths certified as due to heart conditions were often similar, the patient being seen shortly before death with relatively mild symptoms, then being found dead within a few hours or the next day."

Cases referred to the coroner
The deaths of seven patients were referred to the coroner. Most were caused by accidents or overdoses, but one was referred by Shipman and detailed toxological tests were undertaken because he claimed to suspect that the patient had committed suicide. The notes of this patient were available for review and did not contain a history of depression although the patient had recently suffered a bereavement.

When the patients died
The annual numbers of deaths were low leading up to and after 1990-92 when Shipman moved to a single-handed practice. However, they increased steeply from 1993 to 1998. The numbers were also high from 1978 to 1982, and from 1984 to 1989, although the levels in these years were lower than 1993 onwards.

Conclusion
"The audit has uncovered a substantial body of evidence from various sources that raises grave concerns about Shipman's activities throughout the 25 years he spent as a general practitioner."

fields.headline: Ariel Sharon: the waiting warrior
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown profiles Israeli rightwinger Ariel Sharon, the war hero and people's favourite who is poised to succeed prime minister Ehud Barak next month
Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: Derek Brown profiles Israeli rightwinger Ariel Sharon, the war hero and people's favourite who is poised to succeed prime minister Ehud Barak next month.
fields.body:
Two opinion polls published in the Hebrew press this morning carry a grim portent for the frantic diplomatic effort to revive the Middle East peace process.

Both indicate a massive lead for Ariel Sharon, the rightwinger bidding to succeed prime minister Ehud Barak next month.

Sharon says that if he triumphs in the February 6 direct election, as now seems highly likely, he will not honour any agreement Barak reaches with the Palestinians. Instead, he will seek to impose his own 'peace' plan: using force to quell the intifada (uprising), and continuing the military occupation of the West Bank.

That is entirely in keeping with Sharon's stark politico-military philosophy, which barely tolerates the notion that Arabs have any business living west of the River Jordan.

He favours the creation of a Palestinian state - east of the river, in what is now the Hashemite kingdom of Jordan. On the West Bank, captured in the Six Day War of 1967, he dreams of establishing up to 2m Jewish colonists, to make the land forever part of Israel.

That Sharon should now be poised to take the top political job in Israel, is a measure of the fear and passion stirred by the intifada. The irony is that the uprising was sparked by Sharon himself, when he made an extraordinarily provocative visit to Islam's holiest shrine in Jerusalem, al-Haram al-Sharif.

The little riot that erupted during that visit blazed into violent confrontation throughout the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip. So far, some 360 people have been killed, of whom 40 were Israeli soldiers and civilians.

The official Israeli line is that the confrontation has been cynically orchestrated by Palestinian president Yasser Arafat, to squeeze more concessions out of the Israelis and their American sponsors. In reality, events have long since spiralled out of Arafat's control.

Soon, if the opinion polls are any indication, Arafat will have even less influence. Sharon has vowed he will never meet the Palestinian leader, let alone negotiate with him.

His loathing, it must be said, is shared by a large proportion of Israelis, for whom the very word Arafat is synonymous with 'terror'.

Arabs too have an understanding of 'terror'. For them, it is epitomised by the brute force used by the Israeli army and its assassination squads, by the humiliation and hardship of the continuing economic blockade - and by the harsh rhetoric used by men like Sharon.

He is without much doubt the Arab world's most detested Israeli; the embodiment of all they rage against in the Zionist system: ruthlessness, arrogance, and land-grabbing aggression.

Sharon, known to his many followers as 'Arik', would not altogether resent that view. He is indeed a militant Zionist, whose long life has been devoted to the cause.

Born in 1928 of Russian immigrant parents, Sharon was brought up in harsh world of a moshav, or cooperative farm community, where unrelenting hard work was the norm, and the danger of Arab attack a constant fear.

At the age of 14, he joined the Hagannah, the Jewish underground army pledged to protect the community and fight for independence. Fight it did, first against the British mandate authorities, and later against the combined Arab armies which tried to crush the fledgling Israeli state.

Sharon served with dash and distinction, and his rise was swift. In the early1950s, with Israel established but under continuing attack from guerrillas based in Egypt and Jordan, he was given command of the notorious Commando 101, charged with retaliatory action.

On one of his night raids into Jordan he ordered the dynamiting of Qibya village. Sixty nine innocent civilians were killed. In his 1989 autobiography, simply called Warrior, Sharon says he was shocked. Apparently it never occurred to him that Arab houses might contain Arabs.

In the 1956 Suez campaign, Sharon was accused of insubordination by his superior officers. Still he rose, attending Camberley Staff College in Britain, taking over an infantry brigade, and taking time out to pick up a law degree.

In the Six Day War, as a major-general, he brilliantly commanded the armoured division, and six years later in the Yom Kippur war of 1973, he led his armoured column to the far side of the Suez Canal where, to his chagrin, he was ordered to halt.

By that time Sharon had left full-time military service and had embarked on what has ever since been a stormy political career. He has held a number of key government portfolios. Easily the most controversial was his stint as Minister of Defence, when he masterminded Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon.

He personally approved the entry of Phalangist militia - Israel's allies - into the Palestinian refugee camps of Sabra and Chatilla, ostensibly to search for hidden guerrillas. It was the day after Phalangist leader and Lebanese president Bashir Jemayal had been assassinated, and the militia were in no mood for a police action. They massacred up to 2500 helpless refugees that day.

An unrepentent Sharon became the focus for an international storm of protest. An independent inquiry mildly criticised his role in the atrocity, and he was forced to give up the defence portfolio. But still he remained a pivotal figure in successive rightwing governments, perpetually jostling for leadership of the Likud bloc and a consequent chance to become prime minister.

He also vigorously pursued his vision of a dense network of Jewish settlements on the West Bank, a project which he was, and remains, convinced is vital to the defence of Israel. When Likud was displaced by Yitzhak Rabin's Labour government in 1992, the settler movement slowed but never stopped. There are now 144 Jewish colonies, with more than 170,000 inhabitants.

Sharon returned to office, as foreign minister, when Likud recaptured power in 1996. His main chance, however, came in the aftermath of the party's shock defeat last year, when defeated prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu resigned the Likud leadership and Sharon took over as his 'temporary' replacement.

In that role, having seen off a brief comeback attempt by Netanyahu, he is now four weeks from the job he has always lusted after.

The notes of this patient were available for review and did not contain a history of depression although the patient had recently suffered a bereavement.

When the patients died
The annual numbers of deaths were low leading up to and after 1990-92 when Shipman moved to a single-handed practice. However, they increased steeply from 1993 to 1998. The numbers were also high from 1978 to 1982, and from 1984 to 1989, although the levels in these years were lower than 1993 onwards.

Conclusion
"The audit has uncovered a substantial body of evidence from various sources that raises grave concerns about Shipman's activities throughout the 25 years he spent as a general practitioner."

fields.headline: London critics laud Billy Elliot
fields.standfirst: The feel-good yarn about a budding dancer in north-east England during the miners' strike of 1984-85 has been nominated nine times in this year's London Film Critics' Circle Awards
fields.trailText: The feel-good yarn about a budding dancer in north-east England during the miners' strike of 1984-85 has been nominated nine times for this year's London Film Critics' Circle Awards
fields.body:
Billy Elliot, the feel-good yarn about a budding dancer in north-east England during the miners' strike of 1984-85, has been nominated nine times in this year's London Film Critics' Circle Awards.

All the film's stars - 14-year-old newcomer Jamie Bell, Julie Walters and Gary Lewis (who played Billy's father) - and its first-time director Stephen Daldry, have received nominations. In fact, Bell and Daldry are up against each other, in the Best British Newcomer category.

Lewis faces competition for best British actor from Sir Anthony Hopkins in Titus and Ralph Fiennes, for The End Of The Affair. Kate Winslet and Emily Watson join Walters as nominees for best British actress.

Billy Elliot has proved a massive box-office hit on both sides of the Atlantic, recouping its costs within two weeks of its UK release.

Last month, it was nominated for two Golden Globe awards in Los Angeles, and appears to be a strong contender for an Oscar nod.

webTitle: Safeguards were not tough enough, admits DoH

fields.headline: Safeguards were not tough enough, admits DoH
fields.trailText: The Department of Health today admitted its regulations on family doctors were not tough enough to protect patients from serial killer GP Harold Shipman. Clare Horton reports
fields.body:
The Department of Health today admitted its regulations on family doctors were not tough enough to protect patients from serial killer GP Harold Shipman.

As the department unveiled a new report which suggested Shipman could have been responsible for nearly 300 deaths, it moved to reassure patients that strict new safeguards will be introduced this year.

A raft of new controls will come into force in April and further rules are expected to form part of the government's health and care bill.

From April, GPs will be subject to annual appraisals and will also be put through rigorous audits. Health authorities will have greater powers to suspend and bar doctors they believe unfit to practice.

The health and care bill proposes that GPs declare all gifts worth more than £25, a clause directly linked to the Shipman case.

A DoH spokesman said: "We acknowledge that we need to offer more protection to patients, while also supporting GPs to improve clinical performance.

"These measures mean that we can ensure that should another similar case ever occur it is picked up sooner or is less severe.

"The fact that we are trying to tighten up regulations in these areas and provide more support shows there was need for improvement."

Meanwhile, doctors' body the British Medical Association said its own research showed the Shipman case and that of Beverley Allitt, the children's nurse jailed for killing babies, had not dented public confidence in the medical profession.

But Dr John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA GPs' committee, said immediate action from the DoH was needed, rather than waiting for the findings of a public inquiry due to be launched later this year.

"The public needs reassurance now and the Home Office can take some important steps immediately to overhaul the systems for checking drug registers and for death certificates," said Dr Chisholm.

"Although, as the Chief Medical Officer has said a doctor with such sinister and macabre motivation is a once-in-a lifetime event, there is much to be learned from this tragic and horrific case.

"Shipman's crimes were the action of a uniquely evil individual but there was also a tragic systems failure that allowed his crimes to go undetected for so many years.

"I do not think we can simply wait for the outcome of the judicial inquiry."

The BMA is calling for:

 All deaths on practice premises to be automatically referred to coroners

 A clear definition of the categories of death coroners are allowed to investigate

 A statutory obligation to report those deaths to the coroner

 Monitoring and analysis of death information

 Coroners' areas to be made larger and supported with up-to-date technology, allowing patterns of death to be picked up

 GPs and pharmacists drug registers to be checked regularly

 Pharmacy registers to be cross checked to detect whether a doctor is using several different pharmacists to disguise untoward prescribing patterns.

webTitle: Australia and New Zealand ban European beef

fields.headline: Australia and New Zealand ban European beef
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Australia and New Zealand today banned imports of beef from across Europe over fears about mad cow disease.
fields.body:
Australia and New Zealand today banned imports of beef from across Europe over fears about mad cow disease.

British beef imports have been banned in Australia since 1996 but the government has now decided to suspend imports of all beef products from all 15 European Union nations.

Australia's chief medical officer, Richard Smallwood, said the temporary suspension, which comes into force on Monday, was triggered by fears about links between BSE and variant Creutzfeldt Jakob Disease (vCJD) in humans.

Prof Smallwood said New Zealand will also ban EU beef. "It is becoming clearer now that more countries in Europe may be affected by BSE in their cattle," he added.

"While the number of cattle involved in these countries is still small compared to the UK, federal health minister Dr Michael Wooldridge has taken action, in conjunction with other relevant ministers, to exclude these products from sale in Australia as a precaution.

"The risk to the health of Australians from the consumption of these products is extremely small. However, we need to keep one step ahead of the BSE/vCJD situation that is causing great concern in the UK and the rest of Europe."

Retailers would be asked to introduce a voluntary withdrawal of the beef products specified in the ban, and consumers should throw away any cans of food that contained beef from a European country, Prof Smallwood said.

Food already on its way to Australia and New Zealand would be stopped from entering shops.

Imported beef and beef products from the countries specified in the ban accounts for just 0.2% of beef consumed annually in Australia, he said.

A formal certification process is being established to assess future imports to ensure they are BSE-free.

Australia and New Zealand had no BSE in their cattle, Prof Smallwood added.

The import suspension affects 30 countries: Albania, Austria, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Macedonia, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the United Kingdom and Yugoslavia.

fields.headline: Election war chest piles up
fields.standfirst: Christopher Ondaatje joins Labour's £2m club
fields.trailText:
Labour last night astonished the political world and demoralised its opponents
         when it announced that two more multi-millionaires have each matched Lord
         Hamlyn's Christmas generosity and donated £2m to the party's war chest.
fields.body:
Labour last night astonished the political world and demoralised its opponents when it announced that two more multi-millionaires have each matched Lord Hamlyn's Christmas generosity and donated £2m to the party's war chest.

But the announcement that publisher and financier Christopher Ondaatje had joined Lord Sainsbury, now a government minister, in the £2m club was not quite the act of public-spirited openness that Labour immediately claimed.

After the enforced disclosure of Lord Hamlyn's similar gift, controversially filed six weeks before such donors will have to be identified by law, the Economist newspaper had warned Labour headquarters that it was poised to name the pair in today's edition.

Mr Ondaatje told the Economist he had been approached by Labour in November and told of the other £2m gifts. In December he agreed to donate the same. But only on Monday - as the Hamlyn row broke - was he asked to go public.

All three donors are what one top fundraiser last night called "men of impeccable standing in society". All three have given far more than £2m to cultural and educational bodies.

The National Portrait Gallery's new wing in central London is named after Mr Ondaatje, the older brother of Michael Ondaatje, an award-winning novelist.

The shift from dependency on the trade unions and party rank and file to the successful courtship of wealthy philanthropists is seen by MPs and party activists as representing a significant change in Britain's political culture.

The cash will go into a general fund and Millbank described £6m from three men as small beer compared with its £25m annual budget. But it is nearly half what Labour will be allowed to spend at the coming election - a cap is expected to be set at around £15m.

Veteran Labour MP Tony Benn called it "a negation of democracy" while the Conservatives brazenly denounced "Labour's continuing reliance on a small number of very large donors" - precisely its own position for many years. The Liberal Democrats again called for state funding of politics to stop sleaze and prevent governments being "in thrall to big corporations".

To rub salt into Conservative wounds, Mr Ondaatje was revealed as a former Tory donor who had become disillusioned with the party's anti-European stance.

"They [Labour] are doing a very good job [with the econ omy] at a difficult time and I believe they should be given every possible support," Mr Ondaatje said.

A Conservative victory at the election would be a disaster, he added.

Lord Sainsbury, the science minister, has already donated millions to Labour and before that to the SDP, which was also backed for a period by Lord Hamlyn.

Last night Lord Sainsbury said he was announcing his latest gift of £2m to head off speculation. "In our democ racy, political parties have to raise funds to campaign and put their policies to the electorate, and as a proud supporter of the Labour party I am happy that I am in a position where I can make a contribution," he said.

Last night Labour spin doctors insisted that the party retained the broadest fundraising base in Britain with 40% of its income coming from party members and small donors (below £5,000), 30% from the unions, 10% from sales and merchandising and 20% from big donors.

Lord Levy, the prime minister's personal fundraiser and envoy, is believed to have played a brokering role - although Chris Smith, the culture secretary, is admired by Mr Ondaatje and may have smoothed his path.

Labour's spokesman, Lance Price, said: "What we did feel after Lord Hamlyn made the statement he did on Tuesday, that it was right and proper, just to ensure that there was no confusion whatever, that other donors in that league, that we should at least contact them and see how they would feel about having their names made public as well."

Andrew Lansley, a senior Tory MP, complained: "This news of Labour's continuing reliance on a small number of very large donors, alongside the trade unions, for its financial backing highlights strongly the need for a broader base of party funding."

A Labour backbencher, Andrew Mackinlay, last night called for all large donors to be barred from receiving peerages. The Thurrock MP said: "There should be a ceiling on all large individual and corporate donations. All donors to political parties should be disqualified from being nominated for membership of the House of Lords by any party leader.

"Disqualification should exist for at least five years following the last donation," he added.

webTitle: Peer who has swelled Labour coffers by £7m

fields.headline: Peer who has swelled Labour coffers by £7m
fields.trailText:
When Lord Sainsbury , the science minister and multi-millionaire scion of the
         supermarket dynasty, announced yesterday he was pledging £2m to
         Labour's war chest, his generosity came as no surprise.
fields.body:
When Lord Sainsbury , the science minister and multi-millionaire scion of the supermarket dynasty, announced yesterday he was pledging £2m to Labour's war chest, his generosity came as no surprise.

The Labour peer, who bankrolled the SDP in the 80s, was the first Labour backer to go on the record about his largesse - revealing in September 1999 a £2m donation - the biggest ever given to the party. Since 1996 he has swelled the party's coffers by £7m.

He can, of course, afford it. He is worth an estimated £1bn and his family fortune amounts to £2.2bn.

The annual interest on his personal fortune is reported to amount to £35m - making him one of the few to meet the late Alan Clark's definition of the truly rich as those capable of living off the interest on the interest.

His beneficence is borne from being brought up in a family which places weight on principles. He spends more on charity than clothes, and omits Eton from his Who's Who entry because he does not want to appear a snob.

"The family is not flash," he said recently. "We inherited from somewhere a quite puritanical streak."

Critics claim his generosity to Labour is not without a desire for influence.

In 1997, shortly after being ennobled by Tony Blair, he was at the centre of controversy over accusations that a £1m donation was linked to a Sainsbury 's planning application - a charge vigorously denied by the government.

In 1999 he braved calls to resign from his post as science minister since Sainsbury 's has invested millions into GM food research.

He has also channelled millions into the study of genetically-modified organisms through a charitable foundation he established.

But the government insists he has been scrupulous in avoiding conflicts of interest. He resigned as chairman of the family firm on becoming a minister, placed his supermarket holdings in a blind trust and gave up policy responsibility for GM products.

One of a handful of high-profile businessman with whom the prime minister is keen to be associated, the 60-year-old, married with three daughters, entered the family firm on graduating from Cambridge. But his passions were always for science and politics rather than business.

A strong advocate of innovation, he has described himself as "romantic", defining romance as "having a vision of something you pursue that is way beyond what is reasonable."

His donation to Labour's election fund yesterday suggests thoughts of a probable second victory now seem the very antithesis of this.

webTitle: News International bosses scrap Times website merger

fields.headline: News International bosses scrap Times website merger
fields.standfirst: 1pm: Sun websites 'safe'
fields.trailText:
2.30pm: A plan to merge the Sunday Times and The Times websites has been scrapped, writes Guy Middleton.
1pm: Websites 'safe' says Sun
fields.body:
A plan to merge the websites of the Sunday Times and Times has been scrapped.

Management at the newspapers resisted the drive within some quarters of News International to scale back the online service with a joint operation.

They argued that control of the two sites must remain with the newspapers as they operate on entirely different editorial schedules.

And they argued that the brands of the newspapers would be diluted in any merged operation.

A senior source within the Sunday Times said that NewsCorp's UK new media operations had been gradually scaled back after the unsuccessful launch of FiredUp.com last year.

It was launched by News Corp's UK new media arm, News International Digital Publishing, as a European rival to US online auctioneer eBay.com.

fields.headline: Online auctions - bidder beware
fields.standfirst:
Shopping on the net may seem easy. But the consumer protection offered by many sale sites is less than ideal, as Louis Wustemann learned to his cost

Internet news
Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText:
Shopping on the net may seem easy. But the consumer protection offered by many sale sites is less than ideal, as Louis Wustemann learned to his cost.
Internet news
fields.body:
Auction sites such as Ibid, e-bay and QXL like to paint themselves as safe communities of like-minded individuals happily trading goods. But the sites are alarmingly easy for fraudsters to use - and the auction companies take no responsibility for any criminal activities taking place on their pages.

My first, and probably last, experience of online auctions cost me £1,500. I bid on and paid for a high-spec Mac G4 computer and monitor listed on QXL.com that turned out not to exist.

After winning the auction I received an e-mail from QXL congratulating me and giving me the seller's name and phone number and explaining it was now up to us to agree payment and delivery details.

The seller himself, Brinner Patino, an amiable character with an Italian-Glaswegian hybrid accent, said that as soon as the money cleared into his Woolwich account he would arrange for DHL to pick up the computer and monitor and deliver them the next day.

After transferring the money and arranging delivery with Brinner ­ with whom I had become quite chatty by now ­ I waited, and waited. I tried Brinner's number, which had become unobtainable, as had his mobile. I rang DHL, which said it had nothing in its system addressed to me. The Woolwich confirmed his account had been cleared of all funds. After this I contacted QXL and the police.

QXL's first suggestion was that I should give Brinner a "very bad" rating on the feedback section of the site. When I argued that this was a bit inadequate, they blacklisted him from the site.

But he was blacklisted only under that name. A QXL spokeswoman conceded that with a fresh credit card ­ the company requires a valid card-number from each seller ­ he could re-register under any name and work the scam again, since it doesn't check other registration details.

Asked how often the site was used for obtaining money by deception, she offered the pale reassurance that "only a minority" of sales turn out to be fraudulent.

Buried deep in the terms and conditions at QXL is the statement that it has no control over, or responsibility for, the quality, safety, or legality of goods or services in personal or merchant partner auctions, the truth or accuracy of its listings, the ability of these vendors to sell those goods or services, or bidding members' capability to pay for them.

Ajay Patel, principal lawyer for the Consumers' Association, confirmed that auction sites have no legal liability for the transactions they host. He warned that the anonymity offered by the internet makes online auctions more open to fraud than other forms of trading. Most consumer rights would not apply to purchases, since the sellers are usually private individuals rather than businesses.

"There may be greater risks buying from an auction site, and the sites should be more up-front about these risks," Patel said.

Meanwhile the police seem bemused by the whole internet aspect ("So - where exactly would you say the crime took place, sir?") and four weeks later, say they are still waiting for information about Brinner to be passed on by QXL.

All of which leaves me £1,500 out of pocket, still in need of a new computer, and believing the auction sites' homepages ought to carry big banners reading "caveat emptor".

fields.headline: Shipman may have killed 297
fields.standfirst: Full text of report
fields.trailText: Serial killer GP Harold Shipman, convicted of murdering 15 patients, may have killed up to 297 during his 24-year career, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
Serial killer GP Harold Shipman, convicted of murdering 15 patients, may have killed up to 297 during his 24-year career, according to a report published today.

The Greater Manchester family doctor recorded 297 more deaths at his practice than other GPs working at a similar time in the same area.

A statistical audit of his clinical practice between 1974 and 1998 found that he recorded 236 more deaths of patients in their homes than similar doctors.

The excess of deaths was greatest among women over 75, suggesting the Hyde GP may be the UK's worst serial killer.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, ordered the clinical audit after Shipman was convicted in January last year of murdering 15 of his elderly women patients.

Richard Baker of the University of Leicester carried out the audit, the results of which have been passed on to the police and crown prosecution service.

The chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, said: "The questions raised in the report will be distressing reading to the patients and relatives who were under Shipman's care over the years, but it is important for their sake that this work has been done and is published. It has started the process of addressing the many unanswered questions that remain after the trial of Harold Shipman. This review is unprecedented in its remit.

The analysis makes chilling reading. Taken in the rounds, the review suggests that there must be serious concerns about deaths of some patients during Harold Shipman's entire career as a GP."

A helpline has been set up for people worried that their relatives may have been a victim of Shipman, who is serving 15 life sentences in Frankland jail, County Durham. The numbers are 0161-633 8653 and 0161-622 6431/2/3.

Shipman murdered most of his victims in their own homes when no relatives were present, using massive doses of Diamorphine. Professor Baker said that it was the excess of deaths in similar circumstances uncovered by his audit that gave the most cause for concern.

Between 1985 and 1998 information was available for 288 of the 324 deaths for which Shipman issued death certificates. Prof Baker said 57.6% of these were classified as highly suspicious and 14.9% as moderately suspicious.

The audit found an excess of deaths in most years of Shipman's working life as a GP, from his earliest years in practice.

Introducing the report, Prof Donaldson said it had been commissioned after the "terrible crimes" of Shipman were exposed. "There were widespread feelings of horror and outrage among the general public and the medical profession itself," he said. Today's reports had been "painstakingly and rigorously" researched from a variety of medical documents relating to Shipman.

Prof Baker compared deaths of Shipman's patients with those of other local GPs and found that Shipman had 297 more deaths on his books than the average. Of these, 236 were deaths at home.

Prof Baker said: "Some excess of deaths were seen from the earliest years of Shipman's practice. They are not explained by the number, the age, sex or socio-economic characteristics of his patients. I should say 236 is the one I feel is most likely to represent the number of excess deaths."

Prof Baker said one of his sources of information was cremation forms filled out by Shipman between 1985 and 1998.

They revealed that, on average, he had last seen a patient only 49 hours before they died, compared with 88 hours for other GPs.

He was also present at death in 20% of cases, compared with just 0.8% in the cases of other GPs.

In deaths recorded by Shipman, relatives were present only 40% of the time, compared with 80% normally, and his patients died much quicker than normal.

Prof Baker gave examples of comments made by Shipman on cremation forms. One said: "Saw patient at home, diagnosis made, arranged admission ambulance, patient dead when went back, all within 10 mins."

Prof Baker said: "This seems to me very strange. Surely what you would be doing in those circumstances is resuscitating the patient and trying to keep them alive until the ambulance arrives."

webTitle: Samaritans braced for flood of post-holiday emails

fields.headline: Samaritans braced for flood of post-holiday emails
fields.standfirst: Online calls to the international counselling service have doubled year on year, and are proving a vital lifeline for the suicidal
fields.trailText: Online calls to the international counselling charity have doubled year on year, and are proving a vital lifeline for the suicidal. Nicola Hill reports.
fields.body:
January is traditionally a time when large numbers of people feel depressed and the Samaritans service is braced for a flood of requests for help - by email.

Emails to the Samaritans have doubled year on year since its online facility was launched in 1994. In 2000, more than 50,000 people contacted the charity by email - more than 100 messages a week. Figures to be released next week will show the number of email messages sent to the counselling service during the first few days of 2001.

The number of people who use the charity's email service when they feel suicidal is significantly higher than the number who use the telephone to ask for help. In 1999, the figures were 53% and 31% respectively.

Samaritans spokeswoman Rhian Thomas said the email service has been of particular benefit to men - suicides among younger men have doubled over the past 20 years.

"Email is proving a good way for men to reach out for help as they are less likely than women to turn to friends or GPs," said Ms Thomas. "It seems to give them a sense of distance, which is proving crucial. It gives men a chance to express their feelings in private but have a response from someone anonymous."

The charity was initially concerned about hackers breaching the confidentiality of the online service but Ms Thomas said the technology has proved secure.

"Email allows us to provide a service which is accessible to people with limited funds, to people in countries where legislation about suicide is very different and to people who do not have private access to a telephone," she said.

Twenty-seven branches of the Samaritans are equipped to receive emails, including two outposts in Hong Kong and Perth, Australia. Many more branches are currently preparing to come online to help cope with the rising demand. Volunteers handle "calls" from around the world, including a significant number from North America. The Samaritans promise to respond to messages within 24 hours.

The charity currently relies on 19,500 volunteers, but with the exponential increase in email users it is searching for more helpers. Ms Thomas said: "We are hoping that new year's resolutions will bring in more volunteers to match the traditional surge in demand for our services at this time of year."

Volunteers usually complete a shift of three to four hours a week and one overnight shift a month. None of the volunteers is exclusively concerned with email calls. Ms Thomas said: "Trepidation about the technology among some volunteers is easily overcome through training."

The bulk of the training focuses on how to provide the Samaritans' service through the written medium. "Using email, it is important to choose words carefully in order to show compassion, focus on feelings and explore thoughts about suicide," added Ms Thomas.

The charity is also looking to see how it can integrate other new technologies into its service. "With the emergence of interactive television and WAP phones, it will soon be possible and affordable for most people to send and receive emails," said Ms Thomas.

fields.headline: Bill and Ben blooms on BBC1
fields.trailText: 2.15pm TV overnights: The new-look, no-strings-attached Bill and Ben made a flobbatastic return to BBC1 yesterday after 30 years, By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Bill and Ben made a flobbatastic return to BBC1 yesterday afternoon after a 30-year break, boosting the audience in their slot by nearly half a million viewers.

The new colour version, which features animated models without strings, pulled in 1.7 million viewers yesterday afternoon - one in five of those watching TV at the time.

That was more than 400,000 up on the previous day's ratings for 3.45pm, according to unofficial overnights.

When Children's BBC shows were last running in the afternoon on the channel, in the week before Christmas, that slot also averaged 1.3m.

ITV kids' show Hey Arnold! took 1.4m and a 16% share while Bill and Ben was on air.

Elsewhere yesterday, 15m - a whopping 60% of the available audience - watched Mark Fowler escape from the long arm of the law and from Nick Cotton in a cliffhanger episode of EastEnders.

But once EastEnders was over, ratings tumbled to 7.6m with audience share halving.

This was partly due to a rejuvenated Who Wants to be a Millionaire? with 12m tuning in to watch Mr and Mrs Hannaford have a domestic while trying to answer the £250,000 question.

ITV comedy drama At Home with the Braithwaites returned successfully at 9pm with 7.6m, beating BBC1 opposition 2000 Acres of Sky, which was down to 6.2m.

Exactly 1m viewers switched off the new BBC1 drama starring Michelle Collins and Paul Kaye as Londoners who have relocated to a remote Scottish island community.

Channel 4's 1940s House began properly last night, following Tuesday's making-of taster, achieving a healthy 3.4m and 14% share from 9pm.

Hairy people having sex may not sound much of a recipe for popular TV, but Channel 4 pulled off this unlikely feat last night with The Joy of Sex.

The documentary about Dr Alex Comfort, the bearded wonder who became a sex guru in the 1970s after the publication of his Joy of Sex manual, drew 2.9m and a 15% share to Channel 4 from 10pm.

fields.headline: Middle East to West End
fields.standfirst: The relationship between Britain and the Arab world has been reaffirmed by the Syrian president's marriage to a Londoner. Middle East editor Brian Whitaker reports.
fields.trailText: The relationship between Britain and the Arab world has been reaffirmed by the Syrian president's marriage to a Londoner. Middle East editor Brian Whitaker reports.
fields.body:
The oasis begins at Marble Arch. Here, and for half a mile around Hyde Park are the streets frequented by the elite of London's Arab community.

But a little further west, in less fashionable Acton, is a modest terraced house which was the family home of 25-year-old Asma al-Akhras - until her marriage last Monday to the president of Syria.

Miss Akhras, whose father is a heart specialist, was born in Britain to Syrian parents. She first met Bashar al-Assad in London, where - in the days when he had no expectations of becoming president - he studied ophthalmology.

This is by no means an unusual story. The late King Hussein married a British woman, as have several sheikhs from the Gulf.

The Arabs' love affair with Britain, and especially London, dates back to the time when large parts of the Middle East were British protectorates. Princes and wealthy sheikhs would send their sons to British public schools, and then to the military college at Sandhurst.

That is still seen as a good preparation for government. King Abdullah of Jordan, the crown prince of Qatar and the son of Yemeni president Ali Abdullah Salih are among many who have followed the Sandhurst route.

London also became a fashionable place to have medical treatment. Even today, although hospitals in the Middle East have improved greatly, some Arab politicians are still wary of local doctors who might be tempted to administer lethal doses of medicine or fail to wake them up after an operation.

Because of their regular visits to Britain, wealthy Arabs began buying houses - which proved to be an excellent investment. This led them to look for other financial opportunities, and today Britain is regarded - especially in the Emirates - as one of the best places to invest.

Horse racing, a passion among the wealthiest Arabs, is another reason for coming to Britain. One of King Hussein's bodyguards once recited to me the name of every British racecourse, plus the names of all the best gun shops in London.

A couple of years ago, foreign secretary Robin Cook (himself a racing enthusiast) averted a crisis in Britain's relations with Dubai when Sheikh Mohammed al-Makhtoum complained about the state of racing in Britain.

The sheikh, who owns about 400 horses, had threatened to boycott races in Britain unless the authorities who controlled the sport increased the prize money. (One curious but little known fact about the Makhtoums is that an officially recognised Scottish tartan bears their name, designed specially by a Pipe Major Stallard, and can be seen here.)

Infatuation with Britain does have its limits, of course. The Balfour Declaration of 1917, and Britain's role in the establishment of Israel, are still remembered in the Arab world, even if most British people have long forgotten them.

As an educational centre, Britain now faces competition from the United States, particularly among the youth of the Emirates. British diplomats sneeringly attribute this to "the Baywatch factor", easier admission at American universities and the fact that some American colleges will sell doctorates if writing a thesis proves too arduous.

But the special atmosphere of London's "oasis" district is a continuing attraction. During the summer months, when the Gulf becomes unbearably hot, Arabs arrive in their thousands.

The secret, perhaps, is that it caters so well for the cultural schizophrenia - the opposing tugs from east and west - that many Arabs feel today.

You can, if you wish, stroll up from Marble Arch (Marlboro Arch, as some Arabs call it), along the Edgware Road, wearing a dishdasha without looking out of place. You can eat Arab food, read Arabic newspapers, and generally feel at home.

Equally, you can dress as a European, eat western food, and imagine that you're British.

For the young, there's also the exciting prospect of meeting and talking to members of the opposite sex - something that many would be unable to do in their home countries.

Whiteley's shopping mall on Queensway is one of the favourite meeting places, and the circular balconies are perfectly designed for couples who still need to be a little circumspect. You stand on the opposite side of the balcony, gazing at your amour - and chat on the mobile phone.

President Assad and his bride may not have done that, but it's a fair bet that several future Arab leaders have.

British diplomats sneeringly attribute this to "the Baywatch factor", easier admission at American universities and the fact that some American colleges will sell doctorates if writing a thesis proves too arduous. But the special atmosphere of London's "oasis" district is a continuing attraction. During the summer months, when the Gulf becomes unbearably hot, Arabs arrive in their thousands. The secret, perhaps, is that it caters so well for the cultural schizophrenia - the opposing tugs from east and west - that many Arabs feel today. You can, if you wish, stroll up from Marble Arch (Marlboro Arch, as some Arabs call it), along the Edgware Road, wearing a dishdasha without looking out of place. You can eat Arab food, read Arabic newspapers, and generally feel at home. Equally, you can dress as a European, eat western food, and imagine that you're British. For the young, there's also the exciting prospect of meeting and talking to members of the opposite sex - something that many would be unable to do in their home countries. Whiteley's shopping mall on Queensway is one of the favourite meeting places, and the circular balconies are perfectly designed for couples who still need to be a little circumspect. You stand on the opposite side of the balcony, gazing at your amour - and chat on the mobile phone. President Assad and his bride may not have done that, but it's a fair bet that several future Arab leaders have. fields.headline: Arafat strikes conciliatory tone
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: Yasser Arafat is prepared to give up his demands for Palestinian refugees to be allowed to return to their former homes in Israel.
fields.body:
Yasser Arafat is prepared to give up his demands for Palestinian refugees to be allowed to return to their former homes in Israel.

The plan, which Mr Arafat has conditionally accepted as part of US-brokered peace negotiations, would see Israel cede control of a disputed holy site in Jerusalem to the Palestinians.

The Israeli's chief negotiator, Gilead Sher, is now in Washington to find out the exact terms of Mr Arafat's acceptance.

Prime minister Ehud Barak yesterday told an election rally that no refugees would be allowed into Israel and he would not cede sovereignty of the Temple Mount, known to Muslims as Haram al-Sharif.

However, he has not ruled out allowing third-party sovereignty over the holy site and allowing some Palestinians to return to Israel for "family reunification".

Mr Barak is trailing his hardline opponent, hawkish rightwinger Ariel Sharon, in today's opinion polls and faces a resounding defeat in next month's general election.

A Gallup poll in the Maariv daily indicated that 50% of the electorate back Mr Sharon, while 22% favour Mr Barak. A poll in the Yediot Ahronot daily showed Mr Sharon leading Mr Barak by 50% to 32%.

Mr Sharon has said that, if elected, he will not honour any peace accord Mr Barak signs.

But neighbouring states in the region may yet undermine the negotiations. A meeting of Arab foreign ministers in Cairo said yesterday that the right of Palestinian refugees and their descendents to return was "sacred".

According to the United Nations, 750,000 Palestinians left or were expelled from Israel during the two-year war that followed its creation in 1948.

With their descendants, they number about 4m people. Israelis say their return would overwhelm the country, where about 5m Jews live.

Palestinian refugees today welcomed the Arab foreign ministers' declaration upholding their cause.

In the Aida refugee camp in Bethlehem, Ibrahim Jouarish, 66, said, "It is our land, and we must return," referring to his family's old village of Malha, now part of Jewish Jerusalem and the site of sports stadiums, a shopping mall and a biblical zoo.

fields.headline: Shipman may have killed 297
fields.trailText: Serial killer GP Harold Shipman, convicted of murdering 15 patients, may have killed up to 297 during his 24-year career, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
Serial killer GP Harold Shipman, convicted of murdering 15 patients, may have killed up to 297 during his 24-year career, according to a report published today.

The Greater Manchester family doctor recorded 297 more deaths at his practice than other GPs working at a similar time in the same area.

A statistical audit of his clinical practice between 1974 and 1998 found that he recorded 236 more deaths of patients in their homes than similar doctors.

The excess of deaths was greatest among women over 75, suggesting the Hyde GP may be the UK's worst serial killer.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, ordered the clinical audit after Shipman was convicted in January last year of murdering 15 of his elderly women patients.

Richard Baker of the University of Leicester carried out the audit, the results of which have been passed on to the police and crown prosecution service.

The chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, said: "The questions raised in the report will be distressing reading to the patients and relatives who were under Shipman's care over the years, but it is important for their sake that this work has been done and is published. It has started the process of addressing the many unanswered questions that remain after the trial of Harold Shipman. This review is unprecedented in its remit.

The analysis makes chilling reading. Taken in the rounds, the review suggests that there must be serious concerns about deaths of some patients during Harold Shipman's entire career as a GP."

A helpline has been set up for people worried that their relatives may have been a victim of Shipman, who is serving 15 life sentences in Frankland jail, County Durham. The numbers are 0161-633 8653 and 0161-622 6431/2/3.

Shipman murdered most of his victims in their own homes when no relatives were present, using massive doses of Diamorphine. Professor Baker said that it was the excess of deaths in similar circumstances uncovered by his audit that gave the most cause for concern.

Between 1985 and 1998 information was available for 288 of the 324 deaths for which Shipman issued death certificates. Prof Baker said 57.6% of these were classified as highly suspicious and 14.9% as moderately suspicious.

The audit found an excess of deaths in most years of Shipman's working life as a GP, from his earliest years in practice.

Introducing the report, Prof Donaldson said it had been commissioned after the "terrible crimes" of Shipman were exposed. "There were widespread feelings of horror and outrage among the general public and the medical profession itself," he said. Today's reports had been "painstakingly and rigorously" researched from a variety of medical documents relating to Shipman.

Prof Baker compared deaths of Shipman's patients with those of other local GPs and found that Shipman had 297 more deaths on his books than the average. Of these, 236 were deaths at home.

Prof Baker said: "Some excess of deaths were seen from the earliest years of Shipman's practice. They are not explained by the number, the age, sex or socio-economic characteristics of his patients. I should say 236 is the one I feel is most likely to represent the number of excess deaths."

Prof Baker said one of his sources of information was cremation forms filled out by Shipman between 1985 and 1998.

They revealed that, on average, he had last seen a patient only 49 hours before they died, compared with 88 hours for other GPs.

He was also present at death in 20% of cases, compared with just 0.8% in the cases of other GPs.

In deaths recorded by Shipman, relatives were present only 40% of the time, compared with 80% normally, and his patients died much quicker than normal.

Prof Baker gave examples of comments made by Shipman on cremation forms. One said: "Saw patient at home, diagnosis made, arranged admission ambulance, patient dead when went back, all within 10 mins."

Prof Baker said: "This seems to me very strange. Surely what you would be doing in those circumstances is resuscitating the patient and trying to keep them alive until the ambulance arrives."

fields.headline: Wizard of Oz
fields.standfirst: In the three years since he won an Oscar for his electrifying portrayal of a mentally unstable pianist in Shine, Geoffrey Rush has become a superstar - without losing his sanity or good sense.  Stephen Moss  meets the Australian whose bravura performance as the Marquis de Sade could bring him another Academy award
fields.trailText: In the three years since he won an Oscar for his electrifying portrayal of a mentally unstable pianist in Shine, Geoffrey Rush has become a superstar - without losing his sanity or good sense. Stephen Moss meets the Australian whose bravura performance as the Marquis de Sade could bring him another Academy award
fields.body:
Geoffrey Rush spends the entire two and a bit hours of his new movie, Quills, locked in the cell of a lunatic asylum. This is perfect preparation for a day at the Dorchester, where he is incarcerated in an ornate room, given a constant supply of coffee by publicists, and asked to perform for the benefit of a group of cynical journalists. Luckily, Rush is so vivid that he survives both with aplomb: brilliant as the imprisoned Marquis de Sade (some critics have tipped him for a second Oscar), and in his hotel room appearing to offer up freshly-minted answers to questions he has probably already been asked six times that day.

Quills, which is directed by Philip Kaufman, tells the story of the final years of Sade, condemned to the asylum of Charenton and forbidden to write, but smuggling out his incendiary texts with the help of a laundry girl, played by Kate Winslet. It is a costume drama that eschews historical fidelity in the interest of questions of universal significance - good v evil, freedom v censorship, the double-edged sword of creativity - and a broader audience. Thus Winslet as an early 19th-century French laundress, Michael Caine as an authoritarian doctor, and Joaquin Phoenix as the well-meaning priest who runs Charenton - none of them remotely believable, but perhaps that isn't the point.

The critic Anthony Lane was suitably dismissive in the New Yorker, but spared Rush the executioner's blade. "If you can stomach this stuff," he wrote, "Quills should be seen simply for the presence of Geoffrey Rush. Of all the lies perpetrated by the film, his alone will win you over; in place of the Marquis de Sade, perhaps the most wearisome of revolutionary writers, we have a charming combination of scoundrel, flirt, dandy, nudist and wit."

When Rush is on screen, the movie comes alive; when he isn't, it feels laboured and ludicrous. It is like one of those flabby novels with one terrific character, where you find yourself skipping pages in the hunt for his next appearance. It is a bravura performance - locked in that one room, remember - from an actor who, in the three years since he won the best actor Oscar for Shine, has become a superstar without losing his sanity and good sense.

Rush is a valiant defender of the film, and obviously enjoyed working with the literary-minded Kaufman, director of The Right Stuff and The Unbearable Lightness of Being. "You get offered something like this and you have to take the bait and rise to the occasion," says Rush, before launching into a fluent exposition of the historical background to the film.

"The period in which it is set is full of great extremes - a period in European history when the world was changing at an enormous rate, from an aristocratic, feudal structure into hopefully a democratic one. On one side of the coin, you have Rousseau saying man is a noble creature, give him the right nurturing and goodness will prevail. On the other, you have the marquis going, 'No, man is a nasty little depraved animal, take a look at yourself.'" Rush is, as you may have gathered, an actor who both reads and thinks.

"I tried not to judge the marquis too much," he says. "I was interested in the inner personality of the man as a writer, as a creative force who still has unavoidable connections and presence 200 years later. I wanted to assess the distance between the man and the writer, and the story takes you on that journey. He has a fear of intimacy and constructs a brilliant edifice around himself, but that is part of the sadistic personality and search for control. In playing him, I had to ask myself, 'Am I being too big, too crude? Am I using a machete when I should be using a scalpel?' But a machete can be pretty effective in the cinema."

Rush, who is 49, is tall, rangy and fluid: even sitting down, all his limbs seem to be moving simultaneously. He chainsmokes and wears the battered outfit he perfected in the 20 years he spent on the Australian stage before Shine brought him to the attention of Hollywood. He comes across as a human being, and there can be no greater compliment for an actor, especially one enjoying - albeit relatively late - a meteoric film career.

It is probably his stage work, past and present (he has no intention of letting it go), that has kept him sane. He has been attached to the Belvoir Street Theatre in Sydney since 1985, working principally with director Neil Armfield and achieving notable successes with Gogol, Chekhov, Jonson and Beaumarchais, exploring what Rush calls "the grubby corners of the classical repertoire".

Hollywood has latched on to him as a character actor who can play historical figures - Sir Francis Walsingham in Shekhar Kapur's brilliant Elizabeth, Philip Henslowe in the Oscar-garlanded Shakespeare in Love, and now Sade - but he doesn't want to abandon modernity and is happy to be wearing a three-piece suit in John Boorman's forthcoming film of John le Carré's The Tailor of Panama.

The latter was shot last spring, but after that Rush took a five-month break. "The last three years have been extraordinary," he says. "I wanted to assess that on a personal level and on an aesthetic level. I spent time at home in a meaningful way, rather than a constantly disrupted professional way." His solitary engagement in that period was to appear in a production of David Holman's The Small Poppies, a play he commissioned about a child's first day at school. Very un-Hollywood; very Geoffrey Rush.

Even Shine, in which he played the mentally unstable pianist David Helfgott, was a slow-burn triumph, giving him time to adapt to the transformation it would bring to his life. "I read the script in 1992, and knew as an actor that the story was great, very vivid and very direct. In a strange sort of way, it fitted into a broadening repertoire of characters that I was playing on stage. Even though it was about a pianist in Perth, I found a connection through having played Lear's Fool. The film got put on hold for lots of different reasons until 1995. It finally came out at Sundance and people responded very favourably, but then it didn't open for months and months."

Rush gives the impression that if the rollercoaster started by Shine careered off the track tomorrow, he wouldn't be the least bit bothered. "An actor's life is a series of three-month blocks with great question marks constantly over the future," he says matter-of-factly. "I don't really know what I'm doing after this. Things have been talked about, but nothing's set. People have this image that you must have scripts arriving by FedEx and beeping going on outside your door all the time. But it doesn't quite happen like that."

Clearly, however, quite a few FedEx packages are arriving at his Melbourne home, and he is careful about what he accepts: "There are some aesthetic guidelines at work, and there's also a sense of do-or-die daring. I keep thinking, 'Well, what do I have to lose?' It's always been the most interesting time in my theatrical life when I've deliberately not got into a rut with something. Instead of asking what my strong suit is and playing to that, you go, 'No, I'll try something totally different', just for your own amusement and your own sense of variation."

At the moment, that means not accepting every historical role, every reprise of Henslowe and Walsingham, that comes his way. "Choosing parts is based on a series of instincts and hunches," he says. "It's extremely random and haphazard." Neither his instincts nor his aesthetic guidelines kept him out of two panned movies in 1999 - Mystery Men and House on Haunted Hill - but he makes a case for having said yes to both.

"I had very high hopes for Mystery Men, just in the sheer eclecticism of the cast. It was a sample of the greatest comic minds in contemporary America, from Ben Stiller to Paul Reubens to Tom Waits. It was an unusual film because it had a level of irony and fantasy which, with an Australian sensibility, I understood really well: the idea of suburban backyard superheroes. But America was baffled by it, and maybe as a film it suffered by not trusting its own instincts enough. If it had been slightly more subversive, it might have worked better."

And House on Haunted Hill? "It was a time for genre-hopping, a time to have a taste of what my current fortune had given me, and I liked the idea of being in a horror film. It was jumping into a playpen that I was not at all familiar with. The director [William Malone] was a great aficionado of the horror genre - he got very excited one day, and told me that the guy doing the underwater stunts was the son of the guy that played the original Creature From the Black Lagoon. But again that film had a kind of commercial drive to it that satisfied what it set out to do. It was made for the Halloween weekend, blitzed that weekend, did all right the next weekend and then was gone. It made three times the amount of money it was made for." A limp defence, but we'll assume his intentions, and his attraction to the hammy role of Stephen Price, were pure.

One point Rush makes about all these films - the failures as well as the successes - is that they involved big casts or, as the thesp in him prefers to call them, large companies of people. He clearly enjoys the buzz of collective theatrical endeavour, which is why it wasn't just his angular Elizabethan face that made Henslowe the perfect role for him.

Rush, who grew up in Queensland, came from a resolutely non-theatrical background. His father was an accountant and his mother a shop assistant, but he fell in love with the footlights early. "I caught the tail end of vaudeville, travelling tent shows. The tent must have held 700-800 people, like a canvas version of the Palladium with a proscenium arch down one end. They would do a variety show at night and, in the day, the same company would do an Aussie version of the traditional English panto. I went when I was six and was hooked.

"I ran the school drama club at high school, where we always did grand three-acters like Charley's Aunt, The Admirable Crichton, and Arsenic and Old Lace. We liked plays that had canvas doors. Then I went to the University of Queensland at a time, in the late 60s, when the world was shifting at an enormous rate. It was a giddy time with police raiding our local record shop to confiscate copies of Hair."

He got a job with the newly-formed Queensland theatre company, where he spent three years, and in the mid-1970s studied for two years at the Lecoq school of mime, movement and theatre in Paris. "I could have gone to the national drama school in Sydney, but I felt I would be doing more of the same. I knew my preference and facility was for something a little European, something physical."

He must love the stage because he married an actress, Jane Menelaus, who plays Sade's estranged wife in Quills, and they appeared together in The Importance of Being Earnest while on their honeymoon in 1988. They have two children, aged seven and five. Rush says he manages to spend around 60% of his time at home in Australia, with the rest split between the UK and US.

He has never appeared in London's West End, but would like to give it a shot, though on his own terms and not as a visiting Hollywood celeb. "It would be a great challenge, but I feel more and more that I would like to extend a greeting from our side of the world and bring something over with the company I work with."

As for his film future, he realises that Hollywood can be a fickle master. "You look for precedents: people from a theatre background who were heroes before I got into film acting, like Gary Oldman, Daniel Day-Lewis and Alan Rickman. You look at their careers and think there's a period of good fortune, there's a period of excitement, and then a period of boredom and indifference to it because it's not giving you back what you put into it."

If that happens to him, Rush knows he has his old love to fall back on. "I've always been a lifer. I've always liked the idea from my very early days as a professional actor that I could do it for a living. When I was in my 20s, I worked with actors who were in their 70s. That's the washing line that I want to hang it out on."

fields.bodyText: Geoffrey Rush spends the entire two and a bit hours of his new movie, Quills, locked in the cell of a lunatic asylum. This is perfect preparation for a day at the Dorchester, where he is incarcerated in an ornate room, given a constant supply of coffee by publicists, and asked to perform for the benefit of a group of cynical journalists. Luckily, Rush is so vivid that he survives both with aplomb: brilliant as the imprisoned Marquis de Sade (some critics have tipped him for a second Oscar), and in his hotel room appearing to offer up freshly-minted answers to questions he has probably already been asked six times that day. Quills, which is directed by Philip Kaufman, tells the story of the final years of Sade, condemned to the asylum of Charenton and forbidden to write, but smuggling out his incendiary texts with the help of a laundry girl, played by Kate Winslet. It is a costume drama that eschews historical fidelity in the interest of questions of universal significance - good v evil, freedom v censorship, the double-edged sword of creativity - and a broader audience. Thus Winslet as an early 19th-century French laundress, Michael Caine as an authoritarian doctor, and Joaquin Phoenix as the well-meaning priest who runs Charenton - none of them remotely believable, but perhaps that isn't the point. The critic Anthony Lane was suitably dismissive in the New Yorker, but spared Rush the executioner's blade. "If you can stomach this stuff," he wrote, "Quills should be seen simply for the presence of Geoffrey Rush. Of all the lies perpetrated by the film, his alone will win you over; in place of the Marquis de Sade, perhaps the most wearisome of revolutionary writers, we have a charming combination of scoundrel, flirt, dandy, nudist and wit." When Rush is on screen, the movie comes alive; when he isn't, it feels laboured and ludicrous. It is like one of those flabby novels with one terrific character, where you find yourself skipping pages in the hunt for his next appearance. It is a bravura performance - locked in that one room, remember - from an actor who, in the three years since he won the best actor Oscar for Shine, has become a superstar without losing his sanity and good sense. Rush is a valiant defender of the film, and obviously enjoyed working with the literary-minded Kaufman, director of The Right Stuff and The Unbearable Lightness of Being. "You get offered something like this and you have to take the bait and rise to the occasion," says Rush, before launching into a fluent exposition of the historical background to the film. "The period in which it is set is full of great extremes - a period in European history when the world was changing at an enormous rate, from an aristocratic, feudal structure into hopefully a democratic one. On one side of the coin, you have Rousseau saying man is a noble creature, give him the right nurturing and goodness will prevail. On the other, you have the marquis going, 'No, man is a nasty little depraved animal, take a look at yourself.'" Rush is, as you may have gathered, an actor who both reads and thinks. "I tried not to judge the marquis too much," he says. "I was interested in the inner personality of the man as a writer, as a creative force who still has unavoidable connections and presence 200 years later. I wanted to assess the distance between the man and the writer, and the story takes you on that journey. He has a fear of intimacy and constructs a brilliant edifice around himself, but that is part of the sadistic personality and search for control. In playing him, I had to ask myself, 'Am I being too big, too crude? Am I using a machete when I should be using a scalpel?' But a machete can be pretty effective in the cinema." Rush, who is 49, is tall, rangy and fluid: even sitting down, all his limbs seem to be moving simultaneously. He chainsmokes and wears the battered outfit he perfected in the 20 years he spent on the Australian stage before Shine brought him to the attention of Hollywood. He comes across as a human being, and there can be no greater compliment for an actor, especially one enjoying - albeit relatively late - a meteoric film career. It is probably his stage work, past and present (he has no intention of letting it go), that has kept him sane. He has been attached to the Belvoir Street Theatre in Sydney since 1985, working principally with director Neil Armfield and achieving notable successes with Gogol, Chekhov, Jonson and Beaumarchais, exploring what Rush calls "the grubby corners of the classical repertoire". Hollywood has latched on to him as a character actor who can play historical figures - Sir Francis Walsingham in Shekhar Kapur's brilliant Elizabeth, Philip Henslowe in the Oscar-garlanded Shakespeare in Love, and now Sade - but he doesn't want to abandon modernity and is happy to be wearing a three-piece suit in John Boorman's forthcoming film of John le Carré's The Tailor of Panama. The latter was shot last spring, but after that Rush took a five-month break. "The last three years have been extraordinary," he says. "I wanted to assess that on a personal level and on an aesthetic level. I spent time at home in a meaningful way, rather than a constantly disrupted professional way." His solitary engagement in that period was to appear in a production of David Holman's The Small Poppies, a play he commissioned about a child's first day at school. Very un-Hollywood; very Geoffrey Rush. Even Shine, in which he played the mentally unstable pianist David Helfgott, was a slow-burn triumph, giving him time to adapt to the transformation it would bring to his life. "I read the script in 1992, and knew as an actor that the story was great, very vivid and very direct. In a strange sort of way, it fitted into a broadening repertoire of characters that I was playing on stage. fields.headline: Contender honoured for social impact
fields.standfirst: The film, about a female vice-presidential nominee who is dogged by sordid allegations about her past, is to be honoured by the largest film critics group in North America
fields.trailText: The film, about a female vice-presidential nominee who is dogged by sordid allegations about her past, is to be honoured by the largest film critics group in North America
fields.body:
The Contender, the film about a female vice-presidential nominee who is dogged by sordid allegations about her past, is to receive a special critic's award given to outstanding films of social and political significance.

Reuters reports that the Broadcast Film Critics Association (BFCA) has chosen to award its annual Alan J Pakula Award, named after the director of All the President's Men, to the film. The prize will be presented on January 22 to the film's writer-director - and former film-critic himself - Rod Lurie.

The film (out in the UK in April) stars British actor Gary Oldman as a Republican congressman trying to prevent a senator, played by Joan Allen, from becoming the first female vice-president. Allen has already earned a Golden Globe nomination for her role - which was written especially for her - and is likely to be up for an Oscar nod. She was previously nominated for Nixon and The Crucible.

Allen is also no stranger to the BFCA. In 1999 she tied with Kathy Bates (Primary Colors) as best supporting actress for her work in Pleasantville. That was the first year the Alan J Pakula Award was presented - to John Travolta.

The BFCA claims to be the largest film critics group in the United States and Canada, representing more than 140 television, radio and online film reviewers.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: U-571 | The Patriot |  It's the Rage | The Mating Habits of the Earthbound Human
fields.trailText: U-571 | The Patriot | It's the Rage | The Mating Habits of the Earthbound Human
fields.body:
U-571
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
EV Cert 12
***

Travesty of history, part 1: Matthew McConaughey, assisted by Harvey Keitel and some good ol' boys, captures the Enigma machine and turns the war against the Nazis. U-571 starts out as a very old- fashioned, triumphalist war movie with McConaughey being turned down for command as "not ready" but desperate to prove himself, but it becomes far more interesting as it goes along. Claustrophobia is a given in an underwater tin box, but with enemy bombing causing as many unidentified creaking and groaning sounds as a haunted house, and very little time spent above the waves, it's hard to stay uninvolved.

In time, the Trojan Horse-style plot (they're in a US sub masquerading as a German one) becomes a study of subterfuge and strategy as much as nerve and bravery. Writer-director Jonathan Mostow allows all of this to affect his actors convincingly - they look and sound as if this is an experience that has changed them and, at the moment of their triumph, when the film has led you to expect whooping, you just get an exhausted, deep sense of relief. Don't believe a word of it, though.

The Patriot
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Columbia Tristar Cert 15
**

Travesty of history, part 2: Mel Gibson's militia outwits the British while fighting for the side which is freeing slaves in 1776, though the history books tell us slavery was abolished in 1865. ("I'm here now of my own accord," exclaims an inevitably noble freed black soldier.) The Patriot allows you to empathise a little with native Americans pre-1960s, since redcoats are dispatched with as little regard as redskins used to be. If you don't mind all that, it's not a badly made film in any way, just a cynically populist concoction lobbed at Gibson's Braveheart fans and plainly written for him - his character even has seven kids, just like the actor.

Writer Robert Rodat, who also scripted Saving Private Ryan, lobs a few Clint Eastwood staples into the mix: his family suffers at the hands of the enemy like Josey Wales, and he has a violent background he wants to leave behind, like Unforgiven's Bill Munny. The relentless lack of originality makes it a long trawl at 158 minutes, but it looks good, using the countryside and the old town of Charleston to create a convincing period feel. The battle scenes, with Gibson's army arrayed against the forces marshalled by Tom Wilkinson's Lord Cornwallis, are suitably barbarous.

You know you'll get something big and lumbering out of director Roland Emmerich, who brought us Independence Day and Godzilla, but it's a shame when the only laugh in such a long film is an unintentional one: church-burning redcoat villain Jason Isaacs casually kills Gibson's son and then intones: "Stupid boy." Somewhere, the ghost of Arthur Lowe must have chuckled. Considering the sheer disaster Al Pacino had taking on this period of history in Hugh Hudson's risible Revolution, Gibson has not come off too badly in this super-safe vehicle. But for history, stick to Simon Schama.

It's the Rage
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Columbia Tristar Cert 15
***

A heartfelt film about interlocking lives with a strong, underlying moral about what happens when people in moments of high tension have easy access to guns. It owes a debt to Pulp Fiction but repays it with a laugh as Jeff Daniels takes Tarantino's masterwork back to the video store complaining about the plot. Daniels kicks this plot off as he kills his partner, who is also his wife's lover.

Its twists and turns allow a lot of good ensemble acting and gives a number of fine performers unusual parts: Homicide's Andre Braugher is David Schwimmer's gay lover but is also seeing punk hooker Anna Paquin, whose brother is ... and so it goes in a plot whose participants' relationships and connections are only gradually revealed. Good to see a fervently anti-gun American film, though the point is made a little too obviously at times.

The Mating Habits of the Earthbound Human
Rental, Columbia Tristar, Cert 15
*

It's cheeky of this obscure straight-to-video film to list David Hyde Pierce above the title. Pierce provides a voiceover only and any hopes of Frasier-style wit are quickly dispelled in a banal little romance with the single gimmick that Mackenzie Astin's affair with Carmen Electra is being commented on by an alien. "Human females enjoy stories of one person dying slowly. Males prefer those of many dying swiftly," is as amusing as it gets.
