fields.headline: Sun websites safe claim execs
fields.trailText: 1pm: The Sun's internet sites, Page3.com and supergoals.com, are not being closed, senior executives have promised, writes Guy Middleton.
fields.body:
The Sun's internet sites, Page3.com and supergoals.com, are not being folded and will not be hit by cutbacks elsewhere in the newspaper group, senior executives have vowed.

Executive editor Chris Roycroft-Davis said the sites were here to stay despite the drastic decision by Rupert Murdoch to close down NewsCorp's new media division across the US with the loss of 200 jobs.

Mr Roycroft-Davis today assured worried staff in the UK that the change in strategy in the US would not affect TheSun.co.uk or its sister sites.

"Page3.com is a highly successful operation in terms of customer traffic and Supergoals is an integral part of the Sun's site," he said.

Mr Roycroft-Davis said that the content of Page3.com - which showcases topless women who have appeared in the Sun's daily feature - was particularly suited to the internet.

The site also includes offers of slide shows, a page 3 calendar, a feature called 'Undie-Cover', and 'No Frills'.

He added that unlike NewsCorp's US operations, the production of the Sun's three sites was closely integrated with the newspaper.

Page3.com has almost doubled the number of users of parent site TheSun.co.uk and ranks 188th in the UK's league of most visited sites.

Web ratings group Jupiter MMXI's latest traffic figures show that TheSun.co.uk and Page3.com hosted 135,000 and 230,000 unique visitors per month respectively.

Jupiter could not supply user figures for Supergoals as it falls below its lowest measuring point, which is 1% of the UK home internet audience.

Yesterday NewsCorp announced that the US Fox television networks would take on the production of the company's three key news, sports and entertainment websites, a move that the company said would save millions of dollars.

The internet services were previously produced and controlled by a central new media division.

It's generally agreed that you're not a real music fan until you've undergone the Glastonbury festival's baptism of mud.

Only those who have waded through knee-deep lakes of earth, beer and unspeakable effluent in a vain search for the acoustic stage appreciate the spirit of wartime camaraderie that makes Glastonbury the most loved of all rock festivals.

The many regulars, who buy tickets even before acts are announced, swap survival stories about rain, trauma-inducing toilets and the time a boy band himbo called Robbie Williams launched his solo career by invading Oasis's stage.

It's the only festival in an overcrowded calendar to retain its flower-power values by giving most of the profits to charity.

Glastonbury is certainly the only festival held on its promoters own land, and while it has succumbed to sponsorship (by the Guardian, among others), it still feels like a labour of love. It is not unheard of for revellers to have spiritual awakenings while getting down to Glasto favourite Rolf Harris. On a misty summer evening as music wafts from all the many stages, it's easy to believe the place is situated on ley lines, as hippies insist.

Last year wasn't vintage in terms of bands - Radiohead and Madonna declined slots, and banal Travis and the Chemical Brothers didn't exactly up the star factor. Gangs of touts charged £5 a head to let around 100,000 ticketless people in through gaps in the fence, as security guards looked on.

At times the atmosphere seemed closer to a West Ham match than a festival, though football stadiums are usually free of crusties peddling hash brownies. It seems time for festival organiser Michael Eavis to rethink his strategy (suggestion: set rottweilers on the touts, and put the crusties on latrine duty - that'll show them).

Nonetheless, the cancellation is a loss to fans and to the music business, whose participants need their annual orgy to clear their heads of idiots such as Westlife. But there's always 2002, and the oft-promised, still-unrealised lure of flushing toilets to bring the crowds back.

webTitle: View from Washington: All the president's men

fields.headline: All the president's men
fields.standfirst:
George W Bush's new cabinet complies with the rule of bipartisanship, but only just, writes Martin Kettle in Washington

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: George W Bush's new cabinet complies with the rule of bipartisanship, but only just, writes Martin Kettle in Washington.
fields.body:
As the Florida election dispute came to a climax last month, there was a lot of loose talk that the closeness of the result would compel George W Bush to govern partly with Democrats and partly on Democratic terms. Most of that talk, it is worth recalling, came from Democrats, not from Republicans.

In the event, Mr Bush has now clearly determined to do neither. His choices for his cabinet, completed this week - an impressively quick effort overall - reveal a preponderantly conservative lineup which underlines Mr Bush's confidence in his own policy agenda and his own platform.

True, he has fulfilled his commitment to place a Democrat in his cabinet: Norman Mineta, currently the Clinton administration's commerce secretary, will become Mr Bush's transportation secretary. But a limited bipartisanship of this kind is routine these days (Mr Clinton had a Republican secretary of defence). The most important conclusion to draw on the new team is that Mr Bush has not been forced to go beyond convention, or to choose someone against his will.

Nor, even more strikingly, has he shown much sign of being eager to drop key elements of his platform. European diplomats in Washington had convinced themselves that Mr Bush and Colin Powell would find a way of pushing the national missile defence project (NMD) into touch to assuage European opinion, perhaps by the appointment of a low-profile defence secretary.

However, the appointment of Donald Rumsfeld makes those predictions look naive. Mr Rumsfeld is the chief patron of NMD. He chaired the committee that recommended it to Mr Clinton in 1998. He has been appointed, as Mr Bush has made clear, to build national missile defences.

On the home front, the political equivalent of NMD is Mr Bush's $1.6tn tax cut plan. It's the plan his opponents most don't want to see put into action, so it is the programme that the opposition experts have managed to persuade themselves that Mr Bush is hoping to drop. If so, there is not much sign of it.

Judging by his comments this week, Mr Bush remains focused on his tax cuts. It's the reason why he has been so ready to fan an air of mild economic crisis - something no Democratic president would ever dare to do. By talking down the economy, Mr Bush hopes to talk up the case for tax cuts to get the economy moving again.

He is setting his course in a conservative direction, which is why he will get a fight on some of his more controversial cabinet nominations. Of these, three stand out - those for attorney general, labour secretary and interior secretary - and of these three, one is clearly the lightning rod for most of the forthcoming political storms on Capitol Hill.

John Ashcroft's nomination as attorney general is the chosen battleground on which Democrats will try to show their strength in the 50-50 senate. To read the anti-Ashcroft literature that has been bagatelling around the internet these past few days, you would imagine that there is no more obdurate conservative this side of Pat Buchanan.

As the liberal columnist Joe Conason puts it, Mr Bush's nomination of Mr Ashcroft "has reopened a debate that ought to have been settled in 1865 ... [the] apparent endorsement of the defeated Southern slavocracy, with all that necessarily implies about his true attitudes toward black Americans and other minorities."

We will hear more talk like this when, like all cabinet appointees, the ex-senator for Missouri faces his Senate confirmation hearings. Linda Chavez, the anti-affirmative action, anti-minimum wage nominee to head the Labour Department, which administers affirmative action and the minimum wage, will face a tough time in her hearings.

So will Gale Norton, the Coloradan whose support for property rights rather than the creation of nature reserves, and for drilling rights rather than drilling bans in protected lands make her an environmentalist's nightmare as interior secretary.

Mr Ashcroft's, though, will be the true connoisseur's contest. Not since the battles in the 1980s over Ronald Reagan's nomination of Robert Bork to the US supreme court have Democrats managed to fire themselves up with such fervour over a major nomination.

The hearings will see Mr Ashcroft grilled on everything from abortion (which he opposes in all, but the most narrow circumstances) to dancing (of which he also disapproves). The conservative Mr Ashcroft will survive the ordeal in the end, but it will be at a cost.

Yet that is the course that Mr Bush has set. It is undoubtedly a bold one, given the narrowness of the congressional arithmetic and the circumstances of his own election.

But bipartisanship? Forget it. Uniting, not dividing? That's for wimps. As the conservative columnist George Will put it this week, Mr Bush's choices "communicate his conviction that the election, though close, awarded him 100% of the presidency, and he intends to use all of it." Ladies and gentlemen, please fasten your seat belts.

webTitle: Bob Wilson left on the bench

fields.headline: Bob Wilson left on the bench
fields.standfirst: Jan 5: Yorath to front ITV soccer
fields.trailText: 1pm: The news that Des Lynam and Gabby Yorath are to lead ITV's Premier League coverage is a further blow to Bob Wilson, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The news that Des Lynam and Gabby Yorath are to become the faces of ITV's Premier League highlights coverage will be a further blow for fellow presenter Bob Wilson.

Mr Wilson is expected to continue presenting ITV's Tuesday night Champions League highlights show.

But it is understood that he will not feature in the Premiership presenting team when the broadcaster takes over highlights coverage from the BBC in August.

He was said to have been less than impressed when ITV poached Mr Lynam from the BBC in August 1999, having left the corporation himself to escape from Mr Lynam's shadow and front more high-profile football coverage.

Mr Wilson was persuaded to sign a new three-year deal to work alongside Mr Lynam as an ITV football presenter. That contract has two years still to run.

A spokesman for ITV said: "He is still part a major part of the team. He has still has a big part to play."

However, insiders pointed out that Mr Wilson has already got a packed schedule as Arsenal's goalkeeping coach.

webTitle: Liberty Surf to close UK office

fields.headline: Liberty Surf to close UK office
fields.standfirst: Jan 4: Liberty Surf tight lipped on merger
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: French ISP Liberty Surf is planning to close its UK office with the loss of 120 jobs according to French press reports, writes Dan Milmo.
Jan 4: Liberty Surf tight lipped on merger
fields.body:
French internet service provider Liberty Surf is planning to close its UK office with the loss of 120 jobs, according to reports.

Liberty Surf is negotiating a life-saving takeover as it battles to stay afloat in a rapidly consolidating industry, prompting rumours of swingeing cutbacks in its foreign operations.

The report, in French daily newspaper Les Echos, claims the company will close its operations in Britain, Spain and Sweden to boost its dwindling bank balance. Liberty Surf declined to comment on the rumours.

However, a source close to Liberty Surf's London-based operations said it was a case of "French journalists in silly season".

The ISP is the second largest in France but has only 730,000 users across Europe. Italian rival Tiscali and Belgian telecoms operator Belgacom have confirmed that they are negotiating merger deals with the company, which has £166m left in the bank and lost £53m over the last six months.

A streamlined Liberty Surf would be a more attractive target for firms wary of taking on struggling companies, but who want a foothold in the lucrative European ISP market.

UK retail group Kingfisher has a significant stake in the company, and has watched Liberty Surf's shares crash from a year-high of £24 to £4.51 today.

Analysts remain sceptical about Liberty Surf's chances of breaking even, even if it takes drastic cost-cutting measures.

The company's business model of offering customers fixed-rate access fees while it pays telecoms companies a per-minute rate to rent phone lines is seen as unviable.

fields.headline: Glastonbury cancelled in safety scare
fields.standfirst: Special report: Glastonbury 2000
fields.trailText: Glastonbury, for many the highlight of the summer festival scene, has been cancelled because organisers have been unable to find a way to stop tens of thousands of fans from gatecrashing the event.
fields.body:
Glastonbury, for many the highlight of the summer festival scene, has been cancelled because organisers have been unable to find a way to stop tens of thousands of fans from gatecrashing the event.

The decision, which will cause unimaginable angst to a large proportion of the nation's youth, was announced yesterday by Michael Eavis, the Somerset farmer who has held the event on his land at Worthy Farm, Pilton, since 1970.

Mr Eavis, who is facing prosecution after an estimated 100,000 fans sneaked into last year's weekend-long extravaganza, said he hoped the decision would send out a message that the organisers were taking the issue of crowd control seriously.

With tickets for the event costing upwards of £80, finding a way in free has become a challenge that the nation's music lovers have taken up with gusto. Last year fans gained entry by scaling fences, hiding in the boot of cars and tunnelling beneath the perimeter.

Mr Eavis had talked about investing in a 20ft £1m "superwall" to keep out unwanted festival-goers, but in a statement released yesterday he said: "After much deliberation and consultation, I have now decided not to run the festival this year.

"I am very sorry and sad to have to make this announcement but you can be sure of one thing - we will be back next year."

He said there were many good reasons for the decision. "One, to show all the interested parties that there has to be a more effective control over numbers, which means among other things designing a fence that works properly.

"Two, to tell all the people that come without tickets that their behaviour is not sustainable and that by doing so they are taking up valuable resources on site from the people who are here legitimately.

"Three, the problem of excessive numbers is now causing us some concern, particularly after the festival in Denmark where nine people died last year."

He added: "People will have to understand that the growing culture of fence-hopping has to be stopped and the long-term prospects for the festival will depend upon us succeeding."

It is not the first time that the festival has been put on ice. In 1988 a decision was made to allow the land to lie fallow; in 1991 it was scrapped because of disturbances on site the previous year caused by groups of travellers; and in 1996 organisers decided to take a break.

Last night Radio One DJ Steve Lamacq said: "There were rumours that Mr Eavis was thinking very hard and seriously about the future of Glastonbury for this year, given the problems about people getting in for nothing last year. I think there were genuine fears that this would end up in an argument that nobody wanted between Michael Eavis and the local council.

"Glastonbury is a cultural event really and one of those places where you can go and escape the outside world for three days and not worry about anything."

Last year thousands of people broke through the 14ft perimeter fence to avoid paying. Touts then charged ticketless music fans around £30 to help them get over or under the cordon.

With a capacity 100,000 ticket holders already on the site, the extra fans put pressure on areas near the most popular stages and safety concerns were raised when at least 30 people had to be lifted from the packed crowd by security staff during a performance by Travis.

The fencing was in sections held together by nuts and bolts, which could be pushed over, scaled or tunnelled under.

The event, celebrating its 30th anniversary, only sold out on one of the three days. Mr Eavis said it was the first time since the eighties that they failed to sell out straight away. But despite the crime - 187 arrests, mainly for theft and drug possession - the festival had been an overwhelming success, he said.

The event costs around £7m to stage. Revenue from ticket sales and the £1m rent from traders left around £700,000 profit, which he planned to donate to charities such as Oxfam and Greenpeace.

Last year he said: "If we kept the profits, we would have to pay 30% tax on it, which I don't want to do."

webTitle: Belgian child rapist takes prison to court

fields.headline: Belgian child rapist takes prison to court
fields.trailText: The convicted paedophile Marc Dutroux, charged with the murder and torture of four young girls, filed a complaint in a Belgian court yesterday that his jail conditions were illegal and degrading.
fields.body:
The convicted paedophile Marc Dutroux, charged with the murder and torture of four young girls, filed a complaint in a Belgian court yesterday that his jail conditions were illegal and degrading.

His lawyer, Marc Neve, told the court that the conditions violated his human rights and impaired his ability to defend himself. Dutroux, who has been in jail since 1996, did not attend the court in Arlon, south-east Belgium.

He was jailed for five years for escaping from prison while awaiting trial.

In the complaint, he said that being held in isolation stopped him taking part in prison social life, and he also criticised the "incessant" body searches. His lawyer told newspapers that the lights in his cell were switched on every seven minutes at night.

Dutroux, who was freed in 1992 after serving three years for multiple child rape, is due to be tried this year for his alleged part in the rape, torture and murder of four girls, two of them eight-year-olds who starved to death in a dungeon.

Mr Neve asked for an official inspection of his client's cell and fine of BFr50,000 (£770) for each day he remained in such conditions if the court ordered a change. The hearing was adjourned until February 1.
Agencies, Arlon

fields.headline: Observer appoints website editor
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: The Observer has hired Sunder Katwala as the first editor of observer.co.uk, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Observer has announced the appointment of Sunder Katwala as its first editor of observer.co.uk.

Mr Katwala is currently working at the Foreign Policy Centre think-tank, where he runs the publishing programme.

He will spearhead the drive to boost the Observer's profile on the internet, working in conjunction with the newspaper and Guardian Unlimited.

At the Foreign Policy Centre, Mr Katwala has been responsible for a number of agenda-setting reports into foreign policy, including Making the Commonwealth Matter, which suggested modernising member states' approach to the Commonwealth to remove traces of empire.

He joins on January 22.

webTitle: Yorath to present ITV football highlights

fields.headline: Yorath to present ITV football highlights
fields.trailText: 12pm: Gabby Yorath is being lined up to present two new ITV Premier League highlights shows next season, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Gabby Yorath is being lined up to present two new ITV Premier League highlights shows from the start of the next season in August.

Ms Yorath, 28, who fronts ITV's Saturday lunchtime football show On the Ball, is expected to present up to 10 Sunday evening highlights shows, on weekends when there are three or more Sunday Premiership games.

fields.headline: Noor Jehan
fields.standfirst: Actress and singer whose appeal bridged the Indo-Pakistan divide
fields.trailText: Popularly acclaimed in Pakistan as Malak-I-Taranum - the Queen of Melody - Noor Jehan is estimated to have made more than 40 films and sung around 20,000 numbers during a career which lasted more than half a century
fields.body:
The life of the Punjabi-born singer and actress Noor Jehan, who has died aged 74, broadly mirrored the history of the film and music industry in the Indian subcontinent, before and after partition in 1947. Popularly acclaimed in Pakistan as Malak-I-Taranum - the Queen of Melody - she is estimated to have made more than 40 films and sung around 20,000 numbers during a career which lasted more than half a century.

In 1965, when the Pakistani military elite led the country into an ill-planned war with India, Noor Jehan used her talent to shore up the spirit of her country's fighting soldiers. It was she, rather than incompetent generals, that Pakistan's public credited with boosting morale. Yet her music also provided a common bridge and a platform for the shared cultural heritage of the divided states of India and Pakistan. One of her great hits, Awaz Dey Kahan Hey (Call Up My Name With The Ardour Of Youth) still prefaces one of All India Radio's popular programmes.

Born into a poor but musically talented family in the small, sleepy Punjabi town of Kasur, in what is now Pakistan, Allarakhi, as she was originally named, rose to all-India prominence as a child actress in early 1930s Calcutta. In 1935, her precocious talents caught the notice of KD Mehra, who signed her up for his film Pind Di Kuri (A Village Girl). Its success sparked a steady wave of acting and singing offers. The next box-office success, Gul Bakowli (1937), consolidated Jehan's child prodigy reputation.

In 1942, while still only 15 years old, Jehan starred as the heroine in the hit movie Khandan (The Family). She later married the film's director Shaukat Hussain Rizvi, and their creative partnership produced a stream of roles in the 1940s and early 50s. Among the most successful films of the period were Mirza Sahibaan and Jugnoo (1947), which launched the career of another Bollywood legend, Dillip Kumar.

Following partition in 1947, Jehan left Bombay for Pakistan. Between then and 1960, she acted and sang in a string of films, although, in the late 1950s, her first marriage broke up. Ghalib was her last appearance as actress-cum-singer.

Noor Jehan then devoted herself entirely to her first love, music. Using her firm grounding in classical music, she sang Urdu film and Punjabi folk songs with equal felicity. Her 1970s hits remain in the subcontinent's popular memory even today.

She earned the ire of Pakistan's then dictator, General Ayub Khan, when she sang a banned poem of the much-loved poet and bête noire of the regime, Faiz Ahmad Faiz, at an event organised for Ayub. Moved by this gesture, Faiz is said to have gifted the poem to her. Her life also inspired the leading Urdu writer Manto to write a sketch, Noor Jehan, Surooray Jehan, about her.

Jehan's death united the Indian subcontinent in grief - a tribute both to a warm, vivacious personality and to the unifying potential of her songs. She is survived by two sons and four daughters from her two marriages. Her second husband was the actor, producer and director Izaz Durrani. One of her daughters, Zilay Huma, is a popular singer in the tradition of her mother.

Haresh Pandya writes: Outside Pakistan, Noor Jehan endeared herself to music lovers in India, the gulf countries and even in the far east. Yet she remained modest about her achievements. "We singers are nothing," she once said. "We put the ready-made dish before you through the medium of our voice."

The distinguished Indian music director Naushad Ali, meanwhile, maintained that Noor Jehan was a better singer than the Indian music industry's 71-year-old "queen empress" - and another singer of patriotic songs - Lata Mangeshkar. The two women were close friends, chatting on the phone, corresponding across that 53-year-old border.

fields.headline: Sins of the father
fields.standfirst: When JD Salinger's daughter Peggy wrote an account of her life as the great novelist's child, it cost her dear. She was ostracised by her father and brother. She was condemned by the literati. And she became a target for The Catcher in the Rye's obsessive fans. So, asks Julian Borger , why did she do it?
fields.trailText: When JD Salinger's daughter Peggy wrote an account of her life as the great novelist's child, it cost her dear. She was ostracised by her father and brother. She was condemned by the literati. And she became a target for The Catcher in the Rye's obsessive fans. So, asks Julian Borger , why did she do it?
fields.body:
Getting to meet Peggy Salinger is not an entirely straightforward matter. Certain precautions are taken whose very nature I am not permitted to describe, because that is one of the precautions. They are dictated by the "threat management" firm she has hired.

It is Holden Caulfield's revenge. The angry adolescent antihero of The Catcher in the Rye retains his hold on those who worship his creator, the great and mysterious JD Salinger, who stopped writing 35 years ago and withdrew from the world to a fortress of privacy at his home in Cornish, New Hampshire.

But he has been betrayed from within. His 44-year-old daughter, Peggy (Margaret) has written a memoir, from which the writer emerges mostly as an unsavoury weirdo. Now Peggy's father and brother are not talking to her, and a company is protecting her from the assortment of stalkers and weirdos who still apparently tout their paperback editions of The Catcher in the Rye like an avenging bible, 20 years after one such obsessed fan, Mark David Chapman, shot John Lennon dead in New York.

Peggy has her own ideas about why her father's novel of an unhappy youth at an expensive boarding school has become such a fetish and a curse. "It captures the borderline aspects of adolescence brilliantly, beautifully; how well he writes about what it's like to be on your own and appropriately, adolescently crazy - not having anything sorted out. Everyone's the good guys or the bad guys," she says.

"His writing is tremendously seductive. Holden turns aside to the reader and says: 'You would have understood. You would have hated this,' and brings the reader very actively into this sort of circle of elite misunderstood." This is all very well if you are 15, but a bit of a problem if you are in your 30s or 40s, still feel the world is against you, and believe only Holden or JD would truly understand.

It is not just the nutters who are upset. Some of the English professors and literary arbiters at US universities and newspapers are also not too happy with Dream Catcher, her account of growing up as Salinger's daughter. One reviewer in the Indianapolis Star predicted that she would be consigned to a special hell reserved for faithless children who try to capitalise on their parents' fame. The New York Times portrayed her father as a conscientious objector to the "publicity industrial complex", fatally let down by a daughter who failed to understand his art. And the New York Observer declared she had committed something it called an "ontological sin", whatever that is.

In the deliberate elegance of an expensive Boston hotel, Peggy sticks two fingers down her throat in mock disgust. She is unapologetic. For her, Jerome David Salinger is not a literary god but an all-too-mortal father who largely left his children to their own devices while he pursued his art, a string of obscure religions and a series of teenage girls.

Peggy's English mother, Claire Douglas, was 16 when she met the 31-year-old writer in New York. Much later, on what turned out to be their last "family holiday" together, Peggy and her eight-year-old younger brother, Matthew, were thrilled to be flown to London, only to discover that the hidden agenda behind the trip was a rendezvous with her father's besotted female pen pal, who was still in her teens. The hapless girl was ultimately cast out in tears, because JD did not fancy her. "She's terribly homely, poor girl. I had no idea," Peggy recalls him saying.

Peggy describes how she was dispatched to one Colditz-style boarding school after another, and unsurprisingly developed a few personality problems of her own. She drank, ran wild, had occasional blackouts during which she assumed multiple personalities, and suffered from debilitating illnesses. On one occasion when she rang her father for help, he sent her a subscription to a journal put out by the Christian Scientists, his religious gurus of the moment, who teach that all illness is an illusion.

Her devotion to the old man was such that when she finally attempted suicide in 1984, she rang the hospital before she took her cocktail of pills to ensure they would not release her name to the press. "My first instinct at this desperate hour was not to protect myself, but to keep my father's secrets, to obey the family creed," she wrote.

The ties of loyalty only snapped when she was pregnant with her son some years ago (to say precisely when would reveal the age of her son, which she views as a risk - the fewer identifying details the better). She was sick and penniless, and her father advised her to get an abortion. "You have no right to bring a child into the world you can't support," he told her. She was so taken aback that she wrote the words down; this was the start of the long process which eventually produced Dream Catcher.

"Being the mother of a child brought out that lioness," she says now. "You can say what you want to me, but don't go there. That's what knocked down the house of cards.

"Really, the only way I came to understand why it took me so long was reading the literature on cults and people emerging from cults and how when you're forced to believe in the whole package you can't disagree with discrete bits of it. Because really, the whole thing has to fall apart for you to start questioning."

Writing Dream Catcher was not facilitated by the fact that Peggy's father refused to talk to her after word leaked out that she was working on the book. She had to rely on her own memory and the recollections of the various women in the reclusive author's life.

The result is patchily compelling. She writes at great length about episodes she remembers best, which are not always the most absorbing moments of her life. There are seemingly endless quotes from scrawled notes slipped to and from her giggling friends at boarding school.

Unsurprisingly, the best bits throw light on her famously secretive father. He told her almost nothing about his experiences as a soldier in the 1944 D-day landings and in the subsequent advance across Europe, but she has dug out the bloody history of his unit, the 12th Infantry Regiment, which lost more men than it started out with. It was a wonder that Jerry Salinger survived at all. "You never really get the smell of burning flesh out of your nose entirely," he once told her, "no matter how long you live."

For the rest of his life, Peggy believes, he remained essentially a soldier, disciplined and aloof from ordinary civilians. "While the war was often in the foreground of our family life, it was always in the background. It was the point of reference that defined everything else in relation to it," she wrote.

The other dark corner she has taken a torch to is his largely ignored Jewish heritage. Jerome's father was a successful Jewish food importer and his mother was an Irish Catholic who converted to Judaism, making Sonny (as his relatives called him) entirely Jewish. It was an identity he did not embrace.

"My father would get all embarrassed and uncomfortable when the subject would come out. It would be a subject not to be discussed," Peggy recalls. As for her grandparents: "All I knew was that they were incredibly embarrassing people because they spoke with Yiddish accents and they were dismissed."

Some of JD's characters have similar attitudes to their families' histories, but none act out the conflicts in such a bizarre manner as the author, whose first marriage was to a Nazi. Serving as a counter-intelligence officer at the end of the war, he was one of the first soldiers to walk into a newly liberated concentration camp (Peggy is unable to remember its name). He was responsible for interrogating the local Nazis and one of the junior party officials he arrested, Sylvia, he fell for, married and took back to America. According to his sister, Doris, Sylvia remained as anti-semitic as ever, and returned to Germany. The bizarre episode gives new dimensions to the phrase "self-hating Jew".

As far as his daughter knows, JD Salinger is still writing. "He does work from early in the morning till midday every day, and when he can't he's a huge pain in the ass. He starts prowling like a caged beast, and he really has got to get to his typewriter," she says. The output is all carefully filed away and colour coded according to how much editing it requires, waiting to be published after his death. But it is quite possible, she admits, that he will simply change his mind and make a huge bonfire of the past three decades' worth of work, an act that her revelations may have rendered more likely.

In writing Dream Catcher, Peggy has taken an axe to the delicate, residual strands keeping her troubled family together. Her brother, Matthew, wrote a letter to the New York Observer denouncing the book and questioning its accuracy.

Peggy is equally dismissive of her brother, saying she was "embarrassed for him". "He hasn't spoken to me," she says with evident sadness mixed with iron determination. "I'm still his big sister. I'm sorry he didn't have the oomph to say something to me about it and instead wrote a letter to the press. I'm not dwelling on it. I think in a few years he'll probably be quite embarrassed by his own behaviour. I hope for his own sake that he does some sorting through for himself."

She stands by the authenticity of her account, and argues with some degree of pride that if there were factual errors, her father would have taken her to the supreme court, as he did to his previous biographer, Ian Hamilton. She says this with some pride, but it is clearly a melancholy situation for any family when the best thing you can say about relations with your father is that he has not taken you to the highest court in the land, yet. She has not dared to contact her father since word got out that she was writing the book. "I did not want to subject my son to a scene, and I also didn't care to be yelled at, so call me chicken," she says.

When I ask her whether she feels a sense of loss, being cut off from her father and the idol of her youth, she has two answers ready. "Rationally, no, because what I realised was that there wasn't that much there to begin with at that stage. Irrationally, yes, there's always a wish. Certainly I love my father and I want my daddy to be the perfect daddy he was when I was a little girl. The loss of a wish, of something that doesn't exist, can hurt just as much as something that is quite real."

Outside the hotel room, the early afternoon light is already beginning to fade over the snow on Boston common, and Peggy is ready for her photograph. The portrait on the back of her book shows the new Peggy, hap pily married, a mother and seemingly at peace. The woman now adjusting her make-up has cut her hair short and is wearing a no-nonsense suit. She is harried and nervous about the press. A freelance photographer working for a British newspaper has been harassing her family and her neighbours for days. She has taken on the burdens her father has spent most of his life avoiding.

But throughout the two-hour interview her heaviest load seems to be the nagging, unanswerable question of whether she has done the right thing. It is something she returns to again and again.

"Certainly my intention was not to demonise or point the finger at anyone," she says at one point. "My father sets up these sort of guru-acolyte relations where either you're perfect or you're damned, and I really try to sort out for myself who this human being was, is, who I'd never considered as a human being. I don't think it's disrespectful to a human being to take him off a pedestal. Quite the opposite. I feel any time you put a human being on a pedestal . . . it's dehumanising, whether you're pillorying him or worshipping him."

That is what is wrong with the Catcher in the Rye nutters, the Mark Chapmans of this world. They fail to see the human being behind the pages. In her own eyes, Peggy Salinger is only trying to make those pages more transparent.

She says: "If I have discouraged past and present and future readers from seeking out the writer, the creator of a fiction, as someone who will be their catcher, I don't think that's a bad thing."

 Dream Catcher by Peggy Salinger is published by Scribner, price £20.

I feel any time you put a human being on a pedestal . . . it's dehumanising, whether you're pillorying him or worshipping him." That is what is wrong with the Catcher in the Rye nutters, the Mark Chapmans of this world. They fail to see the human being behind the pages. In her own eyes, Peggy Salinger is only trying to make those pages more transparent. She says: "If I have discouraged past and present and future readers from seeking out the writer, the creator of a fiction, as someone who will be their catcher, I don't think that's a bad thing."  Dream Catcher by Peggy Salinger is published by Scribner, price £20.

webTitle: Blow for Trimble as Maginnis quits Commons

fields.headline: Blow for Trimble as Maginnis quits Commons
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Ulster Unionist MP Ken Maginnis today announced he is to stand down at the next general election - but insisted his party could hold on to his Fermanagh and South Tyrone seat.
fields.body:
Ulster Unionist MP Ken Maginnis today announced he is to stand down at the next general election - but insisted his party could hold on to his Fermanagh and South Tyrone seat.

His decision will come as a blow to his party leader, David Trimble, who counts Mr Maginnis as a close ally. Mr Trimble has faced challenges to his leadership over his support for the Good Friday Agreement.

A selection meeting to find the UUP's replacement candidate is expected before the end of the month.

But many observers feel that if a strong republican candidate was put forward the party could struggle to keep the seat Mr Maginnis has held for 18 years.

A UUP security spokesman acknowledged that the next election would be closely contested. "If you do a sectarian head count in Fermanagh and South Tyrone you'll find that it's touch and go either way," he said.

Mr Maginnis stressed that his party's record in trying to find a solution to the difficulties facing Northern Ireland could hold the key to success. "I believe that unionism can hold the seat in so far as unionism, particularly Ulster Unionism, has been constructive," he said.

"We have actually been a party that has tackled the problems and looked ahead rather than rested on our prejudices and the prejudices of the past." Mr Maginnis, 62, said that as "the engine's still good" health had not been a prime reason in his decision to stand down.

The former schoolteacher, soldier and businessman said he felt it was time to devote more time to other pursuits.

His high-profile role within the party has not come without a price, including terrorist attempts on his life.

And he admitted resenting members of the unionist community who showed unwillingness to change or to embrace the principles of the Good Friday Agreement. "One of the things I resented was that people came out in their hundreds of thousands to vote yes at the referendum and then they sat back and thought that they had done their bit for God and Ulster, from whatever perspective, unionist or nationalist and they really hadn't," he said.

"They had a responsibility to get out at the election and share the problems of taking this society ahead rather than saying, 'Oh, we did our bit, now we'll leave it up to Ken Maginnis or David Trimble or whoever'."

Despite his decision to take a back seat in future, Mr Maginnis added that it was unlikely he would disappear totally from public view.

"One way or another I do want to see progress, remember I have come through 18 years of ups and downs. I have seen the absolute downer in the Anglo-Irish Agreement of 1985.

"But I have seen Ulster unionism claw its way back from that to a situation where people now have an opportunity to move forward to heal old divisions, to be constructive in their politics, and although I'm standing down as a member of parliament I don't, if God spares me, intend to go away."

webTitle: McDonald's unveils pork burger in BSE-panicked Germany

fields.headline: McDonald's unveils pork burger in BSE-panicked Germany
fields.trailText: 12pm: As BSE crisis talks are held in Berlin, McDonald's has launched a burger made entirely out of pork in Germany, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
As the German government holds 'mad cow' crisis talks in Berlin, fast food chain McDonald's has launched a burger made entirely out of pork in a bid to protect its sales there.

The McFarmer burger, which is unique to Germany at present, will be promoted by its local roster agency, DDB worldwide-owned Heye & Partner Munich, via a TV and radio campaign.

McDonald's move to sell pork burgers comes as German consumers become increasingly concerned about eating beef.

Although there have only been eight reported cases of BSE since 1997 compared with 11,030 in the UK, there has been a fall in demand for beef products since the first German BSE case was reported on November 24.

When the UK BSE scare was at its peak in the mid-90s, McDonald's was forced into PR crisis management but did not launch the pork burger here.

MPs are today questioning health and agriculture ministers about allegations that the German public has been misled over the safety of beef.

Before Christmas McDonald's embarked on a massive ad campaign in Italy to allay public fears over beef safety, despite no case of BSE being reported there.

webTitle: Tobacco firms in row over film ban

fields.headline: Tobacco firms in row over film ban
fields.trailText: Hollywood actors are increasingly endorsing cigarette brands in films, leading to allegations by medical researchers that the movie and tobacco industries might be flouting a ban on payments for "product placements" in films.
fields.body:
Hollywood actors are increasingly endorsing cigarette brands in films, leading to allegations by medical researchers that the movie and tobacco industries might be flouting a ban on payments for "product placements" in films.

The use of actors to promote the most popular tobacco brands has increased tenfold since the voluntary ban was introduced in the US in 1990, according to a report published in the Lancet.

The findings have alarmed anti-smoking groups. Studies have shown that smoking by teenagers is strongly influenced by the use of tobacco by their favourite actor.

"Tobacco companies know full well that kids are going to see these films and this is probably a deliberate tactic to target the youth market," said Amanda Sandford, research manager for the charity Action on Smoking and Health.

The researchers, from Dartmouth Medical School in the US, said that several possibilities could explain continued tobacco brand appearance in films, from the tobacco industry continuing to pay directly or through payments in kind, to directors using brand imagery to increase a sense of realism or to convey character traits. However, flouting the payment ban would be consistent with regular violation of the cigarette advertising code by the tobacco industry since its inception in 1964.

The study looked at the top 25 US box office films for each year from 1988 to 1997. The researchers found that before 1990, 1% of the top US box office films showed actors with a recognisable brand of cigarette on screen. But in the years after the ban, 11% of the films showed actors endorsing a brand.

The four most highly advertised US cigarette brands accounted for the most on-screen appearances, including those in hits such as My Best Friend's Wedding (pictured), Men in Black and Volcano.

More than a quarter of all 250 films studied featured recognisable tobacco brands, including shots of billboards, shop fronts, logos and packets.

fields.headline: Ally Capellino
fields.trailText: Never mind 80s fashion - it's the fashion designers from the 80s who are truly making a comeback.
fields.body:
Never mind 80s fashion - it's the fashion designers from the 80s who are truly making a comeback. Azzedine Alaïa is finding a whole new audience to clad in his stretchy dresses, while Christian Lacroix is currently rising above his absolutely fabulous connotations and becoming stylish once more.

British label Ally Capellino dominated the wardrobes of many sensible and stylish women throughout the 80s and into the 90s. Roughly translated as "little hat" in Italian (albeit spelt incorrectly), the name refers to the company's beginnings in 1980 as an accessories line. Created by Alison Lloyd and partner Jonathan Platt, the label was characterised by timeless, simple tailoring. Cherie Blair was one of its biggest fans - she opted for Ally Capellino clothes for her first trip to 10 Downing Street and for Labour's triumphant election night.

On May 11 1999, everything went more than a little pear-shaped for designer Lloyd. Not only had her 24-year relationship with Platt turned sour, but her company went into receivership with debts of £500,000. Costs of running the expensive shop in Brompton Cross finally ground down the label, though there were other problems, chiefly the British press's lack of interest in a fashion label that was low on shock value. Flattering coats and elegant suits simply did not grab sufficient attention in a climate that wanted to ogle the newest Alexander McQueen.

But Lloyd has re-emerged. She has bought back from the receivers the name Capellino Design Limited and has launched a small accessories collection on her own. She plans to concentrate on this for the next few years and will start designing clothes again once she has built her business back up.

So forget about your bowling bags and baguettes: for a simple bag that will give you style cred but still be in next year, check out how the experts do it. Stockist enquiries, 020-8880 6828.

fields.headline: Overexposed:  detox diets
fields.trailText: Did you eat some Christmas pud last month? Drink a bit of alcohol, did you? Oooh, you are a naughty girl! Get on that detox now.
fields.body:
Did you eat some Christmas pud last month? Drink a bit of alcohol, did you? Oooh, you are a naughty girl! Get on that detox now.

Lower that cynical eyebrow, this is not a diet (sooo last century). A detox involves eating only fruit, veg and something called "millet". It also involves flogging a video in a tabloid, preferably one with a picture of you drinking a glass of water on the front, and it should be called something like: "You, too, can look as fabulous as me if you fork out £12.99 for this bit of reheated nonsense."

There's Carol Vorderman in one tabloid, bursting with fascinating advice along the lines of "eat lots of fruit and veg and drink lots of water". Carol's Detox Plan will cause you to visit the loo more, develop spots, become bloated and sweat more, but these are all good things (though your nearest and dearest might beg to differ).

Then there's Vanessa Feltz, telling us to eat lots of porridge and demonstrating how to shrug one's shoulders energetically - don't worry if the last manoeuvre sounds complicated, you can watch Vanessa demonstrate it in her detox video.

Every woman's magazine out this month has the words "DETOX SPECIAL" emblazoned across the cover. There is no escape even on TV, where early risers can chart the fascinating progress of Lorraine Kelly's detoxification on GMTV ("Oooh, time for some more wee grapes!").

Let's not kid ourselves: detox is just another name for diet. So you indulged a bit over Christmas - who cares? Life is too short to be patronised by the millet munchers. Go have some leftover roast potatoes instead.

fields.headline: Oversubscribed:  big belts
fields.trailText: Last year they were skinny, now they are fat. They fashionably combine this year's dual decade trends, the 50s and the 80s, and they are cinching the most fashionable waists. Yes, like ankle socks, woolly jumpers and pleated skirts, big belts are having an improbably fashionable renaissance. But unlike those other items, big belts are extremely flattering, especially when worn low-slung over your hips à la Celine - this stylistic twist may not be much help at keeping your trousers up, but it will make you look rather hip and sexy.
fields.body:
Last year they were skinny, now they are fat. They fashionably combine this year's dual decade trends, the 50s and the 80s, and they are cinching the most fashionable waists. Yes, like ankle socks, woolly jumpers and pleated skirts, big belts are having an improbably fashionable renaissance. But unlike those other items, big belts are extremely flattering, especially when worn low-slung over your hips à la Celine - this stylistic twist may not be much help at keeping your trousers up, but it will make you look rather hip and sexy.

Celine aside, Bottega Veneta, Louis Vuitton, Paul Smith Women and Miu Miu all feature big belts in their spring/summer collections, so get in there now before the high street copies do. For true street cred, check out the ones by Boyd. They are created by Skimp, the designer behind the big belt craze in the 80s, but Boyd has updated and prettified them in her own distinctive style.

Speaking of improbable trends, the real force behind the belt phase is the glammed-up cowgirl look, thank you very much, Mrs Guy Ritchie. With one sway of her belted hips and a toss of her Stetson-topped hair, Madonna jump-started the look into trendy territory last year in Brixton Academy, furthering the popularity of big belts. What she did for lacy gloves in the 80s and conical bras in the 90s, she is now doing for big belts in the 21st century. And who are we to argue with her?

fields.headline: A little of what you fancy
fields.standfirst: As the lights go out and the baubles are put back in the box, Jess Cartner-Morley finds a way to keep that festive feeling alive
fields.trailText: As the lights go out and the baubles are put back in the box, Jess Cartner-Morley finds a way to keep that festive feeling alive.
fields.body:
Tonight is Twelfth Night. Time to switch off the fairy lights and shroud the baubles in tissue. And I have a sneaking feeling it's time to tone down our wardrobes as well. After the sequined excess of the festive season, January is the month to hang up your gold dancing shoes and lace up your sturdiest boots. There's nothing like seeing a photograph of yourself wearing a paper hat to make you want to embrace minimalism.

But while open-toed sandals and plunging necklines might have to make way for socks and scarves, we all need a little pick-me-up in our sartorial lives. What with the cold, the dark, the post-Christmas financial squeeze and the chronic lack of parties, January is depressing enough without sentencing ourselves to a month of scratchy jumpers and sensible brown coats.

Especially now. A few years ago, fussiness was right next to fuddy-duddy-ness: we would sooner have decked out our bedrooms with pink satin valances and miniature heart-shaped scatter cushions than allow ruffles, frills and sparkly what-nots on to our sleek, chic clothes. Frou-frous and pompoms were inflicted only on small children and small dogs. Every right-thinking adult knew that clean lines and block colours were the road to style salvation.

But times have changed. Whereas once a discreet triangular Prada badge was the only embellishment necessary on a black nylon hand- bag, these days Dior saddlebags twinkle and jingle with shiny trims and logoed zip-pulls. Hosiery departments, previously a sombre sea of nothing but nude, black and barely-black, have become a riot of interlocking Chanel Cs and outsize fluorescent lobsternets.

This trend towards embellishment is not a one-season wonder, but a shift that has been happening for some time, so it's safe to dip a toe in. Attention to detail is, after all, the easiest way to give a gentle nudge forward to your hung-over January wardrobe. This is not the time to blind the world with premature enthusiasm for fluorescent colours and spray-painting - instead, ease yourself into the season with a sotto voce hint of trends-to-come.

Feathers, beads and frills are all back on the menu, but it is in the return of the non-functional belt that the revival of the Unnecessary Accessory is most clearly visible. Holding your trousers up takes a back seat, with the best belts encrusted with beads or embroidery and slung holster-style over skirts or trousers, with scant regard for belt loops or waistlines.

If the Modern Cowgirl look isn't for you, then instead go for vintage-style delicate glass beading, or jump on the Hoxton bandwagon with the Mary-Poppins-comes-to-EC1 crossover look - Edwardian ribbon-trimmed necklines worn with jeans and court shoes.

Go on, treat yourself. Over-indulgence may be off-season, but a little of what you fancy does you good.

fields.headline: Autonomy records strong revenue growth
fields.trailText: 10.45am: UK software company Autonomy has bucked recent trends in the sector by announcing strong revenue growth, writes Guy Middleton.
fields.body:
Cambridge-based software company Autonomy has announced strong growth in revenues over the last quarter.

This is in sharp contrast to the profit warnings of technology companies such as Microsoft, Intel and German e-commerce software vendor Intershop.

"We have not experienced a slowdown in our overall revenue growth during the fourth quarter of 2000 and have seen strong growth from the third quarter of 2000," said the company.

Autonomy, a developer of software designed to help companies manage information, made its founder Dr Mike Lynch the UK's first software billionaire.

However, the company has seen its stock hammered in line with the technology sector.

Although Autonomy didn't announce details of its revenues, the markets reacted strongly to the announcement, lifting the stock by 14%in early trading after a week that saw a third shaved off its value.

Autonomy, which is also traded on the Easdaq and Nasdaq stock markets, has seen its value drop by half since it took a listing on the London exchange in October.

The company reported revenues of £11.8m in the third quarter of 2000.

webTitle: Cole to provide the beef as Charlton face meaty derby

fields.headline: Cole to provide the beef as Charlton face meaty derby
fields.standfirst: The Arsenal fan hopes to gain revenge when Dagenham go to The Valley
fields.trailText: Tim Cole ruined his chance to make the grade as a professional footballer with Tottenham Hotspur because he always arrived at the club wearing an Arsenal shirt.
fields.body:
Tim Cole ruined his chance to make the grade as a professional footballer with Tottenham Hotspur because he always arrived at the club wearing an Arsenal shirt.

"I played for all the youth teams at White Hart Lane," he explains. "But wearing a Gunners strip every time I turned up for training didn't go down too well. In the end they got fed up with it and let me go. Arsenal have always been my team."

Instead of professional football Cole, 24, now earns a living lifting carcasses around London's Smithfield meat market. But tomorrow, when he plays for the Conference side Dagenham and Redbridge against Charlton Athletic at The Valley in the FA Cup third round, he has a belated chance of football glory. The tie is the talk of the East End, where another Cole is usually at the centre of the conversation.

Cole, the Dagenham centre-half and vice-captain, cannot afford a mistake tomorrow. "Whenever I do anything wrong I get stick from the lads because I'm up at one o'clock every morning to go to work and they put it down to that.

"We only train twice a week. On Tuesday - to get rid of the weekend beer - and on Thursday when we do a bit of ball work. I usually go straight to work from training. I've been doing this job for over two years now."

Cole, who was turned down after a trial with Wimbledon, has a clear idea of what the tactics will be. "I think we might have to kick a few early on, in the nicest possible way of course. We've got to compete and get stuck in and I won't be surprised if there are a few yellow cards early on.

"Charlton have run into some great form lately. But they're resting a few, which might give us a chance. We just can't let them knock it around all afternoon. If we can take them back to our place it will be a great result."

Cole is a throwback to the romantic, butcher-baker-candlestick maker image of the Cup's third round, when so many amateur players were famous for 90 minutes.

These days, though, the non-league clubs are professional or at least, as in the case of Dagenham, semi-pro. Dagenham, who merged with Redbridge Forest in 1992, lost the FA Trophy final in 1997 and last season won the Ryman League Premier Division title by 24 points.

"It's the atmosphere I'm looking forward to more than anything," says Cole. "The biggest crowd I've played in front of before was about 6,000, at Peterborough. On Saturday I reckon there will be more than double that. I've given away my 30 tickets and "King Cole's Barmy Army" will be in good voice. They've got the banners ready."

Dagenham and Redbridge are managed by Garry Hill and his assistant Terry Harris, a partnership that enjoyed outstanding non-league success at Heybridge Swifts and St Albans City.

Hill said: "Tim's been a very good player for us at the back and because he got me a nice piece of turkey for Christmas I made him vice-captain. If he gets me another piece I'll make him the penalty taker.

"Charlton's record at home, where they have beaten Arsenal and drawn with Manchester United, has been fantastic. So we can't afford to stand off and give them too much room to express themselves.

"I think the first 20 minutes will be vital. We're playing a quality Premiership side with million-pound players. I've got one who cost me £5,000 and the rest came on free transfers.

"But there's always at least one shock in the FA Cup every year. We're playing well in the Conference, where we're seventh. And the six teams above us are full-time. We've got a well-balanced side with lots of experience. We're going to The Valley to earn some respect and maybe raise a few eyebrows."

For Cole it is also a personal mission. "It would be nice to put one over on them after what they did to my Gunners on New Year's Day," he says. "I had hoped that Arsenal might do us a favour and put a big dent in their confidence."

fields.headline: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.standfirst: The new year has already given us a masterpiece in the shape of Ang Lee's martial arts epic, says  Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The new year has already given us a masterpiece in the shape of Ang Lee's martial arts epic
fields.body:
The year 2001 has got off to the best start possible with this fantastic film. Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is a martial arts movie in a traditional Chinese action idiom which manages to be both electrifyingly exciting and sweetly romantic - qualities wrapped up in the preternatural innocence of a fairy tale.

Chow Yun-Fat plays the legendary warrior Li Mu Bai, deeply in love with Yu Shu Lien (Michelle Yeoh), the fiercest female martial arts practitioner in China but, through a combination of male pride and reticence, he is unable to declare his passion - and she, too, because of loyalty to a fiance now dead, cannot admit what she feels for him.

The delicate sadness and internalising of their love unfolds in parallel with the blazing passion of another couple: Jen (Zhang Ziyi), a gorgeous young aristocrat, has formed a secret liaison with outlaw Lo (Chang Chen), but she yearns for the life of the warrior and steals the Green Destiny, Li Mu Bai's precious sword, richly and exquisitely carved and inlaid.

Until seeing this film, I had long thought that some kind of moratorium ought to be declared on the indiscriminate use of the word "balletic" to describe fight scenes - a naive cliche generally used by those who have never seen a real fight, or indeed a ballet, in their lives.

But no other word will do for the sublime perfection of these action sequences which Ang Lee's touch - and that of choreographer Yuen Wo Ping of Matrix fame, and cinematographer Peter Pau - have realised with such extraordinary flair. There is real poetry and artistry in the way the visual images are assembled which lifts this film miles above the crudeness of berk flicks like Romeo Must Die.

In one scene, the brutal clash of fists and weaponry disturbs the birds in the trees and Lee interrupts our view of the fight briefly, in favour of an epiphanic vision of the birds ascending into the sky: a pleasing moment of inspiration which anticipates the climactic fight between Jen and Li Mu Bai as they float through the treetops themselves: in its exuberance and charm, it has to be one of the most beautiful moments in modern cinema.

Crouching Tiger adopts the convention of the wu xia martial arts stories: in formal combat, the rules of gravity are suspended, and with them the rules of narrative and ordinary human possibility - bringing into the action genre a delirious new sort of magic realism. It grafts onto it a kind of fabular quality, which confers such distinction on the film, but leaves intact the thrills of the fight scenes themselves.

The opening punch-up is not vouchsafed to us straight after the credits, or even during the credits, in the way we have come to expect from any action picture, but after 10 self-effacing minutes of exposition. Only then does Lee unleash Yu Shu Lien's thrilling rooftop chase with the masked intruder: a fight of incredible strangeness, stark moonlit mystery - and delirious excitement. If you're too cool to be excited by it, then you're too cool. With its pointed intensity and the compelling, single drumbeat on the soundtrack, it's an action sequence to treble the heart rate and cause the skin to prickle with goosepimples.

Ang Lee's achievement is to reconnect the genre with its innate, latent sense of decorum and romance, qualities which have been ignored, or treated ironically or unintelligently. Crouching Tiger juxtaposes the fatal secrets of martial arts with those of meditation and even calligraphy, and persuades us to take them equally seriously. Added to the miniaturist's skill in rendering the delicate touches of the principals' hidden love, he has an epic sense of space and landscape, moving lightly from Peking to the desert: Ang Lee puts a girdle around his earth in seconds.

Frankly, this is what Phantom Menace was supposed to feel like. And Ang Lee must certainly win best foreign language picture Oscar this spring - or indeed best picture. Chow Yun-Fat and Michelle Yeoh carry off their roles with poise and charm, and the melancholy of their unspoken love has real pathos.

In the old-fashioned entertainment that it delivers, and in its inspired combination of seriousness and playfulness, Crouching Tiger is already assuming the lineaments of a classic. And if this film proves to be the father to a series of similar works, then it could almost be that a new popular genre of film-making has been born, or reborn: a new Asian western for the 21st century.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week nineteen

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week nineteen
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. It's a new year, so will they do any better?
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £184.45, Sean Ingle = £70.04, Football Unlimited punters collective = £49.73, Paul MacInnes = £42.70
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £184.45, Sean Ingle = £70.04, Football Unlimited punters collective = £49.73, Paul MacInnes = £42.70

Scott Murray: Liverpool v Rotherham - four goals or more £15 @ 6/5

Rotherham can sit fourth in the Second Division all they like, but any top Premiership side worth their salt should be able to defeat lower-league opposition heavily at home in an important Cup tie. In fact, carnage should be inflicted more often than not.

Now, if you mistake those hackneyed musings for reasoned argument, then a better-than-evens price is far too generous to turn down. Especially when you consider the mess the Reds made of Stoke - one place below Rotherham - away from home in the Worthington Cup.

Of course, you could remind me that Liverpool have a history of clanking uselessly out of the Cup at home to teams from the Second. But as I've already gone and put my bet on, you wouldn't want to make me sick with worry, would you?

Oh.

Sean Ingle: £7 win double: Huddersfield v Bristol City: Huddersfield to win @ 8/11 and Burnley v Scunthorpe: Burnley to win @ 4/9

In the mid-1980s Eric Bristow MBE, perhaps the greatest darts player on his generation, developed a serious case of darts-itis - an infliction that caused his hand to stammer wildly as he went for a winning double.

Over the last few months, the same thing has happened to me. Only with good value singles. I see them. I like them. And I want to put money on them. But as my hand hovers over my mouse, bets-itis strikes and I end up choosing a ropey-looking double.

And so it is this week. I see that in-form Wolves are way over-priced at 7/2 to beat Forest, but hang on a second, what's happening to my hand and before I know it I've picked Huddersfield and Burnley to win instead.

There is some justification for my selections though. Burnley may have lost their last five games, but Scunthorpe haven't won any of their last five either. And I'd back an out-of-form First Division team to win at home against an out-of-form Third Division side at more often than nine times in 13. And Huddersfield - who are unbeaten in seven - should be much too strong for Bristol City, who have lost their last two games away.

I would reckon this double should come off more often than not, and seeing as it pays 2.5-1, it surely constitutes value. So that's where my money is going.

Paul MacInnes: Birmingham to beat Man City at 10/3 - £5

Birmingham City may have fallen out of the play-off spots (I say may, because I don't do anything as boring as check recent form before making a bet), but they've still got to have a good chance of beating a City side that would have to coin new terms for "shocking performance", if their fans hadn't done it already. I put my fiver on this tie and I very much hope that the bet comes off. That is all I have to say on the matter.

Neil Harnett of the Football Unlimited punter's collective: Walsall to beat West Ham, £5 at 7/2

Recent West Ham FA Cup campaigns have been hampered by a succession of embarrassing exits to lower League teams, so it would be of no surprise to me if high-flying Second Division side Walsall were to continue the trend on Saturday.

Walsall met West Ham in the Second Round of the League Cup earlier this season and suffered a narrow 0-1 defeat, then drew the second leg 1-1 at Upton Park - but the Saddlers had the better of both games and should have won the tie.

Apart from that defeat by West Ham, Walsall are unbeaten at home this season and have only lost twice in the last 11 games. For this reason I think 7/2 is a fair price for a home victory. Although West Ham's form has picked up of late, they've lost their last two away games which included a mauling at Old Trafford on Monday evening.

If Harry Redknapp's side think they'll have it easy at Bescot tomorrow, they'll be wrong. And this being the FA Cup, there could be a giant-killing on the cards and some much-needed cash back in the Collective's pot!

webTitle: Shipman may have killed up to 250

fields.headline: Shipman may have killed up to 250
fields.trailText: Government helplines were today being set up amid fears that serial killer GP Harold Shipman may have killed up to 250 patients.
fields.body:
Government helplines were today being set up amid fears that serial killer GP Harold Shipman may have killed up to 250 patients.

The convicted mass murderer recorded at least 250 more deaths over 25 years than other doctors working in similar practices, an audit of his clinical practice has shown.

Police had suspected that the Greater Manchester GP had killed up to 192 patients and the findings of the review of his work have been passed to detectives and the crown prosecution service, the Department of Health said.

He compared the number of patient deaths recorded by Shipman with those of other GPs in the same area.

The study compared trends including the time of death, presence of the doctor involved and the presence of any relatives.

Prof Baker did not investigate individual cases over the 24-year period, but the 250-excess death rate appears to confirm fears that Shipman killed many more people than previously thought.

Police had said they had enough evidence to charge Shipman with the murders of a further 23 patients.

A public inquiry into Shipman's crimes is set to be chaired by high court judge Dame Janet Smith and will be held in Manchester.

No date has yet been announced.

It was believed it could begin as early as February and Ann Alexander, the solicitor for the relatives of Shipman's relatives, said it would look at the deaths of at least 150 additional suspected victims.

She said it would be "far reaching" and would seek to identify gaps in the system which had allowed Shipman to continue his killing spree undetected.

It will also consider how he obtained drugs, altered medical records and arranged for most of his victims to be cremated without post-mortem examinations.

webTitle: Call to buy out people living on eroding coasts

fields.headline: Call to buy out people living on eroding coasts
fields.trailText: Parts of the coastline should be abandoned to the sea, but planners are avoiding making the right decisions because there is no legislation to allow them to compensate the owners who face ruin as a result.
fields.body:
Parts of the coastline should be abandoned to the sea, but planners are avoiding making the right decisions because there is no legislation to allow them to compensate the owners who face ruin as a result.

David Carter, a lecturer at the University of Portsmouth, researching for the Ministry of Agriculture, said new legislation was needed to provide compensation for those whose land and homes needed to be abandoned to the sea in the public interest.

He said rising sea levels and more frequent storms meant it was more and more difficult and expensive to defend parts of the coast. Improvements in science also showed that extra defences in one area meant erosion in others so those adversely affected should receive compensation.

"I am not a lawyer but if there was a planning decision which caused my house to fall in the sea or my land to flood then I think I would have cause to sue," he added.

He said a test case was Medmerry Beach at Selsey, near Chichester, where the largest caravan site in Europe - which had 10,000 residents in the summer - was sheltering behind a shingle beach that was being washed away by the sea. Each year the environment agency was waging a losing battle against the elements by spending £500,000 a year replacing shingle on the beach.

"Basically the right thing to do is let the shingle beach move inland. Eventually the sea will win, but there is no proper way of compensating those who suffer."

The environment agency, which spends £19.2m a year on sea defence, said it was hoping for permission from the Ministry of Agriculture to move back the line of Medmerry Beach. "Three homes will be lost and part of the caravan site and it will cost millions to complete but at least we will have a beach we think we can hold," said a spokesman.

Dr Carter, who is researching the success of new 10-year plans for coastal defence for the ministry, said a lot of radical decisions needed to be made to retreat from the sea. Unstable cliffs could not be defended and must be allowed to fall into the sea and low-lying land in north Kent, Essex and Norfolk must be abandoned to allow salt flats to develop. Small schemes, mostly in harbours such as Chichester, had already been successful but they were needed on a much larger scale.

A second serious problem was developments which were allowed where there were no adequate sea defences. An example was Sovereign Harbour on Pevensey Bay in east Sussex, where hundreds of houses were still being built but were in danger of inundation by the sea. Fellow researcher Jane Taussik, from the same university, said councillors often overruled the advice of coastal engineers, their own officers, and the environment agency and allowed development in dangerous places.

"The recent floods have been eye-opening as far as the devastating effects that bad planning decisions can have. We have not been careful about the safeguards we need to take in tidal areas, either. We need to make a condition of developments that flood mitigation measures are put in place. Builders should be told houses cannot be sold or moved into until defence works are completed.

"When people are buying houses on the coast they should check on the risk. People often expect local authorities to tell them of the dangers but no one does. It is the house owner's or buyer's responsibility. It is not a question solicitors ask on searches, it is 'buyer beware'."

webTitle: Bertelsmann appoints journalist as head of BMG

fields.headline: Bertelsmann appoints journalist as head of BMG
fields.trailText: 10.15am: German media group Bertelsmann has appointed a former journalist to head up its BMG music operation, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
German media group Bertelsmann has appointed a former journalist and TV news star as the head of its BMG music operation, as merger talks with EMI reach a critical stage.

Rolf Schmidt-Holtz, chief creative officer at Bertelsmann, will take the chief executive post following the sudden death of Rudi Gassner before Christmas.

Mr Schmidt-Holtz has no experience of the music industry and made his name as an anchorman covering the Chernobyl disaster in 1986. Since then, he has worked as editor of the massively successful Stern magazine and has run Bertelsmann's European film and TV businesses.

Mr Schmidt-Holtz is, however, seen as a safe pair of hands, as Bertelsmann attempts to rush through the merger with UK music group EMI by the end of the month.

"Rolf Schmidt-Holtz is a 'content man'," said Thomas Middelhoff, Bertelsmann chief executive.

"He has a direct approach to creative talent, artists and performers. He is also one of our own. This ensures a high level of competence and professionalism in the music division's management."

His appointment comes at a crucial time as negotiations over the proposed merger reach a crescendo.

The management structure of the new company is reported to be a major bone of contention but it has been made clear that Mr Middelhoff will continue to lead negotiations over the merger, which began in November last year.

"The music business is undergoing radical upheavals. Reshaping it is one of the most interesting entrepreneurial challenges and opportunities imaginable," said Mr Schmidt-Holtz.

The new man at BMG has extensive merger experience, and oversaw the combination of Bertelsmann's UFA television arm and CLT of Luxembourg in 1997, but does not have the same experience of the music industry as Ken Berry, the head of recorded music at EMI.

It is believed that one structure under discussion would see Mr Schmidt-Holtz and Mr Berry taking joint chief executive roles within the company. BMG's shares would be folded into EMI's and listed in London.

Another option is to float a merged EMI-BMG, although volatile market conditions may put that idea on the backburner.

EMI was not available for comment this morning.

A successful deal would bring together artists such as Robbie Williams, the Rolling Stones and Whitney Houston, and realise Mr Middelhoff's ambition to create the world's largest music group.

EMI will be hoping for a positive outcome following last year's collapse of its £12bn joint venture with Warner Music in the face of opposition from EU watchdogs.

The company is concerned that yet another protracted merger process will distract managers and rack up millions of pounds in legal and advisory fees.

fields.headline: Shipman's victims total 'at least 230'
fields.trailText: Harold Shipman will today be confirmed as the biggest mass murderer known to medical history when an official government report reveals that the Cheshire GP killed 230 elderly patients - and probably in excess of 250.
fields.body:
Harold Shipman will today be confirmed as the biggest mass murderer known to medical history when an official government report reveals that the Cheshire GP killed 230 elderly patients - and probably in excess of 250.

A clinical audit of the suspicious deaths which occurred in his one-man practice at Hyde has produced what Department of Health officials called a "chilling" pattern of "excess deaths", either at home or at the surgery - often between noon and 3 pm which points to deliberate killings - usually by lethal injection.

The report, at least 1cm thick, contains tables which set out the recurring pattern.

Days after Dame Janet Smith was appointed to preside over the public inquiry into the scale of Shipman's crimes - over and above the 15 murder convictions reached against him last year - the chief medical officer of health, Liam Donaldson, will publish the report of Richard Baker of Leicester University. Professor Baker went through all the medical records of Shipman, who is serving a life sentence, during his 20 years in Hyde when his only other staff colleague was his wife, who acted as his secretary.

He delivered his report to Dr Donaldson, who had been asked to arrange the audit by the health secretary, Alan Milburn.

Although it is not clear quite how many deaths can be laid at the GP's door, it is said to be "definitely" 236, and probably 250. Taken with the 15 for which he was tried at Preston crown court, the total is around 265. No medical serial killer is ever known to have murdered so many people, outside the Nazi death camps.

His reputation warded off inquiries for years until it was found that he had lied about a conviction for drug abuse. Under the new health bill, previous convictions will have to be notified to a health authority. The Baker report will be sent to the crown prosecution service, who will decide whether to prosecute.
