fields.headline: 'Romania with burgers' jibe angers council
fields.trailText: Walsall may not be best known for its picturesque landscape but a critic's recent description of the Black Country town as "Ceaucescu's Romania with fast food outlets" has proved too much for its outraged residents.
fields.body:
Walsall may not be best known for its picturesque landscape but a critic's recent description of the Black Country town as "Ceaucescu's Romania with fast food outlets" has proved too much for its outraged residents.

Council leader Mike Bird yesterday led the backlash against art critic Theodore Dalrymple, who launched a vicious attack on the town writing under a pseudonym in American art magazine New Criterion.

The article, titled Crudity Beyond Belief, refers to Walsall as one of the "most depressing areas of urban devastation" in the world, dismissing the internationally acclaimed New Art Gallery as resembling a post-modernist grain silo.

"It is possible that there are uglier towns in the world than Walsall, but if so I do not know them. While Walsall undoubtedly exists, it is difficult to know where precisely it begins and ends, because it is in the middle of one of the largest and most depressing contiguous areas of urban devastation in the world," Mr Dalrymple claims.

Mr Bird said yesterday such criticisms of the town and gallery were totally unwarranted and dismissed them as nonsense. "I have no time for people who remain anonymous and haven't got the guts to stand up and be counted. He should keep his ridiculous views to himself. Walsall is a town which is working hard to pull itself up by its bootstraps and the gallery has received international acclaim."

The town hit the headlines last year when a resident, George Roper, launched an "Ugly-Walsall" website, which features photographs of boarded-up buildings, and other eyesores.

However, its new £21m lottery-funded art gallery, designed by architects Caruso St John, brought more positive publicity to the town after bursting on to the international art map to a rapturous reception from critics around the world.

Descriptions such as "a beautiful collection of spaces", "a world class gallery" and "stunningly beautiful" appear to be at odds with Mr Dalrymple's negative experience of the building and its surroundings.

"One veers between thinking oneself in a fascist foreign ministry and a sauna of gigantic proportions," he complains.

He adds: "There is nowhere in the world where it is possible to travel such long distances without seeing anything grateful to the eye. The Black Country looks like Ceaucescu's Romania with fast food outlets."

Mr Bird last night branded Mr Dalrymple as a narrow-minded individual, who would be "better off staying wherever he lives".

webTitle: Has Greenspan pulled US back from the economic brink?

fields.headline: Has Greenspan pulled US back from the economic brink?
fields.standfirst: No one is quite sure whether rate cut came from prudence or panic
fields.trailText: No one is quite sure whether rate cut came from prudence or panic.
fields.body:
The spectre of recession in the world's biggest economy cast its shadow across Wall Street yesterday as the financial markets began to have second thoughts about the unheralded cut in US interest rates on Wednesday night.

While the initial reaction to the hastily-contrived move was a party atmosphere and sharply rising share prices, a sense of self doubt has begun to creep into the American psyche. A year ago the boast was of the miracle economy and the everlasting boom; today there is a growing sense of foreboding that the departure of Bill Clinton from the White House later this month will mark the end of an era.

At best, the feeling is that the magician of the markets - Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve - has pulled off another Houdini-like trick, as he did when the world economy was teetering on the brink of disaster in the Autumn of 1998. The optimistic scenario is that the US central bank has acted in the nick of time, easing policy to prevent the slowdown in the economy from turning into a crash landing.

But while there are reasons to be cheerful about the US, the violent mood swing that has accompanied the collapse in the value of high-tech stocks since the spring of last year reflects well-founded concern that the good times may not be coming back for quite some time.

The president-elect, George W Bush, was left in no doubt when he met 30 of the titans of corporate America at a gathering in Austin, Texas, that his presidency may be dogged by the economic problems that ensured his father's defeat at the hands of Mr Clinton in 1992. One at a time, the chief executives spoke of orders and sales that had fallen far faster and more steeply than anyone had expected.

Speaking after the meeting, the president elect said: "A lot of folks in this room have brought some pretty bad news - that their sales are slowing, that they're having to trim back their work force ... The warning signs are real, people's bottom lines are being affected."

Even allowing for the fact that Mr Bush's agenda is to create the conditions for tax cuts, his comments appeared to sum up the general mood of gloom. James Morgan, the chief executive of Applied Materials, a high-tech manufacturer, said yesterday: "I was surprised at how broad based the negative sentiment was."

Those still bullish about the prospects for the US say that all this doom and gloom is overdone. They point out that America's unemployment rate is 4%, inflation is only around 3%, despite a decade of strong growth, productivity is booming, America leads the way in the sunrise industries of the 21st century and that there is plenty of scope for policy-makers to stimulate demand. Adjusted for inflation, real interest rates are high and could come down sharply over the coming months if the signs of economic distress intensify. Moreover, Mr Clinton's budget frugality means there is scope for tax cuts and spending increases.

Above all, there is still confidence in the ability of Mr Greenspan - the central banker who has seen it all and done it all - to steer the economy through the current squall and into calmer seas beyond. If the Federal Reserve's chairman can finesse a soft landing for the US, slowing its rate of growth to between 2.5% and 3%, it will be the crowning triumph of his illustrious career, topping even his performance in 1998 when he cut rates aggressively and orchestrated a bail-out for the troubled hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management (LTCM).

But the pessimists put forward three arguments to explain why it will all end in tears. The first is that the state of the American economy is much weaker than most analysts have yet realised. Graham Turner, of the consultancy firm GFC Economics, said that the case for a cut in US rates was compelling, with figures showing demand for new cars slumping and manufacturing in recession. The investment boom of the past few years has led to an over-supply of goods and services, which in turn has led to an erosion of profitability. This has been particularly true of the high-tech sector, hence the downward spiral in share prices.

This downbeat view is shared by the second camp, but with a complication - that there may be something nasty lurking in Wall Street's financial woodwork. Roger Bootle, of Capital Economics, said: "The combination of a rate cut between Fed meetings and the cut being 50 basis points, not 25, indicates Greenspan is seriously worried. He should be.

"It is perfectly possible that he is worried about something apart from the economic slowdown and prospects of recession. Remember we did not find out about how serious the LTCM crisis was until it was already upon us. And there are plenty of candidates out there, both domestically and internationally, for upsetting the applecart. Accordingly, the initial reaction of the equity markets was utterly perverse. They just don't get it."

A short downturn in the US would be one thing. A full-blown recession accompanied by a systemic financial crisis would be quite different, threatening the US with the problem that has bedevilled Japan since its stock market bubble burst - deflation. Mr Bootle believes Mr Greenspan will need to cut and cut again to prevent this happening, with interest rates falling to perhaps 3% over the coming months.

Foolishness

The final scenario is that there is no new LTCM crisis about to break, but that Mr Greenspan has merely decided to bail out Wall Street from the consequences of its own cupidity and foolishness.

Charles Dumas, at Lombard Street Research, believes that the US is experiencing an old fashioned business cycle in which over-capacity has led to a falling return on capital, which can only be rectified by a period of painful retrenchment.

"Only an unknown LTCM-type problem can justify the Fed funds rate cut, which threatens the dollar. The present downswing, led by business spending, could give way to a short-lived recovery based on easy money, tax cuts, and accelerating wages. But with a weak dollar, it will quickly burn out in faster core inflation. Postponed adjustment will be more painful."

In some ways, this is the most disturbing scenario. The prospect of the US becoming the new Japan is worrying enough. But the thought that Mr Greenspan may have"lost it" would transform the spectre of recession into chilling reality.

Even allowing for the fact that Mr Bush's agenda is to create the conditions for tax cuts, his comments appeared to sum up the general mood of gloom. James Morgan, the chief executive of Applied Materials, a high-tech manufacturer, said yesterday: "I was surprised at how broad based the negative sentiment was." Those still bullish about the prospects for the US say that all this doom and gloom is overdone. They point out that America's unemployment rate is 4%, inflation is only around 3%, despite a decade of strong growth, productivity is booming, America leads the way in the sunrise industries of the 21st century and that there is plenty of scope for policy-makers to stimulate demand. Adjusted for inflation, real interest rates are high and could come down sharply over the coming months if the signs of economic distress intensify. Moreover, Mr Clinton's budget frugality means there is scope for tax cuts and spending increases. Above all, there is still confidence in the ability of Mr Greenspan - the central banker who has seen it all and done it all - to steer the economy through the current squall and into calmer seas beyond. If the Federal Reserve's chairman can finesse a soft landing for the US, slowing its rate of growth to between 2.5% and 3%, it will be the crowning triumph of his illustrious career, topping even his performance in 1998 when he cut rates aggressively and orchestrated a bail-out for the troubled hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management (LTCM). But the pessimists put forward three arguments to explain why it will all end in tears. The first is that the state of the American economy is much weaker than most analysts have yet realised. Graham Turner, of the consultancy firm GFC Economics, said that the case for a cut in US rates was compelling, with figures showing demand for new cars slumping and manufacturing in recession. The investment boom of the past few years has led to an over-supply of goods and services, which in turn has led to an erosion of profitability. This has been particularly true of the high-tech sector, hence the downward spiral in share prices. This downbeat view is shared by the second camp, but with a complication - that there may be something nasty lurking in Wall Street's financial woodwork. Roger Bootle, of Capital Economics, said: "The combination of a rate cut between Fed meetings and the cut being 50 basis points, not 25, indicates Greenspan is seriously worried. He should be. "It is perfectly possible that he is worried about something apart from the economic slowdown and prospects of recession. Remember we did not find out about how serious the LTCM crisis was until it was already upon us. And there are plenty of candidates out there, both domestically and internationally, for upsetting the applecart. Accordingly, the initial reaction of the equity markets was utterly perverse. They just don't get it." A short downturn in the US would be one thing. A full-blown recession accompanied by a systemic financial crisis would be quite different, threatening the US with the problem that has bedevilled Japan since its stock market bubble burst - deflation. Mr Bootle believes Mr Greenspan will need to cut and cut again to prevent this happening, with interest rates falling to perhaps 3% over the coming months. Foolishness The final scenario is that there is no new LTCM crisis about to break, but that Mr Greenspan has merely decided to bail out Wall Street from the consequences of its own cupidity and foolishness. Charles Dumas, at Lombard Street Research, believes that the US is experiencing an old fashioned business cycle in which over-capacity has led to a falling return on capital, which can only be rectified by a period of painful retrenchment. "Only an unknown LTCM-type problem can justify the Fed funds rate cut, which threatens the dollar. The present downswing, led by business spending, could give way to a short-lived recovery based on easy money, tax cuts, and accelerating wages. But with a weak dollar, it will quickly burn out in faster core inflation. Postponed adjustment will be more painful." In some ways, this is the most disturbing scenario. The prospect of the US becoming the new Japan is worrying enough. But the thought that Mr Greenspan may have"lost it" would transform the spectre of recession into chilling reality.

webTitle: Hospitals told to clean up over CJD

fields.headline: Hospitals told to clean up over CJD
fields.trailText: Hospitals have been ordered to improve their decontamination and sterilisation procedures to reduce the theoretical risk of patients catching the fatal human form of BSE.
fields.body:
Hospitals have been ordered to improve their decontamination and sterilisation procedures to reduce the theoretical risk of patients catching the fatal human form of BSE.

The government yesterday promised £200m would be spent in England alone on new equipment - and confirmed that surgeons must use throw-away instruments for all tonsil operations in Britain, a change that will cost a further £30m a year.

The measures, part of an extensive overhaul of hospital hygiene to fight the spread of variant CJD, compare with the £6bn cost of programmes to control BSE in cattle and lost exports.

Ministers and senior officials hope that the modernisation of cleansing will help reduce the costs for far more expensive rekitting of hospitals with disposable equipment for more complicated and more expensive operations than tonsillectomy, which is usually performed on children with equipment costing just a few hundred pounds. But they concede that the changes in that operation, expected to be completed this year, could provide valuable lessons for far wider use of once-only instruments if that were necessary.

Eighty-three people have died from vCJD, with five known victims still alive, but scientists still have little idea of the eventual size of the epidemic. The Department of Health is so worried that present decontamination, sterilisation and even washing arrangements are not up to scratch that it is conducting a national survey and has appointed a central management team to ensure improvements are carried out. Every NHS trust is expected to have an official responsible for changes.

Problems with existing sterilisation equipment, regardless of the vCJD threat, were highlighted late last year by orthopaedic surgeons at a Portsmouth hospital who threatened to stop all emergency operations, saying patients' lives were at risk.

The new money for equipment in England will be phased over two years. The NHS in Scotland set aside £3m for improvements this year and an audit is under way to see just what changes may be needed in Wales.

Pat Troop, deputy chief medical officer for England, said: "We still do not know how many people might be incubating vCJD. There is a theoretical risk that it can be passed through surgical instruments from those who have yet to show symptoms of the disease. The highest standards of decontamination are the cornerstone of our strategy to reduce risks."

fields.headline: Remembering the last time
fields.trailText: It is not only in Manhattan and Silicon Valley that the word recession has been expunged from the lexicon of economic terms in day-to-day use since the early 90s. Britain, too, has enjoyed a period of uninterrupted growth. But for those who can't remember what it is like in a recession, here are a few reminders:
fields.body:
It is not only in Manhattan and Silicon Valley that the word recession has been expunged from the lexicon of economic terms in day-to-day use since the early 90s. Britain, too, has enjoyed a period of uninterrupted growth. But for those who can't remember what it is like in a recession, here are a few reminders:

 Interest rates today are 6%. Between May 1988 and October 1989, they rose from 7.5% to 15% and stayed at that level for 12 months. Britain came grinding to a halt in the autumn of 1990, and stayed in the doldrums for two years. Although not as severe as the slump of the early 80s, the economy contracted by 1.5% in 1991 and expanded by 0.1% in 1992.

 Unemployment rose. The number of people out of work and claiming benefit stood at just under 1.6m in the spring of 1990. Two and a half years later it was nudging 3m.

 The result of dear borrowing and longer dole queues was that many of those who bought houses during the property boom of the late 80s promptly lost them during the subsequent slump. The number of repossessions rose from 18,510 in 1988 to a record 75,540 in 1991.

 Those who managed to keep up their monthly payments struggled with negative equity, where the loan outstanding on a property was greater than its market value. After soaring in the late 80s, house prices were flat in 1990 and then fell in each of the next three years.

 Businesses big and small went bust. The number of personal bankruptcies rose four-fold from 8,138 in 1989 to 32,106 in 1992, compulsory liquidations increased from 4,020 to 9,734 over the same period, while voluntary liquidations were up from 6,436 to 14,891. Canary Wharf was lying empty. Mystery still surrounds the death of Robert Maxwell, found drowned at sea off the Canary Islands in November 1991. His Maxwell Communications Corporation faced mounting debts.

 Political reputations were shredded. First to suffer was Nigel Lawson, who went from hero to villain in the space of two years as the heady expansion of 1987 and 1988 was followed by a sharp contraction. Then it was the turn of Lawson's successor, Norman Lamont, who attracted widespread scorn for his optimistic comments in the autumn of 1991 that he could spot the "green shoots of recovery".

Mr Lamont was made the fall guy for the humiliation of the Conservative government on Black Wednesday, which led to Britain's exit from the exchange rate mechanism and was the catalyst for economic recovery. In truth, the reputation of his boss, John Major, never recovered either, although his moment of truth did not arrive until May 1997.

webTitle: London listings outfit approaches ex-Express ad man

fields.headline: London listings outfit approaches ex-Express ad man
fields.standfirst: Special reports: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
8.15am: Former Express ad director Richard Bogie has been approached by London listings magazine and website London.co.uk, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Special reports: Express takeover
fields.body:
Former Express advertising director Richard Bogie has been approached by London listings magazine and website London.co.uk to act as a sales consultant.

Mr Bogie was made redundant at the beginning of December along with at least 20 members of the paper's advertising sales team after Northern & Shell bought the newspaper.

He joins a number of other respected journalists and publishing figures at the new free listings magazine, including former Maxim editor Chris Maillard, former Eat Soup editor David Lancaster and ex-Scene art director Pete Avery.

London.co.uk is pitched as an "older, more sophisticated" version of Time Out, according to Mr Lancaster.

He said that the magazine's accompanying website would liberate it from having to carry "detailed information about an obscure mime artist performing above a pub", and allow it to be more "critic-driven".

"A magazine is such a good business model, but the web allows us to mop up some of the listings that clog up magazines like Time Out."

Backed by printer Woodford Litho, London.co.uk launches a dummy this week with a print run of 15,000 and is expected to launch a full weekly version with a 50,000 run in April.

fields.headline: Telewest's Singer takes role at online auctioneer
fields.trailText: 9.45: Telewest chief Adam Singer has been appointed as non-executive director at online auctioneering firm QXL Ricardo, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Telewest chief Adam Singer has been appointed as non-executive director at QXL Ricardo, the online auctioneering firm that has seen its share value dive by 98% in the past year.

Mr Singer, the former chairman and chief executive of UK cable TV company Flextech, became group chief executive of the newly-merged company when Telewest bought Flextech last year.

"What better place can there be to observe this revolution and contribute to it than at QXL, which is one of the most exciting of the new media companies to have emerged in the past few years," said Mr Singer.

QXL Ricardo, which was created from a merger between UK firm QXL and German online auctioneer Ricardo, had pitched itself as a rival to US auction giant Ebay.

QXL's acquisition last summer of Ricardo for £627m made history as the biggest internet acquisition.

But the company has seen its fortunes fall with the rest of the technology market and ended last year reporting losses of £69m.

fields.headline: World politicians play asylum card
fields.standfirst: Whipping up exaggerated fears of foreign incomers seems to be a global political phenomenon
fields.trailText: Whipping up exaggerated fears of foreign incomers seems to be a global political phenomenon
fields.body:
Another 50 dead this week, in a shipwreck off the Turkish coast, to add to the toll of lives lost trying to enter Europe illegally. Disasters becoming routine, while politicians talk more and more of keeping people out. In Germany, Chancellor Schroder, speaking recently near the border with the Czech Republic, calls for a seven-year ban on the movement of labour from Central European countries after they join the European Union. In Italy, Silvio Berlusconi could win the coming general election on the immigration issue.

In the United States, President Clinton has just failed to overcome opposition to legalising the residence of immigrants from a number of Central American countries. In Australia, the former prime minister Malcolm Fraser describes the asylum detention centre in remote Woomera as "a hellhole". In Britain, the attempt to disperse asylum seekers is in trouble, the criticisms merging into a general row over race and immigration. Fear of people remains a powerful political force everywhere.

How much migration would there be in a better world? There would be far fewer refugees, since there would be fewer wars, fewer tyrannical states and better preparations against natural disasters. There would be less "economic" migration, since the differentials in income and circumstance would be smaller. If there is anything that has been established pretty much beyond doubt in studies of migration it is that the vast majority of people prefer to stay at home. The sociologist Saskia Sassen, who has examined these matters with great insight, has shown that when they do leave home, there have to be very compelling reasons, special opportunities or established habits or some combination of these three. When they nevertheless do leave, they prefer to do so on a temporary basis, returning periodically, often very frequently, to the old country. And if they do leave home permanently, they quite often change their mind and go back in the end, as did two thirds of the Italians who emigrated to the US at the turn of the century.

Does migration show, then, that something is wrong, since it so often involves people doing what they do not really want to do? Not always or necessarily, because there appears, historically, to have been no way of achieving economic growth without creating imbalances and inequalities between countries and regions. Growth feeds on and uses such inequalities. If economic growth has been good, then labour migration, including that of skilled refugees, may in some sense have been "necessary".

The modern problem of migration arises from an obvious divergence between national and international politics. National politics, especially in the better organised and more prosperous states, aimed to iron out the very distinctions and differences that gave rise, at an earlier stage, to large internal migrations - the kind that are, for instance, causing stress in China now.

Every time a British newspaper prints one of those maps showing differentials in job losses or in rates of success in medical treatment across the country it subscribes to the principle that no region should suffer any disadvantage that it is in the power of central government to reduce. The same process eventually took place in the European Union as a whole, when countries which sent out large numbers of labour migrants as recently as 30 years ago, such as Spain, Portugal, Italy and Ireland, ceased to do so as their circumstances improved, an improvement aided by their membership of the union. Now that they are completely free to live anywhere in Europe, Europeans no longer move to any great extent: of the 344m citizens of the EU, only 5m work in a country which is not their country of birth.

Even the new Europeans who will be joining in the next few years, although somewhat poorer than those in the present member states, are not expected to move in large numbers. A recent Chatham House study estimates that the numbers who will move from Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovenia after accession will be relatively small, with a maximum of less than 3m over 15 years, who will mainly either commute or move only temporarily. And the numbers will decline after differentials even up.

The effects on the receiving countries are likely to be an overall net economic gain with the possibility of a slight increase in unemployment and slight downward pressure on wages. Why, in the face of projections like these, is Chancellor Schröder angering central European governments by insisting on his seven years? Is it simply that the popular perception of an impending migrant flood cannot be shifted, however often the facts are laid out? Is it that migrants are disproportionately concentrated in particular places? The policy of dispersal of asylum seekers, who can, unlike other kinds of migrants, be ordered around, suggests that governments think this is part of the problem. Or is it that citizens are hyper-sensitive because they sense a more general threat to their security?

Migration flows can be compared to the weather as something that can be partly understood, modestly forecast, and controlled or mitigated to some extent. They are comparable, too, in that new systems are always emerging and old ones dying out. Particular migrations, each with a specific history, come to an end, new ones begin. They are like the weather in that there is a persistent tendency to overestimate the size and duration of storms. They are like the weather in that most people do not have any great grasp of the global system that produces them. Finally they are not like the weather in that they are the outcome of human action - war making, nation building, enrichment and impoverishment - rather than of physical forces.

A strategic idea of migration is lacking in the general debate, which so often seems to be between those who think migration good and those who deem it bad. Or else the debate is confined to the issue of tolerance - the proper moral behaviour of those in the host society - and can end in a sterile competition over racism, and in a parting of the ways between intellectuals and ordinary people. This is surely a narrowing of the argument that strips migration of its history, economics, and sociology. It is not for want of academic trying, since migration and related subjects, like diasporas, have attracted gifted scholars.

Whether migration is part of the pathology or of the normality of modern capitalism is a high sort of question that has been answered in different ways. But it would be better if there was wider recognition that migration is part of something, that it cannot be understood or treated as an isolated phenomenon. Such a recognition would not alter the genuine and difficult practical problems constantly raised by the movement of people, but it would surely alter for the better the frame of mind in which they are approached.

 EU Enlargement: Prospects for East-West Migration by Christina Boswell, Royal Institute for International Affairs.

fields.headline: Net conference group cuts staff
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Internet conference group RMR yesterday issued a profit warning and said it is likely to almost halve its workforce, writes Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Internet conference group RMR yesterday issued a profit warning and said it is likely to almost halve its workforce.

The company - which took business conferences on to the internet and listed on the Alternative Investment Market last April, said its results for the year would not meet market expectations because of a decline in sales of virtual exhibition stands.

The fall in sales, particularly in November and December, has led to a 60% shortfall against the target level, the company said. RMR shares yesterday dropped 20.6% or 3.25p, to 12.5p.

Up to 75 employees, from a total of 160, are expected to lose their jobs as part of a consultation process which the company says it is now embarking on.

Telesales staff are most likely to lose their jobs - RMR said it was looking for a more personalised approach with a smaller number of skilled and experienced sales employees rather than a large number of telesales staff.

The move will reduce payroll costs by about £1.6m a year, and the firm believes restructuring will lead to lower losses.

"The board believes the restructuring steps will result in a lower level of loss through improved sales and the benefit of a lower cost base. As a result, it is believed that there is sufficient headroom to see the company through to profitability," the company said.

RMR, which concentrates on business to business sales, has worked on conferences covering e-commerce, energy management, virtual banking, communications, pharmaceuticals and investment.

The company, which has offices in Eynsham near Oxford and in Texas, has staged seven conferences since its April flotation, where it raised £12.5m through the placing of shares at 120p each.

The company's turnover rose from £420,000 in 1999 to £1.1mlast year. However, pre-tax loss jumped from £31,000 to £967,000.

Robert Jackson, the chief executive officer of RMR's British operations, declined to comment yesterday.

Telesales staff are most likely to lose their jobs - RMR said it was looking for a more personalised approach with a smaller number of skilled and experienced sales employees rather than a large number of telesales staff. The move will reduce payroll costs by about £1.6m a year, and the firm believes restructuring will lead to lower losses. "The board believes the restructuring steps will result in a lower level of loss through improved sales and the benefit of a lower cost base. As a result, it is believed that there is sufficient headroom to see the company through to profitability," the company said. RMR, which concentrates on business to business sales, has worked on conferences covering e-commerce, energy management, virtual banking, communications, pharmaceuticals and investment. The company, which has offices in Eynsham near Oxford and in Texas, has staged seven conferences since its April flotation, where it raised £12.5m through the placing of shares at 120p each. The company's turnover rose from £420,000 in 1999 to £1.1mlast year. However, pre-tax loss jumped from £31,000 to £967,000. Robert Jackson, the chief executive officer of RMR's British operations, declined to comment yesterday.

webTitle: Asylum issue takes election centre stage

fields.headline: Asylum issue takes election centre stage
fields.trailText: When even a respected liberal Tory such as Michael Heseltine sounded off this week about "bogus asylum seekers" few political commentators were left in any doubt that the Conservatives intend to use this explosive social issue as a key part of their strategy in this year's coming general election.
fields.body:
When even a respected liberal Tory such as Michael Heseltine sounded off this week about "bogus asylum seekers" few political commentators were left in any doubt that the Conservatives intend to use this explosive social issue as a key part of their strategy in this year's coming general election.

When, as home secretary, Kenneth Baker tried to play the asylum card during the 1992 election he soon found himself slapped down by John Major. Michael Howard was given the same treatment in the 1997 general election when he pleaded with Mr Major to be allowed to highlight his differences with Labour over immigration policy. "If Labour want to play dirty, let them play dirty. I am not going down that route," Mr Major was quoted as saying. He did not mention the issue once during the six week campaign.

But this time the gloves are coming off and the Tories recognise that, as Andrew Lansley, their general election campaign strategist, has pointed out, it is an issue that plays particularly well in the tabloids and has the power to hurt Labour.

So what of the main claims made by Mr Heseltine? In an article for the Daily Mail, which has been highlighting cases of "bogus asylum seekers" almost daily for two months now, the former deputy prime minister summed up his case on the basis of "three stark conclusions". The first was that "a very large number are cheats deliberately making bogus claims and false allegations to get into this country". In his second charge he claimed that British citizens were being pushed to the back of the queue for housing and hospital treatment by "dubious asylum seekers". His final conclusion was that the problem of "phoney asylum seekers was likely to grow as the impression spread that this country was a soft touch."

Mr Heseltine's real agenda lay deep in the detail of his Mail article where he made clear that the solution lies in persuading the rest of the European Union, and the United Nations if necessary, to tear up the 1951 Geneva Convention which guarantees the right of an individual fleeing persecution to seek asylum. Instead he wants to "redefine it for the new millennium", which is presumably code for ensuring that it is even harder for those fleeing modern day tyrannies, such as Iraq or Iran, to clamber over the walls of Fortress Europe.

But to analyse his first charge that most asylum seekers are cheats. It is true that in the last three months the Home Office has turned down 88% of the cases it has decided in the past three months. But that masks the fact that only 48% of those cases were refused after full consideration was given to whether their claim to be suffering from persecution was genuine or unfounded. A majority - 52% - were either given full refugee status or allowed to stay on exceptional grounds or were refused without proper consideration of their case.

As to the second claim that "dubious" asylum seekers were pushing British citizens to the back of the queue for housing and hospital treatment, this is the Home Office's response: "Council taxpayers' money is not being used to house asylum seekers and therefore local people are not being disadvantaged. We are using properties that do not have a waiting list." The refugee organisations say this means slum housing and bed and breakfast hostels. As for hospital waiting lists, the number of asylum seekers is not a major factor: the NHS treats millions of people each week.

Finally, is Britain a soft touch compared with the rest of Europe? Well, the system of dispersal and vouchers is the same as that which exists in Germany and within the EU there is a renewed drive to adopt a common definition of who qualifies for refugee status. Britain lies quite a way down the European league table of benefits for asylum seekers. Perhaps a more convincing explanation of why people come here rests on their historic links through Britain's colonial past and the fact that English is the global language.

 Alan Travis is the Guardian's home affairs editor.

fields.headline: Express websites await new owner
fields.standfirst: Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
8.15am: The websites of the Daily Express could soon have a new owner, writes Polly Sprenger.
Special reports: Express takeover
fields.body:
The websites of the Daily Express could soon have a new owner.

Chris Steele, a spokesman for Seymour Pierce, which bought the sites for £1 last month, said the company was in "very detailed negotiations" with prospective buyers.

Any deal could be a matter of "weeks, rather than days" as both sides conduct thorough research, said Mr Steele.

Allaboutparents.com, sportlive.co.uk, companyleader.com, and the Daily Express's official site had their publishing schedule interrupted when new Express owner Richard Desmond turned staff out in December.

Mr Steele said that despite the fact they have not published since then, the four sites have not lost their value or readership.

He added that Seymour Pierce had no plans to shut the sites, and rumours of plans to liquidate the sites were "a load of bollocks".

The rumour mill in the City seems to be squarely focused on Seymour Pierce these days, with reports last week that the financial advisors themselves might be the subjects of a takeover.

The sites, which were losing some £8m annually, were swiftly disengaged from the Express newspaper group after Mr Desmond acquired it from United News & Media.

Mr Desmond sold them to Seymour Pierce for the nominal fee of £1 and staff were immediately advised to consult the new owner with questions about salary and their future jobs.

Mr Steele said he did not think Seymour Pierce would jeopardise the value of the four sites by disenfranchising the staff, and would likely make efforts to keep the former Express site employees happy.

webTitle: Isabel Hilton on US policy in Colombia

fields.headline: Losing before you start
fields.standfirst: George Bush is undoubtedly about to embark on a stupid and disastrous war in Latin America
fields.trailText: George Bush is undoubtedly about to embark on a stupid and disastrous war in Latin America.
fields.body:
Just to get George W Bush into the right frame of mind to start running the world, I propose a short quiz - just one question, actually. It goes as follows: if a policy that has been adopted by your predecessor is highly expensive both in US taxpayers' money and in human life, is unpopular with your closest allies and achieves the opposite of its stated goals, should you (a): abandon it as one of the previous incumbent's characteristically hopeless ideas? (b): modify the policy so that at least it kills fewer people and does slightly less political damage? or (c): carry on in the teeth of all the evidence, loudly proclaiming imminent victory until the point is reached that either everybody is dead or Congress will no longer wear it and you (or your successor) has to pull out?

If I may be permitted a word of advice to the president-elect, it's best not to rush at the answer straight away.

You have not been president before, sir, so you might make the mistake of thinking that (a) is the obvious answer. With a moment's reflection, though, you will understand that this is not the American Way. Think of Vietnam, which of course you remember - and its side wars in Laos and Cambodia; think of El Salvador and Nicaragua - most of Latin America in the 1970s and 80s, in fact. If the details of those escape you, I am sure that George Bush Sr remembers them well.

The right answer, of course, is (c) - carry on, loudly proclaiming victory, regardless of the evidence.

It's important to avoid the blame for bad things that might result - massacres, refugee problems, famine, pestilence. They, of course, are the fault of the Marxist guerrillas, drug barons, Russians or persons unknown. The press, on the whole, is ready to be convinced and television has largely lost interest in "abroad" if it doesn't have good beaches. Don't let any Americans get killed and you should be fine.

If it all goes completely pear-shaped, try to look statesmanlike and get someone to shred the documents. The truth won't come out for a couple of decades and then a commission will be set up to investigate. It will conclude that the right answer all along was (a), but by then nobody will remember which of those small countries it was that you trashed, and you will be long out of office, so what do you care?

I only bring this up because among the documents in the president-elect's pending tray there should be one or two that relate to Plan Colombia. They ought to get his attention, if only because he might wonder why the US is dispensing military aid to Colombia to the tune of $2m a day. Perhaps he will be told that this is the result of an agreement between the Colombian president, Andres Pastrana, and the Clinton administration, in which the US responded to poor, war-torn Colombia's request for assistance in its fight against drug trafficking and in support of a peace process.

That is certainly a version of the events of the last two years, but it's a misleading one. Andres Pastrana did ask for aid to fund coca eradication and a peace process. What he got instead, though, was a huge amount of aid, 70% of which is military, to fund a war.

After a year of preparation, that war is about to begin in earnest. Against whom is it to be waged? Not against the coca cartels in Colombia or the consumers in Manhattan but against the peasants who plant the coca and against the guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc) who protect them. This will solve neither the civil war nor the drug problem.

Just for the record, what were the objectives of Plan Colombia? They were to support the peace process, to reduce drug trafficking and to assist in Colombia's reconstruction. Already the peace process is on the edge of collapse, coca cultivation and trafficking has expanded and, as for reconstruction, the number of internal refugees has soared. Colombian human rights workers estimate that 300,000 people have been driven from their homes.

Nobody disputes that human rights violations have increased dramatically in the past 12 months - so much so that Colombia will certainly lose its certification and George W Bush will find himself obliged to sign a waiver if he wishes to continue to disburse the military aid. All this comes as a surprise only to those who did not read or understand the warnings about the consequences of Plan Colombia that were produced by a series of NGOs and human rights organisations from the beginning.

I would like to add a few predictions of my own: the Farc guerrillas will not be defeated, the coca plantations will relocate across the borders of Brazil, Peru and Bolivia and Colombia's neighbours will find themselves drawn into the conflict. (Ecuador is already the site of a new $62m US airforce base.)

A key part of Plan Colombia is the chemical warfare to be waged on the coca plantations in the south. The intention is, State Department officials admit, to remove the women and children and blitz the place. Leaving aside the ecological damage this Armageddon will cause, it might be worth pointing out that in the 25 years since the US began to use chemicals to eradicate coca, Colombia's area under cultivation has gone from 25,000 to 140,000 hectares.

If US drugs policy were a company, it would have gone bankrupt years ago. But it marches to its own drum, whose peculiar rhythm can be detected in the sayings of General Barry R McCaffrey, the White House drug tsar. A year ago, McCaffrey was being briefed by a series of experts from Colombian NGOs and human rights movements in Bogota on precisely why Plan Colombia was a very bad idea. The general did not disagree. He explained, though, why the plan would go ahead.

"When I was a young soldier," he told the astonished gathering, "I was taught that it was better to entertain a doubt than to make a mistake. But as the years go by I realise that's wrong. It's far better to make a mistake than to entertain a doubt." That's the spirit, general.

webTitle: US facing a slump: For and against

fields.headline: Is the US facing a slump?
fields.standfirst: Arguments for and against
fields.trailText: Arguments for and against.
fields.body:
1. For a recession
Consumer confidence has fallen sharply as heavily indebted Americans fear for their jobs and savings as companies cut back and the stock market plummets. According to figures released last month, the confidence index fell to 128 in December from a high of 144 in May. The downturn in confidence has put a sharp squeeze on spending and therefore the economy.

Against
Confidence levels are still far higher than they were during the 1990 recession, when the same index sunk to a low of 55.

2. For a recession
Several US retailers revealed their worst Christmas sales in years yesterday. Sears, Roebuck, the biggest department store in the US, sacked 2,400 workers and announced 89 store closures after December sales fell 1.1 %. Retailers from Wal-Mart, the world's largest discount retailer, to Tiffanys, the upmarket jewellery store, all suffered from a sharp downturn in consumer spending in the run-up to Christmas.

Against
The poor weather on America's high-spending east coast over the last few weeks prompted consumers to stay at home after a record spending spree earlier in the year.

3. For a recession
Sales and orders at large auto manufacturers such as General Motors, Ford and Chrysler plummeted last month. GM, which announced the closure of its Luton plant last month, revealed yesterday that sales had fallen by 18% in the month, making the year as a whole negative compared with 1999. The sector is expected to continue to suffer weaker sales this year, possibly leading to more job losses. At the same time inventory levels have remained high, a classic recessionary signal.

Against
The heavy manufacturing sector is no longer as important to the US economy as it once was, in spite of the number of people it employs.

4. For a recession
Some of the world's biggest companies warned of a sharp slowdown in personal computer sales in the last quarter. Intel, Microsoft, Dell, Compaq and Gateway disappointed investors by admitting consumer and corporate sales were far lower than they had been.

Against
These companies were enjoying a cyclical boom as companies and consumers upgraded their technology.

5. For a recession
Purchasing orders fell to their lowest level since March 1991 in December. Figures released on Tuesday indicated that US gross domestic product will grow at just 1% this year if things remain as they are, its lowest level for almost a decade.

Against
Home sales and construction figures are still at record levels across America, a sign that consumers are still buying and improving homes.

6. For a recession
Jobless claims rose by 16,000 last week to 370,000, well above the expected figure. Payroll numbers are also likely to be down today.

Against
The overall unemployment level is still close to an all-time low of just 3.9% of the workforce.

7. For a recession
US share prices fell sharply last year. The Nasdaq composite of high-tech companies fell 40% last year, prompting fears of a credit crunch as banks stop lending and the capital markets follow suit. The collapse of the corporate bond market over the past six months suggest that this has already started with the terms for such lending much higher than they were before last April's crash. The inability to raise money stops small companies from financing further expansion.

Against
The stock market was at unsustainably high levels and the downturn is a necessary dose of reality. Economists such as Robert Shiller at Yale University believe that shares were overdue for a correction.

webTitle: Bush may rush in tax cuts to head off US recession

fields.headline: Bush may rush in tax cuts to head off US recession
fields.standfirst: Bush tax cut plan to halt recession
fields.trailText: George W Bush stepped up his campaign for big tax cuts yesterday after corporate America shrugged off the impact of Wednesday's surprise lowering of US interest rates and demanded tougher action to prevent the world's biggest economy sliding towards recession.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson in Austin, Texas, and Mark Atkinson
fields.body:
George W Bush stepped up his campaign for big tax cuts yesterday after corporate America shrugged off the impact of Wednesday's surprise lowering of US interest rates and demanded tougher action to prevent the world's biggest economy sliding towards recession.

As financial markets took stock after their euphoric rise in the immediate aftermath of the Federal Reserve's decision to cut the cost of borrowing by half a percentage point, the president-elect responded to mounting pressure from company chief executives by floating plans to fast-track promised tax cuts worth $1,300bn (£900bn).

With General Motors announcing last night that it is temporarily laying off 20,000 workers because of slack demand, the Fed is already facing calls for a further rate cut at the end of the month when it holds its next scheduled meeting and there are growing expectations that the Bank of England may soon follow suit.

However, a reduction in the cost of UK borrowing at next week's meeting of the monetary policy committee looked less likely after figures yesterday suggested consumer demand remained robust.

Mr Bush's 10-year tax cutting programme was scheduled to begin in 2002 but Larry Lindsey, the new head of the White House's economic team, said the legislation for tax cuts might have to be speeded up "as a way of stimulating the economy".

Mr Bush was in his home state yesterday holding behind-closed-door discussions with the bosses of some of America's largest companies, including General Electric, General Motors, Dell, Intel, and Cisco Systems. Speaking in Austin, Texas, Mr Lindsey said the "insurance policy" of tax cuts was needed "particularly for moderate-income people".

The Republican tax plans have been criticised by Democrats for favouring the wealthy but Mr Lindsey's mention of lower income groups was seen as a way of building cross-party support in Congress.

Jack Welch, head of General Electric, called the interest rate cut just "one step". He said: "What we are clearly seeing is a slowdown in the fourth quarter in consumer spending that runs the risk of spreading across the industrial sector."

The case for action to boost demand in the UK was undermined by figures showing healthy growth in high street spending in December, accelerating activity in the services sector as a whole, and rising demand for mortgages.

City economists said the data suggested the Bank of England would not be panicked into an immediate cut in the cost of borrowing, which has remained at 6% since February.

However, most expect interest rates to begin falling within three months to guard against a sharp slowdown in growth.

"Taken together, this morning's numbers suggest that the case for lower interest rates is rather less urgent in the UK than in the US," said Jonathan Loynes, chief UK economist at Capital Economics.

Short sterling - an indicator of future interest rate trends - is pricing in the likelihood of just over a quarter point cut by March, with a similar cut by June.

David Walton, of Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank, said the weakness of UK inflation gave the Bank of England ample scope to make bigger rate cuts if needed.

fields.bodyText: George W Bush stepped up his campaign for big tax cuts yesterday after corporate America shrugged off the impact of Wednesday's surprise lowering of US interest rates and demanded tougher action to prevent the world's biggest economy sliding towards recession. As financial markets took stock after their euphoric rise in the immediate aftermath of the Federal Reserve's decision to cut the cost of borrowing by half a percentage point, the president-elect responded to mounting pressure from company chief executives by floating plans to fast-track promised tax cuts worth $1,300bn (£900bn). With General Motors announcing last night that it is temporarily laying off 20,000 workers because of slack demand, the Fed is already facing calls for a further rate cut at the end of the month when it holds its next scheduled meeting and there are growing expectations that the Bank of England may soon follow suit. However, a reduction in the cost of UK borrowing at next week's meeting of the monetary policy committee looked less likely after figures yesterday suggested consumer demand remained robust. Mr Bush's 10-year tax cutting programme was scheduled to begin in 2002 but Larry Lindsey, the new head of the White House's economic team, said the legislation for tax cuts might have to be speeded up "as a way of stimulating the economy". Mr Bush was in his home state yesterday holding behind-closed-door discussions with the bosses of some of America's largest companies, including General Electric, General Motors, Dell, Intel, and Cisco Systems. Speaking in Austin, Texas, Mr Lindsey said the "insurance policy" of tax cuts was needed "particularly for moderate-income people". The Republican tax plans have been criticised by Democrats for favouring the wealthy but Mr Lindsey's mention of lower income groups was seen as a way of building cross-party support in Congress. Jack Welch, head of General Electric, called the interest rate cut just "one step". He said: "What we are clearly seeing is a slowdown in the fourth quarter in consumer spending that runs the risk of spreading across the industrial sector." The case for action to boost demand in the UK was undermined by figures showing healthy growth in high street spending in December, accelerating activity in the services sector as a whole, and rising demand for mortgages. webTitle: Leader: Market players are easily scared

fields.headline: The Gadarene tendency
fields.standfirst: Those who play markets are easy to scare
fields.trailText: Those who play markets are easy to scare.
fields.body:
Wall Street started having second thoughts yesterday about the rejuvenating properties of Alan Greenspan's 0.5% reduction in interest rates, and not without reason. It was not intended to bolster the stock markets but to prevent the US economy from slithering from a controlled slowdown to an actual recession (defined as two successive quarters of negative growth).

There is now a real danger that the US could talk itself into an unnecessarily steep recession. Almost half of US households now own shares, and when they see cover stories such as the one in the current issue of Time magazine headlined: "Here Comes The Slump" they might immediately reach for a phone to unload their shares, even though the text of the story in fact concluded that the US economy had a chance of a "graceful landing". Fund managers in the US and in the rest of the world, who control the big money, may sell simply to get their retaliation in first because they fear others will anyway.

Stock markets are no longer a descant happening in the background; they are directly hooked into the real economy. US consumers have run their savings into the ground because of the security that stock market wealth afforded them. Collapsing stock prices will force people to cut their spending in the shops and induce international investors to pull the plug on the huge sums they have invested on Wall Street, money which has financed the US's record trade deficit.

It is easy to chart a disaster scenario in which the twin weaknesses of the US economy - the financial sector's deficit and the trade deficit - spark a collapse of confidence in which a recession, or even a slump, becomes self-fulfilling. Mr Greenspan's sudden change of heart has not helped. A couple of weeks ago he did not feel a 0.25% cut in interest rates was justified. Now he announces an emergency cut of 0.5% several weeks ahead of the Fed's next meeting.

Europe cannot insulate itself from the effects of a US recession - but it can take pro-active policy decisions to exploit the opportunities. With high unemployment, a trade surplus and a surprisingly closed economy (over 90% of imports and exports are with other European countries) Europe should seize the opportunity to reflate its own economy. This should be done with a mixture of tax cuts for those countries in need of them, such as Germany, France and Italy, accompanied by lower, not higher, interest rates.

The inflationary danger of this action will be offset by the emerging strength of the euro as investment money pours out of the US into Europe in pursuit of a safer haven. A strengthening euro, especially if it is accompanied by an economic revival, will enhance the arguments of the pro-Europe lobby during the run-up to the planned referendum.

Indeed, such is the madness of markets, as they swing from one extreme to another, that the problem in a year or two could be the over-valuation of the euro. But that is to jump ahead. The problem now is to prevent a long-overdue correction in the record-breaking expansion of the US from turning into a rout. No one, not even Mr Greenspan, knows what the outcome will be.

webTitle: Premier League aims for global sponsor

fields.headline: Premier League aims for global sponsor
fields.trailText: Some of the world's biggest companies including Budweiser and Coca-Cola are vying to become the Premiership's next sponsors, writes Daniel Taylor.
fields.body:
The Premiership's growing appeal as a global product is likely to see Carling's ties with English football gazumped as some of the world's biggest companies vie to become the league's next sponsors.

Budweiser, Pepsi and Coca-Cola are all to enter the bidding rights for sponsorship of the Premiership when Carling's £30m three-year deal expires at the end of the season.

The league believes its worldwide growth - 10m people entered a recent competition in Thailand to win tickets for a Manchester United match - should be able to attract a three-year package worth in the region of £60m.

Although Carling, owned by Bass, remain in the bidding, it is becoming increasingly likely that the competition's overseas appeal will lead to a company of global standing succeeding the existing sponsor.

An agreement is also thought to be imminent for the sale of the Premiership's overseas television rights to a consortium comprising the French cable company Canal Plus, Rupert Murdoch's Fox television network and the UK sports company Transworld International.

If everything goes to plan, it would mean the Premiership receiving substantially more than the £100m that Canal Plus and TWI paid jointly to conclude the existing deal three years ago.

The figures reflect how the popularity of the Premiership has spread over the last few years. While much of Europe, particularly Scandinavia, has always followed English football, the influx of foreign players has made the Premiership a worldwide phenomenon.

The new sponsor can expect greater visibility than Carling because of changes to broadcasting arrangements next season. More games will be televised and, with a regular highlights programme on ITV due to replace BBC's Match of the Day, there will be greater potential for advertising.

fields.headline: Manchester rises from the ashes
fields.standfirst: United are top, City and the Halle are back from the brink, Badly Drawn Boy is top of the pops - even Lowry is fashionable again. But what about the soul of the city? Angelique Chrisafis on the rebirth of Manchester
fields.trailText: United are top, City and the Halle are back from the brink, Badly Drawn Boy is top of the pops - even Lowry is fashionable again. But what about the soul of the city? Angelique Chrisafis on the rebirth of Manchester
fields.body:
It is four years since the IRA ripped Manchester's guts out with a 3,300lb bomb. Since then, the city has had the most ambitious urban facelift in Britain since 1945, at a cost of £700m. The bomb took no lives. What it left was a crater where some of the ugliest buildings in Britain once stood - the inspiration for three generations of working-class pop bands who wrote lyrics to escape from the rain. There was one stock answer to journalists who asked these bands about their home town: "It's a shithole."

Since the bomb, the Manchester of "bag of shite", baggy jeans, flowerpot men hats and the Madchester music scene has become "loft apartment world". Flats sell for £1m. Harvey Nichols is being built on the IRA bomb site. The Hacienda nightclub urinals, which caught the chemical-smelling piss of Manchester's best musicians of the 90s, have been auctioned off for peanuts. The club has been bulldozed to make way for loft apartments.

Manchester has a tradition of producing a youth culture scene every 10 years which will be copied by the rest of Britain and then exported to US trailer parks. Ten years ago it was Madchester's summer of love with the Happy Mondays and the Stone Roses; before that was the Manchester post-punk scene of New Order and Joy Division, followed by the Smiths. All these were missed by the music press until they hit the big time. Record executives predict that the next youth culture cycle is about to start, and will probably come from Manchester. The question is what effect a city of wooden-floored studio flats will have on the creativity of the a scene which till now has been inspired by bad-lad working-class misbehaviour.

Michael Winterbottom, director of Welcome to Sarajevo, starts photography next week on 24 Hour Party People, the story of the Madchester record business in the 1990s. Steve Coogan is to play Tony Wilson, the head of Factory Records and co-founder of the Hacienda nightclub. This week, the Lowry Centre in Salford opens its "I, Mancunian" exhibition, subtitled "I only went with your mother 'cos she's dirty". It's a collection of embroidered installations inspired by the Hacienda, interspersed with the working class paintings of LS Lowry.

Ten years ago 250 people lived in the city centre, a maze of redbrick and broken windows. This year 10,000 people are ready to move in. There are now so many luxury loft apartments in Manchester, there is no warehouse space left. Developers are building brand-new lofts to look like imitation converted Victorian cotton mills.

Shopping development upon shopping development has been built and, in a city of half a million residents, each week sees the opening of around seven restaurants and bars (including a new Conran). Among the city's new attractions is the £150m Printworks - Europe's first "urban entertainment centre" - with 35 themed bars, 14 food joints, a health complex, the second largest Imax screen.

But Manchester is a city of independents, marked by three generations of youth culture, still regularly scoured for talent by record bosses such as Dave Ambrose, who, when asked why Manchester produces so much musical creativity, responds: "Because Manchester kids have the best record collections in the country."

People are talking of a Manchester "renaissance". Manchester United on top, City on the up, the Hallé orchestra, the Lowry arts centre, the M60 orbital, the Commonwealth games in 2002, the velodrome producing Olympic golds, the Mercury music prize for Bolton-born Badly Drawn Boy. But Luke Bainbridge, editor of City Life, Manchester's listings magazine, says Manchester is fragment ing. On the surface, the city is dumbing down. Robert Topping, the manager of Waterstone's on Deansgate, was dismissed in July for stocking too many good books and not enough mass-market titles. Nick Johnson of Independents, a group of 600 anarchic, independent Manchester businesspeople, who are challenging the big corporations, says: "Sterilised entertainment is sucking the soul out of Manchester. The city is becoming manufactured, mass-produced; it's almost a city without a soul."

In the past year, the history of the Madchester glory days has become a publishing trend, filling the entrances to Manchester bookshops with paperbacks. Shaun Ryder and Bez wrote their stories. Dave Haslam, a DJ at the Hacienda, wrote Manchester, England: The Story of the Pop Cult City. He called the book "a celebration and an obituary". People asked if Manchester was dead. Oasis, in the words of Factory founder Anthony Wilson, "have done bugger all for Manchester, because they're Irish and the Irish leave. This is the problem Liverpool had. Everyone left."

At the Castlefield end of Manchester, in Atlas bar, one of Manchester's first independent bars to open in 1996, Wilson is stirring his expresso plotting the third-wave Manchester comeback. Through the window there are loft development billboards. "Manchester is poised," Wilson says. "Something is coming. It feels very exciting. Let's see what happens with all these buildings, all these lofts. There is going to be a real explosion in 2003 and 2004 when the centre of Manchester is really lived in like no other city."

Wilson explains his 13-year cycle theory of youth culture. He worked it out in his kitchen in 1989. He thought: 1963, the Beatles; 1976, punk. Then he went into to the office of Factory Records, saying: "It's got to be 1989, this year. So what is it?" The label had already signed the Happy Mondays; they were sitting on the latest thing and didn't realise. The NME didn't get there until it had already exploded. So by rights, 2002 is the next movement. It is probably already happening now very quietly.

Malcolm McLaren has argued that the next cultural wave will not be music, but computers. Wilson disputes this and says youth will always be music-led. But others think the Manchester scene will be art-based.

Justin O'Connor, director of the Manchester Institute for Popular Culture at the Metropolitan University, says the next Manchester movement will be less working class, less overtly populist. "It won't be anti-working class, because Manchester will never be anti-working class, but it will be more arts-dominated, whereas Madchester rejected that. No one wants to buy into the working-class image of the dope-smoking, rave-dancing Manc any more. It will be more inventive next time round. Less of the flowerpot men hats."

Art Review magazine has been sniffing around the north to make Manchester art next month's cover story. The city that produced Chris Ofili, the first black Turner Prize winner two years ago, is now exporting a lot of painters and installation artists. Manchester artist Nick Crowe is showing at the San Francisco museum of Modern Art. David Mackintosh, Jim Medway and Graham Parker are exhibiting at A22 gallery in London - the capital's gallery owners are coming up to scour for talent. Helen Benden and Jo Landsley are exhibiting in Paris. The number of small gallery spaces is growing. Martin Vincent, an installation artist and gallery owner whose bronze plaque installation saying "Life is good in Manchester" hangs in the town hall, says the extension of City Art Gallery, due to reopen next year after a £25m refurbishment programme, has had policy-makers clamouring for advice from small artists. "They realise they need to rethink the scene. We're ready for a Modern Art gallery. We need a Guggenheim."

On screen, Manchester's arthouse cinema, the Cornerhouse, is recently showcased the latest independent film-makers inspired by Manchester music. Carol Morley's the Alcohol Years opened the show. The younger sister of Stockport-born NME journalist and writer Paul Morley, Carol spent her teenage years in a blur of alcoholism and promiscuity in post-punk, pre-ecstasy mid-80s Manchester, involving everyone from New Order to Pete Shelley. In February 1998, she put an ad in City Life, saying: "Carol Morley film project. Please contact me if you knew me between 1982 - 1997." The result is a scrapbook of their memories, praised for its shots of Manchester after dark. Also showing is Unloveable, Peter Naylor and Carl Hunter's short about Shed, a self-styled Smiths tour guide, who shows American Morrisey-pilgrims around Salford Lads Club and the Southern Cemetery, then nicks their wallets. "You're so lucky to live here," says one tourist. "I pinch myself daily," says Shed.

More importantly, Manchester is building up a base of new media and internet start-ups that could in the next two years overtake Bristol as Britain's second e-city. "The IT scene is vibrant but underestimated, because Manchester keeps its ideas under wraps in case they're stolen," says Peter Stewart, who heads the multimillion-pound, four-people firm Root 101. The company went live last week with a trial version of Wilson's new web music venture to sell songs for 33p and give artists a higher cut than traditional sales. Stuart predicts Manchester as the world centre of secure, unhackable servers. Web startups are an example of a new pattern of cultural industry in Manchester. Some 42% of people work in companies of under 10, while 32% are self-employed.

Meanwhile, back at Atlas bar, Wilson stops talking when he spots a man in an anorak out in the street gazing towards the Castlefield canals. "Property developer. He's looking at our patch," says record boss Yvette Livesey, Wilson's partner. "You can always spot them, walking around town with a golfing umbrella." There seems to be a war over the patch. What does Livesey have in mind? Lofts? "No, a unique innovation, a post office. All these developments and no one's thought of it."

Outside, back down Deansgate, there are men in anoraks, moving in threes, with golfing brollies, looking at buildings to house the Manchester third wave - when it comes.

webTitle: Deaths in police custody fall as Met recruits nurses for station

fields.headline: Deaths in police custody fall as Met recruits nurses for station
fields.trailText: Deaths in police custody have fallen sharply, according to a review by the police complaints authority.
fields.body:
Deaths in police custody have fallen sharply, according to a review by the police complaints authority.

There were 23 in the nine months to December, compared with 47 in the 12 months to April 2000 and 65 in 1998/99.

The figures were released to coincide with the launch of two initiatives by the Metropolitan police which could reduce the number of deaths even further.

As part of a pilot scheme, the Met is recruiting a nursing manager and six staff to work in the custody suite at Charing Cross police station, one of the busiest in the capital, where they will examine prisoners.

If the scheme proves a success, the Met will consider putting nurses in more than 60 other stations.

The force has also produced a hard-hitting training video which highlights some of the medical emergencies that can arise in arrests, such as when prisoners swallow drugs or struggle when restrained.

Assistant Commissioner Michael Todd said: "There are real risks, real dangers."

Three people have died in custody in London since last April, compared with 13 in the 12 months to April 2000.

"We have seen a significant decrease in the number of deaths in custody in London but we are not complacent," said Mr Todd. "One death in custody is too many."

All police forces have been under pressure to reduce deaths in custody. Many have revised training methods and introduced cctv cameras into cells.

There were 64 suicides in 1996. In a new year message to prison governors, Martin Narey, the prison service director general, said that suicide prevention had to be given the "highest priority".

The Howard League for Penal Reform said the figures masked a rise in the number of women killing themselves in prisons - eight died last year, compared with three the year before.

webTitle: Donohoe recruited by Navy for £4m ad campaign

fields.headline: Donohoe recruited by Navy for £4m ad campaign
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Foxy actress Amanda Donohoe has been drafted in by the Royal Navy to front its new advertising campaign, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Foxy British actress Amanda Donohoe has been drafted in by the Royal Navy to front its new advertising campaign this month.

Donohoe, who is set to replace Jerry Hall as the seductive Mrs Robinson in The Graduate stage show, will star in a £4m ad drive to hit TV and cinema screens from January 15.

She has been chosen by the Navy's ad agency, Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R, to brighten the image of the force and help hit its target of 5,000 new recruits by the end of the year.

Donohoe, famous for her feisty performance in 80s TV show LA Law, is cast as a hard-nosed City slicker who talks about stepping on people to get to the top. She then voices over the rest of the commercial, which contrasts this cynicism with the heroic teamwork required in the Navy.

The choice of 38-year-old Donohue sends out a particular message to potential recruits.

She is renowned for her independent spirit and her unabashed nature - many male viewers drool over her following her naked appearance alongside Oliver Reed's in the 1987 movie Castaway and in the 1988 film Lair of the White Worm.

The campaign has been created by to drive recruitment to the Navy at a time when it urgently needs 5,000 new recruits.

It forms part of a new media strategy developed by sister company The Media Edge which focuses on TV and the internet for the first time - a contrast from its traditional newspaper-led recruitment ads.

"Our strapline used to be "Join the Navy and see the world" but these days young people travel so broadly that we need to change the emphasis," said Stuart Sullivan, strategist at The Media Edge.

"We wanted to move away from the defence role of the Navy and focus on its fulfilling humanitarian activities."

fields.headline: Broadcasters' protests meet cool response
fields.standfirst:
Jan 4: Minister stands accused
Broadcasters' letter to Chris Smith
Jan 3: Rivals challenge BBC
Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
8.15am: Broadcasters' protests to Chris Smith about the BBC's new digital TV stations have been greeted with a cool response, reports Jason Deans.
Jan 4: Minister stands accused
Broadcasters' letter to Chris Smith
Jan 3: Rivals challenge BBC
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
Commercial broadcasters' protests to Chris Smith about the BBC's plans for new digital TV stations have been greeted with a cool response.

The culture secretary is unlikely to accede to their demands for a summit meeting, say officials.

Mr Smith will not formally respond to the request, which came in a strongly worded letter sent just before Christmas, until he returns from holiday on Monday.

But a spokesman for the Department of Culture, Media & Sport said that a meeting could not be ruled out, although he admitted it would be unlikely.

"I doubt much will be offered beyond an invitation to take part in the consultation process," he said.

The DCMS is expected to ask for comments on the BBC's proposed new digital TV channels later this month, after the corporation has officially submitted its plans for new offerings including BBC3, BBC4 and two children's services.

In a strongly worded letter, seven commercial broadcasters including BSkyB, Telewest and MTV requested a meeting with Mr Smith to discuss their concerns about the BBC's plans.

The letter unleashed the broadcasters' fury, accusing Mr Smith of attempting to "rubber stamp" the BBC's plans without due consultation.

webTitle: Pilat lets its baby leave home

fields.headline: Pilat lets its baby leave home
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Pilat Technologies International, the Israeli human resources and information technology services company, is planning to demerge its media software arm, Pilat Media.
fields.body:
Pilat Technologies International, the Israeli human resources and information technology services company, is planning to demerge its media software arm, Pilat Media.

Pilat saw its shares, which have underperformed the support services sector by about 65% in the past year, jump 25% or 8.5p to 42.5p following the announcement.

"We are convinced that the demerger of Pilat Media will substantially enhance overall value for our shareholders," said Avi Engel, chief executive of the company that was set up nearly 20 years ago in Tel Aviv and whose psychometric tests were used by the Israeli army.

Mr Engel, who said he is likely to concentrate on the media business which develops software to support digital TV broadcasters, added: "We think that what we managed to do was to give birth to a child that now needs to leave home and be on his own."

Pilat said it expected the process, as well as some fund raising, to be completed later this year. The demerged business will be listed on the London stock exchange and the Tel Aviv stock market.

Pilat Media was formed in 1997 when it developed an integrated broadcast management system for BSkyB. It has new contracts with Channel 5, CineNova, a new European Disney Sony partnership, and Digital Latin America of Florida, USA. The company estimates the first year value of these contracts at about £1.5m.
