fields.headline: Doubts over News Corp deal
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch's $5.35bn deal to acquire 10 additional US television stations could run into trouble because of concerns that he is breaching rules restricting foreign ownership of media assets.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's $5.35bn deal to acquire 10 additional US television stations could run into trouble because of concerns that he is breaching rules restricting foreign ownership of media assets.

Regulators have questioned whether the agreement for Mr Murdoch's News Corporation to buy the stations from Chris-Craft Industries violates a 1995 ruling designed to limit the Australian-listed company using its Fox Television subsidiary to buy US assets.

The federal communications commission, which studies media mergers, has asked for further information from News Corp about the structure of the agreement after halting its review of the deal last month.

News Corp played down the suggestion that the inquiry was anything out of the ordinary. A spokesman said: "The structure of the Chris-Craft acqusition is entirely consistent with the way we have structured station deals in the past. This is a routine inquiry by the FCC and we are not concerned about it at all."

Australian-born Murdoch became a US citizen in 1985, but News Corp, the parent company for his holdings, is still based in Australia. US law limits foreign ownership to 25% of an American television or radio station. Past deals have avoided violating the rule by structuring acquisitions as if Mr Murdoch, as the controller of the voting shares, was the sole buyer.

Under the terms of the Chris-Craft deal, Fox, which already owns 23 stations in the US, would control the FCC licence for the stations being acquired. According to a report in the Washington Post yesterday, however the FCC is concerned about the way a newly created company subsidiary, NewCo, would control all other management functions of the new stations.

Most analysts believed that News Corp would be questioned about its ownership of the New York Post, which does violate cross-media ownership rules. The company has argued that nobody else wants to buy the loss-making daily.

The way was cleared for Mr Murdoch to buy Chris-Craft after Viacom, the media conglomerate run by Sumner Redstone, withdrew from talks to buy the stations.

Viacom, the world's biggest media company after Time Warner, owns MTV, VH1, United Paramount and Paramount Studios and recently acquired the CBS network.

Chris-Craft, a former boat-building business, is owned by Herbert J Siegel, 72. The company owns 80% of BHC Communications, which in turn owns about 59% of United Television, which owns most of the stations Mr Murdoch is buying.

webTitle: High petrol price sparks renewed protests

fields.headline: High petrol price sparks renewed protests
fields.standfirst: Special report: the fuel crisis
fields.trailText: Fuel protests were taking place today amid accusations retailers were not passing recent cuts in the price of crude oil on to the consumer with enough speed.
fields.body:
Fuel protests were taking place today amid accusations retailers were not passing recent cuts in the price of crude oil on to the consumer with enough speed.

A group of up to 30 fuel tax protesters picketed the Manchester Fuels Terminal in Trafford Park, Greater Manchester, earlier today. About a dozen protesters assembled at the UK Shell oil terminal at Jarrow, south Tyneside.

At both locations, police said supplies were running as normal, although in Manchester protesters had asked some tanker drivers to turn back from making their deliveries.

Oil prices have plummeted from $34 (£24) a barrel, at the height of the September fuel crisis, to less than $24 (£17) now.

Organisers of last year's protests have expressed anger at oil firms' failure to reduce pump prices quickly enough in the face of a falling crude oil price. They said they had warned that demonstrations could start within days if the government failed to act.

In Jarrow, protesters were talking to drivers but were not blockading the terminal near the A19 Tyne tunnel.

Andrew Spence, who led the fuel convoy protest from Tyneside to London, was leading the protest which started shortly after 6am. "We are not here to stop wagons going in or out. We are here as a presence to remind the government, the press, and the fuel companies that we are still here and that we are still watching you," he said.

He added that this was a short-term protest and there was no need to panic buy: "We are talking to the tanker drivers this morning but we don't expect to be stopping any fuel from going through the gates."

But in Manchester the protesters, who picketed the site for three hours up to 8am, persuaded a number of tanker drivers to turn back at the gates of the TotalFinaElf terminal before police arrived and cordoned off the area.

Paul Ashley, another of the leaders of September's fuel blockade, said: "It is intended to carry out short, sharp spontaneous guerrilla-style protests at fuel depots across the country."

He added that a steady stream of protests would occur in the run-up to the general election.

Meanwhile, the Opec secretary general, Rilwanu Lukman, indicated that the organisation was likely to cut production in order to stabilise crude oil prices - a move which would keep prices high.

"We are looking for a price of around $25 a barrel, and this price has been accepted by consuming countries as well as other producers as a reasonable level," Dr Lukman said.

"If we are going to stick to that as a reasonable price for everybody, both consumers and producers, then of course the price has gone far too low over such a short period of time and may go even further down if no action is taken now." The Treasury said the chancellor, Gordon Brown, was monitoring the behaviour of the oil companies. But a spokesman stressed that Mr Brown would not be rushed into short-term decisions on a windfall tax on their profits.

fields.headline: Toyota takes output gamble
fields.standfirst:
Japanese carmaker's investment at main UK plant rekindles single currency debate

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Japanese carmaker's investment at main UK plant rekindles single currency debate.
fields.body:
Toyota, the Japanese car-maker, yesterday took a risky bet on the UK entering the euro in the near future by confirming plans to raise output at its Burnaston plant in Derbyshire by 30%.

The company is betting that the pound will, at the very least, enjoy a more competitive rate against the euro in the short term by increasing production at Burnaston from 170,000 units a year to 220,000 and taking on 300 more staff by 2002.

Its main UK plant is the second most productive in Europe, with an annual output of 78 cars per employee, but its British operations lost £50m in 1999 and are still in the red because 80% of its output goes to mainland Europe.

Toyota's plans stirred up the arguments over the merits of UK entry to the European single currency, with pro-euro union leaders arguing that they spelled a hedged bet on joining and Business for Sterling, the main anti-euro campaign, insisting that they simply testified to Britain's continuing attractiveness for inward investment.

Bryan Jackson, a senior Toyota UK director, said the "survival plan" entailed switching production of three-door Corolla from Japan to Derbyshire where the five-door version has been built since 1998. The company, which em ploys 3,000 in the UK, will take on an extra 250 staff at Burnaston and 50 at its engine plant on Deeside, north Wales.

The aim is to help counteract the "extreme market conditions" affecting the entire UK car industry where US giants such as Ford and General Motors (Vauxhall) are drastically scaling back production via plant closures, and other Japanese groups have or are planning to switch output overseas because of currency uncertainties. Dr Jackson said that Toyota hoped to improve cost efficiencies by spreading its fixed overhead costs but there was no guarantee that the plans would help overcome the company's financial difficulties. "It's very difficult to be profitable with the pound at its current rate against the euro," he said.

John Monks, TUC general secretary, pointing to greater convergence between the UK and continental economies, said: "Toyota is clearly banking on the fact that, while these changes are taking place in Derby, there will be a change in the exchange rate relationship with Europe and that Britain will either be at a more competitive exchange rate or, more desirably, be in the euro area."

Sir Ken Jackson, the AEEU leader, said: "Toyota is taking a clear decision to deal with exchange rate risk in a more positive way. We are pleased they are, unlike others, increasing rather than cutting capacity and this is an example others should follow."

 Peugeot, the French group, aims to sell 3m cars this year after announcing record sales of 2.82m in 2000, fuelled by demand for its 206 small car, which is built in Coventry, and the Citroen Xsara Picasso and for diesel-powered cars.

webTitle: Falling dollar could help British voters learn to love the euro

fields.headline: Falling dollar could help British voters learn to love the euro
fields.standfirst:
Change in fortunes hits sceptics' case

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Change in fortunes hits sceptics' case.
fields.body:
Pro-European campaigners showed a mixture of relief and quiet delight yesterday at the prospect that a falling US dollar and rising euro would finally lift the curse from their campaign to make British voters love the single currency.

The prospect of Europe growing more rapidly than the US has seen the euro steadily rising in value - the single currency touched 0.95 cents midweek against its 0.83 cent low in October.

The question now is whether a rising euro and a falling pound will materially affect sentiment in the UK towards the single currency. Over the past two years political doubts about the project have been reinforced by the euro's steady decline on the foreign exchanges. Now there is the distinct possibility that some of the edge will be taken off the Euro-sceptic argument by an improvement in the single currency's fortunes.

"This definitely benefits the pro-Europeans," said Kitty Ussher, chief economist at Britain in Europe. "This is positive news for us," confirmed a spokesman for the GMB union, which has campaigned hard against the high pound's damaging impact on manufacturing jobs and exports.

There is a downside. Although half of Britain's trade is done with Europe - compared to just 16% with the US - the American economy is too important for anyone to be indifferent, not least on the investment side.

That does not mean that Tony Blair will seek to rush the promised, long-delayed referendum as soon as he has won the likely May general election if the pound and dollar continue to weaken. Fresh talk of a snap referendum in September or October was brushed aside yesterday by pro-EU ministers. "There is no such working assumption at all," said the Foreign Office.

Besides, Gordon Brown would not allow it. Wary of the perceived autocracy of the Brussels hierarchy and determined not to jeopardise his domestic reforms, the chancellor would not announce that his famous "five economic tests" had been met, let alone give his blessing to a referendum, unless he could be certain it will be won.

That too is still a long way off, however bullish some pro-Europeans are starting to sound. The euro has rallied briefly more than once since 1999, and so have the pro-euro polls. It did not last.

So opponents of British membership of the eurozone were undeterred even as they too admitted that a stronger single currency makes it easier for Mr Blair to relaunch the Britain in Europe campaign - and with it the virtues of joining the 12-nation club - however long it actually takes to get there.

Business for Sterling, the most effective of the anti-euro lobbies, was already sketching out a scenario yesterday whereby the chancellor will kick the issue safely into touch during the election by announcing - quite soon - that his five tests cannot possibly be met before early 2002. The tests involve the euro's effect on investment, financial services, flexibility, and the long-term compatibility of the business cycles and jobs. Critics say the test are too subjective to have real value, except to give Mr Brown maximum freedom of manoeuvre. But relief for exporters would make the euro a cheerier product to sell.

For both sides the manoeuvres ahead are daunting and messrs Blair, Brown, Cook and Mandelson all know that one false move leading to a No vote could hamstring their second term.

Experts on both sides admit that the pound/euro exchange rate is, if not trivial than at least short term compared with more fundamental issues at stake: whether the European central bank can macro-manage one currency for 12 still-diverse economies, and whether the political controls are adequate or effective.

Although half of Britain's trade is done with Europe - compared to just 16% with the US - the American economy is too important for anyone to be indifferent, not least on the investment side. That does not mean that Tony Blair will seek to rush the promised, long-delayed referendum as soon as he has won the likely May general election if the pound and dollar continue to weaken. Fresh talk of a snap referendum in September or October was brushed aside yesterday by pro-EU ministers. "There is no such working assumption at all," said the Foreign Office. Besides, Gordon Brown would not allow it. Wary of the perceived autocracy of the Brussels hierarchy and determined not to jeopardise his domestic reforms, the chancellor would not announce that his famous "five economic tests" had been met, let alone give his blessing to a referendum, unless he could be certain it will be won. That too is still a long way off, however bullish some pro-Europeans are starting to sound. The euro has rallied briefly more than once since 1999, and so have the pro-euro polls. It did not last. So opponents of British membership of the eurozone were undeterred even as they too admitted that a stronger single currency makes it easier for Mr Blair to relaunch the Britain in Europe campaign - and with it the virtues of joining the 12-nation club - however long it actually takes to get there. Business for Sterling, the most effective of the anti-euro lobbies, was already sketching out a scenario yesterday whereby the chancellor will kick the issue safely into touch during the election by announcing - quite soon - that his five tests cannot possibly be met before early 2002. The tests involve the euro's effect on investment, financial services, flexibility, and the long-term compatibility of the business cycles and jobs. Critics say the test are too subjective to have real value, except to give Mr Brown maximum freedom of manoeuvre. But relief for exporters would make the euro a cheerier product to sell. For both sides the manoeuvres ahead are daunting and messrs Blair, Brown, Cook and Mandelson all know that one false move leading to a No vote could hamstring their second term. Experts on both sides admit that the pound/euro exchange rate is, if not trivial than at least short term compared with more fundamental issues at stake: whether the European central bank can macro-manage one currency for 12 still-diverse economies, and whether the political controls are adequate or effective.

fields.headline: Unpicking knots in ties that bind
fields.standfirst:
Uncharted course between two big powers lies ahead

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Traditionally, as the governor of the Bank of England Sir Eddie George noted recently, if the US sneezes, the rest of the world catches a cold. But the world has changed since the last time the US economy hit the brakes. A new economic power has emerged - the 12-nation European single currency zone.
fields.body:
Traditionally, as the governor of the Bank of England Sir Eddie George noted recently, if the US sneezes, the rest of the world catches a cold. But the world has changed since the last time the US economy hit the brakes. A new economic power has emerged - the 12-nation European single currency zone.

For Europe, the question is whether the new economic bloc is more than the sum of the parts. The question for the Treasury and the Bank of England, however, is how the new economic order will affect the UK. Is it now ideally situated with strong links not only to an economic powerhouse which is slowing but also to one that is picking up speed? Or is it caught between a rock and a hard place?

Certainly, there is plenty of optimism in euroland. The German research institute IWD published a remarkably upbeat assessment of the outlook for 12-nation single currency zone. "In contrast to the US, the euro zone is not at the end but at the beginning of an economic upturn," said the institute. With plenty of slack still in the labour market and none of the imbalances of the US economy, it is widely tipped to be the strongest of the three big global economies over the next couple of years.

Unemployment in the eurozone is now 8.8% compared with America's 4.1%. However, Europe is changing. France's adoption of the 35-hour week has given many firms greater flexibility over working hours and has not harmed job growth. Indeed, unemployment has fallen from 10.7% to 8.9% in France in the past year.

Euroland is also likely to benefit from the relative lack of "irrational exuberance" in financial markets. Having not risen as high as in the US, share prices in Europe have a shorter distance to fall. Moreover, only 5% of private household wealth in euroland is invested in the stock market compared to 25% in the US so the effect of falling share prices on consumer spending is much more limited.

The impact of the falling oil price, down 30% since its peak last September, is another plus for Europe which is much more dependent on oil imports than the US. Lower energy costs will help to boost the profitability of euroland firms, enabling them to compete in global markets.

Britain, which does about half of its trade with euroland, will benefit from stronger continental European growth and the strengthening euro, which makes UK exports cheaper.

But the extra business may not be enough to offset the impact of a steep downturn in the US. While the UK is no more exposed than anywhere else in Europe to a drop in demand for imports from America, it is intimately connected to the world's biggest economy by a much stronger web of investment ties. As home of the biggest financial centre in Europe, the UK is also uniquely vulnerable to a bear market in financial assets.

Attracted by the culture and attractive business environment, US companies like to come here and vice versa. Britain accounts for $183bn (£120bn), or a fifth, of the total stock of foreign direct investment in the US from which its annual income is currently $12bn (£7.9bn) a year, according to research by HSBC. That represents about a third of the UK's total income from foreign direct investment.

As well as being the biggest outward investor in the world, the UK is also the most popular place in Europe for inward investment, especially from the US. Hi-tech companies, in particular, now struggling from the bursting of the dot.com bubble, have been flocking to the UK in recent years to expand their European operations. If the US economy slides into recession, Britain will suffer both from falling income from abroad and less investment in the domestic economy.

For David Walton, senior economist at Goldman Sachs in London, however, the bigger threat to the UK is of a meltdown in financial markets. "Britain has enjoyed the fruits of the big boom in US financial assets including very substantial growth in business and financial services. If we go through a period of falling asset prices leading to weaker investment bank and asset management activity, it could have a very big negative effect on an important sector of the UK economy," he said.

Mr Walton expected the MPC's benchmark lending rate to be cut by half a percentage point by the middle of the year, with the possibility of an even greater fall. Roger Bootle, of Capital Economics, has pencilled in a one point cut by the end of the year.

Expectations are rising that the European Central Bank will cut euro-zone interest rates, too, despite yesterday's decision not to move. Most analysts believe the sheer size of the US economy will mean any slowdown there is bound to have an impact but falling oil prices and the recovery in the euro will give the bank scope to lower rates. Planned tax cuts in the some larger eurozone countries should help underpin economic growth.

The single currency will play a role, too in that it will prevent the sort of exchange rate fluctuations between the member countries which have previously exerted a disruptive influence during global turbulence. That is turn will strengthen the case of those in the UK who believe Britain should sign up for the single currency.

fields.headline: Analysis
fields.standfirst:
Special report: refugees in Britain
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: When even a respected liberal Tory such as Michael Heseltine sounded off this week about "bogus asylum seekers" few political commentators were left in any doubt that the Conservatives intend to use this explosive social issue as a key part of their strategy in this year's coming general election.
fields.body:
When even a respected liberal Tory such as Michael Heseltine sounded off this week about "bogus asylum seekers" few political commentators were left in any doubt that the Conservatives intend to use this explosive social issue as a key part of their strategy in this year's coming general election.

When, as home secretary, Kenneth Baker tried to play the asylum card during the 1992 election he soon found himself slapped down by John Major. Michael Howard was given the same treatment in the 1997 general election when he pleaded with Mr Major to be allowed to highlight his differences with Labour over immigration policy. "If Labour want to play dirty, let them play dirty. I am not going down that route," Mr Major was quoted as saying. He did not mention the issue once during the six week campaign.

But this time the gloves are coming off and the Tories recognise that, as Andrew Lansley, their general election campaign strategist, has pointed out, it is an issue that plays particularly well in the tabloids and has the power to hurt Labour.

So what of the main claims made by Mr Heseltine? In an article for the Daily Mail, which has been highlighting cases of "bogus asylum seekers" almost daily for two months now, the former deputy prime minister summed up his case on the basis of "three stark conclusions". The first was that "a very large number are cheats deliberately making bogus claims and false allegations to get into this country". In his second charge he claimed that British citizens were being pushed to the back of the queue for housing and hospital treatment by "dubious asylum seekers". His final conclusion was that the problem of "phoney asylum seekers was likely to grow as the impression spread that this country was a soft touch."

Mr Heseltine's real agenda lay deep in the detail of his Mail article where he made clear that the solution lies in persuading the rest of the European Union, and the United Nations if necessary, to tear up the 1951 Geneva Convention which guarantees the right of an individual fleeing persecution to seek asylum. Instead he wants to "redefine it for the new millennium", which is presumably code for ensuring that it is even harder for those fleeing modern day tyrannies, such as Iraq or Iran, to clamber over the walls of Fortress Europe.

But to analyse his first charge that most asylum seekers are cheats. It is true that in the last three months the Home Office has turned down 88% of the cases it has decided in the past three months. But that masks the fact that only 48% of those cases were refused after full consideration was given to whether their claim to be suffering from persecution was genuine or unfounded. A majority - 52% - were either given full refugee status or allowed to stay on exceptional grounds or were refused without proper consideration of their case.

As to the second claim that "dubious" asylum seekers were pushing British citizens to the back of the queue for housing and hospital treatment, this is the Home Office's response: "Council taxpayers' money is not being used to house asylum seekers and therefore local people are not being disadvantaged. We are using properties that do not have a waiting list." The refugee organisations say this means slum housing and bed and breakfast hostels. As for hospital waiting lists, the number of asylum seekers is not a major factor: the NHS treats millions of people each week.

Finally, is Britain a soft touch compared with the rest of Europe? Well, the system of dispersal and vouchers is the same as that which exists in Germany and within the EU there is a renewed drive to adopt a common definition of who qualifies for refugee status. Britain lies quite a way down the European league table of benefits for asylum seekers. Perhaps a more convincing explanation of why people come here rests on their historic links through Britain's colonial past and the fact that English is the global language.

 Alan Travis is the Guardian's home affairs editor.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Northumberland
fields.trailText: Northumberland
fields.body:
The countryside here is thick with snow as I write, and in the fields, groups of sheep, heavy with wool and pregnancy, gather around feeding troughs of hay. Hard work to trudge in the fields, so I took the dogs to the shore, where a heavy swell was coming into Craster's little harbour. Both Muckle and Little Carr are lost in a welter of steely-blue, white-capped waves. A peroxide blonde is being mobbed by seagulls. I went to her rescue and she turned out to be a poor under-nourished marsh harrier.

Fulmars drifted in the wind currents, turning inscrutable disc faces towards the canine invaders. These gulls of the petrel clan have gliding down to such a fine art that they swoop and bank, giving only an infrequent wing-beat. Today, the beach and foreshore below Dunstanburgh Castle no longer belong to the human element; the sea and its tenants are to the fore. Later, in the car park, the wildlife warden came over to speak to me. He told me that this month he'll be working with a volunteer coast conservation group on Holy Island, building up the sand dunes with old Christmas trees.

This is organised by Berwick-on-Tweed council, and those areas done three years ago are now being planted with marran grass. The trees are layered into the dunes and the wind blows the sand in. "It's been a successful recycling exercise," he told me. "Later, we'll be looping in willows on the Coquet river, clearing paths and brashing in the woods." While we talked, he kept interrupting me with sightings of birds and I was so busy with binoculars that my dachshund, hungry after her lovely walk, scoffed my last sandwich.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Mask Of Zorro | The Big Chill | Wag The Dog | Bob Roberts
fields.body:
The Mask Of Zorro

(Martin Campbell, 1998)

11.40am, 5.40pm, Sky Premier

Old California's own Robin Hood legend is rather overlong, but it's done with great verve. Antonio Banderas, an extremely dashing hero in the Tyrone Power mould, is

the rugged but buffoonish Murrieta, protégé of the now elderly Zorro (played by Anthony Hopkins) who trains him to fight, ride and smile wickedly, and to take on corrupt Governor Montero (Stuart Wilson). Amid all the zestful action, Catherine Zeta Jones plays Zorro's long-lost daughter, a pretty sharp blade herself.

The Big Chill

(Lawrence Kasdan, 1983)

8pm, FilmFour

Glossy, engrossing ensemble piece about old college chums reuniting on the death of one of their number. The gang's all here: Kevin Kline a millionaire Nike-man; Jeff Goldblum a high-profile columnist; doctor Glenn Close; lawyer Mary Kay Place, and drug-dealing William Hurt.

Wag The Dog

(Barry Levinson, 1998)

12.10am, Sky Premier

When the president's election campaign is about to collapse due to some hanky-panky with a girl scout in the Oval Office, a shady consultant (Robert De Niro) is called in, who in turn calls on Dustin Hoffman's Hollywood producer to fake a war against Albania, distracting attention till polling day. A bit too shambolic for top-notch satire, but done with vaudevillian glee and, co-scripted by David Mamet, it's very funny.

Bob Roberts

(Tim Robbins, 1992)

3.50am, FilmFour

Robbins directs and stars as a rightwing folk singer turned would-be senator who's adept at hitting the right notes with an undiscriminating electorate. The satirical message is wittily drummed in: politics is all about entertaining the masses and those who don't, like Gore Vidal's more decent Democratic candidate, are out of time. An eminently watchable cast keeps up the tempo.

fields.headline: Tories signal Ulster retreat
fields.standfirst:
Ancram discourages party candidates in province

Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Ancram discourages party candidates in province.
fields.body:
William Hague is abandoning the Tory cause in Northern Ireland, raising doubts about his crusade to depict the Conservatives as the true defenders of the Union.

On the 200th anniversary of Ireland's incorporation into the United Kingdom, the Tory chairman, Michael Ancram, has issued a blunt message that the party will look foolish if it continues to contest seats in the province at the election.

Northern Ireland Tories, who suffered a drubbing in 1997, are determined to field nine candidates at the next election, one fewer than they fielded last time. But Mr Ancram has told activists they should not field candidates who are likely to lose their deposits.

This means that central office will offer its support to candidates in only three out of Northern Ireland's 18 parliamentary constituencies.

The decision by central office - still home to the Conservative and Unionist Party - to wind down its efforts in Northern Ireland has dismayed local members who were welcomed into the party 10 years ago after a long campaign.

In the 1990s the Tory leadership hailed its Northern Ireland members as a sign of the party's commitment to the Union, in contrast to the Labour party which refuses to organise in the province.

One senior Northern Ireland Tory underlined the anger among local party members. "Michael Ancram was very clear that we should only stand in seats where he thinks we can hold on to our deposit," he said. "We did not agree with that because we have intelligence from the ground and believe we can do well."

Jonathan Lund, the party's vice-president in Northern Ireland, steered clear of criticising central office, while making it clear that the Tory torch should still burn in the province. "We offer a refreshing alternative to the traditional orange and green politics," he said. "This is an important time for Conservatism in Northern Ireland because of the sectarian and bigoted political system in the province."

The decision by central office contrasts with its determined efforts to celebrate this year's 200th anniversary of the United Kingdom. Northern Ireland Tories, who welcomed their leadership's criticism of the government for failing to celebrate the 200th anniversary, believed that the rhetoric from central office falls dis mally short of its actions on the ground.

One senior Tory said last night that central office had a high regard for the stalwarts of the party in the province who were seen as genuinely anti-sectarian. But it was also keen not to take votes away from David Trimble's Ulster Unionist party, which could be beaten by Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionists by a couple of hundred votes in some constituencies.

The senior Tory said: "There is a strong feeling that whatever we do we should strengthen the position of David Trimble, who is a very brave politician. We do not want to make his life more difficult and help the DUP."

The source also confirmed that central office was hoping eventually to heal the rift with the Ulster Unionist party, whose MPs used to take the Conservative whip at Westminster.

The party leadership has painful memories of the way in which Mr Trimble attempted to hold John Major to ransom as the Tory majority dwindled in the run-up to the last election.

webTitle: Teenage ecstasy habit spiralling, says US drug tsar

fields.headline: Teenage ecstasy habit spiralling, says US drug tsar
fields.trailText: President Clinton's often controversial drugs policy adviser, General Barry McCaffrey, warned yesterday of an "explosive increase" in young people's use of the recreational drug ecstasy.
fields.body:
President Clinton's often controversial drugs policy adviser, General Barry McCaffrey, warned yesterday of an "explosive increase" in young people's use of the recreational drug ecstasy, after years in which public campaigning against drugs has focused mainly on marijuana, crack cocaine and heroin.

In his final annual report before he leaves his job, Mr McCaffrey admitted that America's drugs education and prevention efforts had failed to stem the rising use of ecstasy by the teenagers at whom much of the campaigning was aimed.

Ecstasy use, long familiar in Britain and elsewhere in Europe, was relatively uncommon in the US until the late 1990s, when it rapidly became the preferred drug of teenagers of all social classes, not least because of restrictions on teenage access to alcohol.

The use of ecstasy, known chemically as methylenedioxy-methamphetamine or MDMA, has been established in eastern US cities for several years but it has now spread rapidly across the whole of the country, Mr McCaffrey said.

"We are seeing an explosive increase in exposure to MDMA among our children.

"They think it's a hug drug, it's a dance-all-night, feel-good drug."

But in the otherwise upbeat assessment of his years in charge of the Clinton administration's national and international anti-drugs efforts, Mr McCaffrey claimed that he had helped to make "substantial progress in confronting illegal drug abuse and drug trafficking", reducing teenage drugs use overall by 21% in the past two years.

Official figures, though notoriously difficult to compile, suggest that overall illegal drugs use has declined by half in the past 20 years, alongside steep and steady falls in murder and other forms of crime associated with drugs use and dependency.

"Federal drug policy is succeeding because of the involvement of parents, teachers, coaches, religious leaders, business leaders, law enforcement personnel, and community coalitions who are working hard to protect our children. America's team effort is working," Mr McCaffrey said.

In his report, Mr McCaffrey also focused attention on steroid use, particularly by young people of both sexes who wanted "to get that slightly ripped look, to improve their chance of getting selected [for school sports teams]".

In the past, Mr McCaffrey has been criticised by liberal drugs counsellors and other observers for bringing his military vocabulary to the issue.

His use of terms like the "war on drugs" has helped to spawn a so-called "zero tolerance" culture in American schools, where even such innocuous things as cough lozenges have led to teenagers facing suspension from school.

Yesterday, however, Mr McCaffrey was in a more peacetime mode.

"Although wars are expected to end, drug education - like all schooling - is a continuous process," he said.

"The moment we believe ourselves victorious and drop our guard, drug abuse will resurface in the next generation. To reduce the demand for drugs, prevention must be ongoing."

fields.headline: ONdigital pays £100,000 compensation
fields.trailText: ONdigital, the pay television business, has been forced to pay out almost £100,000 in compensation to former director John Egan.
fields.body:
ONdigital, the pay television business, has been forced to pay out almost £100,000 in compensation to former director John Egan.

At an industrial tribunal hearing in November, ONdigital attempted to justify witholding a bonus by proving the launch of the service had not been a complete success.

Mr Egan was yesterday told he had been awarded £37,500 for the lost launch bonus and £59,000 relating to an unpaid performance bonus the year before he left the company.

He will receive another, as yet undetermined, sum relating to his claim for unfair dismissal. "It's a very good result," Mr Egan said. "A fair reflection of what was due." A spokesman for ONdigital said it had no comment.

During the hearing, chief executive Stuart Prebble said ONdigital was "a commercial success and a public success, but it was not a success internally in terms of managing the situation.

"Any commercial enterprise will describe its launch as a success. It is not surprising that we did not share details of a range of issues with the public. It would be naive to think otherwise."

He cited problems in supplying set-top boxes and with the callcentre as areas where the launch had been troublesome.

Mr Egan had been paid half the £100,000 launch bonus at the time. The result of the tribunal in Croydon will encourage another former director, Ashley Faull, who is also taking legal action for non-payment of a bonus.

ONdigital has had a poor record maintaining good relations with former directors. It previously settled out of court a claim from erstwhile chief executive Stephen Grabiner. Mr Egan and Mr Faull are reunited at Sit-up.com, operator of the digital TV and online auction business Bid-up.TV.

fields.headline: No: 1794 Oliver Reed
fields.trailText: Appearance: Only in a video store near you, alas. Reed staggered off to the great hospitality room in the sky two years ago.
fields.body:
Appearance: Only in a video store near you, alas. Reed staggered off to the great hospitality room in the sky two years ago.

Status: Bon viveur of the old school.

Ah yes, he liked a jar or two, if I recall correctly? Indeed. Some say Reed's premature demise in a bar in Malta at the age of 61 was hastened by the fact he had just downed three bottles of rum and beaten five sailors in an arm-wrestling contest.

Notable achievements: Well, 106 pints in 24 hours was pretty impressive. Or there was the two-day binge in which Reed and 36 rugby players put away 60 gallons of beer, 32 bottles of Scotch, 17 bottles of gin and four crates of wine.

Anything else? Sorry, you're right. I forgot the bottle of Babycham.

No, I meant any other notable achievements. Well he did a bit of acting - most memorably, his naked wrestle with Alan Bates in Ken Russell's Women in Love.

That's more like it. Though whether Bates and Reed could remember much of it, having downed a bottle of vodka each . . .

Enough of the drinking tales! What is he doing in Pass notes? It's just that by the time of his death Reed's bacchanalian exploits had become rather more celebrated than his thespian ones. But no longer.

Explain? Reed's last performance, as Proximo in Gladiator, is set to earn him the recognition he never achieved in life. Hollywood insiders are predicting he'll win an Oscar as best supporting actor.

But didn't he die before the movie was finished? A mere detail. Scott spent £2m morphing the deceased's head onto the body of another - living - actor, and Ollie lived to down another flagon of vinum.

Reed in the words of others: "An immaculate professional" (Glenda Jackson); "He compelled your attention" (Michael York); "Oliver Reed is God" (Quentin Tarantino).

Reed in his own words : "You know, I saw an old movie of mine on television the other night and all I could think was 'Jesus! I never realised how bad I was.'"

Do say : "An Oscar? I'll drink to that!"

Don't say: "Shouldn't the bar get the award for supporting the actor?"

fields.headline: A leap in the dark
fields.standfirst:
Salmon farming has put a once rare delicacy on all our plates - but is it safe to eat? And how does it compare with the wild variety, asks James Meek

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Salmon farming has put a once rare delicacy on all our plates - but is it safe to eat? And how does it compare with the wild variety, asks James Meek.
fields.body:
This is a tale of two salmon. The first, the wild one, emerges in spring from a gravel-covered trench in the upper reaches of a Scottish river and begins to feed. It may take a year, it may take eight, but eventually she gets the strength to swim downstream to the sea. She roams the Atlantic as far as Greenland, feeds and grows and, if she survives disease and predators, including man, returns to the river, struggles upstream, digs a trench, lays her eggs, waits for a male salmon to fertilise them, and buries them with flicks of her tail. The whole cycle can take more than a decade.

The gaunt wild salmon's sleek new cousin lives out his life in a series of cages on a Scottish fish farm. Reared in fresh water, he is moved to the salt water of a sea loch when he is ready to migrate and spends the rest of his short life swimming in aimless caged circles in a kind of living soup made up of 2% fish and 98% water. Fed a steady diet rich in fish protein, with added axanthin to give his flesh a consumer-friendly pink colour, he is safe from fly fishermen and poachers; if he gets ill, the vet comes and prescribes medicine for the whole cage. In as little as two years, he reaches about three kilos in weight, and is killed for our table.

Up until the 1970s, salmon was a luxury. Even now, the way it is often served, tissue-thin smoked slices with dainty triangles of brown bread, as if it was rare as caviar, is a nod to its nob origins. The truth, of course, is that thanks to Scottish fish farming, it's about as rare as bacon. Britain produces 125,000 tonnes of farmed salmon a year, against a couple of hundred tons of the wild stuff. Just in time. With wild sea fish such as cod turning from staples to delicacies, farmed salmon - healthy, locally produced and cheap - is well placed to fill a niche in the national diet.

Which is why the latest revival of long-standing concerns about pollutants in farmed fish has caused such a stir. A scientist at the University of Surrey in Guildford, Miriam Jacobs, has come up with evidence that the kind of salmon on sale in Britain today contains levels of man-made toxins which could be dangerous, particularly for young children.

Pre-publicity for a BBC documentary featuring her findings this weekend exaggerated her results, triggering a furious reaction from Scottish salmon producers and the Food Standards Agency, which insists that salmon is safe. A recently disbanded government-appointed advisory committee on medical aspects of food policy, Coma, recommended that everyone eat a portion of oily fish, like salmon, once a week. Salmon contains substances called long chain omega-3 fatty acids, which are thought to help keep heart disease at bay.

Even setting aside the BBC's hype about the Jacobs research, however, her results do not make comfortable reading. As she admits, the number of fish she took samples from is too small to form the basis for scientific advice. But they are pointers to worry about.

Jacobs was studying the fish for the presence of toxins called PCBs and dioxins, notorious carcinogens released into the environment by decades of unsafe waste disposal. Although there has been a clampdown in this kind of pollution, they take a long time to degrade.

The concern is that the traditional dumping ground for PCBs and dioxins was the sea, and salmon are fed with fishmeal which may come from areas that are still heavily polluted, such as the North Sea and the Baltic.

One of the fish Jacobs analysed had 340 picograms of PCB per 100 gramme serving. The World Health Organisation's recommended maximum daily intake of PCBs is 1 to 4 picograms per kilogramme of bodyweight. For a 70-kilogramme adult, that would put the intake slightly over the daily limit with just that small serving; for a young child, the intake of PCBs would be many times too high.

Jacobs argues that more research is needed, and that the potentially dangerous fishmeal in the diet of farmed salmon should be replaced with vegetable matter - something organic salmon farmers are already doing. "There is the potential to make farmed salmon one of the least contaminated animal foods there is," she said.

The salmon farmers are not happy. Although the number of organic fish farmers is growing, there are worries that the fish produced doesn't taste quite as, well, fishy as the conventionally reared salmon. The industry's lobby group, Scottish Quality Salmon, claims that European research shows the level of PCBs and dioxins in salmon to be no more or less than that in a whole range of foodstuffs; the pollution is simply embedded in the environment, and only time will make it fade away.

"If you look hard enough, you'll find these things in most foods people eat," said John Webster, a technical adviser to the organisation and a wild salmon fisherman for 40 years. "My advice to people in the salmon farming industry is they need to be aware of this and they need to be sourcing their feed from areas that haven't suffered so much from dumping, like the South Atlantic."

Whether there is any extra safety to be had in opting for wild salmon is uncertain. In Jacobs' research, wild and farmed fish had similar levels of contamination, although the "wild" fish may have been farm escapees.

The two are, at least, still distinguishable, and not just by price (wild salmon is six times more expensive than farmed). "I can usually tell the difference from about 40 yards away," said Paschal Tiernan, managing director of London restaurant owners Fish! plc. "One has fought for a living all its life. It's a bit like seeing a town dweller up against a guy who's spent his life crofting in the Highlands."

Tiernan prefers the wild salmon - it has a "slightly richer flavour" - but the difference is nothing like as great as that between a French free range chicken and an English battery hen, he said. Although the Fish! restaurants use only organic salmon, he was unconcerned about the claims of contaminants. "I don't want to sound like John Selwyn Gummer," he said, "But I would give my kids any fish that came out of a supermarket, organic or not."

webTitle: Intifada divides the Israeli peace camp

fields.headline: Intifada divides the Israeli peace camp
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli peace campaigners predicted yesterday that the Palestinian uprising would put back the resolution of the Middle East conflict for another 10 or 20 years.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill in Jerusalem and  Khaled Dawoud  in Cairo
fields.body:
Israeli peace campaigners predicted yesterday that the Palestinian uprising would put back the resolution of the Middle East conflict for another 10 or 20 years.

The peace camp, which at one time was supported by at least half the Israeli population, is deeply divided and bewildered as a result of the violence of the past three months.

Many of the campaigners, who include prominent academics, writers and politicians, accuse the prime minister, Ehud Barak, once their great hope, of failing to make enough concessions to the Palestinians to secure peace.

But others, unnerved by the scale of the Palestinian violence, blame the Palestinians and insist that the offer on the table is the best their leader, Yasser Arafat, can expect.

The paralysis of the Israeli left comes at a time when the hardline right has become increasingly vocal, holding a series of demonstrations in Jerusalem yesterday to show support for the Jewish settlers on the West Bank and reject any compromise with the Palestinians.

Mr Arafat returned to Gaza yesterday after meeting Arab leaders in Cairo to pave the way for a summit with Mr Barak and the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, in the next few days.

He is expected to tell President Bill Clinton formally within the next 24 hours that he will conditionally accept this peace proposals.

Two issues have clouded the Israeli peace camp. One is that many reject outright the prospect of 3.7m Palestinian refugees obtaining the right to return to Israel, fearing they could swamp the Jewish population. The other is the fear that the uprising shows that the right may be correct in their assessment that Palestinians and Arabs will not stop until the Jews have been pushed back to the sea.

Gershon Baskin, co-chairman of the Israel-Palestine Centre for Research and Information, admitted yesterday that the peace camp was divided. He described the intifada as a "disaster for the left".

"Many on the left do not know what to say anymore," he said. "Some people say the Palestinians are not ready for peace. This is what the Palestinians say about the Israelis."

Unlike many on the left, Mr Baskin said he would still vote to give Mr Barak a second term on February 6, because the "alternative was terrible".

But he would do it without enthusiasm.

"Barak has taken away hope. Until now there was a sense that we were close to peace. People think the chance has gone for 10 or 20 years if [the Likud leader Ariel] Sharon comes in."

Janet Aviad, who founded Peace Now with Amos Oz, a leading Israeli novelist and intellectual, agreed with her co-founder that Mr Barak's package was a very good offer, but added: "At the moment our people are greatly distressed by the resort to violence by the Palestinians."

She questioned whether the Israeli peace camp was internally divided, but added: "For the first time in 20 years [it] does not agree with the Palestinian peace camp.

"That does not mean we have to shoot it out. We have to see their point of view on settlements and Jerusalem and they have to see our point of view on the right of return.

"The distress of the peace camp is that peace seemed to be close but is now so far away."

fields.headline: Upwardly mobile
fields.standfirst: Handset sales beat all predictions
fields.trailText: Handset sales beat all predictions.
fields.body:
The explosive growth of the mobile phone industry continued unabated in the final three months of last year with sales outstripping even the most optimistic of forecasts.

Figures from Vodafone yesterday showed the company adding a record-breaking 1.4m new customers in Britain over the period. Orange did even better, signing up 1.6m.

The strong performance from Orange suggests it may be poised to overtake BT Cellnet as Britain's second largest network.

One2One and BT Cellnet have yet to report figures but the indications are that the four combined will comfortably beat analysts' forecasts of up to 5.5m sales in the run-up to Christmas. Almost 40m handsets are now in circulation, representing around two-thirds of the population.

webTitle: Martin Woollacott on the refugee debate

fields.headline: Migrant storm in a teacup
fields.standfirst:
Whipping up exaggerated fears of foreign incomers seems to be a global political phenomenon

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Whipping up exaggerated fears of foreign incomers seems to be a global political phenomenon.
fields.body:
Another 50 dead this week, in a shipwreck off the Turkish coast, to add to the toll of lives lost trying to enter Europe illegally. Disasters becoming routine, while politicians talk more and more of keeping people out. In Germany, Chancellor Schröder, speaking recently near the border with the Czech Republic, calls for a seven-year ban on the movement of labour from Central European countries after they join the European Union. In Italy, Silvio Berlusconi could win the coming general election on the immigration issue.

In the United States, President Clinton has just failed to overcome opposition to legalising the residence of immigrants from a number of Central American countries. In Australia, the former prime minister Malcolm Fraser describes the asylum detention centre in remote Woomera as "a hellhole". In Britain, the attempt to disperse asylum seekers is in trouble, the criticisms merging into a general row over race and immigration. Fear of people remains a powerful political force everywhere.

How much migration would there be in a better world? There would be far fewer refugees, since there would be fewer wars, fewer tyrannical states and better preparations against natural disasters. There would be less "economic" migration, since the differentials in income and circumstance would be smaller. If there is anything that has been established pretty much beyond doubt in studies of migration it is that the vast majority of people prefer to stay at home. The sociologist Saskia Sassen, who has examined these matters with great insight, has shown that when they do leave home, there have to be very compelling reasons, special opportunities or established habits or some combination of these three. When they nevertheless do leave, they prefer to do so on a temporary basis, returning periodically, often very frequently, to the old country. And if they do leave home permanently, they quite often change their mind and go back in the end, as did two thirds of the Italians who emigrated to the US at the turn of the century.

Does migration show, then, that something is wrong, since it so often involves people doing what they do not really want to do? Not always or necessarily, because there appears, historically, to have been no way of achieving economic growth without creating imbalances and inequalities between countries and regions. Growth feeds on and uses such inequalities. If economic growth has been good, then labour migration, including that of skilled refugees, may in some sense have been "necessary".

The modern problem of migration arises from an obvious divergence between national and international politics. National politics, especially in the better organised and more prosperous states, aimed to iron out the very distinctions and differences that gave rise, at an earlier stage, to large internal migrations - the kind that are, for instance, causing stress in China now.

Every time a British newspaper prints one of those maps showing differentials in job losses or in rates of success in medical treatment across the country it subscribes to the principle that no region should suffer any disadvantage that it is in the power of central government to reduce. The same process eventually took place in the European Union as a whole, when countries which sent out large numbers of labour migrants as recently as 30 years ago, such as Spain, Portugal, Italy and Ireland, ceased to do so as their circumstances improved, an improvement aided by their membership of the union. Now that they are completely free to live anywhere in Europe, Europeans no longer move to any great extent: of the 344m citizens of the EU, only 5m work in a country which is not their country of birth.

Even the new Europeans who will be joining in the next few years, although somewhat poorer than those in the present member states, are not expected to move in large numbers. A recent Chatham House study estimates that the numbers who will move from Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovenia after accession will be relatively small, with a maximum of less than 3m over 15 years, who will mainly either commute or move only temporarily. And the numbers will decline after differentials even up.

The effects on the receiving countries are likely to be an overall net economic gain with the possibility of a slight increase in unemployment and slight downward pressure on wages. Why, in the face of projections like these, is Chancellor Schröder angering central European governments by insisting on his seven years? Is it simply that the popular perception of an impending migrant flood cannot be shifted, however often the facts are laid out? Is it that migrants are disproportionately concentrated in particular places? The policy of dispersal of asylum seekers, who can, unlike other kinds of migrants, be ordered around, suggests that governments think this is part of the problem. Or is it that citizens are hyper-sensitive because they sense a more general threat to their security?

Migration flows can be compared to the weather as something that can be partly understood, modestly forecast, and controlled or mitigated to some extent. They are comparable, too, in that new systems are always emerging and old ones dying out. Particular migrations, each with a specific history, come to an end, new ones begin. They are like the weather in that there is a persistent tendency to overestimate the size and duration of storms. They are like the weather in that most people do not have any great grasp of the global system that produces them. Finally they are not like the weather in that they are the outcome of human action - war making, nation building, enrichment and impoverishment - rather than of physical forces.

A strategic idea of migration is lacking in the general debate, which so often seems to be between those who think migration good and those who deem it bad. Or else the debate is confined to the issue of tolerance - the proper moral behaviour of those in the host society - and can end in a sterile competition over racism, and in a parting of the ways between intellectuals and ordinary people. This is surely a narrowing of the argument that strips migration of its history, economics, and sociology. It is not for want of academic trying, since migration and related subjects, like diasporas, have attracted gifted scholars.

Whether migration is part of the pathology or of the normality of modern capitalism is a high sort of question that has been answered in different ways. But it would be better if there was wider recognition that migration is part of something, that it cannot be understood or treated as an isolated phenomenon. Such a recognition would not alter the genuine and difficult practical problems constantly raised by the movement of people, but it would surely alter for the better the frame of mind in which they are approached.

 EU Enlargement: Prospects for East-West Migration by Christina Boswell, Royal Institute for International Affairs.

fields.headline: Belgium challenges Byers
fields.standfirst: Diplomatic row as minister questions reversal of Interbrew's purchase of Bass
fields.trailText: Diplomatic row as minister questions reversal of Interbrew's purchase of Bass.
fields.body:
A diplomatic row has broken out between Britain and Belgium over the decision by trade secretary Stephen Byers to reverse Interbrew's £2.3bn purchase of Bass's brewing operations. Belgian economics minister Charles Picque fired off a terse letter to Mr Byers yesterday querying whether the order was made purely on "competition" grounds.

Mr Picque expressed alarm at the damage caused to one of Belgium's biggest companies. Interbrew, best known for producing Stella Artois, has seen its shares dive 27% in two days.

The Belgian government has also written to the European competition commissioner, Mario Monti, asking him to consider intervening. Mr Picque urged Mr Monti to investigate whether the ruling takes into account "the logic of globalisation and the objectives of the single market".

Government-level intervention from one of Britain's close European allies marks a sharp escalation in the dispute surrounding Interbrew, which is threatening to seek a judicial review of Mr Byers' decision.

Mr Picque pointed out that Scottish & Newcastle was left unaffected by the competition commission's review of the case. This is despite the Edinburgh-based company's 26% share of the beer market, which puts it a close second to Interbrew.

A spokeswoman for the Belgian economics ministry said: "Mr Picque is asking questions, he is not judging the decision at this stage. He is not angry, he just regrets the situation. The purpose is to ask Mr Byers why he hasn't tried other solutions, such as asking Interbrew to sell some of Bass's beer brands."

Mr Byers was on a trade mission to India yesterday and is yet to issue a formal response. However, a spokeswoman for the Department of Trade and Industry said: "The decision was taken on competition grounds - the deal would have reduced competition in the market and led to higher prices. We did look at other remedies, but they would not have had the desired effect."

Analysts believe Interbrew will lose between £500m and £1bn if it is forced to sell Bass Brewers, which produces 49 beers including Carling, Tennent's, Worthington and Caffrey's. Opposition to the deal has been led by pub companies, who say Interbrew will be able to dictate prices and terms because of its huge portfolio.

Interbrew's advisers disagree and one said: "Pub companies have a choice over where they buy their products from. The only beer you could describe as a "must-stock" brand in Britain is Guinness."

A legal challenge to Mr Byers' decision is considered unlikely to succeed. One expert, Alistair Gorrie of law firm Coudert Brothers, suggested Interbrew's best hope could be to cite the Human Rights Act, adopted by Britain last year.

Mr Byers' order requires Interbrew to offload Bass Brewers to a buyer approved by the office of fair trading. However, EU officials pointed out yesterday that the EC also had the right to scrutinise any deal, as long as the companies involved have sales of more than €250m (£160m) in member states.

Possible buyers include Heineken, South African Breweries and US firm Anheuser Busch. Bass's brewing operations employ 7,000 people, with big sites in Burton-on-Trent, Birmingham and Glasgow.

Supporters of Interbrew include Commons Speaker, Michael Martin, who told the competition commission the deal could lead to more jobs in his Glasgow constituency.

webTitle: Lawrence row judge tells of death threats

fields.headline: Lawrence row judge tells of death threats
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macpherson report - one year on
fields.trailText: Sir William Macpherson, author of the damning report into the death of Stephen Lawrence, received death threats after accusing the Metropolitan police of "institutional racism", he revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Sir William Macpherson, author of the damning report into the death of Stephen Lawrence, received death threats after accusing the Metropolitan police of "institutional racism", he revealed yesterday.

In an interview in the Spectator, the former high court judge admitted: "I get awful letters from people who say they are going to come and murder me, and that Enoch Powell was right, and that I ought to have said they all ought to be sent back."

Last night he confirmed that he had received "quite a number" of anonymous threatening letters - believed to number at least 50 - after the report was published in February 1999.

"Early on I received a lot of letters from people that were just very unpleasant, threatening grievous bodily harm and things," he said. "The last arrived a few months ago. The police knew about it, but I didn't think they were genuine. In the end, I threw them away."

Sir William also made a surprising defence of the Tory leader, William Hague, who last month prompted accusations of racism after blaming the report for lowering police morale and causing a recruitment problem, with its conclusion "institutional racism" was rife among officers. The report had been seized upon as "a stick to beat the police", after its condemnation of the bungled investigation into the black teenager's murder, Mr Hague said.

"Hague's speech was pretty good stuff, really," Sir William told the Spectator. "Most of it was from the report and I don't think he was playing the race card."

The chairman of the Lawrence inquiry elaborated by saying that his criticism of Mr Hague at the time - when he suggested he had been discourteous in attacking him two years after accepting the report - was because the Tory leader had failed to distinguish sufficiently between the report and the distortion of it. But, on reading the speech, he realised Mr Hague had adopted many of his recommendations, including a change to the double jeopardy law and issues concerning private prosecutions and victim support.

Sir William also told the Spectator that he had hesitated before using the "institutional racism" charge, that the phrase was not his, and that he had expressly denied every Metropolitan police officer was racist. But he insisted that it was the only way he could sum up a systemic failure of policing in which unconsciously racist assumptions had played a part at several stages.

"It was a collective failure, little groups of people. Not just one person, not the rotten apple in the barrel, but each infecting the other," he said.

"I could have bottled out. I could have decided not to mention racism at all, and stuck to all the policing questions. But as this procession of coppers came in, our mouths sort of fell open, and we thought, we are bloody well going to have the courage to say it publicly."

Sir William's defence of the charge of "institutional racism" - and his revelation of the threats it prompted - came as the friend who was with Stephen when he died called on the home secretary, Jack Straw, to reverse his decision to reinstate a Metropolitan police officer sacked for racism.

Duwayne Brooks, 25, who witnessed the 18-year-old stabbed to death by a white gang in Eltham, south-east London, in April 1993, described Mr Straw's decision last month to reinstate Steve Hutt - sacked for calling a 14-year-old boy a "black bastard" - as a "concession to racism".

In a letter sent to Mr Straw yesterday, he added that the Macpherson report had sparked a backlash in the police, and the campaign which led to the reinstatement of Mr Hutt was part of this.

fields.headline: John Cooper
fields.trailText: John Cooper, who has died aged 77, was the junior half of the famous father-and-son partnership which revolutionised grand prix racing in the 1950s.
fields.body:
John Cooper, who has died aged 77, was the junior half of the famous father-and-son partnership which revolutionised grand prix racing in the 1950s. The small racing-car company he ran with his father Charles hit the headlines in 1958 when Stirling Moss won the Argentine Grand Prix at the wheel of Rob Walker's tiny 2.2-litre Cooper-Climax.

Thanks to its better handling, the rear-engined Cooper saw off the more powerful, front-engined Ferraris to score a seminal victory. Within three years, all formula one cars had their engines at the back. In 1959 and 1960, the Australian Jack Brabham dominated the world championship with a works Cooper-Climax.

Cooper senior was active before the war at Brooklands circuit and was employed by the racing ace of the late 1920s and early 30s, Kaye Don. Born in Surbiton, John was apprenticed with one of his father's companies and, shortly after the second world war broke out, went to work for a toolmaking company which specialised in work for the Admiralty.

In 1946, the Coopers built a 500cc motorcycle-engined hillclimb special that would lay the foundations for their racing car business. By 1948, they were in serious production, making 500cc formula three cars. In those heady post-war days, almost all drivers of note learnt their trade in those spindly little single-seater racers. There was not an English circuit where Cooper 500s did not do battle during the period. Mike Hawthorn, in 1958 Britain's first world champion driver, cut his international racing teeth on a formula two Cooper-Bristol in 1952.

The Coopers' way of motor racing was stark and primitive. Charles Cooper's Surbiton works were dark, dank and dingy, his staff underpaid and often grumbling. Yet he instilled tremendous loyalty and a peculiar brand of affection in a workforce which frequently reckoned it was getting the rough end of the deal. By contrast, the genial, pipe-smoking John Cooper strained against penny-pinching. He was imaginative, and saw the scope for business expansion, but was prone to letting his enthusiasm for new projects get slightly out of control.

Meanwhile, the rival Lotus boss, Colin Chapman, refined the rear-engined concept into a succession of winning cars during the early 1960s, while the Cooper team went into a gentle decline. In 1963, John Cooper was badly injured when his prototype twin-engined Mini-Cooper saloon - one of his pet projects - somersaulted to destruction on the Kingston bypass. Ken Tyrrell took over as Cooper team manager while he recuperated.

The following year Charles Cooper died, aged 71, and his son accepted a buyout from the Chipstead Garages group. Although now out of Cooper's immediate control, the team carrying the family name enjoyed a brief renaissance with the advent of the three-litre formula one regulations in 1966. John Surtees won the 1966 Mexican grand prix in a Cooper-Maserati and Pedro Rodriguez followed with victory in the 1967 South African grand prix.

In the summer of 1967, an unknown 19-year old joined the Cooper formula one team as a junior mechanic. He was Ron Dennis, today chief executive of the McLaren formula one team; Cooper continued the British motor racing tradition of proving that the sky is the limit for even the most modestly qualified recruit. The company also received royalties from the British Motor Corporation for each of the Mini-Cooper saloons sold during the 1960s, when they became one of the most familiar fashion items, a touchstone for their time, immortalised in the 1969 film The Italian Job, starring Michael Caine.

That same year, John Cooper retired to Ferring, on the Sussex coast, where he opened a garage business, which his family operates to this day. Last year, he was awarded the CBE. He leaves his wife, a son and a daughter; a second daughter predeceased him.

 John Cooper, motor racing engineer, born July 17 1923; died December 24 2000
fields.bodyText: John Cooper, who has died aged 77, was the junior half of the famous father-and-son partnership which revolutionised grand prix racing in the 1950s. The small racing-car company he ran with his father Charles hit the headlines in 1958 when Stirling Moss won the Argentine Grand Prix at the wheel of Rob Walker's tiny 2.2-litre Cooper-Climax. Thanks to its better handling, the rear-engined Cooper saw off the more powerful, front-engined Ferraris to score a seminal victory. Within three years, all formula one cars had their engines at the back. In 1959 and 1960, the Australian Jack Brabham dominated the world championship with a works Cooper-Climax. Cooper senior was active before the war at Brooklands circuit and was employed by the racing ace of the late 1920s and early 30s, Kaye Don. Born in Surbiton, John was apprenticed with one of his father's companies and, shortly after the second world war broke out, went to work for a toolmaking company which specialised in work for the Admiralty. In 1946, the Coopers built a 500cc motorcycle-engined hillclimb special that would lay the foundations for their racing car business. By 1948, they were in serious production, making 500cc formula three cars. In those heady post-war days, almost all drivers of note learnt their trade in those spindly little single-seater racers. There was not an English circuit where Cooper 500s did not do battle during the period. Mike Hawthorn, in 1958 Britain's first world champion driver, cut his international racing teeth on a formula two Cooper-Bristol in 1952. The Coopers' way of motor racing was stark and primitive. Charles Cooper's Surbiton works were dark, dank and dingy, his staff underpaid and often grumbling. Yet he instilled tremendous loyalty and a peculiar brand of affection in a workforce which frequently reckoned it was getting the rough end of the deal. By contrast, the genial, pipe-smoking John Cooper strained against penny-pinching. He was imaginative, and saw the scope for business expansion, but was prone to letting his enthusiasm for new projects get slightly out of control. Meanwhile, the rival Lotus boss, Colin Chapman, refined the rear-engined concept into a succession of winning cars during the early 1960s, while the Cooper team went into a gentle decline. webTitle: Atlantic rowers' fighting Spirit undaunted by loss of Team Phillips

fields.headline: Atlantic rowers' fighting Spirit undaunted by loss of Team Phillips
fields.trailText: It promises to be a gruelling test of mind and body that could lead to two transatlantic rowing records being smashed at the same time.
fields.body:
It promises to be a gruelling test of mind and body that could lead to two transatlantic rowing records being smashed at the same time.

On their odyssey from Canada to the Isles of Scilly, British rowers Mark Stubbs, Mark Phillips, Mark Woods and Steve King will face a number of hazards including towering waves, giant icebergs, freezing conditions, and perhaps the boat itself.

In the clearest indication to date that adventurers and seamen whose boats snap in half are bowed but never broken, Britain's latest attempt to challenge the transatlantic rowing record is being orchestrated by Pete Goss, the man who launched Team Phillips, the world's most advanced and costliest catamaran, last year and lost it last month.

The doomed Team Phillips, which Goss claimed at its launch would be the fastest in the world, was lost in a storm in the Atlantic as it made its way to the start of a round-the-world race. A few weeks after its launch the 45ft bow of the £4m catamaran snapped during sea trials.

Members of Goss's latest record-seeking expedition will set sail in Atlantic Spirit, which has been dubbed the world's most advanced rowing boat.

The transatlantic challenge, which takes place this summer, is titled the Goss Atlantic Row. The Atlantic Spirit has been built using the same technology and carbon fibre material as Team Phillips. All involved are hoping that is where any similarity will end.

"I don't think this is my last chance," said Goss yesterday at the launch of Atlantic Spirit on the first day of the London Boat Show. "Team Phillips was a success story in many ways. Unfortunately, we became caught in a freak storm and I was not prepared to risk the lives of my crew. That is why we decided to abandon the vessel.

"I was very sad when I lost Team Phillips. I am an adventurer and if you go into these challenges then you have to accept some of the consequences. I certainly do not think it was a failure and I have not been beaten."

Team Phillips was launched by the Queen last March and heralded as the world's most sophisticated ocean racer. Adrian Thompson, designer of the catamaran, also designed Atlantic Row and both vessels have been constructed at Goss's headquarters at Totnes, Devon.

Atlantic Spirit member Mark Phillips, 39, said: "There was a lot of concern from our families following what happened to Team Phillips. But we have to assure them that we will be safe.

"People have been coming up to us and saying that we must be mad going in a Pete Goss boat. But we should not lose sight of all the things that Adrian Thompson and Goss have achieved. It's all about the design of the boat and we are confident that we will be safe and stay afloat."

The crew of four aim to break two records; the Atlantic rowing record, held by 11 Frenchmen at 35 days, and the record across the Atlantic from west to east which stands at 55 days.

Goss, 39, is a former Royal Marine who was awarded France's highest honour for rescuing a French sailor in a single-handed round the world yacht race. He estimates that his expedition members will be able to complete the west to east crossing in 32 days.

According to the Goss camp's blurb, the Atlantic Spirit, like Team Phillips, has been designed to ensure that it "concentrates on maximising strength to weight ratios, and creating an aero-dynamic and frictionless vessel".

Goss is confident his boat will sail victoriously into his Devon headquarters 32 days after it sets sail from Canada.

The Atlantic Spirit's total weight of 220 kgs, half the weight of the four crew, is being cited as one of the main reasons for its possible success.

Goss said: "We have a fantastic team and a boat that has been built using advanced concepts. I would not say that we are going to fail this time and I am confident that we can do it. We might have had a setback with Team Phillips but we have brave hearts."

webTitle: Sinn Fein politician accuses RUC after damages award

fields.headline: Sinn Fein politician accuses RUC after damages award
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A leading Sinn Fein politician who yesterday received £9,000 damages for being assaulted by a policeman accused the RUC of shielding the officer concerned.
fields.body:
A leading Sinn Fein politician who yesterday received £9,000 damages for being assaulted by a policeman accused the RUC of shielding the officer concerned.

The RUC settled out of court after Gerry Kelly, a Stormont assembly member, claimed an officer had struck him over the head with a baton as nationalist residents demonstrated against an Orange Order march in west Belfast in June.

It was the second time in 12 months the force had to pay compensation to the former IRA bomber and Maze prison escaper. Last January he received £4,000 in relation to a similar incident at a loyalist parade in June 1996. On that occasion he was accused of assaulting two police officers but a magistrate dismissed the charge after a two-day hearing.

Belfast recorder's court made yesterday's award for "exemplary and aggravated damages for assault, battery and trespass to his [Kelly's] person".

Afterwards Mr Kelly, whose lawyers insisted on keeping a police video of the incident, claimed he was attacked be cause he was an elected representative, and said the police had put up a wall of silence to protect the officer who hit him.

"The award and video evidence have shown to be true that last year, while attempting to calm a crowd protesting against an Orange march, I turned my back and was assaulted by an RUC officer," he said. "The case highlights a number of serious issues, particularly the canteen culture of the RUC which has shielded the officer responsible.

"The RUC stated they were unable to identify the officer. This is despite the fact many of those in the crowd at the protest identified him and that he was removed from the front line by his superiors immediately after the attack."

A spokesman for the new Northern Ireland police ombudsman's office, which took over the case from the independent commission for police complaints last November, said it passed the matter to the director of public prosecutions in December. If an officer was found guilty of assault the ombudsman would press for internal disciplinary action.

The RUC declined to comment.
