fields.headline: William Rogers
fields.standfirst: As Richard Nixon's secretary of state, his years of friendship and loyalty went ill-rewarded by the disgraced president
fields.trailText: As Richard Nixon's secretary of state, his years of friendship and loyalty went ill-rewarded by the disgraced president.
fields.body:
William Rogers, who has died aged 87, was one of Richard Nixon's closest and most loyal friends, but was treated abominably by the US president, whose early political career he had saved from extinction.

As Nixon's secretary of state between 1969 and 1973, Rogers was repeatedly sidelined by the White House. The president conspired with his national security adviser, Henry Kissinger, to withhold from Rogers all knowledge of the administration's three main foreign policy initiatives - the US reconciliation with China, its secret approaches to Hanoi to end the Vietnam war, and its strategic arms agreement with the Soviet Union.

Even worse, having agreed that Rogers should determine US middle eastern policy in the period following the six-day war of 1967, Nixon and Kissinger deliberately undermined the so-called Rogers plan for a return of the Israeli-occupied west bank territories, with consequences that we are living with to this day. The Clinton administration's recent negotiations have been largely based on what Rogers proposed three decades ago.

Later, Nixon and Kissinger offered belated apologies for their behaviour, but Rogers kept his own counsel. He wrote no memoirs, observing that it was "hard to write interestingly without being critical of people". He also maintained a firm public commitment to his long friendship with Nixon. In the aftermath of Watergate, a scandal from which Rogers was one of the few senior figures to emerge unstained, he described the disgraced president as a great world leader whom history would eventually rehabilitate.

Rogers was born in Norfolk, New York, and educated at Colgate and Cornell universities. He first met his patron on Capitol Hill in 1947; he was a senate committee lawyer, Nixon a recently-elected Republican congressman. Their collaboration began when Rogers encouraged Nixon to pursue charges against Alger Hiss, a senior state department official accused of secret Communist party membership. In spite of President Truman's dismissal of the allegations, Rogers was convinced they were true and persuaded Nixon to keep up the pressure. Amid huge controversy, Hiss was eventually jailed for perjury.

The case established Nixon so firmly as a rising star that he was nominated as Dwight Eisenhower's running mate in the 1952 presidential election. But his candidacy was threatened by accusations that he operated a secret slush fund financed by California business interests. As Eisenhower distanced himself from his running mate, Nixon turned desperately to Rogers, who largely drafted the famous Checkers television broadcast, built around the Nixon daughters' black and white puppy, that kept the vice-presidential candidate on the ticket.

Rogers's support for the Eisenhower campaign was initially rewarded with the job of assistant attorney general. Later, as attorney general, he found himself embroiled in the racial unrest sparked in Arkansas by the US supreme court's desegregation rulings. He played a large part in drafting the original Civil Rights Act, and later set up the justice department's civil rights division, which established America's present legal framework against racial and other discrimination.

With the election of John Kennedy in 1960, Rogers returned to private practice. Among his clients was the civil rights leader Martin Luther King, whom he represented in a libel action that eventually reached the supreme court, and significantly enhanced newspapers' ability to comment adversely on public figures.

His nomination as US secretary of state in 1969 was a deliberate move by Nixon to pick someone with little knowledge of foreign policy in the hope that this would nullify the influence of a department the president saw as a hotbed of his Democratic opponents. In his memoirs, Kissinger also speculated that the choice might have been founded on Nixon's neurotic need to establish supremacy over a well-connected friend on whom he had been too dependent for too long.

The inevitable result was a growing alienation between the president and Rogers, and a ferocious bureaucratic war between Rogers and Kissinger. In the end, even Nixon found it intolerable and, in 1973, abruptly demanded Rogers's resignation, turning the job over to Kissinger. "Neither Rogers nor I," Kissinger commented later, "mustered the grace to transcend an impasse that we should have recognised was not in the national interest. If we had been prepared to overcome our not inconsiderable egos, we could have complemented each other's efforts."

After this political humiliation, Rogers again retreated into the law. As one of the good and great, he was nonetheless picked by President Ronald Reagan to head the official inquiry into the 1986 Challenger space shuttle disaster. One of his early conclusions was that the accident had come not simply through a mechanical failure but from deep-seated administrative flaws in Nasa. He consequently declined to take evidence from any of the officials directly involved in the launch.

Though it was the scientist Richard Feynman who spotted the inadequacy of the gasket which wrecked the shuttle, Rogers's fundamental judgment was that it was "an accident rooted in history". In a fierce attack on the space agency's inappropriately macho culture, he recommended that "mission schedules should be based on what Nasa can do safely and well, not on what is possible with maximum effort".

It was yet another product of a sharply analytical mind which had, down the years, been focused on problems ranging from the war against New York gangsters to the use of a small dog as a diversion from his boss's seamy politics.

Rogers is survived by his wife Adele, whom he married in 1937, their three sons and a daughter.

 William Pierce Rogers, lawyer and politician, born June 23 1913; died January 2 2001

fields.headline: Hugh Richardson
fields.standfirst: Our last man in Lhasa, he brought unrivalled knowledge of Tibet to warnings of Chinese ambitions
fields.trailText: Our last man in Lhasa, he brought unrivalled knowledge of Tibet to warnings of Chinese ambitions.
fields.body:
On August 15 1947, the British mission to Lhasa pulled down the Union Jack and hoisted the Indian national flag as the new republic inherited the raj's diplomatic ties. At a stroke, Hugh Richardson, who has died aged 94, became Britain's last representative to an independent Tibet and the first from India. But while the mission continued seamlessly with the same staff, the world of central Asian politics was changing fast, something that Richardson, the finest Tibetan scholar of his era, pointed out in dispatches to both his British and Indian masters.

"We ignored Tibet," said India's prime minister Jawaharlal Nehru, but the Chinese did not. If the new republic failed to understand the threat on its northern border, Richardson could see China coming. He left Tibet for good in 1950, a few months before the Chinese overran Lhasa. He was called "a vicious aggressor" by Chinese propagandists, though, in truth, few men were less vicious or aggressive.

In fact, Richardson's greatest threat to the Chinese was his objective observation of the labyrinthine world of Tibetan politics and his deep understanding of Tibetan culture. When he argued that Tibet had been an independent state before its occupation by the Chinese, he did so with immense authority.

An army officer's son, he was born at St Andrews, Fife. His elder brother, Frank, followed their father into the military, also as a doctor, while Hugh won a scholarship to Keble College, Oxford, to read greats, the subject chosen by his predecessors in Tibet, Sir Charles Bell and Sir Basil Gould, both great Tibetologists whom Richardson would eventually surpass.

After briefly teaching at his old school, Trinity College at Glenalmond, Richardson sat the Indian civil service exam. He learned to speak Bengali fluently, a skill that later helped him to befriend the Bengali poet Rabindranath Tagore. His first posting, to Tamluk, in modern Bangla- desh, also drew on his Bengali skills, and from there he crossed the border from Sikkim into Tibet, travelling as far as Phari in 1933 with his Tibetan servant Pema.

But it was during his next posting, to Baluchistan, that Richardson's interest in Tibet blossomed. Left with almost nothing to do, he indulged his passion for gardening and got to know his colleague Basil Gould, the former agent in Sikkim who, in 1936, recruited Richardson as his protégé to join a new mission to Lhasa. The pretext was to mediate for the return from exile in China of the Panchen Lama, but Gould was determined to counter increasing Chinese influence by establishing a permanent British presence. This he achieved, leaving Richardson in charge when he left.

Richardson spent eight of the next 15 years in Tibet, from 1936 to 1940, when he returned to India for the remainder of the war, and from 1946 to 1950, latterly for the Indian government. He learned to speak Tibetan fluently, his accent described by the Tibetan politician Tsipon Shakabpa as "impeccable Lhasa Tibetan with a slight Oxford accent". He witnessed astonishing times in Lhasa, including the arrival of the 14th (and current) Dalai Lama in 1936, and the unwelcome expedition of 1939, led by Ernst Schaefer, which had been dispatched by Himmler to prove the Tibetans were a lost Aryan race.

Such intrusions did not, however, dispel the magic of the place. "A party at Lhasa," Richardson later recalled, "could last from 10 in the morning to 10 at night and could go on for two days." He made his own contributions to the fun, introducing golf - the thin air being useful for long drives - and soccer.

Although he missed the Dalai Lama's installation, Richardson kept in touch with the Tibetan leader after the war - through the Austrian mountaineers, Heinrich Harrer and Peter Aufschnaiter, when protocol prevented private interviews, and, after 1959, more personally during the Dalai Lama's continuing exile. He continued to lobby the United Nations to oppose the Chinese invasion and described himself "ashamed" when the British abstained.

After leaving Tibet, he returned to St Andrews, where he remained until his death, a cherished member of the Royal and Ancient. He began a second career as a scholar on Tibetan culture and politics, and wrote prodigiously, co-authoring a cultural history of the country with David Snellgrove and writing papers and monographs, expertly collected by the Himalayan scholar Michael Aris in 1998 as High Peaks, Pure Earth. Subjects range from the origins of the Tibetan state to early Tibetan law on dog bites, something anyone who has travelled in Tibet will appreciate.

Richardson's work, encapsulated in this book, fills important gaps in the historical record, as well as bearing witness to a culture that has been systematically dest- royed over the last 50 years. At the time of his memorial service in St Andrews, monks lit butter lamps in the Jokhang in Lhasa, and the Dalai Lama sent a personal message praising Richardson as "an honorary Tibetan".

In 1951, Richardson married Huldah Rennie, whose first husband had been killed during the war, and became stepfather to her children, David and Elizabeth. She predeceased him in 1995.

Richardson spent eight of the next 15 years in Tibet, from 1936 to 1940, when he returned to India for the remainder of the war, and from 1946 to 1950, latterly for the Indian government. He learned to speak Tibetan fluently, his accent described by the Tibetan politician Tsipon Shakabpa as "impeccable Lhasa Tibetan with a slight Oxford accent". He witnessed astonishing times in Lhasa, including the arrival of the 14th (and current) Dalai Lama in 1936, and the unwelcome expedition of 1939, led by Ernst Schaefer, which had been dispatched by Himmler to prove the Tibetans were a lost Aryan race. Such intrusions did not, however, dispel the magic of the place. "A party at Lhasa," Richardson later recalled, "could last from 10 in the morning to 10 at night and could go on for two days." He made his own contributions to the fun, introducing golf - the thin air being useful for long drives - and soccer. Although he missed the Dalai Lama's installation, Richardson kept in touch with the Tibetan leader after the war - through the Austrian mountaineers, Heinrich Harrer and Peter Aufschnaiter, when protocol prevented private interviews, and, after 1959, more personally during the Dalai Lama's continuing exile. He continued to lobby the United Nations to oppose the Chinese invasion and described himself "ashamed" when the British abstained. After leaving Tibet, he returned to St Andrews, where he remained until his death, a cherished member of the Royal and Ancient. He began a second career as a scholar on Tibetan culture and politics, and wrote prodigiously, co-authoring a cultural history of the country with David Snellgrove and writing papers and monographs, expertly collected by the Himalayan scholar Michael Aris in 1998 as High Peaks, Pure Earth. Subjects range from the origins of the Tibetan state to early Tibetan law on dog bites, something anyone who has travelled in Tibet will appreciate. Richardson's work, encapsulated in this book, fills important gaps in the historical record, as well as bearing witness to a culture that has been systematically dest- royed over the last 50 years. At the time of his memorial service in St Andrews, monks lit butter lamps in the Jokhang in Lhasa, and the Dalai Lama sent a personal message praising Richardson as "an honorary Tibetan". In 1951, Richardson married Huldah Rennie, whose first husband had been killed during the war, and became stepfather to her children, David and Elizabeth. She predeceased him in 1995.  Hugh Edward Richardson, diplomat and author, born December 22 1905; died December 3 2000

fields.headline: Slay it again
fields.standfirst: Once the ultimate cult character, Buffy The Vampire Slayer is now a fully fledged icon. But four years on, is she losing her bite?
fields.trailText: Once the ultimate cult character, Buffy The Vampire Slayer is now a fully fledged icon. But four years on, is she losing her bite?
fields.body:
It's a bit like the moment your dad started humming along to the Spice Girls. Far from being a cultural high point, the moment that Sunday Times arts critic Brian Appleyard dropped his weekly analysis of post-structuralism and turned over two pages in breathless tribute to the sheer brilliance that is a teenage vampire slayer must surely be the beginning of the end.

Clearly the possibility that Mr Appleyard has been possessed by the demon spirit Moloch cannot be overlooked. But if, after 80-odd episodes, the highbrow establishment has finally caught on to the fact that a smartly written sci-fi, horror or fantasy series might just be a metaphor, then we must resist the temptation to mock. Buffy The Vampire Slayer has withstood greater threats than this - the opening of the hellmouth on her graduation day from high school and nearly being axed after just 11 episodes, to name just two.

In fact it's rather appropriate that the grown-ups have suddenly got with the programme, for so, as we enter season five, has the world's oldest vampire. Yes, Vlad the Impaler, Count Dracula of Transylvania, has woken up to the world's leading slayer and decides to pay a visit to Sunnydale to convince Buffy that the two are soul mates - with a love that, naturally, spans time, geography and the small matter of being undead.

It might also be possible to interpret episode one of the new series as the writers getting cocky. Rewriting Bram Stoker must have seemed like a challenge. And so, up pops the ould enemy, and who can blame him? Five minutes into the show, there's this leather-clad wee blonde girl in that state of undernourishment which is considered healthy only in Hollywood, kicking ass and taking responsibility for the world's ills. No wonder Nosferatu wants a piece. "I am Dracul," he drawls, all eastern European seductiveness. Ooh, colour me impressed, reads the response from the Valley girl.

After four years, Buffy's preternaturally smart writers seem determined to acknowledge that Sunnydale's combination of a monster of the week with a parallel teen crisis was becoming a tad predictable. Giles the watcher is visibly suffering some ennui (unsurprisingly, as he barely seemed to leave his condo last series) and threatens to head back to England, retirement and Gold Blend ads. This prompts his search for a new career (prompting Buffy to ask "How bored were you last year?").

But it's Buffy's latest love-interest, poor old Riley, who's beginning to look incongruous. Given the tough job of following now-he's-good-now-he's-bad Angel, Riley was always going to find it hard to match the love that dare not speak its name. And God knows there's nothing like a bit of pale-faced yearning over centuries for a passion that sates the inner turmoil to make a girl feel special. So when Buffy succumbs to Dracula's initial advances and spends the next day using the lamest "scarf over the love-bite" disguise in an attempt to hide her vampiric encounter from her boyfriend, you don't need to be Brian Appleyard to see through the metaphor.

"Last night..." she breathes at Dracula after their mutual blood has been let, "it's not going to happen again..." Moral: one-night stands can leave you feeling a bit cheap and vulnerable to the influence of the undead.

Desperate both on and off-screen to emphasise how integral they are to the success of the slayer, Buffy's sidekicks are determined to make their presence felt this season. This is a crucial time for Buffy and the Scooby gang - the team has to recreate the ensemble feeling to ensure enough characters equals enough storylines equals enough legs to reach the all-important seventh series. For those who aren't Hollywood players, that's when syndication becomes a serious money-maker and you can retire on the repeat fees.

When everyone left high school, the focal location of the show disappeared - like losing Central Perk from the set of Friends. To correct this, moves are made early in this series to create a new base-camp for the slayer-ettes, and some new characters are introduced. A previously unheard-of little sister, Dawn, pops up out of nowhere and conveniently returns the much-missed high school element.

One might suppose that, at 14, Dawn has been brought in as an insurance policy against the increasing stardom of Buffy herself, that FHM favourite, Sarah Michelle Gellar. So far, the high-kicking one has confined her extra-Buffy activities to some cool cameos (Scream 2 and She's All That) and second-tier teen flicks (I Know What You Did Last Summer and Cruel Intentions), along with the dire Simply Irresistible in which she plays a chef with mystical powers. But she's heading for her mid-20s now, and has a babe film-star boyfriend in Freddie Prinze Jr, so the possibility that she might just pick a blinding script and move into the big league can't have escaped the producers. Whedon, himself a veteran of two of the least distinguished movies ever made (Titan AE and Waterworld) and two of the best (Toy Story and Speed) must also be on the prowl for greater glory.

It will be a sad day, no doubt about it. But there must be at least one more season to come after this, if the cast hold to their original seven-year contracts. And then there's always the repeats on BBC2 for Mr Appleyard to catch up on.

 Buffy The Vampire Slayer, tonight, 8pm, Sky One

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip.
fields.body:
Can't boil an egg, but can't get enough of good cooking? Then TV is the place to be. Cookery has always been a staple of any daytime TV viewer's diet but in the past few years it's also smothered primetime TV in layers of mayonnaise and ice cream. Latest addition to the ranks of great women is the ubiquitous domestic goddess, Nigella Lawson.

Recently, she's been all over our screens more often than olive oil's been drizzled over a lettuce frisée. What with her addition to the TV cookery genre - Nigella's Bites - and a yuletide round of publicity appearances to plug her goddess manual, viewers would be forgiven for feeling queasy at the sight of her.

Perhaps the lovely Lawson's best turn was when she put in an appearance on a seasonal edition of Graham Norton's pre-Christmas chat show, aptly titled Snow Graham Norton. Our Nige was treated to the camp Graham's usual tour of risqué pop culture and encouraged to elaborate on the essence of goddessness. But as well as being made to read out some of her own simpering prose from the book (as TV plugs go, reading aloud from a book has to go down as pretty in yer face), Lawson gave viewers her own garnish tip.

In the book she may dreamily invoke images of "trailing nutmeggy smells from a baking pie", but on the programme Lawson jested that her secret ingredient - and key to total, blissful domination on the domestic front - was in fact "slut dust". We're already ordering it by the truckload.

Staying with trucks, have you wondered why we've heard so much about Bob the Builder this winter? OK, so he made number one at Christmas. But just how did he get so much publicity? Could it be anything to do with a strict edict at BBC Worldwide, the commercial arm of the BBC that looks after hot properties like Bob? Press officers are whipped into a frenzy to get at least one story a week into the national press. Remember this next time you read about how Tweenies is outstripping the Teletubbies' fame.

webTitle: Labour: Election war chest piles up

fields.headline: Election war chest piles up
fields.standfirst:
Just when you think you can't find a multi-million pound donor, three come along in a week. Christopher Ondaatje joins Labour's £2m club

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Just when you think you can't find a multi-million pound donor, three come along in a week. Christopher Ondaatje joins Labour's £2m club.
fields.body:
Labour last night astonished the political world and demoralised its opponents when it announced that two more multi-millionaires have each matched Lord Hamlyn's Christmas generosity and donated £2m to the party's war chest.

But the announcement that publisher and financier Christopher Ondaatje had joined Lord Sainsbury, now a government minister, in the £2m club was not quite the act of public-spirited openness that Labour immediately claimed.

After the enforced disclosure of Lord Hamlyn's similar gift, controversially filed six weeks before such donors will have to be identified by law, the Economist magazine had warned Labour headquarters that it was poised to name the pair in today's edition.

Mr Ondaatje told the Economist he had been approached by Labour in November and told of the other £2m gifts. In December he agreed to donate the same. But only on Monday - as the Hamlyn row broke - was he asked to go public.

All three donors are what one top fundraiser last night called "men of impeccable standing in society". All three have given far more than £2m to cultural and educational bodies. The National Portrait Gallery's new wing in central London is named after Mr Ondaatje, the older brother of Michael Ondaatje, an award-winning novelist.

The shift from dependency on the trade unions and party rank and file to the successful courtship of wealthy philanthropists is seen by MPs and party activists as representing a significant change in Britain's political culture.

The cash will go into a general fund and Millbank described £6m from three men as small beer compared to its £25m annual budget. But it is nearly half what Labour will be allowed to spend at the coming election - a cap is expected to be set at around £15m. Last night's news means Labour has almost certainly reached that target.

Veteran Labour MP Tony Benn called it "a negation of democracy" while the Conservatives brazenly denounced "Labour's continuing reliance on a small number of very large donors" - precisely its own position for many years. The Liberal Democrats again called for state funding of politics to stop sleaze and prevent governments being "in thrall to big corporations".

To rub salt into Conservative wounds, Mr Ondaatje was revealed as a former Tory donor who had become disillusioned with the party's anti-European stance.

"They [Labour] are doing a very good job [with the economy] at a difficult time and I believe they should be given every possible support," Mr Ondaatje said.

A Conservative victory at the election would be a disaster, he added.

Lord Sainsbury, the science minister, has already donated millions to Labour and before that to the SDP, which was also backed for a period by Lord Hamlyn. Last night Lord Sainsbury said he was announcing his latest gift of £2m to head off speculation. "In our democracy, political parties have to raise funds to campaign and put their policies to the electorate, and as a proud supporter of the Labour Party I am happy that I am in a position where I can make a contribution," he said.

Last night Labour spin doctors insisted that the party retained the broadest fundraising base in Britain with 40% of its income coming from party members and small donors (below £5,000), 30% from the unions, 10% from sales and merchandising and 20% from big donors.

Lord Levy, the prime minister's personal fundraiser and envoy, is believed to have played a brokering role - although Chris Smith, the culture secretary, is admired by Mr Ondaatje and may have smoothed his path.

Labour's spokesman, Lance Price, said: "What we did feel after Lord Hamlyn made the statement he did on Tuesday, that it was right and proper, just to ensure that there was no confusion whatever, that other donors in that league, that we should at least contact them and see how they would feel about having their names made public as well."

Andrew Lansley, a senior Tory MP, complained: "This news of Labour's continuing reliance on a small number of very large donors, alongside the trade unions, for its financial backing highlights strongly the need for a broader base of party funding."

A Labour backbencher, Andrew Mackinlay, last night called for all large donors to be barred from receiving a peerage. The Thurrock MP said: "There should be a ceiling on all large individual and corporate donations. All donors to political parties should be disqualified from being nominated for membership of the House of Lords by any party leader.

"Disqualification should exist for at least five years following the last donation," he added.

Talk about it
Should political donors be named?

webTitle: Russians deny nuclear deployment to Baltic

fields.headline: Russians deny nuclear deployment to Baltic
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russian military commanders dismissed American claims yesterday that the Kremlin had covertly deployed short-range nuclear weapons in eastern Europe for the first time since the end of the cold war.
fields.body:
Russian military commanders dismissed American claims yesterday that the Kremlin had covertly deployed short-range nuclear weapons in eastern Europe for the first time since the end of the cold war.

According to American intelligence leaks, the Russians have been moving tactical nuclear warheads to Kaliningrad on the Baltic in the past year. The action would be in line with President Vladimir Putin's new military doctrine, which raises Russia's nuclear threshold to compensate for the sorry state of its conventional forces.

Sources in the Russian armed forces general staff rejected the US allegation. "The information has nothing in common with reality and has the character of a provocation," a source said.

But the US state department said Washington would raise the issue with the Russians soon. The secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, is expected to have her final meeting with the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, in the next fortnight before being replaced by General Colin Powell.

The departmental spokesman Richard Boucher said: "It's an issue we want to take up."

Kaliningrad, Germany's former east Prussian fortress of Königsberg, is Russia's strategically vital window on the west and home to its Baltic fleet.

The Soviet Union's collapse and the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact left Kaliningrad cut off from Russia, sandwiched between Poland, now a Nato member, and Lithuania, a prospective member.

Moscow's denial was buttressed by senior Lithuanian officials, who said they had no evidence to support the US report, nor had they monitored shipments of nuclear weapons on the Russian military routes into Kaliningrad.

The foreign minister in Vilnius, Antanas Valionis, played down the report.

But the Polish defence minister, Bronislaw Komorowski, called for international inspectors to verify Moscow's claim that it had not deployed nuclear weapons.

"Poland needs to monitor the situation in Kaliningrad on a day-to-day basis and it is doing that," he said on the Polish public television station Channel One.

"Verification will include pushing for international inspection, which is a usual thing," he said.

US intelligence and military officials told journalists in Washington that Moscow had moved battlefield nuclear weapons, possibly warheads for the SS-21 Tochka missile, into Kaliningrad in June, within weeks of Mr Putin endorsing Russia's new military doctrine.

In April, in one of the first acts of his presidency, he blessed a doctrine which foresees first and earlier use of nuclear weapons to forestall conventional attacks on Russia.

Western and Russian analysts agree that Moscow has become more dependent on its vast nuclear arsenal because of the dire condition and poor morale of its armed forces.

The accession of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic to Nato in 1999 brought renewed hostility between Moscow and the western alliance, exacerbated by Nato's war in Kosovo the same year.

But it remains unclear whether tactical nuclear missiles are being moved to the Kaliningrad enclave or have been stored there for years.

In non-binding agreements with Washington in 1991 and 1992, the Kremlin committed itself to withdrawing all short-range nuclear weapons from eastern Europe and keeping the Baltic nuclear free.

It said the missiles were withdrawn and placed in storage in Russia.

Some of these stores could be in Kaliningrad, and the missiles there could have been taken from Baltic fleet ships.

Yesterday's Russian denial of the American report left open the possibility that the weapons are being stored in the enclave.

Hawkish American politicians voiced alarm at the report and said they showed the need for the Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to be taken under the shelter of the Nato umbrella.

Any serious move by the new US administration to bring them into Nato would precipitate a bigger crisis in Russia's relations with the west.

But if the nuclear deployment is confirmed, that could cause a rift between western Europe and the US on security strategy, and set Germany against further Nato expansion.

In the past two months Moscow has been applauding western European moves towards a security strategy more independent of Nato and Washington, seeking to exploit transatlantic tension regarding the new European rapid-reaction force.

In non-binding agreements with Washington in 1991 and 1992, the Kremlin committed itself to withdrawing all short-range nuclear weapons from eastern Europe and keeping the Baltic nuclear free. It said the missiles were withdrawn and placed in storage in Russia. Some of these stores could be in Kaliningrad, and the missiles there could have been taken from Baltic fleet ships. Yesterday's Russian denial of the American report left open the possibility that the weapons are being stored in the enclave. Hawkish American politicians voiced alarm at the report and said they showed the need for the Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to be taken under the shelter of the Nato umbrella. Any serious move by the new US administration to bring them into Nato would precipitate a bigger crisis in Russia's relations with the west. But if the nuclear deployment is confirmed, that could cause a rift between western Europe and the US on security strategy, and set Germany against further Nato expansion. In the past two months Moscow has been applauding western European moves towards a security strategy more independent of Nato and Washington, seeking to exploit transatlantic tension regarding the new European rapid-reaction force.

fields.headline: Failure of BSE tests revealed
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Worried food standards chiefs last night admitted that meat has been passed as fit to eat while still containing potentially fatal material, despite tight controls designed to stop BSE-contaminated material going into food.
fields.body:
Worried food standards chiefs last night admitted that meat has been passed as fit to eat while still containing potentially fatal material, despite tight controls designed to stop BSE-contaminated material going into food.

Cattle and sheep carcasses containing spinal cord have been found by government vets in spot checks on at least two abattoirs in the last year. Another case in Northern Ireland involving a cow is still under investigation.

Spinal cord, among the most potentially infective parts of cattle not displaying obvious signs of BSE, has also been found in carcasses imported from Ireland in the last year.

The food standards agency last night admitted that it was worried by the apparent lapses but insisted that investigations to date indicated that these were isolated incidents and that the carcasses had since been destroyed.

Staff are expected to be given new warnings over the importance of cast-iron procedures for inspecting carcasses because in the two proven cases the responsibility lay with a government meat inspector and a contract vet, rather than abattoir workers.

Before the latest lapses, no meat passed as healthy had been found with spinal cord since 1996, when the probable link between eating BSE-infected cattle and vCJD in humans was established. Similar anti-BSE measures now apply in sheep because of the theoretical risk they too could be infected.

The cases come to light just weeks before European commission vets inspect Britain's anti-BSE regime.

The Human BSE Foundation, representing the families of victims, 83 of whom have so far died in Britain, said the incidents showed there was no room for complacency.

Spokesman Malcolm Tibbert said: "I have always thought there was still scope for BSE-infected material to enter food and this goes to show that any attempt to let the industry regulate itself would be beyond belief."

The Consumers' Association said: "We have to find out whether these are isolated cases or evidence of a larger problem."

It was concerned that in some instances the abattoirs where the failures had been discovered had not been named, especially as consumers are regularly told by the food standards agency to check where food is coming from.

A food standards agency spokesman said last night: "We are worried. The meat hygiene service says the presence of any SRM (the risk materials) in healthy marked carcasses is viewed very seriously."

Failures by inspectors could be regarded as gross misconduct and lead to dismissal. "While there is no reason to suppose people are becoming more laissez-faire and could not care less anymore, these cases are a matter of concern."

The government argues that controls are now far better than in the mid-90s when horrified agriculture officials and Tory ministers discovered appalling lapses.

In January last year a member of the state veterinary service checking standards at a Manchester abattoir run by Cruisedeal Ltd found a piece of spinal cord more than two inches long hanging from a beef carcass. It had been marked fit for consumption by an inspector working for the meat hygiene service, then answerable to the agriculture department but now to the food standards agency.

The inspector was suspended pending inquiries but the investigation team found "mitigating circumstances" at the plant at the time and he was allowed to return to work at another plant after a formal caution.

The abattoir later lost its licence for other hygiene failings.

In Northern Ireland there have been five breaches of anti-BSE controls in meat imported from Ireland, prompting stiff exchanges with Dublin.

But in another case in September, vets working for the Northern Ireland executive found spinal cord in a meat plant. All the carcasses were destroyed.

Officials there insist the cases are not evidence of a larger on-going problem but will not give further details while investigations continue.

Last month checks by government vets at a Devon abattoir found remains of spinal cord in a sheep carcass.

The contract vet involved is likely to be allowed to return to similar work. He appears to have missed the sheep out when returning to the inspection line after being called away.

The food standards agency has insisted that procedures are changed to ensure such a mistake does not happen again.

It is not identifying the plant "because it is the meat hygiene service at fault, rather than the abattoir owner".

webTitle: BA chief backs third runway for Heathrow

fields.headline: BA chief backs third runway for Heathrow
fields.trailText: British Airways yesterday backed a third runway for Heathrow in a future stage of the government's plans to relieve congestion at airports in the south-east.
fields.body:
British Airways yesterday backed a third runway for Heathrow in a future stage of the government's plans to relieve congestion at airports in the south-east.

Rod Eddington, British Airways' chief executive, told a business audience that BA supported the expansion of Heathrow because it was the company's home base and was a natural choice. "The decision will be a political one and there are other airports in the London area which can be expanded," he said.

Mr Eddington said he expected that the government would decide to build a second runway at Stansted in Essex because it would be faced with many political problems if it chose Luton or Gatwick. But there was room for a third runway at Heathrow.

Mr Eddington said that he fully expected the new government to back the completion of terminal 5 at Heathrow in a decision expected after the election. It was vitally necessary for the economic health of "Britain plc". If it was not approved, Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris and Frankfurt in Germany would leave Heathrow far behind.

He said terminal 5, which will increase Heathrow's throughput by 30m passengers a year, would provide a permanent base for BA, freeing up the remaining terminals for other airlines.

Mr Eddington forecast that Concorde would be flying again in the spring and said he would be on the first scheduled service between London and New York.

He said Air France and BA had been working together since last July's fatal crash of the Air France Concorde in Paris. "We hope to be reintroducing our flights simultaneously, but the French have to await the outcome of their safety report into the accident."

Mr Eddington said considerable work had been carried out by the manufacturers and the airlines on modifications to Concorde's fuel tanks and increased protection from debris flying off the wheels.

He agreed that Concorde had a finite life, but he saw no reason why it should not fly for several more years.

BA's chief executive said that the Concorde's airframe was built to last until 2006-7 after which it would have to be modified. "You have to remember that although it has been flying for around 30 years, it has not been used as a workhorse like a 747."

fields.headline: BT announces £2bn property sale
fields.standfirst: Move to cut debt may fall foul of regulator
fields.trailText: Move to cut debt may fall foul of regulator.
fields.body:
British Telecom, which is struggling to reduce its £20bn debt mountain, yesterday revealed that it is seeking to sell its properties in Britain for about £2bn.

But the move could fall foul of Oftel, the industry regulator, if it threatens the telecom group's operational efficiency. The property deal, if it goes through, would leave third parties responsible for maintaining the buildings which house BT's 6,000 telephone exchanges.

David Edmonds, the director general of Oftel, said yesterday he would be scrutinising the deal carefully. "Oftel will want to be assured that the planned disposals do not affect BT's ability to meet its licence and other obligations, including those relating to provision of the universal telephone service and local loop unbundling," he said.

"Oftel will seek full information from BT about the details of the disposals and the leasing arrangements. I know that BT is also fully aware of these obligations and the need to retain control of its operational buildings such as telephone exchanges."

The telecoms group is planning to dispose of its properties either through outright sale or by selling the leasehold to a property or finance company.

Such a deal, involving 7,500 properties with a total floor space of 6m square metres, would be the biggest transaction of its kind in Britain.

BT expects the deal will generate about £2bn in cash which will be used to reduce the enormous debt it has incurred as it has sought to expand its mobile phone and internet-based businesses.

BT, which is talking to five property or finance groups, hopes to sell the whole portfolio to a single company. Nomura, the Japanese bank, is among the front runners.

About 30% of the properties, mainly offices, warehouses and garages, will be sold outright, with BT taking a 30-year lease on those it needs to use.

It plans to sell 116-year leases on the other 70%, which includes its telephone exchanges, and then lease the properties back for 30 years.

The property deal is expected to save BT about £100m a year mainly as a result of reduced depreciation charges.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: Should I stop sending gifts to my estranged 19-year-old daughter?
fields.trailText: Should I stop sending gifts to my estranged 19-year-old daughter?
fields.body:
I have not had direct contact with my 19-year-old daughter for eight years. Over that time I have regularly sent her gifts which she has accepted, though not acknowledged. On her recent birthday I sent her £50. Her solicitor wrote to me stating that if I write to her again she will take me to court for harassment. This is the work of the mother, with whom I lived briefly when my daughter was born. I cared for my daughter daily until school age, when the mother said she felt my presence would prevent her finding a partner. She then disrupted my contact with my daughter and, in spite of court orders, alienated my daughter so that she stopped contacting anyone in touch with me. My choices seem to be: (a) ignore the lawyer's letter and continue to send gifts; (b) stop contacting my daughter in the hope that she will soon leave the mother and see the situation differently; (c) force the matter to court to make my daughter aware that she has been alienated for her mother's ends.

Do as much as you can

I was moved by your letter; well done to know the three options; my suggestion is do all three, but with steadfastness and integrity. At the deepest level, this is only about your relationship to your daughter. Do your best; she will understand now or later if she cares to. Feel the pain, look out for yourself and be patient. In brief, do the most without intruding on their patch.

My daughter is 12 and lives with her formidable but slightly crazy mum. I was absent for the first eight years and tried hard to make the eventual contact work, but all three of us were overoptimistic. It seems the mum sabotaged all our meetings; yet it was more the lack of glue that exists in long-standing relationships.

I send presents and pay maintenance and school fees, all of which are unacknowledged. I no longer think that I will definitely see her again. The best thing that ever happened around all this for me was helping a friend find her dad 40 years after he left. They are best of friends now. But beware the suffering and heartache; stay alive.
Name and address withheld

Reply to the solicitor

Given your daughter's age, any attempt to force her would be pointless. She has presumably been poisoned against you, as she must, at 19, be at least nominally retaining her own solicitor. However, the solicitor is therefore corresponding with her, and she will read his or her letters; yours, she may not. My advice would be to reply to the solicitor. State that you want to respect your daughter's feelings, but that you also wish for her to know that your love for her is unconditional. You therefore want to arrange to pay a regular monthly sum of money for her own use, via the solicitor, if she prefers.

Even if she refuses to take the money at this point, let it build up in an account in her name. It doesn't have to be much, as long as it isn't insultingly less than you can reasonably afford; the point is that the consistent nature of the gesture will speak for itself. By indicating to her directly that you are willing to accept responsibility, you are subtly asserting your role as her father. You are making a commitment to her welfare without asking for or obtaining any immediate return.

You cannot force these things without alienating her further, but it will help in the future.
Olivia Challands
Cambridge

Wait and hope

My husband had the same treatment for 13 years. After his first partner left him for another man, taking their five-year-old daughter, he was refused any contact. He guessed that letters and presents were kept from her as he heard nothing except for vicious phone calls from the mother, warning him off. We could only guess at the terrible image of her father that his daughter was being given and this distressed my husband terribly.

Imagine our joy when his daughter turned up at our home without warning last year, 18 years old and longing to know her father. She had been helped to trace him by her sympathetic stepfather.

If you can be patient and stop trying to contact her for now, there's no guarantee you'll have a similar happy ending, but surely this is much better than a) battling against the mother in the courts when only the lawyers will benefit, or b) continuing to send goodwill and money into the blue with absolutely no acknowledgment. In any case, your efforts probably result only in giving a warped kind of pleasure to her mother. But perhaps you won't have to wait for long. At 19 your daughter must surely be starting to work out her life - and her father's part in it - for herself, independent of her mother's manipulations and, before long, will be seeking you out. I hope so.
Name and address withheld

Next week

 Recently I was invited to my friend's wedding. I have known her for more than 10 years and, naturally, I was delighted.

I went out with my friend a couple of days later and, hesitantly but forthrightly, she told me that the invitation may be withdrawn. I am a male-to-female transsexual in the process of transition, living and working as a woman.

However, my friend's husband to be has said that I can only come as a man as he does not appear to be able to treat my needs seriously and is worried about how his extensive family may react to my presence.

I sympathise with my friend's position but am extremely angry about her fiance's attitude, especially as he is a very active member of the local Labour party and purports to have a commitment to socialist ideals and human rights. What can I do?

Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020-7239 9935, email private.lives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

webTitle: Nato urged to clean up its uranium debris in Kosovo

fields.headline: Nato urged to clean up its uranium debris in Kosovo
fields.standfirst:
Call for ban on radioactive shells as EU investigates link with soldiers' cancer deaths

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Call for ban on radioactive shells as EU investigates link with soldiers' cancer deaths.
fields.byline: Peter Capella  in Geneva and Owen Bowcott
fields.body:
Nato should dispose of large fragments of depleted uranium (DU) ammunition remaining in Kosovo 18 months after the conflict ended, because they represent an unnecessary risk to health, a UN study says.

Further details of the preliminary results of the UN Environment Programme investigation emerged yesterday as the EU began an inquiry into whether there is a link between radioactive military debris and the death from cancer of soldiers who served in the Balkans.

Meanwhile, the European commission president, Romano Prodi, called for DU-coated shells to be banned, after the French defence ministry said that four French soldiers who served in the Balkans during Nato's bombing of Yugoslavia in 1999 were being treated for leukaemia in a military hospital.

"It is clear that if there is even a minimal risk, these arms must be abolished," he said. "And even if this risk was not there, I don't like the idea of using these particular weapons".

Britain remains one of the few countries to resist compulsory screening of troops returning from Kosovo for traces of contamination. The ministry of defence insisted that in its solid form was not a health hazard. "The UN's initial findings were that there were a lot of other things which were of far greater concern," a spokesman said.

Italy opened an inquiry last week into a possible link between DU and 30 cases of serious illness in troops who served in the area, 12 of whom developed cancer. Five have already died of leukaemia.

The Campaign Against Depleted Uranium in Manchester says that most of the areas where DU shells were dropped during the Kosovo war are in the south, in the Italian sector.

Spain said it would examine all the 32,000 soldiers who have served in the Balkans since 1992. Portugal, Finland, Turkey, Bulgaria and Greece also plan to screen their peacekeepers and check radiation levels to discover if there is such a condition as "Balkans syndrome".

The biologist leading the Royal Society's inquiry into the long-term effects of DU weapons, Professor Brian Spratt of Oxford University, called on the government to test British troops.

"The leukaemia cases are probably not related, but the health of soldiers who go out to fight for their country should be taken seriously," he said.

In its preliminary statement, the UN said it had found "slightly higher" radioactivity in Kosovo at eight of the 11 sites examined last November. Nato had given details of 112 sites where an estimated 31,000 rounds of armour-piercing DU ammunition were used during attacks on Serb targets.

A US army officer on the team, who helped develop DU ammunition, was apparently surprised to find that it had not vapourised or dispersed.

The UN statement said that its scientists had found "either slightly higher amounts of Beta-radiation, specifically at or around the holes left by DU ammunition, or remnants of ammunitions, such as sabots and penetrators".

The team collected seven DU outer casings and seven penetrators.

"It is an extra risk for the population, and that is something that military experts were surprised to find," Pekka Haavisto, the Finnish head of the mission, said yesterday.

There is also concern about mine clearance, because most DU was found in heavily mined areas or sites with unexploded ordinance - some of which is cleared by controlled explosions. The UN believes this can turn DU back into its most dangerous form - a dust that can be inhaled.

What is depleted uranium?
Tim Radford, science editor

Natural uranium is a mix of different isotopes, including a small proportion of very radioactive U-235. The proportion of U-235 is concentrated for atomic fuel rods, and what is left over is depleted U-238. This has a radioactive half life of 4.5bn years, that is, it would take roughly the lifetime of the solar system for half of a lump of U-238 to break down into something else. It remains, however, radioactive.

"In contact, you could get quite a sizeable dose [of radiation], but a few inches away, it's gone," Michael Clark of Britain's National Radiological Protection Board said.

The rays from depleted uranium, or DU, may not be particularly penetrating but the substance itself is one of the densest metals available. It is therefore desirable as a military shell casing.

Its density enhances military firepower. Tungsten splinters when it hits the hard steel of a tank; DU penetrates and catches fire, which makes it a perfect weapon for armour-piercing shells. These were first used in the Gulf war, when US forces fired almost 1m rounds into Kuwait and Iraq. Nato forces fired more than 30,000 rounds in Kosovo and 10,000 in Bosnia, inevitably leaving fragments and particles behind.

Leukaemia is linked to radiation exposure. The connection was observed among the survivors of the atomic bomb attacks on Hiroshima and Nagasaki more than 50 years ago.

Because DU ignites on impact, it leaves behind clouds of potentially toxic uranium oxide dust. The fear is this dust could lodge in the lungs and be hazardous.

But scientists aren't so sure.

"The calculations show that you would have to inhale almost choking amounts to get appreciable lung dust," said Dr Clark. "You would see kidney problems due to its chemical action before you saw any radiation problems."
fields.bodyText: Nato should dispose of large fragments of depleted uranium (DU) ammunition remaining in Kosovo 18 months after the conflict ended, because they represent an unnecessary risk to health, a UN study says. Further details of the preliminary results of the UN Environment Programme investigation emerged yesterday as the EU began an inquiry into whether there is a link between radioactive military debris and the death from cancer of soldiers who served in the Balkans. Meanwhile, the European commission president, Romano Prodi, called for DU-coated shells to be banned, after the French defence ministry said that four French soldiers who served in the Balkans during Nato's bombing of Yugoslavia in 1999 were being treated for leukaemia in a military hospital. "It is clear that if there is even a minimal risk, these arms must be abolished," he said. "And even if this risk was not there, I don't like the idea of using these particular weapons". Britain remains one of the few countries to resist compulsory screening of troops returning from Kosovo for traces of contamination. The ministry of defence insisted that in its solid form was not a health hazard. "The UN's initial findings were that there were a lot of other things which were of far greater concern," a spokesman said. Italy opened an inquiry last week into a possible link between DU and 30 cases of serious illness in troops who served in the area, 12 of whom developed cancer. Five have already died of leukaemia. The Campaign Against Depleted Uranium in Manchester says that most of the areas where DU shells were dropped during the Kosovo war are in the south, in the Italian sector. Spain said it would examine all the 32,000 soldiers who have served in the Balkans since 1992. Portugal, Finland, Turkey, Bulgaria and Greece also plan to screen their peacekeepers and check radiation levels to discover if there is such a condition as "Balkans syndrome". The biologist leading the Royal Society's inquiry into the long-term effects of DU weapons, Professor Brian Spratt of Oxford University, called on the government to test British troops. "The leukaemia cases are probably not related, but the health of soldiers who go out to fight for their country should be taken seriously," he said. In its preliminary statement, the UN said it had found "slightly higher" radioactivity in Kosovo at eight of the 11 sites examined last November. Nato had given details of 112 sites where an estimated 31,000 rounds of armour-piercing DU ammunition were used during attacks on Serb targets. A US army officer on the team, who helped develop DU ammunition, was apparently surprised to find that it had not vapourised or dispersed. The UN statement said that its scientists had found "either slightly higher amounts of Beta-radiation, specifically at or around the holes left by DU ammunition, or remnants of ammunitions, such as sabots and penetrators". The team collected seven DU outer casings and seven penetrators. "It is an extra risk for the population, and that is something that military experts were surprised to find," Pekka Haavisto, the Finnish head of the mission, said yesterday. There is also concern about mine clearance, because most DU was found in heavily mined areas or sites with unexploded ordinance - some of which is cleared by controlled explosions. The UN believes this can turn DU back into its most dangerous form - a dust that can be inhaled. What is depleted uranium? Tim Radford, science editor Natural uranium is a mix of different isotopes, including a small proportion of very radioactive U-235. The proportion of U-235 is concentrated for atomic fuel rods, and what is left over is depleted U-238. This has a radioactive half life of 4.5bn years, that is, it would take roughly the lifetime of the solar system for half of a lump of U-238 to break down into something else. It remains, however, radioactive. "In contact, you could get quite a sizeable dose [of radiation], but a few inches away, it's gone," Michael Clark of Britain's National Radiological Protection Board said. The rays from depleted uranium, or DU, may not be particularly penetrating but the substance itself is one of the densest metals available. It is therefore desirable as a military shell casing. Its density enhances military firepower. Tungsten splinters when it hits the hard steel of a tank; DU penetrates and catches fire, which makes it a perfect weapon for armour-piercing shells. These were first used in the Gulf war, when US forces fired almost 1m rounds into Kuwait and Iraq. Nato forces fired more than 30,000 rounds in Kosovo and 10,000 in Bosnia, inevitably leaving fragments and particles behind. Leukaemia is linked to radiation exposure. The connection was observed among the survivors of the atomic bomb attacks on Hiroshima and Nagasaki more than 50 years ago. Because DU ignites on impact, it leaves behind clouds of potentially toxic uranium oxide dust. The fear is this dust could lodge in the lungs and be hazardous. But scientists aren't so sure. "The calculations show that you would have to inhale almost choking amounts to get appreciable lung dust," said Dr Clark. "You would see kidney problems due to its chemical action before you saw any radiation problems."

fields.headline: Naked truth
fields.trailText: I am currently remanded and segregated in prison on two non-imprisonable charges of section 5 of the Public Order Act. I have been continuously unclothed since December 17, when I handcuffed myself to the gates of Downing Street.
fields.body:
I am currently remanded and segregated in prison on two non-imprisonable charges of section 5 of the Public Order Act. I have been continuously unclothed since December 17, when I handcuffed myself to the gates of Downing Street. I was earlier charged with section 5 on December 13, wearing only a transparent PVC coat and trousers, whilst strolling through the West End with friends. In the cell next to mine is Vincent Bethell, who has been continuously unclothed since August 13. If I am found guilty, I cannot be sent to prison. However, while I remain innocent, I am in prison.

It is my belief there is no reason why clothing should be compulsory. It is simply my ordinary human body that is visible. We are criminalised because of prejudice against our appearance. Religious concepts of bodily sin and shame continue to inform our contemporary self-perceptions, while advertising exploits both our fascination with the body as well as our low self-esteem, through limited representations of ideal bodies. This campaign of public nakedness is a simple action that simultaneously invigorates numerous complex issues.

I am not a naturist, a nudist, a streaker, nor an exhibitionist. Labels are for clothes. My unclothed appearance is also not motivated sexually nor out of any gratuitous need to seek attention. I believe that while society continues to have a fundamentally negative relationship with the human body and appearance, we can never be a free or mature society. It's the 21st century. Time to evolve.
Russell Higgs
Brixton prison

fields.headline: Bill's burden
fields.trailText: I was dismayed to read Joan Smith trashing Clinton as a president who has "failed in almost every respect" (Hypocrite to the last, January 3).
fields.body:
I was dismayed to read Joan Smith trashing Clinton as a president who has "failed in almost every respect" (Hypocrite to the last, January 3). This does an injustice to someone who has had to cope with a hostile Republican majority in Congress, and with foreign policy subject to monitoring by extremist rightwingers like Jesse Helms. It is scandalous to bring up Clinton's "failure" in health-care, when his attempt to provide a better system was scuppered by the propaganda of business interests. His successes include the creation of new national parks and extensive measures for the environment. Joan Smith would do better to expose the nastiness of rightwing groups in US politics.
RA Foakes
Santa Monica, US
rafoakes@yahoo.com

fields.headline: The horse in history
fields.trailText: You state that the horse was first domesticated in Ukraine in 5000BC (The rock art from 6,000 years ago, December 27). Recent research, including new radiocarbon dates, suggests otherwise.
fields.body:
You state that the horse was first domesticated in Ukraine in 5000BC (The rock art from 6,000 years ago, December 27). Recent research, including new radiocarbon dates, suggests otherwise. I have been investigating the origins of horse domestication since 1985, including the material from Dereivka upon which your date is based, and can state with considerable confidence that we do not know when or where it was first domesticated.

The earliest certain date for the domesticated horse, c2000BC, comes from Middle Bronze Age chariot burials in the steppelands, west of the Ural mountains. Clearly the horse must have been domesticated for some time before that date, but just how long is a matter of ongoing debate by specialists in the field.

This might seem trivial. But the domestication of the horse would have had an immense impact upon human life, whenever it did take place. Until the invention of the internal combustion engine, the horse was the most important form of transport (in many places, it still is). Social, political and economic relations between people would have been profoundly affected by its acquisition as a work animal and as a food source in the harsh environment of inner Eurasia, but until we know when it was domesticated, there is no way to gauge its early impact.
Dr Marsha Levine
University of Cambridge
ml12@cam.ac.ukm

webTitle: Letters: UK can lead on defence

fields.headline: UK can lead on defence
fields.trailText: You rightly highlight the increasing importance of continuing to develop the new European security arrangements (Leader, January 4). The EU needs to promote its regional interests, and these will not always be the same as those of the US. However, defence capability is not a free good.
fields.body:
You rightly highlight the increasing importance of continuing to develop the new European security arrangements (Leader, January 4). The EU needs to promote its regional interests, and these will not always be the same as those of the US. However, defence capability is not a free good. EU nations must be prepared to fund the necessary military capability. Britain could take a lead here. Nearly two decades of decline in the defence budget share of GDP will have to stop. Holding the defence budget at 2.5% of GDP for the next 10 years might just allow current British military strength to be maintained. No political party is yet prepared to make this pledge. Resources are needed for a number of expensive shared capabilities, currently provided by the US. These would have to be funded and operated on a pooled EU basis, and would require a EU defence budget.
Air Marshal Sir Timothy Garden
Visiting professor, Centre for Defence Studies, King's College London
tgarden@mac.com

 So the US is about to be led by a "hardline team with dangerous views about the world"? The Atlantic Alliance may be less concrete than it was, but America has guaranteed European security for over half a century, and very largely paid for it.

Far from being a relic, Nato protects democratic Europe. Only Nato has the capacity to manage extra-European operations, and pan-European unity on defence and security remains elusive. Britain, like America, is a sovereign pro-market democracy largely because of Nato and the Alliance. We could be more grateful.
Alexander Evans
London
aiaevans@yahoo.com

fields.headline: Platform for rail revival
fields.trailText: The government is a shareholder in Railtrack (Government could take stake in Railtrack, January 4). It has a 0.2% stake which two months ago delivered a £300,000 dividend to the Treasury.
fields.body:
The government is a shareholder in Railtrack (Government could take stake in Railtrack, January 4). It has a 0.2% stake which two months ago delivered a £300,000 dividend to the Treasury. In the Commons in November, I urged the prime minister to use that money to boost the government's shareholding. Sadly, he declined, saying the government, with the private sector, was already making a record investment in the transport infrastructure.

Huge public subsidies are indeed going into the industry, but how much say does that give us? Not much. We have ceded control to the private sector, with deadly consequences. The former chief executive of Railtrack, Gerald Corbett, candidly admitted last year: "We cannot actually keep our shareholders happy at the same time as fulfilling our public service obligations ... In the early days, I think we probably did concentrate too much on shareholders and the profit agenda."

The deputy prime minister has said bringing Railtrack back into the public sector would be prohibitively expensive because huge amounts of compensation would be payable. The answer is to increase, over time, the government's stake. Gerald Corbett, told Labour MPs on June 7 last year he wanted the government to do just that. What on earth are we afraid of?
Gordon Prentice MP
gordonprentice@compuserve.com

 Your story is incorrect. The government has not got any plans to take a stake in Railtrack, nor has it ever had any. To suggest otherwise is misleading to your readers.
Alun Evans
Director of communication, Department of Transport

 Most taxpayers want public transport back in public hands, with railworkers, who actually know about the railways, making the decisions and not accountants. During the term of the next government, many of the franchises will come up for renewal. Whichever government is in power should not reissue them but move the companies into a new British Rail Authority with a long-term aim of reuniting our fragmented rail system.

If the same amount of subsidy was awarded to a new British Rail, we would have one of the best rail systems in the world, with staffed stations, the return of weekend and bank holiday excursions, night trains and a service that is for the public and not the shareholders.

The government should admit that this experiment in privatisation has failed and for once listen to the people.
Pamela Sexton
Manchester
pam-uk@freeuk.com

 In the midst of the dismal Railtrack fiasco, wouldn't it be miraculous if a new company built an international railway across the heart of Britain, using disused line, spending not a penny of public money and removing a very significant proportion of long-distance lorry freight from our roads? It would be the very best example of green investment by private capital, the first new UK public railway for over a century.

It would be more heartening still to know the company was backed by several of the world's leading engineering and rail companies, including Parsons, Arup and SNCF, all convinced the new line's lorry-carrying capability, which Railtrack lacks, would have immense commercial appeal to the hauliers.

This company, Central Railway, has (surprise, surprise!) existed for 10 years. The only reason we are not already enjoying the benefits of its enterprise is that it requires the government to support it through the necessary statutory consent process. The last government submitted to the blandishments of Railtrack and disgracefully failed to support it. Does the present lot have the backbone to take a real decision? And why are you not campaigning for it?
Jonathan Wynne Evans
South Molton, Devon
jwe@magenta-netlogic.com

webTitle: Letters: Hitting back at classroom violence

fields.headline: Hitting back at classroom violence
fields.trailText: Mr Blunkett has done everything to ensure not only that classroom violence takes place, but that it disrupts the education of as many non-violent children as possible (£174m to improve classroom discipline, January 3).
fields.body:
Mr Blunkett has done everything to ensure not only that classroom violence takes place, but that it disrupts the education of as many non-violent children as possible (£174m to improve classroom discipline, January 3). Moreover, he has cleverly linked the violent children with the disabled and those with specific learning difficulties so that any complaint about their presence in the classroom can be used to label the plaintive as uncaring, unprofessional, politically incorrect and whatever other shallow label can be found.

I have seen this from the perspective of a parent, with my son's education being disrupted by a violent classmate for the past six years, and as a head of department, with more of my time being taken up not by teaching and preparation, but by managing aberrant behaviour and filling out the endless and utterly futile avalanche of paperwork caused by the disruptives. Inclusion, combined with the threat of inspection if suspensions exceed a government guideline, means quite simply that disruptive students can get away with more and more and we are protected less and less. This situation has been created by the government to save money.

Each new intake includes more and more students whose behaviour is deemed worthy of "special attention". In managing my department I am denied specialist teachers as they are required for teaching personal and social education; soon, no doubt, they will also be required for teaching citizenship. Senior management is reduced to Churchillian exhortation rather than professional guidance in efforts to maintain morale.
Name and address supplied

 Finding truants and taking them back to school might save some from a life of unemployment and worse. Preventing disaffection in primary school will do a lot more - 10% of children have exceptional difficulties learning to read. There are teachers with qualifications in specific learning difficulties, if the schools employed them. The political will to provide for all does not exist. Stopping children having their self-esteem destroyed in primary school must be the priority.
Lillemor Clark (Mother of two dyslexics)
London
Clarksissc@aol.com

fields.headline: Millennium to come
fields.trailText: Your leader (January 1) underestimates us pedants. Until the 18th century the year date didn't change until midnight on Lady Day (March 25), so this pedant is planning millennium celebrations on March 26.
fields.body:
Your leader (January 1) underestimates us pedants. Until the 18th century the year date didn't change until midnight on Lady Day (March 25), so this pedant is planning millennium celebrations on March 26. But I can't banish doubts as to whether the 11 days lost on the conversion to the Gregorian calendar in 1752 should be taken into account, moving the date to April 6 or even 8, since the difference would by now be 13 days ...
Tom Morton
Otley, W Yorks

 The year AD0 did not exist, but neither did 0BC - so we should be celebrating on January 1 2002.
John Howat
Hemel Hempstead, Herts

 Charles Kennedy says that Lib-Lab links are in a "coma" as a result of Labour shelving voting reform proposals (Report, January 4). In such circumstances, the humane option is usually to switch off the life-support machine.
Tom Watson
Labour national policy forum

 The price just quoted to me for heating oil is 23% lower than the price I paid in September. Why are petrol prices not being reduced similarly?
M Beaman
Kilndown, Kent

 The only people I have heard say Brissol are non-Bristolians. The true Bristolian not only adds the letter "l" on to a word ending in a vowel (Letters, January 4), but often removes it when the word ends with it. Bristol, therefore, is more likely to be pronounced Bristuh.
Jason Putt
Swindon, Wilts

 To Martin Long (Letters, January 2), I oppose Alderman the Reverend Frederick Charles Vyvyan-Jones, lord mayor circa 1968. Normal's birth as their youngest, he told me, was a relief to the parents, as their older girls were Idal and Eval.
Robert Hornung
London
