webTitle: Leader: The environment is not a government priority

fields.headline: Pale green politics
fields.standfirst: The environment is still not a high priority
fields.trailText: The environment is still not a high priority.
fields.body:
Environmentalists may be carting their Christmas trees off to be chipped and their Christmas cards for recycling, but the cheer of the festive season is fading fast. They know that one of the first victims in an election year is the environment. When it comes to the crunch, it is hospital beds, teachers and jobs which win votes, not the climate change levy, wind farms or scrapping bypasses. There is also a suspicion that the Labour government did its best in the autumn to tart up its environment record with the aim of killing it off as an election issue.

If challenged, Labour can now point to a significant achievement in the Countryside and Right to Roam Act. The government threw in a rural white paper for good measure, and in October Tony Blair, finally, made a major speech on the environment (as cynics pointed out, he also did so shortly before the last election, indicating a four-year cycle of green enthusiasm which then disappears without a trace). The pièce de résistance should have emerged at the Hague climate change conference; John Prescott would then have been able to add to his Kyoto prestige as a major force in international environmental negotiations. But the Hague descended into a farce of Anglo-French recriminations.

That leaves an international agreement on climate change as the most pressing environmental task for 2001. The deadline is now May in Bonn; efforts before Christmas to get an outline agreement before Bill Clinton leaves the White House failed when the US refused to attend a meeting in Oslo. With George W Bush as president, negotiations are likely to be even more difficult.

If the international picture on climate change is gloomy, the domestic one is only marginally less so. On the positive side, the government has reiterated its target to cut carbon emissions by 20%, well over the Kyoto agreed targets. Then the climate change levy on industry, Gordon Brown's scheme to tax polluters, comes into force in April, generating funds for a £50m carbon trust to be invested in research and development of renewable energy.

But this is a paltry sum given the scale of the challenge - 60% cuts needed in carbon emissions - which Mr Blair acknowledged for the first time in his October speech. Frustration mounts that while the prime minister has enthusiastically backed technological development from biotech to the internet, he has virtually ignored renewable energy. So Denmark and Germany are now the leading exporters in the technology, although the UK, as an island, has the greatest potential for offshore wind farms in Europe.

But the biggest blot on the government's record on climate change is its position on road transport, which is the fastest growing producer of carbon emissions. With traffic congestion predicted to grow 65% by 2010, this is one environmental issue likely to come to the forefront in the election. The government's policy is in chaos, with the railway crisis accelerating car use. A spectacular u-turn masterminded by transport minister Lord Macdonald on road building to assuage the Middle England motorist has left environmentalists infuriated.

In the 10-year transport plan unveiled last summer, roads got a virtually equal share of the cake with rail - £59bn to £60bn. More than 70 road schemes are now going through the planning process, including highly controversial proposals in Salisbury, Hastings and Weymouth. A paper delivered at the Royal Geographical Society conference in Plymouth this week calculates that Labour is now even out-building the Tories.

One other environmental issue which may come up is the state of the rural economy. The rural white paper was generally well received, but such a piecemeal approach will not solve the problem. The brightest hope is more niche farming, particularly organic, to replace our dependence on imports. If re-elected, the government will have to get back to work for more reform of the common agricultural policy to increase support for "green farming schemes" as the only way to secure the countryside's future.

One issue which the government will do all it can to duck is what to do about nuclear waste. A green paper promised for early December shows no sign yet of appearing. There are two others which environmental campaigners are determined to get on to the agenda. The first is what should be done about the cocktail of household chemicals, from those which line tin cans to flame retardants in duvets. Few of them have been properly tested and there are increasing suspicions that some disrupt hormones. The second issue is that of waste incinerators, resistance to which could come into play in some marginals.

This government should have learned by now that it ignores the environment at its peril. Many of the issues which have most unexpectedly tripped it up during the course of this parliament have been environmental: transport, genetic modification and flooding caused by global warming. What frustrates the environmental movement is that, despite the excellent work of Michael Meacher, the environment minister, and the efforts of the deputy prime minister, No 10 has repeatedly blocked the kind of radicalism needed. On a host of issues, from traffic congestion to nuclear waste, the government is simply burying its head in the sand, postponing a problem which everyone ought to know by now is only going to get worse.

fields.headline: Powell's high-risk strategy cost dear
fields.trailText: Interbrew's chief executive, Hugo Powell, was in the United States yesterday, steering well clear of the flak surrounding the company's aborted purchase of Bass Brewers.
fields.body:
Interbrew's chief executive, Hugo Powell, was in the United States yesterday, steering well clear of the flak surrounding the company's aborted purchase of Bass Brewers.

The Indian-born, Charterhouse-educated Englishman faces a struggle to hang on to his job, however. Mr Powell, 55, stands accused of one of the most expensive misjudgments in corporate history.

Unlike rival bidder Carlsberg-Tetley, Interbrew made its bid for Bass's brewing arm unconditional on regulatory clearance. That high-risk option followed advice from City law firm Simmons & Simmons.

Advisers rallied round Mr Powell yesterday. One said: "The competition commission's decision is off the scale in terms of the outcome anybody expected. If Hugo had been stemming the tide of analysts who were worried about this risk, you could point the finger at him, but the fact is that no one expected this."

An Interbrew spokesman insisted that Mr Powell's position was "absolutely not" under threat. Yet shareholders are furious - Interbrew's stock has fallen nearly 30% in two days.

Questions are being asked about why Interbrew proceeded with an £8.5bn flotation while still waiting for regulatory clearance on the deal.

Mr Powell made his name running Labatts - which was bought by Interbrew in 1995. He may yet find himself returning to his family home in Toronto - to spend more time in the fully functional pub in his front room.

webTitle: The vultures gather after Bass fiasco

fields.headline: The vultures gather after Bass fiasco
fields.standfirst: Landlords toast Byers as he calls time on Interbrew
fields.trailText: Landlords toast Byers as he calls time on Interbrew.
fields.body:
Britain's landlords are raising a glass to trade secretary Stephen Byers after his unexpected intervention to prevent the Belgian firm Interbrew from dominating the country's beer supply. "If Mr Byers came into my pub, I'd give him a free drink and a meal to go with it," said Gary McClure, landlord of the Old King's Head in Barrow-in-Furness.

Mr McClure, like many pub managers, was concerned that if Interbrew were allowed to keep the brewing operations of both Whitbread and Bass, it would pay little attention to the needs of individual pubs. He pointed out that few local boozers could boycott a supplier which controlled 78 brands, including Carling, Stella Artois, Tennent's, Worthington and Flowers: "They carry such a large range of beers that we'd have had no choice - we'd have been tied to whatever prices they stipulated."

Richard Leith, manager of the Union Rooms, a JD Wetherspoon outlet in Newcastle, agrees: "They'd have been able to charge what they like - it's scary. And what happens when their level of service falls? There's nothing you can do."

Interbrew's claim that it would "nurture local brands" simply does not wash with seasoned pub operators. Mr Leith says: "It would have diluted the English pub concept, whereby you can go into ten pubs and get ten different beers. They'd have standardised everything and when you standardise, you lose something."

Mr Byers's order that Interbrew sell Bass's brewing operations in Britain has left the Belgian company with a hangover of epic proportions. The total cost of the transaction is believed to be approaching £100m, and the company is likely to make a loss of well over £500m on selling the assets, which it bought just a few months ago for £2.3bn. So how did the world's second biggest brewer misjudge the mood of the authorities so badly?

Initially, Interbrew's argument was quite simple. It pointed out that in comparison with the rest of Europe, the British beer industry remains highly competitive, even if Interbrew and Scottish & Newcastle could each boast a market share of well over 30%.

The firm's chief executive, Hugo Powell, is fond of rattling off a list of countries in which one brewer is dominant - France, the biggest brewer has 40%, the leading player in Greece has 82% and in Denmark, Carlsberg-Tetley has 71%.

This may have swayed regulators in Brussels but it became largely irrelevant in August, when Mr Byers exercised his right to "repatriate" the investigation to Britain's competition commission.

Interbrew then changed tack, saying that although a handful of players dominated the British beer market, smaller competitors were gaining ground - citing the strong performance of regional beers such as London Pride and Old Speckled Hen.

This was blown out of the water by Carlsberg-Tetley, the third biggest beer supplier in Britain, which declared to the commission that "if the merger were to proceed, it could not survive as an independent brewer in the UK". Smaller brewers rely on the big players to distribute their beers, but the commission pointed out that there was no incentive for the likes of Interbrew to promote third-party products.

Interbrew's hopes now rest on the possibility of seeking a judicial review, although no one has ever succeeded in over turning a competition ruling in this way. The company's advisers say the commission came up with no solid evidence to suggest that Interbrew and Scottish & Newcastle could, or would, collude over pricing. One adviser said: "There are clearly some inconsistent and pretty ill-thought through arguments. How do they get to the conclusion that there will be a duopoly? It's all based on circumstantial evidence."

However, the chances of success are minimal - competition lawyer Tim Frazer of Arnold & Porter says: "They would have to come up with some very solid arguments to demonstrate that the decision was unreasonable. It's a long shot." In the meantime, the vultures are gathering - Heineken, South African Breweries and Anheuser Busch are all running their slide rules over Bass. Another fierce battle is looming for Britain's most popular beers.

fields.headline: Privates on parade
fields.trailText: The Joy of Sex | The 1940s House
fields.body:
I missed out on Dr Comfort's Joy of Sex, being preoccupied at the time with the equally popular and inevitable sequel Dr Spock's Baby and Childcare.

Alex Comfort died last year. This is never a safe sort of thing to do, as the grave-robbers are waiting. The Joy of Sex (Channel 4) was, however, unexpectedly light-hearted and loving. Which was very much in tune with his book. Apparently it was inspired by his mistress, Jane, a librarian, who asked him to jot down notes about their lovemaking, with sketches if necessary, to jog her memory. Not, perhaps, the most flattering request, but charmingly bookish.

The sketches proved absolutely necessary ("Alex was suggesting things we had never seen before") and presented a problem for the illustrators, Charles Raymond and Chris Foss. They trawled magazines. They hired Soho models. Comfort brought in Polaroids of his cavortings with Jane. Finally and secretly, Charles Raymond ("I was the bearded man!") offered to demonstrate more than 100 explicit sexual positions with his wife, Edeltraud, while Chris Foss photographed them. They were a good-looking couple - if, in Charles's case, a touch furry.

Chris takes up the commentary. "Edeltraud was very Germanic and 'Right, Charles, we start now. Position number one!' She'd tap her leg and say 'Come on, Charles!' and off they would go and do that and she would tick it off and say 'Right Charles, now we do this one!'" It was the icy winter of the miners' strike. The lights would suddenly go off but Charles and Edeltraud were generating their own electricity. Chris said "Poor old Charlie was only human, so every now and then he - how do I say it - blew it a bit. I'd say 'Charlie, you can't do it now. We've got 15 more positions and just an hour left. Charlie, can you get back into business as quick as you can?'"

Poor old Charlie became a sexual icon. And, incidentally, the inspiration for Harry Hill's Hairy Man: "Tonight, Harry, I will attempt the most dangerous sexual position known to man!"

Foss made line drawings, considered less inflammatory than film, from his photographs. The text was laid out playfully like a cookbook with starters, sauces and main dishes. Even so, the publishers were nervous and Comfort himself pretended he was only the editor. The first print-run was a timorous 10,000. The result was wholly unforeseen, like the day the young Alex Comfort, conducting a chemical experiment in his parents' greenhouse in Barnet, blew up the greenhouse and blew off his hand. The Joy of Sex just exploded. It seemed to blow Comfort's marriage to pieces too. He divorced, married Jane, and landed in America where The Joy of Sex was outselling the Bible. He felt at home in California, the epicentre of uninhibited sex, but Jane did not. They came back.

It seemed he came to resent the book, as people said "the joy of sex" and laughed.

In The 1940s House (Channel 4) the darkness thickens. "War," said 10-year-old Ben, "is not a good game. It's a lot of hard work. Especially for the elders." "By Jove!" agreed 85-year-old Marguerite Patten, "we worked hard during those years."

Where are the rissoles of yesteryear which went down so well with the boys ("Absolutely gorgeous!") and the pink blancmange in a rabbit mould ("Just perfect!"). Real rabbits, provided for food, were briskly returned to the pet shop. "It's distasteful, it's disgusting and I can't live with it," said Lyn Hymer, who, even with her hand tied up in a pudding cloth, is showing great spunk and muscle. She used to be, and you are not amazed to hear it, a tax inspector.

Speaking from experience, I advise the Hymers to move away from Kent. It's like living in a circus tent under trainee trapeze artists. I recommend siren suits, as modelled by Mr Churchill, for night air-raids. I suggest they write warmly to long lost relatives in Canada (tinned salmon) and Australia (fruit cake). And I strongly urge them to send the tasty Kirstie to Mr Lovegrove's corner shop to get their rations. Alone.

fields.headline: All-rounder batting for Blair
fields.standfirst:
Man who has succeeded as financier, publisher, author, Olympian, explorer and philanthropist finds a new cause

Talk about it
Should political donors be named?
fields.trailText: Man who has succeeded as financier, publisher, author, Olympian, explorer and philanthropist finds a new cause.
fields.body:
Christopher Ondaatje has led a remarkable life. The elder brother of the novelist Michael, Booker-winning author of The English Patient, he made his immense fortune playing Canada's fledgling stock markets in the the 60s and 70s, but there is more to him than cold-eyed financier.

Mr Ondaatje was described by one friend yesterday as "a buccaneering character", a fitting description for a man who has managed to fit stints as a publisher, author, Olympian, explorer, collector and philanthropist into his 67 years.

Before yesterday's announcement, Mr Ondaatje's most notable contribution in the UK was a £2.75m donation in 1995 to the National Portrait Gallery towards its new wing, which bears his name, opened in May last year.

His gift remained anonymous until a week before the wing was opened but the donation brought him into contact with Chris Smith, the culture secretary, a meeting which began his conversion to New Labour.

"I'm absolutely confident that through meetings with Smith after the 1997 election he would have registered that New Labour was pragmatic, not too ideological and willing to be creative," said a source close to both men. The wooing of Mr Ondaatje continued with the prime minister's friend and chief fundraiser Lord Levy spearheading Millbank's efforts to recruit him to the New Labour cause in the most tangible way possible - by making a large donation.

Mr Ondaatje says Labour contacted him in November 2000, three months after he received his CBE. During the course of these discussions he was told that Lords Hamlyn and Sainsbury were on the verge of agreeing to donate £2m each. Last month Mr Ondaatje told Labour party chiefs that he would join them.

Born in Sri Lanka, then called Ceylon, in 1933 to tea-farming parents, Mr Ondaatje was sent to Britain in 1940 to be educated at Blundells school, to which he still gives generously.

Mr Ondaatje describes himself as an odd child: "I must have been a strange boy. Tall, slim and angular, always alone, always thinking."

When he was 17, his father Mervyn died and the family business collapsed, taking Christopher's school fees with it.

Searching for a career, Mr Ondaatje attended a course in investment practice at the London School of Economics, a decision that changed his life. After hearing a lecture on share trading - "I couldn't believe my ears, I said 'How long has this been going on? This is fantastic'." - he decided on the path his life would take. Judging that Canada offered more opportunity than London to an outsider, he left Britain in 1956 and arrived in Toronto with £10 in his pocket. Within 10 years he was a millionaire.

He founded Canada's first institutional brokerage, Loewen, Ondaatje, McCutcheon & Co in 1970, and publishing house Pagurian Corporation, reckoned to be worth £500m. While in Canada he married his Latvian wife, Valda, with whom he had three children, and in the 1964 winter Olympics represented Canada in the bobsleigh event.

By the mid-1980s he had tired of Canada and, according to Charles Saumarez-Smith, director of the National Portrait Gallery, "decided to enjoy himself."

"He is interested in history, in writing, in collecting and in travel and adventure, and since returning to Britain he has indulged those passions," said Mr Saumarez-Smith.

"He is an incredibly energetic man, inventive, creative and independent-minded. He is someone who has his own views and wants to put them into practice interestingly. He is not conventional."

Mr Ondaatje has said his change of career from financier followed the discovery of a book called The Devil Drives by Fawn Brody, a biography of the Victorian explorer Sir Richard Burton, whom Mr Ondaatje would become fascinated by. That book touched a deeper part of Mr Ondaatje's psyche, and he became concerned about how he would be remembered.

"I don't want to die with financier written on my gravestone," he said. "Nobel invented gunpowder but is remembered for the Nobel Peace Prize. I have the fear of dying with the wrong acclaim."

Since discovering the life of Burton, he has traced the explorer's footsteps through Africa and India. He has written six books, including Journey to the Source of the Nile, Sindh Revisited, both accounts of his recreation of Burton's adventures, and Maneater of Punani about his Sri Lankan roots.

Yesterday when the news of his donation broke he was away from his Exmoor home, researching his next book, Hemingway in Africa.

He is an avid collector of south-east Asian art and a benefactor of numerous institutions in Canada, Sri Lanka, the Caribbean and the UK. A keen cricket fan, Somerset County Cricket Club is among them.

Mr Ondaatje is far from a silent donor. One of his passions is the Royal Geographical Society where he is a trustee, attending three meetings a year, and a member of its fund-raising advisory group trying to raise £10m over five years. He regularly attends its Monday night lecture programme and was last seen in its Kensington Gore headquarters in December listening to Sir Crispin Tickell talk about the dangers posed by near-earth objects.

"He has a lovely sense of fun, a very nice sense of humour. He comes across as immensely cultured, well-read, highly educated and a thoughtful man," said Rita Gardner, director of the Royal Geographical Society.

"He is outgoing, energetic and enthusiastic, but I've never heard him express anything about politics."

"He is hugely entertaining, distinguished and inventive, but I get the impression he is something of an outsider", said a leading figure in the art world.

"As for his approach he is a bit of a populist in the best sense of the word. He is in favour of providing access to the very best for all."

Other gifts

Ondaatje's previous donations include:

 £2.75m to the National Portrait Gallery to build the Ondaatje wing

 £10,000 a year to the Royal Society of Portrait Painters for the Ondaatje prize for portraiture

 C$1m (£465,000) to the Royal Ontaria Museum in Canada to build the Christopher Ondaatje South Asian Gallery

Other beneficiaries include: the Victoria and Albert Museum, the Royal Geographical Society, Somerset county cricket club's school of excellence in Taunton, Blundell's school in Devon, the Bermuda National Gallery; Dalhousie University, Canada, the Art Gallery of Nova Scotia, Canada, the National Ballet School of Canada, Massey University, New Zealand

webTitle: What the Travelcare ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Travelcare ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Travelcare ad says about you.
fields.body:
The ad: We open on two young women on a package holiday in the sun. They're by their hotel swimming pool, soaking up the rays and splashing about in the water. Suddenly the pool starts to rumble and the nose-cone of Thunderbird 1 begins to emerge. The girls clamber out and run away screaming as the rocket blasts off and the camera pulls back to reveal that they've unwittingly booked into Tracey Island, the secret South American destination that's home to the Thunderbirds. "Travelcare. We'll tell you what the brochure won't" reads the endline.

The jargon: With Christmas over, now's the start of the holiday booking season, and this spot is aimed at promoting Travelcare as the UK's biggest independent travel agent, offering truly honest, impartial advice to travellers. Given the current craze for all things Thunderbirds, triggered by the rerun of the classic TV series, the choice to set the ad on Tracey Island was fortuitous.

Personality: You're possibly northern (Travelcare is based in Manchester) and part of a family, probably mum or dad, although the company is trying to aim its services at younger travellers too (hence the nubile young women in the commercial). You could even be a gay couple - while researching the brand, the ad creatives posed as two male lovers wanting to book a skiing holiday.

Financial status: Travelcare offers anything from a week's snowboarding in Meribel to a weekend in West Hartlepool, so it caters for all pockets.

Telling lifestyle detail: The chances are you have been stung in the past, ending up on a building site somewhere in southern Europe instead of the sun-drenched luxury accommodation you were promised.

Other relevant data: This ad marks the first time that Thunderbirds has been mixed with live action. It was shot in Malaga, and the models of Thunderbird 1 and Tracey Island were based on the original Thunderbirds drawings.

fields.headline: MoD developing 'fuel-air' bomb
fields.standfirst: Doubts raised over legality of urban warfare device with impact of a tactical nuclear weapon
fields.trailText: Doubts raised over legality of urban warfare device with impact of a tactical nuclear weapon.
fields.body:
Britain is developing a new type of a highly controversial weapon for urban warfare that uses an overwhelming combination of heat and pressure to destroy buildings and kill the occupants.

The "thermobaric" weapon, being designed by Ministry of Defence scientists, is based on technology in "fuel-air" bombs used by Russian troops in Grozny, the Chechen capital, with an impact similar to that of a tactical nuclear weapon.

The technology was developed by the US which used "fuel-air" bombs in the 1991 Gulf war. They were designed as a replacement for napalm, widely used in Vietnam.

In a carefully-worded statement, the MoD admitted yesterday it was "investigating the possibility of a future purchase of a weapon for use by the infantry in an urban environment designed to incapacitate the occupants of a defended building".

It was intended to be a "lightweight precision weapon which must be capable of being fired by a single soldier and capable of penetrating the wall of a building rather than having to be fired through a door or window".

The MoD added the weapon "must have a limited area of effect such that it can be safely used at ranges as close as 30 metres without risk of injury to either our own troops or civilians nearby".

It said it would be "irresponsible" not to keep developments in weapons technology under review, not least to develop protective measures. If the army decided to buy the weapon, the ministry would "ensure this was fully in accordance with international law".

The weapons are particularly effective in confined spaces which amplify the shockwaves. Conventional body armour offers no protection.

Though based on similar technology to "fuel-air" weapons, it is believed the British-designed heat and pressure device will not use fuel and would be significantly smaller than US and Russian weapons.

Major Ian Orr, commander of the army's urban warfare training team, said yesterday the plan was to have the weapon available by 2005. "We are looking at two areas, offensive and defensive," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. "These things are out there, we've got to acknowledge that."

He added: "The lethality gradient is very abrupt. It is much more effective against structures than conventional high explosive. It can have serious effects on people."

The Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, said: "A lot of people in the United Kingdom will be surprised to learn that the Ministry of Defence is taking such an interest in a weapon which is designed for urban warfare."

The decision to develop the weapon raised questions "as to when and in what circumstances British forces might be expected to use a weapon that has such barbaric and severe consequences".

Under the Geneva conventions, Mr Campbell said, "countries using weapons of any kind are obliged only to use proportionate force and to ensure civilians are not subject to the indiscriminate consequences of use of that force".

Joost Hilterman, of the international campaign group Human Rights Watch, questioned whether thermobaric weapons were legal. "These are wide area weapons, and under international human rights law there are clear limits on the use of weapons whose use cannot be limited to strict military objects," he said.

"We are very concerned that these weapons would be used near population centres, thereby posing a very serious threat to innocent civilians."

Paul Rogers, professor of peace studies at Bradford University, said yesterday that "thermobaric" bombs were part of a generation of area-impact weapons which had been almost entirely overlooked by people concerned with arms control.

"The MoD appears to be being economical with the truth," he said. The devices were "devastating anti-personnel weapons".

An American army study found that weapons of the kind used by the Russians in Chechnya could have the effect of a tactical nuclear weapon without the radiation.

It said those further away from the blast site would experience crushing injuries, concussion, multiple internal haemorrhages, collapsed lungs, ruptured eardrums, and displacement of the eyes from their sockets.

webTitle: Tories lag in race to raise £15m fund for election

fields.headline: Tories lag in race to raise £15m fund for election
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Labour could be on course to achieve a historic first by raising more funds than the Tory party, which is traditionally bankrolled by big business.
fields.body:
Labour could be on course to achieve a historic first by raising more funds than the Tory party, which is traditionally bankrolled by big business.

Both parties are struggling to raise the estimated £15m needed for the forthcoming election, but the Tories' dire position in the polls is making their task particularly hard.

A recent survey showed that corporate donations to the Tories are at their lowest levels in real terms since records began.

They received £359,059 from 31 companies last year, compared with £2.5m handed over in the equivalent year of the last parliament, according to the independent analysts Labour Research.

In the run-up to the 1992 election, the Tories banked almost £5m a year in corporate donations.

Their difficulty in raising cash means that they are privately delighted by the £15m spending cap which is to be imposed on parties at the forthcoming election. The Tories spent £28m last time round compared to Labour's £26m.

Lord Ashcroft, the Tory treasurer, has succeeded in broadening the party's funding base in the last year. The number of people giving more than £5,000 to the party last year rose from 83 to 126. But this only netted an extra £800,000.

This has meant that the party is still embarrassingly dependent on Lord Ashcroft. He has given the party more than £1m a year since the general election, on top of interest-free loans of up to £2m at any one time.

His donations are supplemented by £1.2m generated by Tory constituencies. In all, the Tories have around £1m in the bank. But this is offset by an estimated debt of £9m.

Labour appears to be pulling ahead of the Tories in the funding race, but party managers have expressed concern that it too is finding it increasingly difficult to raise cash.

Labour received £22m in donations in 1999. This came from three main sources -£8.9m from donors, £6.1m from the unions and £3.7m from members. The rest came from commercial activities. The party has a deficit of around £2m.

Tony Blair is keen to highlight the breakdown of funding to show that the party is less reliant on unions for its annual £25m running costs.

However, Labour is still heavily dependent on unions at election time. The party is believed to be looking for around £12m from the unions, who have so far pledged £8m.

Some of the difficulties faced by the two main parties in raising money are similar. Labour and Tory hopes of doubling party membership, which would lead to increased subscriptions, have fizzled out. The Tories' membership remains at around 300,000, while Labour's has declined from 405,000 to 387,000.

However, the Tories are facing a greater challenge in filling the party coffers than Labour. Many businesses have given up on the Tories because of their failure to pull ahead in the polls, while others have been dismayed by the party's growing Euroscepticism.

Castlemore Securities, which gave £100,000 to the party in 1998, has ended its donations. Even Haymarket Publications, Michael Heseltine's publishing group, has abandoned the Tories. It has started giving money to the pro-European Conservative Mainstream instead.

The difficulties in raising funds, combined with embarrassment when donors are revealed, means that officials in both parties are warming to the idea of state funding. But both the Tory and Labour leaderships know that voters would strongly oppose such a move.

webTitle: Fischer sorry for violent past attack

fields.headline: Fischer sorry for violent past attack
fields.trailText: Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, last night took the extraordinary step of making a public apology after admitting taking part in a violent attack on a police officer during a radical protest in the 1970s.
fields.body:
Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, last night took the extraordinary step of making a public apology after admitting taking part in a violent attack on a police officer during a radical protest in the 1970s.

Mr Fischer's street-fighting past was brought vividly to life in a series of photographs published by Germany's Stern magazine yesterday. It was unclear whether his televised apology would head off calls for his resignation. "Huge damage has been done to the international image of Germany," said Günther Beckstein of the opposition Christian Social Union. "Fischer is no longer tenable as Germany's representative abroad."

Speaking after a meeting with his Israeli counterpart, Shlomo Ben-Ami, Mr Fischer said he owed "an apology for the wrongdoing to others". He added that he had later renounced political violence, which he described as "a tremendous mistake". His humiliation comes at an awkward moment when Germany is gradually assuming a more pro-active role in Europe. Mr Fischer initiated a controversy last year when he openly called on the EU to commit itself to an eventual federation.

The foreign minister admitted to Stern that he was the central figure in a sequence of photos that show a German policeman in riot gear apparently being lured into an ambush by demonstrators. The photos, which Stern said were taken in 1973, show the officer being beaten to the ground and then kicked by at least four protesters.

The foreign minister has also been summoned to testify later this month at the trial of a former friend accused of taking part in one of the most spectacular terrorist operations of the period - the mass kidnapping of Opec's oil ministers in Vienna in 1975.

webTitle: Peer who has swelled Labour coffers by £7m

fields.headline: Peer who has swelled Labour coffers by £7m
fields.standfirst:
Talk about it
Should political donors be named?
fields.trailText: When Lord Sainsbury, the Science minister and multimillionaire scion of the supermarket dynasty, announced yesterday he was pledging £2m to Labour's war chest, his generosity came as no surprise.
fields.body:
When Lord Sainsbury, the Science minister and multimillionaire scion of the supermarket dynasty, announced yesterday he was pledging £2m to Labour's war chest, his generosity came as no surprise.

The Labour peer, who bankrolled the SDP in the 80s, was the first Labour backer to go on the record about his largesse - revealing in September 1999 a £2m donation - the biggest ever given to the party. Since 1996 he has swelled the party's coffers by some £7m.

He can, of course, afford it. He is worth an estimated £1bn and his family fortune amounts to £2.2bn.

The annual interest on his personal fortune is reported to amount to some £35m - making him one of the few to meet the late Alan Clark's definition of the truly rich as those capable of living off the interest on the interest.

His beneficence is borne from being brought up in a family which places weight on principles. He spends more on charity than clothes, and omits Eton from his Who's Who entry because he does not want to appear a snob.

"The family is not flash," he said recently. "We inherited from somewhere a quite puritanical streak."

Critics claim his generosity to Labour is not without a desire for influence.

In 1997, shortly after being ennobled by Tony Blair, he was at the centre of controversy over accusations that a £1m donation was linked to a Sainsbury's planning application - a charge vigorously denied by the government.

In 1999 he braved calls to resign from his post as science minister since Sainsbury's has invested millions into GM food research.

He has also channelled millions into the study of genetically-modified organisms through a charitable foundation he established.

But the government insists he has been scrupulous in avoiding conflicts of interest. He resigned as chairman of the family firm on becoming a minister, placed his supermarket holdings in a blind trust and gave up policy responsibility for GM products.

One of a handful of high-profile businessman with whom the prime minister is keen to be associated, the 60-year-old, married with three daughters, entered the family firm on graduating from Cambridge. But his passions were always for science and politics rather than business.

A strong advocate of innovation, he has described himself as "romantic", defining romance as "having a vision of something you pursue that is way beyond what is reasonable."

His donation to Labour's election fund yesterday suggests thoughts of a probable second victory now seem the very antithesis of this.

fields.bodyText: When Lord Sainsbury, the Science minister and multimillionaire scion of the supermarket dynasty, announced yesterday he was pledging £2m to Labour's war chest, his generosity came as no surprise. The Labour peer, who bankrolled the SDP in the 80s, was the first Labour backer to go on the record about his largesse - revealing in September 1999 a £2m donation - the biggest ever given to the party. Since 1996 he has swelled the party's coffers by some £7m. He can, of course, afford it. He is worth an estimated £1bn and his family fortune amounts to £2.2bn. The annual interest on his personal fortune is reported to amount to some £35m - making him one of the few to meet the late Alan Clark's definition of the truly rich as those capable of living off the interest on the interest. His beneficence is borne from being brought up in a family which places weight on principles. He spends more on charity than clothes, and omits Eton from his Who's Who entry because he does not want to appear a snob. "The family is not flash," he said recently. "We inherited from somewhere a quite puritanical streak." Critics claim his generosity to Labour is not without a desire for influence. In 1997, shortly after being ennobled by Tony Blair, he was at the centre of controversy over accusations that a £1m donation was linked to a Sainsbury's planning application - a charge vigorously denied by the government. In 1999 he braved calls to resign from his post as science minister since Sainsbury's has invested millions into GM food research. He has also channelled millions into the study of genetically-modified organisms through a charitable foundation he established. But the government insists he has been scrupulous in avoiding conflicts of interest. He resigned as chairman of the family firm on becoming a minister, placed his supermarket holdings in a blind trust and gave up policy responsibility for GM products. One of a handful of high-profile businessman with whom the prime minister is keen to be associated, the 60-year-old, married with three daughters, entered the family firm on graduating from Cambridge. But his passions were always for science and politics rather than business. A strong advocate of innovation, he has described himself as "romantic", defining romance as "having a vision of something you pursue that is way beyond what is reasonable." His donation to Labour's election fund yesterday suggests thoughts of a probable second victory now seem the very antithesis of this. Useful links Labour party Committee on standards in public life

webTitle: Harry works magic on favourite names

fields.headline: Harry works magic on favourite names
fields.trailText: He has bewitched children around the world with his exploits, and now bespectacled schoolboy wizard Harry Potter appears to have worked his magic on parents as well.
fields.body:
He has bewitched children around the world with his exploits, and now bespectacled schoolboy wizard Harry Potter appears to have worked his magic on parents as well.

The soaring worldwide popularity of the children's books has helped make the name Harry one of the most popular in England and Wales, it was revealed yesterday.

Last year 5,328 boys were named Harry, launching it for the first time into the top 10 of favourite boys' names in England and Wales. Harry now stands as the sixth most popular name for a boy, the office of national statistics said.

A spokeswoman said: "We can only speculate about Harry's popularity but the only thing we can think of in the past year is Harry Potter."

The name Harry is a fairly modern phenomenon, the spokeswoman said.

In 1999 the name was given to 4,162 newborns, making it the 14th most popular boy's name, one place up on the previous year.

Harry, usually a nickname for people christened Henry as in the case of Prince Harry, was ranked 17th in 1997, while in 1994 it came in at number 30.

But number one slots went to the names Jack and Chloe. Jack has been the favourite name for boys for the past six years, while Chloe has remained at the top for girls for the past four.

For the fifth year running Thomas, James, Joshua and Daniel also stayed among the top five parents' choices.

After Chloe, Emily and Megan remain firm favourites for girls, followed by Charlotte and Jessica.

fields.headline: Shipman's victims 'total at least 230'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: Harold Shipman will today be confirmed as the biggest mass murderer known to medical history when an official government report reveals that the Cheshire GP killed 230 elderly patients - and probably in excess of 250.
fields.body:
Harold Shipman will today be confirmed as the biggest mass murderer known to medical history when an official government report reveals that the Cheshire GP killed 230 elderly patients - and probably in excess of 250.

A clinical audit of the suspicious deaths which occurred in his one-man practice at Hyde has produced what Department of Health officials called a "chilling" pattern of "excess deaths", either at home or at the surgery - often between noon and 3 pm which points to deliberate killings - usually by lethal injection.

The report, at least 1cm thick, contains tables which set out the recurring pattern.

Days after Dame Janet Smith was appointed to preside over the public inquiry into the scale of Shipman's crimes - over and above the 15 murder convictions reached against him last year - the chief medical officer of health, Liam Donaldson, will publish the report of Richard Baker of Leicester University. Professor Baker went through all the medical records of Shipman, who is serving a life sentence, during his 20 years in Hyde when his only other staff colleague was his wife, who acted as his secretary.

He delivered his report to Dr Donaldson, who had been asked to arrange the audit by the health secretary, Alan Milburn.

Although it is not clear quite how many deaths can be laid at the GP's door, it is said to be "definitely" 236, and probably 250. Taken with the 15 for which he was tried at Preston crown court, the total is around 265. No medical serial killer is ever known to have murdered so many people, outside the Nazi death camps.

His reputation warded off inquiries for years until it was found that he had lied about a conviction for drug abuse. Under the new health bill, previous convictions will have to be notified to a health authority. The Baker report will be sent to the crown prosecution service, who will decide whether to prosecute.

webTitle: Fury greets new failure to reopen city's rail station

fields.headline: Fury greets new failure to reopen city's rail station
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack shocked one of Britain's biggest cities last night by announcing that the virtual closedown of the local railway station will continue for at least another week.
fields.body:
Railtrack shocked one of Britain's biggest cities last night by announcing that the virtual closedown of the local railway station will continue for at least another week.

Only a handful of trains will be able to use Leeds City station, one of the busiest parts of the rail network, until January 15 and disruption on some lines may continue for an unspecified time beyond that.

The failure to meet the third of a series of deadlines to reopen the station infuriated business leaders in Leeds, which has been without direct links to London, Manchester, Scotland and the midlands for almost three weeks. Railtrack closed Leeds City for crucial work on a £165m rebuilding of platforms and lines at what company executives said was the quietest time of the year.

Railtrack originally promised a full reopening on January 2, a target which slipped to January 4 and then - after four days of Arctic weather - to January 8. In spite of paying 350 engineers to work round the clock, the complex building operation has gone wrong.

Robin Gisby, new director of Railtrack's London North Eastern division, apologised yesterday to passengers who have been forced to queue forlornly for "rail support buses" to take them to the nearest trains at Wakefield, Huddersfield and the suburban station of Crossgates on the York and Scotland route.

"What has gone on in recent days is clearly unacceptable," Mr Gisby said. "The frustration felt by passengers is Railtrack's responsibility and blame should not be laid at the door of the train operating companies. I have set up a full review of the Leeds project because work will clearly not be finished by January 8. It will be at least a week late."

Railtrack may decide to open one end of the station next week, allowing services across the Pennines to Manchester and Liverpool, but further delaying the London link. The issue of economic damage to Leeds is being pressed on Railtrack by the city's chamber of commerce. But retailers in smaller Yorkshire towns including Huddersfield have enjoyed a Christmas boom because of the lack of a train link to Leeds.

webTitle: Taxi drivers join tribute to victim of stabbing

fields.headline: Taxi drivers join tribute to victim of stabbing
fields.trailText: A town which saw the brutal murder of an Asian taxi driver on Christmas Eve was brought to a temporary standstill yesterday as almost every local hire car joined a commemorative procession.
fields.body:
A town which saw the brutal murder of an Asian taxi driver on Christmas Eve was brought to a temporary standstill yesterday as almost every local hire car joined a commemorative procession.

Rival taxi firms in Rotherham, South Yorkshire, abandoned business for several hours to send their cars on the slow, five mile drive from the town to a nature reserve where the victim was stabbed through the heart.

Flowers and written tributes were laid in the wooded area at Thorpe Hesley, where the body of 30-year-old Sarfraz Khan was found in his burnt-out Ford Mondeo.

A 26-year-old man, Craig Gilbert, appeared before Rotherham magistrates on Monday and was remanded in custody for a week, charged with murdering Mr Khan.

Yesterday's convoy toured Rotherham before heading out to Thorpe Hesley, where colleagues of Mr Khan also paid trubute to their "quiet, well-spoken friend".

Mr Khan had only worked for A1 taxis in Rotherham for eight days before the tragedy occured.

Police said after Mr Khan's body was found, by a local milkman on his early morning round, that the driver had been stabbed six times after apparently putting up a desperate fight.

About £100 was missing from the wrecked car.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Poet And The Astronaut | Performance On 3
fields.body:
Joe Tanner has been one of America's leading astronauts for the past eight years, spending over 500 hours in space. At the age of 50 he was in the crew sent up to add the power plant to the International Space Station. His cousin is the Welsh poet Gwyneth Lewis, whose work Zero Gravity was conceived after watching Tanner leave on the 1997 shuttle mission to repair the Hubble space telescope. In The Poet And The Astronaut (11.0am, Radio 4) the cousins compare their reactions to that mission.

The National Youth Orchestra is drawn from more than 150 of the country's best young performers, all under 20. It brings to Performance On 3 (7.30pm, Radio 3) one of its periodic live concerts, this time from the Bridgewater Hall in Manchester. Mark Elder conducts the players through a programme specially designed to show off their many talents: Tchaikovsky's Hamlet Overture, Respighi's The Pines Of Rome and Sibelius's First Symphony.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: IT spend According to Merrill Lynch, this year will see a slowdown in the growth of US IT spending.
fields.body:
 IT spend According to Merrill Lynch, this year will see a slowdown in the growth of US IT spending. The TechStrat survey of 50 US and 20 European firms suggests budget growth in the US could slow to about 5% in 2001. In contrast, the budgets of European firms are expected to continue growing strongly at 13%.

 Smart in Scotland Specialist technology firm Aspects Software announced a £12m funding round yesterday, allowing it to develop software to transform mobile phones into credit cards. The Edinburgh-based firm has set up mobEcom to exploit the growth in "m-commerce" - transactions executed via a mobile phone.

 Missed target Software group Knowledge Support Systems ' shares fell sharply yesterday as the British firm said its full year revenues would miss earlier market forecasts.

 Scaled back US-based financial net magazine Motley Fool has closed its German-language site because it was unable to find a German partner due to market turbulence. The closure comes in the wake of other content providers scaling back operations: Neuer Market-listed Tomorrow Internet said in December it was shedding 20 staff, and in November, Motley's US rival TheStreet was forced to cut 111 jobs and end its UK operation.

fields.headline: No sex please, we're famous
fields.standfirst: On celebrity celibacy
fields.trailText: On celebrity celibacy.
fields.body:
Okay, so where's MY fake celebrity boyfriend? This is getting ridiculous. How come Geri Halliwell gets to go on holiday with one of the country's sexiest men - who is also, let us not forget, officially addicted to sex - and pretend just to be friends with him? I realise that staring fixedly at a jam doughnut while holding a yoga position, or whatever it is she does all day, is pretty difficult, but this just seems rum. Perhaps she is skiing down hills shouting: "Well, Billie Piper got a Ferrari."

Interesting, that one. Billie doesn't exactly strike one as a "rules" girl, does she? But here she is, getting all the cars and holding back all the sex. I have to say, she is definitely being a role model of sorts, which is pretty good for a girl who has made it on, frankly, looking like she's constantly up for it. In similar circumstances, I suspect I'd be more like the page three model Jordan, a woman apparently so unable to let it lie that her ex-boyfriend, pop "star" (in the broadest sense of the word) Dane Bowers is having to release a single to tell her to please, calm down a wee bit. But Billie, Britney, Jessica Simpson . . . there's definitely a new bunch, all not going at it like rabbits.

This is possibly just good old far-sighted wisdom. You can't get two of the egos required to get famous - the sheer work, time, effort and "me, me, me"-ness of it - into one relationship. You need one at the front and one to applaud, which is why people like Cilla Black marry nice, quiet guys and stay married forever. Even David Beckham is clearly a low-key kind of man who just happens to be a supernatural genius at one particularly in-demand thing, but who is generally pretty happy to stand back watching his wife do her thing. What is her thing again?

Anyway, avoiding fuelling the inevitable press bunfight which the celebrity break-up invariably precipitates might just be the latest thing. Sensible celebrities! God, how unbelievably boring. Just as well we have Amanda Holden, who may have demurely married her old geezer, but didn't let it stop her for a moment.

Still, on the whole, abstemious female celebrities appear to leave the rest of us in with a shout with all the male celebrity talent out there. Doesn't it tell you a lot about the state of our benefits sys tem when women will go out with Michael "big tits" Winner to escape it? And by far the best website I've found in ages is lucycarr.com, a simple story of how a humble, pretty country girl "borrowed" her boss's company car, got falsely signed off work for depression, and set off to make it in the wonderful world of lapdancing, on the way managing to pick up Peter Stringfellow.

The site is hilarious and bizarrely insightful. There's one paragraph on how romantic Stringfellow is and four pages listing the various gifts she has been bought. My personal favourite is the DIY page on how to lapdance for your own man. "You will need . . . a chair. Make up AND toiletries. Try not to nic [sic] yourself whilst shaving." As a word of warning, it does describe in fairly gruesome detail what it's like to have Peter Stringfellow come on to you - he pulls you behind curtains apparently - so you probably shouldn't read it on your own late at night.

I've never had a sugar daddy, as Winner and Stringfellow clearly are and Chris Evans clearly aspires to: unfortunately almost all of my body is real. Now, however, as the starlets are all mysteriously behaving themselves (Bless you, Amanda), they must finally be stooping to us mere mortals. And you know, girls, I hear Jim Davidson is available - and he has a double garage!

Actually, a minor confession. When I sold my first novel, I suddenly found that I had become a much more interesting person at parties than when I was explaining in great detail the intricacies of health management policy. Odd that. Anyway, I did eventually get carried away by the possibilities, and dated the most beautiful young Adonis, but it got too much . . . every time we walked in places people would look at me rather strangely, with thoughtful looks on their faces. Thoughts such as (I imagine): "Is that his older sister?"; or, "Does he come by the hour?"; or worse, "I wonder what her weird oriental trick is?" So I gave up being a sugar mummy, but I have to admit I can see the appeal. Now I just need to tempt some cute young celebrities. Which, I seem to remember, is where Robbie came in . . .

 Jenny Colgan's new novel, Talking to Addison, is out now on Harper Collins, price £5.99.

webTitle: Country Diary notches up its 50th anniversary

fields.headline: Lakeland love letters
fields.standfirst: 'Write about anything you like, but keep off birds,' the editor told A Harry Griffin . Today, half a million words later, his Country Diary notches up its 50th anniversary
fields.trailText: 'Write about anything you like, but keep off birds,' the editor told A Harry Griffin . Today, half a million words later, his Country Diary notches up its 50th anniversary
fields.body:
There have been 1,300 altogether, one every other Monday for 50 years. Little love letters, I suppose you could call them - my Country Diary pieces from the Lake District. They started when King George VI was on the throne, Clem Attlee the prime minister, and Tony Blair not even a glint in his father's eye. The Korean war had just started, with British troops in action: only five years earlier I had still been serving with the "forgotten" 14th Army in Burma.

Then, one day towards the end of 1950, right out of the blue, the late AP Wadsworth, editor of what was then the Manchester Guardian, wrote to me - I think he also telephoned - and asked whether I would like to contribute to the paper's Country Diary once a fortnight. We had never met, nor even, probably, heard of each other, but I think my immediate predecessor, the gifted George W Muller of Cockermouth, an original member of the climbing club to which I belonged, who had just died at the age of 75, might have mentioned me. I can think of no other reason why my obscure ramblings about the Lake District in a Lancashire evening paper had come to be known within the august portals of the Guardian. I had known and admired the paper for years, especially the writings of Neville Cardus, partly because, for a few years before the war, I had been the northern music critic of another national paper - also with offices in Deansgate, Manchester. (This had been a fiddle, on my part, in order to get free tickets for the Halle concerts. To my lasting regret I never met Cardus, for I had to dash out at the end of each concert, sometimes before the end, to rush off my piece for the paper).

Wadsworth's instructions were simple and to the point. "Write about anything you like," he ordered, "but for God's sake, keep off birds. We get all we want about them from the others," meaning the other diarists. I had to send off my first piece in time for the first Monday in January 1951, and have continued, without a break, ever since - nearly half a million words about hills, snow, tarns, stone walls, red deer, golden eagles, breathtaking scenery and a host of other important things. By and large, I have tried to follow these original instructions, during successive editorships, and kept off birds in general, especially small birds - not being a confirmed twitcher - but have felt free to write, now and again, about mountain birds such as ravens and peregrines and, especially, that magnificent, newly returned denizen of the Lake District, the golden eagle.

In those distant days 50 years ago we remained in comparative obscurity, identified only by our initials. So I was AHG, unknown and unsung, for 15 years until, in May 1966, the decision was made, no doubt at the highest level, that we should be named. No longer could we skulk in decent oblivion: suddenly, we were thrust into the limelight. From now on readers would know who we were, perhaps even talk to us in the streets. We would have to be most careful in our revelations.

Then there was one day, I think in the early 1970s, when we country cousins were invited down to London to lunch with the Guardian hierarchy. They wanted to see what we looked like and have us photographed. Perhaps they thought we would have straw in our hair, but I seem to remember we appeared pretty ordinary, although on the elderly side. But the talk over the wine was certainly wide-ranging and it was a rare chance, for me at least, to get a whiff of city air. Alastair Hetherington, editor of the Guardian for many years until 1975, who had a cottage in the Lake District near my home, became a close friend. We often walked the hills together and now and again did some rock-climbing - my principal passion for a lifetime. Although rock-climbing, winter mountaineering and skiing - apart from classical music - were my main interests I generally avoided these in my Country Diary pieces, believing they would not interest the average reader, and concentrated, instead, on the hills in more general terms.

Originally, and for many years, I wrote from "Westmorland" but after this ancient, splendid, unspoiled county was wiped off the map by Whitehall in 1974 it has usually been the "Lake District". Occasionally, though, when writing about an area just outside the national park - to cock a snook at authority - I have written from "Old Westmorland" hoping that the Whitehall mandarins would notice this. I have also written, frequently, from the Howgills, the Yorkshire Dales, the Northern Pennines and often from my beloved Scottish Highlands, which I know far better than any part of England south of the Lake District. And I have also written from the Alps and the Canadian Rockies but, for the most part, from lovely Lakeland - now sadly, because of mass tourism, not quite the place I knew as a boy, but still the most beautiful corner in England. Although the traffic and the crowds and the tawdriness of some of the "honeypots" infuriate me at times I wouldn't live anywhere else - and at least I know where to find the quiet places.

I have certainly enjoyed writing these love letters. They have attracted an enormous correspondence - several letters every weekend - and I have replied to every one. Indeed, in old age, letter writing now seems my main activity! Two of my 12 books - A Year in the Fells (Robert Hale,1976) and A Lakeland Mountain Diary (The Crowood Press, 1990) - were based on my Country Diary . webTitle: Richard Norton-Taylor on released government papers

fields.headline: For their eyes only
fields.standfirst:
The papers released each year by the public record office may be interesting, but they are not the whole story

Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The papers released each year by the public record office may be interesting, but they are not the whole story.
fields.body:
This new year, as in years past, a group of journalists launched their annual sortie on the public record office in Kew, south-west London. Their target? Thousands of documents released by Whitehall departments under the "30-year rule".

For two days, we rummage through a selection of yellowing papers helpfully provided by the PRO's press officers. They are a small fraction of the newly available files, chosen for their contemporary resonance or subject matter and deemed suitable for a mass audience.

This year, for example, we were shown files on Northern Ireland, Britain's relations with Europe and the arrest in Colombia of Bobby Moore, England's soccer captain, before the 1970 World Cup in Mexico. There were some intriguing nuggets - for instance, Harold Wilson's Labour government contemplating prosecuting Peter Hain, now a Foreign Office minister, for conspiracy over his campaign to stop a tour by the South African cricket team, and MI5's secret contacts with the former dockers' leader, Brian Nicholson.

Other documents bring on a depressing sense of plus ça change, how successive governments continually reinvent the wheel and are obsessed with the press. We could read how Solly Zuckerman, chief scientific adviser to the Ministry of Defence, told Wilson 30 years ago: "Nuclear weapons can be regarded as having a greater political than military significance." And how Whitehall mandarins, as aghast then as now at the thought of reforming the Official Secrets Act, advised ministers that a "public interest defence" was "clearly unacceptable".

Hundreds more documents are released under what Whitehall quaintly calls "extended closures" - papers which have been withheld for 50, 75, even 100 years. Yet many are utterly banal. Why is it considered appropriate now, and not before, for us to read that a British diplomat in 1950 described Eva Perón as "dangerous" and Argentina an "adolescent Latin American country"?

The answer is that what papers are released, and when, is decided almost entirely arbitrarily by unaccountable officials in the historical records sections of Whitehall departments. They weed as well as select. Missing this time are files relating to the now-defunct Communist party of Great Britain, to Northern Ireland and to evidence, as the cabinet secretary put it 30 years ago, that "[not] everything in the intelligence world is perfect, far from it".

The term "public records" is a misnomer. The PRO officially defines them as "administrative and departmental records of the Crown". Whitehall can withhold files on the grounds that they contain "exceptionally sensitive" material relating to national security, defence, international relations, or contain information supplied in confidence whose disclosure would constitute a "breach of good faith".

Papers can be withheld if their disclosure would cause "substantial distress" to individuals or their descendants. This, according to officials, is why papers on the 1936 abdication crisis, and also on the royal family's relations with pre-second world war right-wing opinion, will not be released at least until after the death of the Queen Mother.

The PRO itself admits these obstacles to disclosure are, in its words, "so wide" that few people bother to appeal against them. But there is more. Under section 3 (4) of the Public Records Acts, Whitehall departments can hold on to documents indefinitely for "administrative purposes" or "for any other special reason" subject to the approval, never knowingly withheld, of the lord chancellor - the minister officially responsible for the nation's archives.

Absolute discretion is the name of the game. Despite official rules that once a file has been shown to one person, it should be available to all, Whitehall, and notably security and intelligence agencies, gives privileged access to documents to approved writers. And despite strict rules covering the preservation of documents, some have been destroyed.

Sir Edward Heath, chief whip at the time, revealed in his memoirs two years ago that Sir Anthony Eden ordered the destruction of his copy of the secret plan to invade Egypt agreed with France and Israel during the 1956 Suez crisis. This writer has been told by a cabinet office source that papers on the 1985 Westland crisis have also been destroyed.

The PRO is a precious resource under its keeper, Sarah Tyacke. But it needs more support and resources to inject into closed Whitehall battalions the culture of openness shared by its small band of archivists.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Jiri Hodac, the Czech state television chief at the centre of a journalists' strike and mass protests over alleged political bias, was in a serious condition in a Prague hospital yesterday. The nature of his illness was not disclosed.
fields.body:
New threat to Czech TV boss

Jiri Hodac, the Czech state television chief at the centre of a journalists' strike and mass protests over alleged political bias, was in a serious condition in a Prague hospital yesterday. The nature of his illness was not disclosed.

The furore has prompted the Social Democrat cabinet to hasten a move to dismiss the committee of politicians which appointed him and replace it with a body representing professional and civic groups.
Reuters, Prague

Bomb drama in Lisbon office

An armed man accompanied by his wife and two daughters burst into the Portuguese state television (RTP) offices in Lisbon yesterday and threatened to set off a homemade bomb.

The man, who is involved in a protracted dispute with RTP for damages following a 1994 report on his company, gave himself up eight hours later. No one was hurt.
AP, Lisbon

Laundry lifeline for woman, 84

A Spanish woman of 84 survived a six-storey fall when her descent was broken by neighbours' washing lines.

The woman, who was hanging out washing on a balcony when she lost her balance and fell 17 metres (55ft) from her central Madrid flat, suffered a broken arm.
AP, Madrid

Five die in Brazil shop shootout

Five people were killed and 10 hurt in a gun battle at a supermarket in Jacarei, Sao Paulo state, between security guards and a gang trying to rob an armoured car.

Five robbers disguised as shoppers opened fire on the van when it arrived at 6pm on Wednesday. Two shoppers - one a seven-months pregnant woman - a cashier, an off-duty policeman and a robber died.
Reuters, Sao Paulo

Dutch fire 'due to sparklers'

The owner of the nightclub in the Dutch town of Volendam where a fire on New Year's Eve killed eight and fatally injured two others blamed sparklers for the blaze. Jan Veerman said yesterday a youngster waving the sparklers ignited Christmas tree branches.
AP, Volendam

webTitle: Parents defend breast implants for girl, 15

fields.headline: Parents defend breast implants for girl, 15
fields.trailText: When Jenna Franklin's parents were organising their daughter's 16th birthday present - a breast enlargement operation - they did not expect it to cause such a furore.
fields.body:
When Jenna Franklin's parents were organising their daughter's 16th birthday present - a breast enlargement operation - they did not expect it to cause such a furore.

But Martin and Kay Franklin, who run a company offering plastic surgery, were criticised by health professionals yesterday for encouraging Jenna to have the £3,250 operation.

Jenna, of Warsop Vale, near Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, said she had been thinking about breast enlargement since she was 12. She insisted yesterday: "You've got to have breasts to be successful.

"Every other person you see on television has had implants. I used to pray that my boobs would grow. Then I just thought, what's the point when I can have implants when I want?"

She will be 16 in August. "I just want to be happy with my body and I think having my breasts enlarged will give me more self-confidence."

Her father Martin said he and his wife had been in the plastic surgery industry for a number of years, "so all our children have grown up with plastic surgery. They don't see anything wrong with it and neither do we".

His wife, who has had two breast implant operations, said she wanted her daughter to "feel confident about the way she looks. If that means having breast implants, then so be it. If Jenna has not developed enough, then she will have to wait".

Jenna features in a Channel 4 documentary, Perfect Breasts, to be screened next week, which examines the motivations of teenagers who want larger breasts.

A spokesman for the British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons expressed surprise that any surgeon would carry out the procedure on such a young girl without a psychological assessment.

David Dunaway, a Harley Street plastic surgeon, said he would be concerned about her psychological and physical development.

"Somebody of this age may not have reached psychological or physical maturity," he said. "We would have to decide if it is appropriate, depending on whether she is mature enough. The potential complications and the downside of the operation would have to be made quite clear."

He said he would recommend a psychological assessment before going ahead. "I would not rule it out, but I would make absolutely sure it was not just a whim to get someone through a difficult phase in late adolescence.".

Eileen Bradbury, a psychologist who advises surgeons at the Alexandra Hospital in Cheadle, Cheshire, said she was particularly worried that Jenna wanted the operation so that she could be successful.

"That is a very disturbing belief for a 15-year-old girl to have, and also a false one," she said. "I have seen women coming for surgery who work in television and they say they have to have it done or they won't get the work. I usually go along with that because it is probably true.

"But to be successful in life, or in a relationship, is a completely different matter. Implants are totally irrelevant. Of all the cosmetic operations, implants are the one you have to be most careful about."

She said she was concerned that Jenna's mother had had plastic surgery herself.

Linda Blair, a clinical psychologist from the University of Bath, said Mrs Franklin was giving "the wrong message to her daughter - she should be saying you are beautiful already and I love you unconditionally".

Christine Williamson, of the Silicone Support Group, which offers help and advice to those whose breast implants become faulty, described it as the birthday present from hell. "She could be buying her daughter a lifetime of misery and suffering," she said.

"Lots of people are late developers and it is ridiculous to consider a breast enlargement operation at this age. These implants only have a lifespan of about four years, if she is lucky."

Ms Williamson said there was a growing problem of young women having breast enlargement surgery. "Girls with small breasts are made to feel inadequate, but they don't realise that implants can make them ill."

webTitle: New suspension at young offender unit

fields.headline: New suspension at young offender unit
fields.trailText: The prison service confirmed yesterday that a man was suspended from a troubled young offenders' institution after allegations that the deputy governor assaulted an inmate.
fields.body:
The prison service confirmed yesterday that a man was suspended from a troubled young offenders' institution after allegations that the deputy governor assaulted an inmate.

Police have been called in to investigate the claims at Portland Young Offenders' Institution after the complaint was made during the Christmas period. The institution is currently at the centre of a separate police investigation into alleged beatings by warders over a 14-year period.

Four other officers were suspended in August last year, after allegations of abuse of inmates were highlighted by the pressure group, the Howard League for Penal Reform. The prison service immediately called in police.

No charges have yet been brought by police against the four officers.

The prison service yesterday refused to name the latest staff member to be suspended, but said the incident was not linked to the police inquiry.

In a statement, the prison service said: "We can confirm that a senior member of staff at Portland Young Offenders' Institution was suspended on December 26 last year pending an investigation into allegations that he assaulted a prisoner. The allegation has been referred to the police."

Last March conditions at Portland were criticised in a report by the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, as a "moral outrage".

Press Association

webTitle: 'Romania with burgers' jibe makes Walsall turn ugly

fields.headline: 'Romania with burgers' jibe makes Walsall turn ugly
fields.trailText: Walsall may not be best known for its picturesque landscape but a critic's recent description of the Black Country town as "Ceaucescu's Romania with fast food outlets" has proved too much for its outraged residents.
fields.body:
Walsall may not be best known for its picturesque landscape but a critic's recent description of the Black Country town as "Ceaucescu's Romania with fast food outlets" has proved too much for its outraged residents.

Council leader Mike Bird yesterday led the backlash against art critic Theodore Dalrymple, who launched a vicious attack on the town writing under a pseudonym in American art magazine New Criterion.

The article, titled Crudity Beyond Belief, refers to Walsall as one of the "most depressing areas of urban devastation" in the world, dismissing the internationally acclaimed New Art Gallery as resembling a post-modernist grain silo.

"It is possible that there are uglier towns in the world than Walsall, but if so I do not know them. While Walsall undoubtedly exists, it is difficult to know where precisely it begins and ends, because it is in the middle of one of the largest and most depressing contiguous areas of urban devastation in the world," Mr Dalrymple claims.

Mr Bird said yesterday such criticisms of the town and gallery were totally unwarranted and dismissed them as nonsense. "I have no time for people who remain anonymous and haven't got the guts to stand up and be counted. He should keep his ridiculous views to himself. Walsall is a town which is working hard to pull itself up by its bootstraps and the gallery has received international acclaim."

The town hit the headlines last year when a resident, George Roper, launched an "Ugly-Walsall" website, which features photographs of boarded-up buildings, and other eyesores.

However, its new £21m lottery-funded art gallery, designed by architects Caruso St John, brought more positive publicity to the town after bursting on to the international art map to a rapturous reception from critics around the world.

Descriptions such as "a beautiful collection of spaces", "a world class gallery" and "stunningly beautiful" appear to be at odds with Mr Dalrymple's negative experience of the building and its surroundings.

"One veers between thinking oneself in a fascist foreign ministry and a sauna of gigantic proportions," he complains.

He adds: "There is nowhere in the world where it is possible to travel such long distances without seeing anything grateful to the eye. The Black Country looks like Ceaucescu's Romania with fast food outlets."

Mr Bird last night branded Mr Dalrymple as a narrow-minded individual, who would be "better off staying wherever he lives".
