Council leader Mike Bird yesterday led the backlash against art critic Theodore Dalrymple, who launched a vicious attack on the town writing under a pseudonym in American art magazine New Criterion. The article, titled Crudity Beyond Belief, refers to Walsall as one of the "most depressing areas of urban devastation" in the world, dismissing the internationally acclaimed New Art Gallery as resembling a post-modernist grain silo. "It is possible that there are uglier towns in the world than Walsall, but if so I do not know them. While Walsall undoubtedly exists, it is difficult to know where precisely it begins and ends, because it is in the middle of one of the largest and most depressing contiguous areas of urban devastation in the world," Mr Dalrymple claims. Mr Bird said yesterday such criticisms of the town and gallery were totally unwarranted and dismissed them as nonsense. "I have no time for people who remain anonymous and haven't got the guts to stand up and be counted. He should keep his ridiculous views to himself. Walsall is a town which is working hard to pull itself up by its bootstraps and the gallery has received international acclaim." The town hit the headlines last year when a resident, George Roper, launched an "Ugly-Walsall" website, which features photographs of boarded-up buildings, and other eyesores. However, its new £21m lottery-funded art gallery, designed by architects Caruso St John, brought more positive publicity to the town after bursting on to the international art map to a rapturous reception from critics around the world. Descriptions such as "a beautiful collection of spaces", "a world class gallery" and "stunningly beautiful" appear to be at odds with Mr Dalrymple's negative experience of the building and its surroundings. "One veers between thinking oneself in a fascist foreign ministry and a sauna of gigantic proportions," he complains. He adds: "There is nowhere in the world where it is possible to travel such long distances without seeing anything grateful to the eye. The Black Country looks like Ceaucescu's Romania with fast food outlets." Mr Bird last night branded Mr Dalrymple as a narrow-minded individual, who would be "better off staying wherever he lives".

webTitle: Paris van guard's murder prompts stoppage

fields.headline: Paris van guard's murder prompts stoppage
fields.trailText: Brink's armoured van guards in Paris, furious at the murder of yet another of their colleagues, called a wildcat strike yesterday less than a month after legislation to improve their safety conditions was passed.
fields.body:
Brink's armoured van guards in Paris, furious at the murder of yet another of their colleagues, called a wildcat strike yesterday less than a month after legislation to improve their safety conditions was passed.

Emergency talks were under way last night between the guards' unions, the country's leading security firms, their clients and the transport and interior ministries to avoid a repeat of the crippling two-week stoppage in May which emptied France's 33,000 cash points within days and caused chaos in shops and banks.

The police said that Jean-Luc Hulot, 40, was shot at point-blank range on Wednesday while refilling a cash dispenser at a busy hospital in the Paris suburb of Villejuif.

He was the 15th security van guard killed in France in five years, and the fifth in the past year.

Hundreds more guards and drivers have been injured.

Two masked men opened fire on Mr Hulot and his driver in the middle of a crowded concourse, where about 40 staff, patients and visitors were shopping or having lunch. The robbers got away with £45,000 in cash.

The incident came a week after a spectacular attack on another armoured Brink's van, in which no one was killed. A dozen men carrying automatic rifles, machine guns and a shoulder-held missile-launcher surprised the van near the Paris ringroad and punched huge holes in its side before fleeing with £3.4m.

Hervé Lafranque, head of the serious crimes squad, said yesterday that he estimated that about 30 highly organised gangs specialising in security-van robberies were currently operating in France.

The extreme violence used by some of the gangs was a new phenomenon, and very worrying, he said. He added that there were also new, younger gangs emerging, which were less professional, less well-prepared, and therefore likely to be even more dangerous.

After the May strike, new safety measures - including surveillance cameras and structural alterations at vulnerable banks, shops and cash points - were agreed in June and became law on December 19. The banks, which have complained that the measures were unrealistic and far too expensive, have been given until the end of 2002 to carry out the work.

"For two years we're going to get attacked, we're going to get killed," said Jacques Charles, a Brink's guard for 30 years. "We're demanding immediate measures. We're not going to walk straight into a slaughter."

The leading guards' unions said they would wait for the outcome of the meeting before deciding whether to call members out in sympathy with the Brink's employees in the Paris region.

"This matter is now of the greatest possible urgency," said Roger Poletti of Force Ouvrière.

"We couldn't give a toss about meetings and discussions. Men are dying because the government and security firms' clients are not prepared to spend a few extra francs."

webTitle: Cruel end for sport loving boy

fields.headline: Cruel end for sport loving boy
fields.trailText: The sports trophies and photographs adorning the mantelpiece of Carol Raven's home portray a boy brimming with health who dreamed of playing for Spurs.
fields.body:
The sports trophies and photographs adorning the mantelpiece of Carol Raven's home portray a boy brimming with health who dreamed of playing for Spurs. But shortly before Christmas, when Marc Raven died, his shrivelled body weighed less than six stone and he was racked with pain, unable to speak, smile, eat or even wash himself. He was 18.

Mrs Raven, of Westcliff-on-Sea, Essex, believes she effectively lost her son in November 1994, when he was given an MMR vaccination at school. Hours later Marc complained of a blinding headache. Over the next few months his speech became slurred and his behaviour and movements confused and clumsy.

Mrs Raven, a mother of seven, is adamant she will not not allow her three-year-old twins Callum and Kayne, daughters Michaela, four, and Bobbianna, six, and son Matthew, 15, the MMR vaccine she believes caused Marc's death. Another daughter, Claire, 20, also received the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine and has suffered recurrent bowel problems since, in common with other suspected victims.

Mrs Raven said that after the vaccination, Marc "started to look vacant and then later he would just fall over inexplicably. He went on to develop severe behavioural problems and would often become confused and aggressive."

Doctors thought it was epilepsy but when he deteriorated further he was admitted to Great Ormond Street hospital. Doctors there diagnosed subacute sclerosing panencephalitis,a rare, slow but fatal degeneration of the brain. It is seen in children and young adults and occurs six to eight years after the initial measles attack.

Mrs Raven said: "As my son never had measles, it didn't add up at first. Then the specialists kept asking me whether he had received MMR and I wondered why the question was so important to them.

"The only reason I agreed for Marc to have the vaccine was because my daughter was just nine months old and the health visitor said measles was a great risk to a young baby and put me under a fair amount of pressure to have it done.

"Now, I live in constant fear that my remaining children could catch measles but there's no way I would go for the triple vaccination. I would need to know it was 100% safe and my other children wouldn't end up dying in agony like Marc."

fields.headline: At this price?  Chorion
fields.trailText: Entertainment company Chorion had a lucrative Christmas, as revellers packed into its trendy Tiger, Tiger and On Anon late-night bars. The firm specialises in chameleon outlets which begin the evening as restaurants, later turning into drinks-led bars and nightclubs.
fields.body:
Entertainment company Chorion had a lucrative Christmas, as revellers packed into its trendy Tiger, Tiger and On Anon late-night bars. The firm specialises in chameleon outlets which begin the evening as restaurants, later turning into drinks-led bars and nightclubs.

A trading update yesterday said like-for-like sales leapt 18% during December, with six new openings pushing total takings up 135% to £5.3m.

These figures bode well for others in the industry - none of the bigger players have yet reported on their Christmas perfomances. Chorion's finance director, Malcolm Gardner, said: "The feeling is that it was a generally good Christmas period for everyone. There was no sign of the post-millennium lull that people feared."

Chorion's shares, however, were subdued, edging up just 1p to 38p. The stock, listed on the Alternative Investment Market, has barely moved since this column tipped it in October. The City is not keen on the company's structure - as well as nightclubs, it has an unrelated business which exploits the intellectual property rights to cartoon characters such as Noddy. Investors are keen for a demerger, to allow the two elements to flourish independently, although some doubt the intellectual property side is big enough to be unleashed alone. Chorion says it is in talks to buy the rights to more characters which, if successful, could provide critical mass.

A demerger is unlikely before April, by which time Chorion will have a three-year trading record, allowing it to synchronise a split with a move from Aim to the main market. Analysts at Old Mutual Securities reckon the combined value of the two entities will be worth 64p a share.

In the meantime, the firm's Tiger, Tiger bars are burning bright, with more openings planned here and abroad. Broker Teather & Greenwood expects profits of £9.2m this year. The firm has a market capitalisation of £194m. Hold, in the hope of action later this year.

webTitle: Game's up for six Future titles

fields.headline: Game's up for six Future titles
fields.trailText: Magazine publisher Future Network, which specialises in computer game and new technology titles, issued its second profit warning yesterday in less than two months.
fields.body:
Magazine publisher Future Network, which specialises in computer game and new technology titles, issued its second profit warning yesterday in less than two months.

Future is considering the closure of more than six titles within weeks, after disappointing Christmas sales throughout Europe and a decline in advertising revenues.

Chief executive Greg Ingham also reiterated the group's frustrations over delays in Sony's roll-out of its much-hyped Playstation2. He said 30% of Future's revenues came from games magazines but this Christmas there had been few big attractions in the console market.

"We rely on reviewing the games for these products," he said. "When Sony delayed its launch it had severe knock-on effects for us: we had spent money on people, promotions and print runs. In the end advertisers were lost or put back."

The group, which publishes more than 130 titles worldwide, said it had reduced its profit estimate for 2000 from £40m to £34m, after November figures showed no expected seasonal upturn. It has lowered its sales expectation from £260m to £253m. Shares in the group closed down 64p at 80p yesterday.

The revision comes on top of an announcement in November that the company was cutting its underlying profits estimate by £6m, citing an overstatement of earnings at its French business; a weak advertising market; and delays in the launch of next-generation games consoles such as Sony's Playstation2.

Ingham said that the severity of these problems had been underestimated. He said dwindling advertising budgets among embattled hi-tech businesses had hit Future hard because its portfolio was focused on computer games, PCs, internet products and the new economy.

"Problems in the technology sector have created a more cautious environment and we have been affected by that."

Future also announced that it expects to post a one-off £10m charge in its results for the year to end-December after writing down the goodwill value of its German games titles and a number of internet investments.

Mr Ingham said that some cuts would now be considered, including the closure of some titles. "If there are magazines which are taking too long to come through for us, we will have to walk away," he said.

He would not say which publications were likely to fold but one source said at least six would to go in the near future, with others put under review.

Future's investment budget for 2001 will also be cut from £30m to £20m in an effort to stave off further losses, he said. But one source said this could store up problems for the future, possibly creating a sales slowdown in two years time.

Mr Ingham said the need for a second profits warning had, in part, been due to difficulties in anticipating revenues from magazines sold on a sale or return basis in Europe. As a result he warned that the latest profits estimate was subject to a £2m margin of error, with the results not expected to be available until February.

In a separate announcement, Future said it had handed its UK distribution business to Seymour Distribution, whose clients already include Time Out and John Brown Publishing.

webTitle: Mystery of Saddam Hussein's health deepens

fields.headline: Dead or alive?
fields.standfirst:
Mystery of Saddam Hussein's health deepens
Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Mystery of Saddam Hussein's health deepens.
fields.body:
Iraq-watchers took out their magnifying glasses yesterday to scrutinise pictures from Baghdad purportedly showing Saddam Hussein chairing a cabinet meeting.

Depending on who you believe, the Iraqi leader is dead, incapacitated ... or his usual robust self.

The latest rumours surfaced after a military parade on Sunday in which President Saddam stood for four or five hours, saluting the troops as they marched past by firing a rifle into the air.

"He fired more than 142 rifle shots, using one hand," said an Iraqi government spokesman, Salam Khatab. "Most of the youth could not do such."

But according to Iranian-backed opposition sources, he suffered a severe stroke during or shortly after the parade.

Other opposition sources in London suggest that he had a minor stroke or heart attack.

The Saudi-owned al-Hayat newspaper, citing "trusted Iraqi sources", said that President Saddam had felt chest pains and had been taken to hospital, where a medical team under Dr Aziz Mahmoud Shukri "confirmed to those accompanying the president that he was suffering the effects of standing for a long time in the cold".

On Wednesday Iraqi television showed the president, who is officially 63, looking his usual self as he walked into the cabinet room wearing a brown suit, but there was no way of confirming when the film was shot.

An official denial of his illness as "a nonsensical fabrication that is not even worth responding to" did little to dampen the speculation.

Some analysts even saw the denial as suspicious, noting that the Iraqi authorities do not usually comment on such reports.

But a Kurdish opposition source in London suggested that the reports could be part of a disinformation campaign by President Saddam himself. "His security service spreads rumours that he is dangerously ill or has been assassinated, then after a few days you see him making a speech on TV."

The purpose might be to flush out opponents of the regime.

In July, when he made an odd and unusually short speech to mark the 32nd anniversary of the coup that brought his Ba'ath party to power, there were claims that he was seriously ill. Two weeks later, and apparently in good health, he welcomed President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela to Iraq and personally drove him on a tour of Baghdad.

In September there were reports that he was about to undergo chemotherapy for lymph cancer.

A subsequent Israeli report said the story was based on a misunderstanding: the treatment was for a senior member of his regime.

Analysts were reluctant yesterday to commit themselves either way. Most agreed that if he were dead or seriously ill the regime might well conceal it until his successor's position had been secured.

Few expect a smooth transition, because of the rivalry between his two sons, Uday, 36, and Qusay, 34.

Qusay, who runs the Special Security Organisation and the Special Republican Guard, seems to be the favoured successor.

Uday, a playboy, runs several Iraqi media organisations and is said by opposition groups to be a rapist, a serial killer, and heavily involved in oil smuggling. Last year he was elected to parliament in a Baghdad constituency with 99.9% of the vote.

fields.headline: Sony invests in Silicon Radio
fields.trailText: Cambridge Silicon Radio, the British silicon chip maker, has completed a funding round of between $45m (£30m) and $50m with an investment of more than $3m by Sony.
fields.body:
Cambridge Silicon Radio, the British silicon chip maker, has completed a funding round of between $45m (£30m) and $50m with an investment of more than $3m by Sony.

The unlisted company would not reveal the exact size of the Sony investment but said the Japanese company was just one contributor to the final $8m stage of its third round funding.

Hinting at further collaboration with Sony, CSR managing director and co-founder Phil O'Donovan said: "We have been trying to bring in corporations who would be natural customers for us."

Sony will join other investors including Compaq, Philips, Intel Capital and fellow Cambridge chip manufacturer, ARM.

CSR will use the funds raised to develop its single chip version of Bluetooth technology. Bluetooth provides low cost, short range radio links between laptops, mobile phones and palmtop organisers.

"The funds raised will help to further secure our leading market position and take full advantage of opportunities [after] the anticipated explosion of Bluetooth," said CSR chief executive John Hodgson.

CSR would not be drawn on the question of whether joint projects with Sony had been planned, but it is thought that its chips would be suitable for a number of Sony products.

The Cambridge company is expected to float some time this year.

webTitle: Fear of measles epidemic as jab rate drops

fields.headline: Fear of measles epidemic as jab rate drops
fields.standfirst: Theories linking vaccine with autism and bowel disease have led to dangerously low levels of immunisation, say experts
fields.trailText: Theories linking vaccine with autism and bowel disease have led to dangerously low levels of immunisation, say experts.
fields.body:
Children returning to school after the Christmas holidays could fall victim to an outbreak of measles for the first time in a decade, because of low uptakes of the MMR jab.

Large numbers of parents have not had their children immunised after fears that the combined measles, mumps and rubella jab is linked to autism and bowel disease.

The World Health Organisation recommends that 95% of children be immunised against measles to guarantee protection of the entire population. In the UK, 88% of children have been immunised and this figures drops to 75% in some areas.

Public health officials warned yesterday of the seriousness of the situation, stressing that Britain could again see children dying of a preventable childhood infection.

The fall is most serious in London and the south-east. The latest figures collected by the public health laboratory service (PHLS), up to June last year, reveal that in six London boroughs less than 80% of children under two have had their first MMR jab. In Croydon, only 74% have been vaccinated. In Kensington, Chelsea and Westminster, Lambeth, Southwark and Lewisham, only 76% have had their first MMR. In Berkshire, 79% of two-year-olds have been immunised.

The figures for the first MMR jab are higher than for the second injection, which is given shortly before a child starts school. Most children will have immunity after the first dose, but some will not. Only 61.5% of five-year-olds in London have had the second jab. Trent, the south-east and the north-west of England are all on around 74%.

An epidemic of either measles, mumps or rubella is now possible. In the Netherlands, the disease rampaged through a community which refused to vaccinate its children. There were 1,750 cases and three children died. Ireland, where vaccination has dropped below 80%, is experiencing its worst measles outbreak for seven years, with 1,220 cases so far and two deaths.

Parents' worries stem from research carried out at the Royal Free hospital in London. A group of scientists, led by Andrew Wakefield, have spent years in pursuit of their theories that there are links between bowel disease, autism and the measles virus. The crucial paper raising the possibility that the vaccine was to blame, published in the respected medical journal the Lancet in February 1998, caused uproar in the public health community and received wide publicity.

A group of experts convened by the Medical Research Council at the request of the chief medical officer, then Sir Kenneth Calman, studied the Wakefield research, interviewing the scientists and looking at their source material. They found no evidence to implicate the MMR jab in either bowel disease or autism.

But the scare took hold and vaccination rates dropped. The first generation of children not immunised before their second birthday three years ago are now starting school, and the PHLS is urging parents to get then vaccinated.

Brian Duerden, medical director of the PHLS, said: "This is a serious situation. We have to do all we can to convince parents that the MMR jab is safe. We have a safe vaccine which we have looked at in detail because of concerns that were raised and we have found it is not linked to these side effects people are worried about.

"The government is well aware of the problem we are facing and is determined to educate people about the importance of having the vaccine, and quite rightly so."

Some parents have asked GPs for single doses of measles vaccine for their children, instead of the combination, but the government is against this. It argues that the triple jab is just as safe and more efficient.

Some 2,000 families are contemplating legal action against the vaccine manufacturers.

The worries do not seem to have taken root in Scotland, however. Statistics show that 93% of children had been given the vaccine by their second birthday.

fields.headline: Becker vs Becker grips Germany
fields.standfirst: Tennis legend who conquered Wimbledon begins a new court battle ... with his wife
fields.trailText: Tennis legend who conquered Wimbledon begins a new court battle ... with his wife.
fields.body:
The former German tennis star Boris Becker fired the first courtroom volley yesterday in an attempt to keep his divorce proceedings from becoming an out-of-control transatlantic media spectacle.

Lined up against the triple Wimbledon men's singles champion was an opponent as formidable as any he ever faced across the net in his championship winning days: the German media.

Becker appeared in the Miami-Dade county family court in Florida to ask Judge Maynard Gross to exclude the public and the media from the proceedings brought against him by his estranged wife Barbara for custody of their two children and ownership of their luxury home on Fisher Island, Miami.

Barbara Becker, the daughter of a German mother and black American GI father, wants her alimony and child-support action to be conducted in public, giving the media full access to documents in the case and perhaps even allowing television cameras into the courtroom.

She has the support of a German press pack hungry for any and every detail about the battle between Boris und Babs, as the tabloid Bild-Zeitung calls the celebrity couple.

Becker said in an affidavit that he was "fearful to testify" in open court, and that he had received repeated threats against "my life and the life of my family, including the life of my six-year-old son Noah".

In court he said he had been getting threats against his family since 1985, when he first won Wimbledon. He said he received three or four threatening letters a month.

"I did receive one two years ago doing the tournaments on Key Biscayne. I received a kidnapping threat against my children," he said through a translator. He said the threat was seeking ransom money.

Becker argued that disclosing details of his financial affairs "gives rise to the fantasies of criminals".

Mrs Becker's lawyers have challenged his claim that the children would be put at greater risk of injury or harm by open proceedings. They said in court papers that Noah and Elias, one, were always protected by security guards while in the United States.

Judge Gross must decide whether Becker's petition is sufficiently pressing to shut the public out and seal the court proceedings from reporters, something that is normally done under Florida law where there is a real threat to children in a custody dispute.

If he does so, German television channels say, they will immediately begin broadcasting regular live updates from Miami. The case has spiralled from dignified separation to a no-holds-barred divorce and custody battle in little more than a month.

In addition to the German media, the Miami Herald newspaper and a local television station have filed affidavits asking for the case to remain open and accessible to the media.

Whatever the outcome of the procedural hearing, Judge Gross has set another hearing for Monday, when he will decide whether the Florida courts have the power to hear Mrs Becker's custody and matrimonial property claims.

The couple were married in Germany and had their primary residence in Munich, and their children were born and lived mostly in Germany until Mrs Becker brought them to the United States in December.

The divorce has become an all-absorbing national drama in Germany.

For years their marriage gave them the reputation of one of Europe's most emotionally mature celebrity couples.

Underlying the case is the increasingly prominent problem of international child custody law under the 1980 Hague Convention.

The issue has become a bone of contention between the United States and Germany, which is widely accused internationally of making custody judgments which unfairly favour the German parent in such disputes.

webTitle: Deaths in police custody fall as Met recruits nurses for station

fields.headline: Deaths in police custody fall as Met recruits nurses for station
fields.trailText: Deaths in police custody have fallen sharply, according to a review by the police complaints authority.
fields.body:
Deaths in police custody have fallen sharply, according to a review by the police complaints authority.

There were 23 in the nine months to December, compared with 47 in the 12 months to April 2000 and 65 in 1998/99.

The figures were released to coincide with the launch of two initiatives by the Metropolitan police which could reduce the number of deaths even further.

As part of a pilot scheme, the Met is recruiting a nursing manager and six staff to work in the custody suite at Charing Cross police station, one of the busiest in the capital, where they will examine prisoners.

If the scheme proves a success, the Met will consider putting nurses in more than 60 other stations.

The force has also produced a hard-hitting training video which highlights some of the medical emergencies that can arise in arrests, such as when prisoners swallow drugs or struggle when restrained.

Assistant Commissioner Michael Todd said: "There are real risks, real dangers."

Three people have died in custody in London since last April, compared with 13 in the 12 months to April 2000.

"We have seen a significant decrease in the number of deaths in custody in London but we are not complacent," said Mr Todd. "One death in custody is too many."

All police forces have been under pressure to reduce deaths in custody. Many have revised training methods and introduced cctv cameras into cells.

The number of prison suicides has also dropped for the first time in five years, from 91 in 1999 to 82 last year, according to figures published by the prison service yesterday. There were 64 suicides in 1996. In a new year message to prison governors, Martin Narey, the prison service director general, said that suicide prevention had to be given the "highest priority".

The Howard League for Penal Reform said the figures masked a rise in the number of women killing themselves in prisons - eight died last year, compared with three the year before.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: And so to the second and final part of the Turncoat of Turncoats race card, the Diary's form guide to the runners in the competition to determine which of New Labour's myriad political metamorphoses have been the most spectacular.
fields.body:
And so to the second and final part of the Turncoat of Turncoats race card, the Diary's form guide to the runners in the competition to determine which of New Labour's myriad political metamorphoses have been the most spectacular.

Yesterday we considered the merits of five of the field - Clare Bomber Short (100-30 co-fav); Paul Boateng (14-1); Alan Milburn (18-1); Margaret Enver Hodge (25-1) and Chris Mullin (66-1) - and we conclude today with the other five declared runners. Two places are vacant for late entrants; Dick Caborn, Patricia Hewitt and egregious MEP Richard Balfe are among those nominated already, and more suggestions are welcome. Odds are provided, as always, by Diary pundit Steptoe, who remains the western world's most respected canine soothsayer.

 Lord Macdonald: 100-30 co-favouritism in no way flatters Gus, for the length and speed of his rightward journey have been staggering. The teenage firebrand from the Clydeside docks (where even Alex Ferguson was scared of him) spent donkey-jacketed decades preaching revolution, and even at Granada TV his credo was "comfort the afflicted and afflict the comfortable". Then came ermine and the sniff of power ... and last year on Question Time Gus looked close to collapse when renationalising the railways was mooted. Remarkable.

 Peter Hain: the last 100-30 co-favourite may be the only Turncoat to feel guilt. This once heroic enemy of apartheid (no one forgets that) turned enforcer of the poisonous failed sanctions against Iraq wants to keep in with old leftie mates, but his ambition overpowers his good intentions. In a 1993 pamphlet he attacked modernisers for wanting to turn Labour into a revived SDP designed to win elections by offending as few voters as possible. Apart from your proximity to cabinet, Peter, what's changed?

 Robin Cook: the highest ranking contender looks decent value at 9-2, given the transformation from long-time CND stalwart to smug press conference partner of Madeleine Albright during the video game bombing of Belgrade. We could fill this column for months with Cookie's weaselly ways (the Lost Iraqi Boy fiasco, for instance; or the ethical foreign policy that led to him selling Hawks and much else to Indonesia) but lack of space confines us to asking this regarding the Turncoats on offer: suits you, sir?

 Barbara Roche: once a hard leftie in north London, 20-1 odds reflect her obscurity more than her constancy. As the most senior Jewish minister, how depressing that it was she, whose ancestors fled here from newly Soviet Russia for a better life ("economic migrants" as we now call them), who spoke of some asylum seekers coming here to work the system and using their children to beg in a "vile" manner. Such selective amnesia about his roots was nauseating when it came from Michael Howard, and is no less so with her. Shame on you, madam.

 Son Simon: the 66-1 chance is included as New Labour's most gifted propagandist. His atrocious News of the World column aside, in the Telegraph and Spectator he writes almost well enough to disguise how closely the content appears based on No 10 briefings. And there's nothing he won't write to be helpful: once fanatically anti-hunting, he quite suddenly adopted Mr Tony's more laissez-faire approach to the issue. Touch wood Son keeps the weight off, or that coat will cost a fortune should he spring an upset.

 Voting on Turncoat of Turncoats by fax, letter or email is now open, and will not close until the day Mr Tony calls the election. The specially designed garments - red with yellow dots (pieces of silver) one side, yellow with red rectangles (red boxes) the other - will be presented to the winner and two runners-up on election day, as they arrive at their local polling stations to vote.

webTitle: Hospitals told to clean up over CJD

fields.headline: Hospitals told to clean up over CJD
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Hospitals have been ordered to improve their decontamination and sterilisation procedures to reduce the theoretical risk of patients catching the fatal human form of BSE.
fields.body:
Hospitals have been ordered to improve their decontamination and sterilisation procedures to reduce the theoretical risk of patients catching the fatal human form of BSE.

The government yesterday promised £200m would be spent in England alone on new equipment - and confirmed that surgeons must use throw-away instruments for all tonsil operations in Britain, a change that will cost a further £30m a year.

The measures, part of an extensive overhaul of hospital hygiene to fight the spread of variant CJD, compare with the £6bn cost of programmes to control BSE in cattle and lost exports.

Ministers and senior officials hope that the modernisation of cleansing will help reduce the costs for far more expensive rekitting of hospitals with disposable equipment for more complicated and more expensive operations than tonsillectomy, which is usually performed on children with equipment costing just a few hundred pounds. But they concede that the changes in that operation, expected to be completed this year, could provide valuable lessons for far wider use of once-only instruments if that were necessary.

Eighty-three people have died from vCJD, with five known victims still alive, but scientists still have little idea of the eventual size of the epidemic. The Department of Health is so worried that present decontamination, sterilisation and even washing arrangements are not up to scratch that it is conducting a national survey and has appointed a central management team to ensure improvements are carried out. Every NHS trust is expected to have an official responsible for changes.

Problems with existing sterilisation equipment, regardless of the vCJD threat, were highlighted late last year by orthopaedic surgeons at a Portsmouth hospital who threatened to stop all emergency operations, saying patients' lives were at risk.

The new money for equipment in England will be phased over two years. The NHS in Scotland set aside £3m for improvements this year and an audit is under way to see just what changes may be needed in Wales.

Pat Troop, deputy chief medical officer for England, said: "We still do not know how many people might be incubating vCJD. There is a theoretical risk that it can be passed through surgical instruments from those who have yet to show symptoms of the disease. The highest standards of decontamination are the cornerstone of our strategy to reduce risks."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Father charged with murder
Church paying jailed vicar
Mousetrap's move
Looking back in anger at Liam
Crackdown on kerb crawlers
Service for Kirsty MacColl
Billy Elliot up for awards
fields.body:
Father charged with murder

A 48-year-old man will appear before Blackpool magistrates today charged with the murder of his 12-year-old son. Henry Bangs was accused following the discovery of the body of his son Anthony at a house in Blackpool last week.

Church paying jailed vicar

A vicar jailed for obtaining £11,000 by deception from church officials at St Peter and St Mary in Stowmarket, Suffolk, is still receiving his Church of England stipend, it has emerged. Trevor Jones, jailed for nine months last year, is receiving an estimated £300 a week because, until disciplinary proceedings end, he remains technically in charge of his parish.

Mousetrap's move

The world's longest-running play, The Mousetrap, is to get its first UK performance outside London. The Agatha Christie murder mystery will relocate to the Palace theatre, in Westcliff-on-Sea, Essex, in June for a one-off performance as part of a festival to mark the 25th anniversary of the author's death. The Mousetrap, which recently had its 20,000th performance, opened in the West End in November 1952.

Looking back in anger at Liam

People hate or fear Oasis lead singer Liam Gallagher more than they do Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein, according to Madame Tussaud's annual popularity poll. Gallagher was beaten only by Adolf Hitler, who came first, and former Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic. Saddam Hussein, who topped the poll last year, was fourth this year, with Tony Blair fifth.

Robbery victim has miscarriage

A 24-year-old pregnant shopworker has suffered a miscarriage after she was robbed in the street in Glasgow. She had been taking a four-figure sum of money to a post office on Wednesday when she was attacked by a man. The robber was then driven off by an accomplice in a stolen car.

Manager claims sex bias

A manager who returned to work after maternity leave to find her job no longer existed is suing her former firm for £60,000. Pauline Mitchell, 31, of Glasgow, claims she returned to First National Bank to find she had nothing to do but filing and cleaning up. She will claim sex discrimination at an employment tribunal. The bank says her job was replaced by a team leader post, which she was offered.

Crackdown on kerb crawlers

Convicted kerb crawlers are to be forced to provide a DNA sample to police in Avon and Somerset Constabulary's area. It is the first force in Britain to adopt the hardline policy.

Service for Kirsty MacColl

A public memorial service will take place for the late singer-songwriter Kirsty MacColl at St Martin-in-the-Fields church near Trafalgar Square, London, on January 20. The star was killed by a speedboat while swimming on a Mexican holiday.

Farming hits birdlife

Intensive farming has caused more damage to birds in Europe than any other single factor, research from the RSPB suggested yesterday. Across 30 European countries, those with the most intensive farming have suffered the most rapidly declining bird populations, with British birds badly hit.

Billy Elliot up for awards

The British film Billy Elliot has been nominated for nine prizes at next month's awards of the London Film Critics' Circle. There are 15 categories.

Crackdown on kerb crawlers Convicted kerb crawlers are to be forced to provide a DNA sample to police in Avon and Somerset Constabulary's area. It is the first force in Britain to adopt the hardline policy. Service for Kirsty MacColl A public memorial service will take place for the late singer-songwriter Kirsty MacColl at St Martin-in-the-Fields church near Trafalgar Square, London, on January 20. The star was killed by a speedboat while swimming on a Mexican holiday. Farming hits birdlife Intensive farming has caused more damage to birds in Europe than any other single factor, research from the RSPB suggested yesterday. Across 30 European countries, those with the most intensive farming have suffered the most rapidly declining bird populations, with British birds badly hit. Billy Elliot up for awards The British film Billy Elliot has been nominated for nine prizes at next month's awards of the London Film Critics' Circle. There are 15 categories.

webTitle: Westbury white horse turning into old grey nag

fields.headline: White horse turning into old grey nag
fields.trailText: Conservation experts have been called in to help find the answer to a worrying decline in the appearance of one of England's best known rural landmarks.
fields.body:
Conservation experts have been called in to help find the answer to a worrying decline in the appearance of one of England's best known rural landmarks.

For almost two and a quarter centuries the Westbury white horse has stood on the steep chalk escarpment of Salisbury plain in west Wiltshire. Visible from up to 20 miles away, the scheduled ancient monument is a popular visitor attraction and features prominently in tourist literature.

But the equine outline has seen better days. Deterioration of a protective concrete overcoat laid down in 1993 has left the white horse looking more like an old grey nag.

English Heritage, guardian of the horse, said it was aware of its present condition.

"We are concerned about its discoloured appearance and we are aware of the concerns of local people for whom it is an important landmark - something needs to be done about it," a spokeswoman said.

"A technical investigation is under way to see what is causing the deterioration in its appearance."

The Westbury horse is the oldest and largest of eight horses carved into chalk hillsides across Wiltshire.

The Westbury horse, the only one to have been given a protective concrete coating, dates back to 1778 and was carved into the hillside on the orders of the then landowner, Lord Abingdon.

Wiltshire Tourism said the deterioration was part of a wider problem for the county's chalk figure horses, which had not been helped by the appalling winter weather. "We would like to see them all looking better because they are a tremendous part of the county's landscape."

webTitle: Call to buy out people living on eroding coasts

fields.headline: Call to buy out people living on eroding coasts
fields.standfirst: Some land should be abandoned to the sea
fields.trailText: Some land should be abandoned to the sea.
fields.body:
Parts of the coastline should be abandoned to the sea, but planners are avoiding making the right decisions because there is no legislation to allow them to compensate the owners who face ruin as a result.

David Carter, a lecturer at the University of Portsmouth, researching for the Ministry of Agriculture, said new legislation was needed to provide compensation for those whose land and homes needed to be abandoned to the sea in the public interest.

He said rising sea levels and more frequent storms meant it was more and more difficult and expensive to defend parts of the coast. Improvements in science also showed that extra defences in one area meant erosion in others so those adversely affected should receive compensation.

"I am not a lawyer but if there was a planning decision which caused my house to fall in the sea or my land to flood then I think I would have cause to sue," he added.

He said a test case was Medmerry Beach at Selsey, near Chichester, where the largest caravan site in Europe - which had 10,000 residents in the summer - was sheltering behind a shingle beach that was being washed away by the sea. Each year the environment agency was waging a losing battle against the elements by spending £500,000 a year replacing shingle on the beach.

"Basically the right thing to do is let the shingle beach move inland. Eventually the sea will win, but there is no proper way of compensating those who suffer."

The environment agency, which spends £19.2m a year on sea defence, said it was hoping for permission from the Ministry of Agriculture to move back the line of Medmerry Beach. "Three homes will be lost and part of the caravan site and it will cost millions to complete but at least we will have a beach we think we can hold," said a spokesman.

Dr Carter, who is researching the success of new 10-year plans for coastal defence for the ministry, said a lot of radical decisions needed to be made to retreat from the sea. Unstable cliffs could not be defended and must be allowed to fall into the sea and low-lying land in north Kent, Essex and Norfolk must be abandoned to allow salt flats to develop. Small schemes, mostly in harbours such as Chichester, had already been successful but they were needed on a much larger scale.

A second serious problem was developments which were allowed where there were no adequate sea defences. An example was Sovereign Harbour on Pevensey Bay in east Sussex, where hundreds of houses were still being built but were in danger of inundation by the sea. Fellow researcher Jane Taussik, from the same university, said councillors often overruled the advice of coastal engineers, their own officers, and the environment agency and allowed development in dangerous places.

"The recent floods have been eye-opening as far as the devastating effects that bad planning decisions can have. We have not been careful about the safeguards we need to take in tidal areas, either. We need to make a condition of developments that flood mitigation measures are put in place. Builders should be told houses cannot be sold or moved into until defence works are completed.

"When people are buying houses on the coast they should check on the risk. People often expect local authorities to tell them of the dangers but no one does. It is the house owner's or buyer's responsibility. It is not a question solicitors ask on searches, it is 'buyer beware'."

webTitle: Britain sparkles for Signet as US dims

fields.headline: Britain sparkles for Signet as US dims
fields.trailText: An increasing love of diamonds in Britain helped Signet, the world's largest speciality retail jeweller, to a sparkling Christmas with UK like-for-like sales up 8.7%.
fields.body:
An increasing love of diamonds in Britain helped Signet, the world's largest speciality retail jeweller, to a sparkling Christmas with UK like-for-like sales up 8.7%.

Shares in the former Ratners group pushed forward to end the day up more than 20% to 61.5p while the strong results opened prospects for strong figures from other retailers.

Signet, the first really large retailer to provide holiday trading figures, said profits for the year ending January 27 2001 should be higher than expected.

This encouraged stockbroker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney to upgrade its estimates for Signet's pre-tax prof its from £154m to £158m. The encouraging sales figures from Britain for the period from November 1 to December 24 were not matched by the US, which provides 71% of group sales.

The results from North America showed like-for-like sales up by only 1.3%, a figure which outperformed many rivals affected by economic slowdown and an exceptionally strong millennial period

Terry Burman, Signet's chief executive, said he was very pleased with the figures overall and promised a range of initiatives to drive sales further.

In the UK, where Signet is represented through branches of H Samuel and Ernest Jones, the company has plans for new stores.

webTitle: The making of DW Griffiths' Intolerance

fields.headline: 'Move those 10,000 horses a trifle to the right... '
fields.standfirst: Tom Dewe Mathews  on the making of Intolerance, the cinematic masterpiece by the flawed genius DW Griffiths
fields.trailText: Tom Dewe Mathews on the making of Intolerance, the cinematic masterpiece by the flawed genius DW Griffiths
fields.body:
He is called "the father of film technique", the man "who invented Hollywood", "the first to photograph thought" and even "the Shakespeare of the screen". Yet, despite all this praise, DW Griffith is a movie-maker we don't really know. Instead, we mythologise him as the "pioneer" who invented the techniques of narrative film, and as the director who made The Birth of a Nation, the biggest hit of the silent era, and then Intolerance, the biggest flop, which reduced him to penury and a lonely death in obscurity.

More recently, he has been castigated as one of America's most pernicious racists, thanks to his glorification of the Ku Klux Klan in The Birth of a Nation. Until recently the Directors Guild of America called its prestigious lifetime achievement honour the DW Griffith award, but his name was dropped in 1999.

His contribution to cinematic technique, however, was outstanding. "There were others at the time who were technically better," says Kevin Brownlow, the film-restorer and historian who is introducing a rare screening of Griffith's Intolerance, with full orchestra at London's Royal Festival Hall. "But none had his artistic bravery. There were other directors, such as Von Stroheim and Allan Dwan, who learnt from Griffith and contributed a lot - but Griffith did the biggest job of all. His films altered the whole course of cinema."

Like most middle-class Americans at the time, Griffith despised film. He preferred the theatre. As the son of a Confederate army colonel, David Wark Griffith considered himself a southern gentleman. Nonetheless, he was brought up in relative poverty in rural Kentucky and worked as a shop assistant and hop-picker before he became an actor in a travelling theatre company. Even then he never achieved his ambition of becoming a playwright or stage director. So, in 1907, he reluctantly moved into the movies where - because of his ability to turn a film around quickly - he became the main director of the Biograph company. But he still saw cinema as a shoddy stopgap. In 1908, he told his wife: "In a way, it's very nice but, you know, we can't go on living for ever and not tell our friends and family how we earn our living."

"He had done more than 400 films for Biograph by the time he made The Birth of a Nation," says Brownlow, "and he hadn't invented all that much. Griffith had very talented press agents, who said he invented absolutely everything."

All the narrative techniques of modern-day cinema - the close-up, the tracking shot, the flashback, the fade-out and so on - had been established by 1912. Nevertheless, says Brownlow, "while the components had been devised no one was fully exploiting them". It was Griffith who "struck the first match". The French film-maker Georges Méliès, according to Brownlow, "linked his scenes with dissolves way back in 1899, but it was Griffith who made the fade-out his trademark; the very first film ever made [by Thomas Edison in 1894] was a close-up - created 13 years before Griffith got into pictures - but filmgoers never forgot Griffith's close-ups. They were under the impression that because Griffith was so good at showing off these new devices, he'd invented them."

Even so, by the time he completed The Birth of a Nation - originally entitled The Clansman - in 1915, Griffith had polished and put cinematic grammar into its current place. The previous year he had said: "We are striving for real acting. When you saw only the small, full-length figures, it was necessary to have exaggerated acting, the waving of the hands and so on. The close-up enabled us to reach real acting, restraint, acting that is a duplicate of real life." So, solely through the use of the close-up, Griffith moved screen acting away from pantomine towards a facial style which meant that a look could now sustain or propel a whole sequence of a film. There is one other refinement, which was to be just as influential, that Griffith brought to the cinema a year later in one of the most extraordinary epics ever made.

Just before the first world war, says Brownlow, "the American film industry was very much secondary to the French and Italian because they could both do far bigger pictures". Griffith himself had already tried to do a big picture, Judith of Bethulia, in 1913 but it wasn't nearly as spectacular as Italian epics like Cabiria. Three years later, however, Griffith had money pouring into his pocket via the box office from The Birth of a Nation. His next film would therefore be his definitive response to the Europeans.

"Move those 10,000 horses a trifle to the right, and that mob out there, three feet forward," was among the instructions Griffith allegedly gave during his direction of Intolerance. Though there was little historical evidence to support their presence, Griffith wanted white elephants for his immense epic, eight of them perched on massive mushroom pedestals, dwarfing the colossal court of Belshazzar's palace and all built out of plaster alongside a dirt road which would become Sunset Boulevard. Along that trail came 4,000 extras on $2 a day to impersonate Assyrian soldiers, Numidian eunuchs, priests of Bel, handmaidens of Ishtar, slaves of Mesopotamia; and, soaring up over this vision of Babylon on a 100-foot camera-crane, Griffith brought it all to life. All this activity was immortalised in the Taviani brothers' Good Morning, Babylon, in which Charles Dance played Griffith.

To begin with, the director asked for a big modern-day banqueting scene to be designed; but nobody on the set really knew what was going on because Griffith didn't have a script. All the crew knew was that they were moving between different historical periods on four different movies, all called The Mother and the Law. The final film, though, isn't sequential - the stories don't follow each other chronologically. Instead Griffith mixed up his four plots in the editing room and intercut between Babylon, Christ's Judea, Reformation Europe and modern America, and this is why Brownlow thinks the film is regarded by many as the greatest of all.

"The way he brings all four stories to a climax at the same time so that you're chasing along in a chariot, the cross is being carried through Jerusalem, the Huguenots are being slaughtered and you're tearing along in a train across modern America, is just amazing. The scale of his ambition and the level to which that ambition is achieved are astounding."

Ironically, for a film that foreshortened what Brownlow thinks would have been years of slow technical progress, Intolerance marked the beginning of Griffith's decline. It flopped badly at the box office and Griffith then dug himself into a deeper financial hole by buying the picture back from the banks. For a while, his career revived. He had hits such as Orphans of the Storm and his 1919 movie, Broken Blossoms, and even introduced another technical innovation - the use of gauze and filters on cameras to lend a luminous light that separates characters from the background - which would in turn give us those fabulous, soft close-ups of silent stars.

Legend has it that Griffith died unknown and in poverty. In fact he had many friends - especially actresses from his films, who adored him - and previous successes provided him with an annuity of $30,000. But work wasn't forthcoming and, as the scriptwriter Charles Brackett said at Griffith's funeral in 1948, "What does a man full of vitality care for the honours of the past?" But then, of how many men can it be said, as it was said of Griffith: "He thought that cinema should be an art, so he turned it into one"?

 Intolerance, with music performed by the London Philarmonic Orchestra and conducted by Carl Davis, will be shown on January 20 at the Royal Festival Hall, London, SE1 (box office: 020-7960 4242).

fields.headline: We're all saved
fields.standfirst: Even if Cast Away doesn't quite cut it, Hollywood is already on a roll this year
fields.trailText: Even if Cast Away doesn't quite cut it, Hollywood is already on a roll this year
fields.body:
The past 12 months were not a distinguished year in cinema history but, much to my surprise, the holiday season went some way towards restoring my faith in the movies. It's been a long time since I saw three new movies in a week and loved them all.

Let me rephrase that. I loved Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and Steven Soderbergh's Traffic, and, while I had as many problems with Robert Zemeckis's Cast Away as I've had with all his recent movies, the experience of seeing it with a jubilant, expectant holiday crowd was more than adequate compensation for its shortcomings.

I do love a packed house. Perhaps that's because, given the nature of my job, I find myself in so few. Because I have to see so many movies, I tend to hit the less thickly populated bargain matinees attended by little old ladies, school truants, adulterous couples and fugitive criminals.

Otherwise, I see new movies in the sterile atmosphere of a studio screening room, surrounded by jaded reviewers and associated prose-farmers. There's the fat, scruffy critic from the local freesheet, a man I thought was a gutter-basking derelict until I overheard his name. I don't demand that critics wear black tie and tails, but I will draw the line at candlewick dressing gowns and shirt-tails tangled up in one's flies. Then there's the usual complement of freeloaders from the studio and the PR company, and often a small group of know-nothing film majors from UCLA and USC - because they teach film criticism to kids in college these days. (I didn't stop laughing at that news until it started to make me feel ill.)

And if we're really lucky, the terrified PR reps will delay the screening until the Big Critic from the Los Angeles Times arrives - sometimes by up to an hour. If they have the temerity to roll the movie one nanosecond before this august figure (a petulant, over-the-hill hack) is in his reserved seat, we can sit back and enjoy a sustained, spittle-flecked tirade that usually includes the phrase: "Do you have any idea who I am?"

All of this just alienates me from the movie we're about to see. Critics and film pros don't laugh or cry in the places paying audiences do. They're always too busy looking for an angle from which to one-up the next scribbler, or you overhear them in the elevator saying that they plan to "champion" this or that movie, or that they won't "dignify" it with a decent notice. Real people just want to see a good movie, which is why I so love a cinema groaning to the rafters with a Saturday night crowd, dying to be thrilled.

I've been seeing these crowds over the holiday season. The audience for Cast Away at my local multiplex was teeming with families, kids, old ladies and teenage gangbangers. The line outside stretched 60ft and no one resented the crowded auditorium. I love settling in and feeling that hush of expectation as the lights dim.

Throughout the movie, people talk and react viscerally to what's on the screen. Sometimes you can hear a Mexican dad translating all the dialogue into Spanish for his children. In a half-empty house I don't usually put up with this for long - I'm a strong advocate of yelling "Shut your goddamn trap!" at recalcitrant chatterboxes - but when the movie is second-rate, like Cast Away, then the audience can make up for it.

Cast Away did provide me with a reminder of one phenomenon I'd forgotten about. When Tom Hanks is washed up on a desert island, the film enters an almost silent hour as he learns to survive, feed and clothe himself. Silence makes audiences nervous and the noise level in the auditorium will rise to fill the space. Popcorn bags crackle louder and you can hear people masticating loudly in the darkness. As Mike Hodges, a director who knows the strategic use of silence, once said: "There's so much music in movies because the modern audience doesn't like to hear itself eating."

But my treks to see Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and Traffic made me even more optimistic about the movie-going experience. Tiger is playing on about one 50th of the screens allocated for a piece of Christmas crap like The Family Man, but the audiences - which are so mixed as to defy demographic categorisation - are huge. I was turned away four times before I could see it with a paying audience (for me, it had previously transcended the pitfalls of a hacks' screening) and when I did finally see it on an Imax screen the size of a warehouse wall, I saw an audience utterly rapt. Who says US audiences can't handle sub-titles? Someone who thinks we're all stupid, apparently. Likewise Traffic, which has been showing in four cinemas in the whole country - one in LA - and for which audiences have been beating down the doors.

Good movies attracting massive audiences? For a brief, happy moment all the stars are in alignment. For a few days I have been able to say something I rarely feel: "I love going to the movies again."

I'm praying it'll last.
fields.bodyText: The past 12 months were not a distinguished year in cinema history but, much to my surprise, the holiday season went some way towards restoring my faith in the movies. It's been a long time since I saw three new movies in a week and loved them all. Let me rephrase that. I loved Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and Steven Soderbergh's Traffic, and, while I had as many problems with Robert Zemeckis's Cast Away as I've had with all his recent movies, the experience of seeing it with a jubilant, expectant holiday crowd was more than adequate compensation for its shortcomings. I do love a packed house. Perhaps that's because, given the nature of my job, I find myself in so few. Because I have to see so many movies, I tend to hit the less thickly populated bargain matinees attended by little old ladies, school truants, adulterous couples and fugitive criminals. Otherwise, I see new movies in the sterile atmosphere of a studio screening room, surrounded by jaded reviewers and associated prose-farmers. There's the fat, scruffy critic from the local freesheet, a man I thought was a gutter-basking derelict until I overheard his name. I don't demand that critics wear black tie and tails, but I will draw the line at candlewick dressing gowns and shirt-tails tangled up in one's flies. Then there's the usual complement of freeloaders from the studio and the PR company, and often a small group of know-nothing film majors from UCLA and USC - because they teach film criticism to kids in college these days. (I didn't stop laughing at that news until it started to make me feel ill.) And if we're really lucky, the terrified PR reps will delay the screening until the Big Critic from the Los Angeles Times arrives - sometimes by up to an hour. If they have the temerity to roll the movie one nanosecond before this august figure (a petulant, over-the-hill hack) is in his reserved seat, we can sit back and enjoy a sustained, spittle-flecked tirade that usually includes the phrase: "Do you have any idea who I am?" All of this just alienates me from the movie we're about to see. Critics and film pros don't laugh or cry in the places paying audiences do. They're always too busy looking for an angle from which to one-up the next scribbler, or you overhear them in the elevator saying that they plan to "champion" this or that movie, or that they won't "dignify" it with a decent notice. Real people just want to see a good movie, which is why I so love a cinema groaning to the rafters with a Saturday night crowd, dying to be thrilled. I've been seeing these crowds over the holiday season. The audience for Cast Away at my local multiplex was teeming with families, kids, old ladies and teenage gangbangers. The line outside stretched 60ft and no one resented the crowded auditorium. I love settling in and feeling that hush of expectation as the lights dim. Throughout the movie, people talk and react viscerally to what's on the screen. Sometimes you can hear a Mexican dad translating all the dialogue into Spanish for his children. In a half-empty house I don't usually put up with this for long - I'm a strong advocate of yelling "Shut your goddamn trap!" at recalcitrant chatterboxes - but when the movie is second-rate, like Cast Away, then the audience can make up for it. Cast Away did provide me with a reminder of one phenomenon I'd forgotten about. When Tom Hanks is washed up on a desert island, the film enters an almost silent hour as he learns to survive, feed and clothe himself. Silence makes audiences nervous and the noise level in the auditorium will rise to fill the space. Popcorn bags crackle louder and you can hear people masticating loudly in the darkness. As Mike Hodges, a director who knows the strategic use of silence, once said: "There's so much music in movies because the modern audience doesn't like to hear itself eating." But my treks to see Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and Traffic made me even more optimistic about the movie-going experience. Tiger is playing on about one 50th of the screens allocated for a piece of Christmas crap like The Family Man, but the audiences - which are so mixed as to defy demographic categorisation - are huge. I was turned away four times before I could see it with a paying audience (for me, it had previously transcended the pitfalls of a hacks' screening) and when I did finally see it on an Imax screen the size of a warehouse wall, I saw an audience utterly rapt. Who says US audiences can't handle sub-titles? Someone who thinks we're all stupid, apparently. Likewise Traffic, which has been showing in four cinemas in the whole country - one in LA - and for which audiences have been beating down the doors. Good movies attracting massive audiences? For a brief, happy moment all the stars are in alignment. For a few days I have been able to say something I rarely feel: "I love going to the movies again." I'm praying it'll last.

webTitle: Sun may protect against MS and strokes

fields.headline: Sun may protect against MS and strokes
fields.standfirst: Stimulating vitamin D could ward off degenerative disease
fields.trailText: Stimulating vitamin D could ward off degenerative disease.
fields.body:
Sunlight protects people against multiple sclerosis (MS) and prevents high blood pressure and strokes, according to research at the University of East Anglia.

Two related studies, covering 30 countries from the equator to the poles, show the beneficial effects of ultraviolet light in sunlight on both conditions.

Graham Bentham told the conference in Plymouth that it was already known that people in northern latitudes such as Britain were 100 times more likely than those on the equator to get MS but no one knew why. Within the UK there was a marked difference, with one in 100 getting MS in England and Wales and one in 500 in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

MS is a degenerative disease in which the immune system attacks the central nervous system. Professor Bentham said sunlight had the effect of suppressing the immune system, but he believed ultraviolet light stimulating the production of vitamin D was the probable protective element. People on the west coasts of Norway and Iceland, who ate oily fish such as herring and salmon, which were rich in vitamin D, had lower MS rates than populations in similar northern climes. "It is the vitamin D that is the key. If the body has enough then it protects against MS. More work is needed but it looks as if this could become an important method of preventing the disease."

Fellow researcher Andy Jones, a lecturer in environmental science, looked at blood pressure, which causes heart problems and strokes. People living near the equator had considerably lower blood pressure than those in temperate regions. Again he believed that vitamin D production caused by sunlight was responsible for the difference.

One of the key factors again was diet. Stone age man evolved in sunny places and had a high calcium intake because of the meat and raw plants that he ate. With modern eating habits, vitamin D was used by the body to absorb more calcium and avoid any deficiency.

When there was a shortage of vitamin D the body produced parathyroid hormone, which caused increased blood pressure. His theory was backed by research which showed that nurses who took calcium supplements had a 25% reduction in heart disease.

Both men were reluctant to reverse advice against sunbathing, with its risk of skin cancer. Dr Jones said: "We are talking about an incremental benefit on sunlight over years, not one big hit lying on a beach. That is much more likely to give you skin cancer and kill you in the long run while only giving you a small temporary benefit of vitamin D."

Lorna Layward, head of research at the MS Society, said the difference in the number of cases between north and south latitudes was well known but the cause had never been established. "This is very interesting but we need more research to find the direct cause."

webTitle: The Constant Gardener by John le Carré

fields.headline: The Constant Gardener by John le Carré
fields.standfirst:
Hodder & Stoughton, £16.99
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: British diplomat loses a wife and finds a conscience as he follows her one-way journey into the dark heart of the pharmaceutical industry
fields.body:
"We've got a problem, Justin," Sandy Woodrow, HM's Head of Chancery in Nairobi, said. "Tessa's been found murdered and her, er, companion, Arnold Bluhm, has gone missing. I'm sorry."

"Good of you to tell me," said Justin.

"All hell's broken loose this end," said Sandy a few hours later as he phoned Bernard Pellegrin, HM's top spook back in London. "The papers are going wild about 'Wife of British diplomat killed by African lover'. I'm not surprised, Sandy thought, recalling his own unrequited passion for Justin's wife.

"Bury the story as best you can," barked the Pellegrin. "Scotland Yard's sending out two detectives and we don't want them poking their noses in. Tessa was a loose cannon and we don't want her and her African doctor's investigation into the Dypraxa TB drug trials jeopardising relations with the Kenyans or the pharmaceutical industry."

"Terribly sorry about Tessa, old chap," soothed the Pellegrin after Justin's recall to London. "Take a bit of time off. Now you didn't happen to find Tessa's laptop, did you? The police say it's still missing."

"No," replied Justin. "It must have been taken when she was killed."

Bugger them, thought Justin. They all reckon Tessa was having an affair with Arnold, but he was gay; theirs was a meeting of minds, not bodies. But what would the diplomatic service know about truth or integrity? He opened the laptop and started reading Tessa's exposé of the pharma-giants, BBB and KVH. A virus then wiped the hard disk. They were on to him. Never mind. He would continue her crusade regardless.

"You need to speak to Lara Emrich in Saskatchewan," said Birgit, the German activist, at their clandestine rendezvous. "She helped develop Dypraxa."

Hmm. They're still on to me, thought Justin, after receiving a severe beating back at his hotel.

"They rushed the clinical trials," said Emrich. "They were so keen to get the drug on the market they suppressed bad results. Just ask Markus Lorbeer."

Hmm. They're still on to me, thought Justin, after he was followed. "Yes, you're right," confessed Lorbeer in his Sudanese outpost.

"I'm at my journey's end," thought Justin as the Land Rover pulled up at the spot where Tessa had been killed.

And if you really are pressed, the digested read, digested: British diplomat loses a wife and finds a conscience as he follows her one-way journey into the dark heart of the pharmaceutical industry

fields.headline: Goldman lifts 2000 merger title
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The mergers and acquisitions activity that has led to boom conditions at investment banks slowed in the last three months of 2000, but still produced an eighth successive record year of corporate weddings.
fields.body:
The mergers and acquisitions activity that has led to boom conditions at investment banks slowed in the last three months of 2000, but still produced an eighth successive record year of corporate weddings.

American investment bank Goldman Sachs topped the global league for company advisers, ranked by the value of the completed deals, that is compiled by Thomson Financial.

After a year which saw a frenetic pace of mergers between investment banks themselves, Thomson predicted that Merrill Lynch, a US rival, could slip out of the top three group of advisers to European companies in 2001.

Merrill risks being dwarfed by competitors which have undertaken big acquisitions themselves. Credit Suisse First Boston, for instance, now appears more threatening after buying the US banking group DLJ last year - as does JP Morgan, which was bought by Chase Manhattan, the fellow American bank which had already boosted its size by acquiring the privately owned British bank, Robert Fleming.

More than a third of the takeovers and mergers recorded involved telecoms companies, a sector which many of the investment banks believe will see further deals this year.

However, after a year during which there were 37,000 mergers together worth more than £2,400bn, bankers said they were expecting a period of slower activity.

This was the result of the delicate economic situation in the US.

"It is going to be quieter this year," one senior investment banker predicted last night.

As many of the leading banks in the City of London have American parent companies, sources said, economic conditions across the Atlantic might lead to a more cautious approach to business in Europe by those banks this year.

webTitle: Funds hatch rescue plan for Equitable

fields.headline: Funds hatch rescue plan for Equitable
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Some of Britain's biggest company pension schemes are considering ways of helping to bail out Equitable Life to increase the chance of the beleaguered insurer finding a buyer.
fields.body:
Some of Britain's biggest company pension schemes are considering ways of helping to bail out Equitable Life to increase the chance of the beleaguered insurer finding a buyer.

Chris Armitage, pensions manager at Uniq (the convenience foods group formerly called Unigate), said yesterday that a number of his fellow pension chiefs have been discussing possible initiatives to support Equitable, which provides occupational schemes for many of the country's largest employers.

Mr Armitage, a council member of the National Association of Pension Funds, said: "If the whole industry is supportive we can keep Equitable going."

He said there were no firm plans and appeared to rule out direct financial support. But it emerged later that one idea being discussed is securing a deal with 90,000 Equitable policyholders who have guaranteed annuities, with the aim of capping the insurer's liabilities.

Equitable closed its doors to new business early last month and warned up to 1m policyholders that they would face lower investment returns and be hit with a 10% penalty if they transferred their funds to another provider.

The moves followed the company's failure to find a buyer after it lost a legal battle in July involving guaranteed annuities sold as part of pension plans. The company is still solvent.

Equitable is the country's biggest provider of top-up pensions, with AVC (additional voluntary contribution) schemes for 4,000 employers including the national health service, Sainsbury's supermarkets and BT.

At an NAPF press conference, Mr Armitage was asked about possible rescue moves. He said: "There are people in the industry who are considering whether such arrangements could be made."

The primary concern was to make sure Equitable stayed afloat. But he added: "There are no firm plans yet. It is very early days."

Geof Pearson, pensions manager at Sainsbury's, some 4,000 of whose staff have been saving into an Equitable AVC scheme, said one way forward might be to strike a deal with the guaranteed annuity policyholders, whose dispute with the company led to its current predicament.

More than a dozen companies including Prudential considered buying Equitable but walked away, apparently because of concern that the total cost of meeting the guarantees could spiral upwards to reach several billion pounds.

The company has already held preliminary talks with some of the guaranteed annuity policyholders about trying to reach a compromise. Mr Pearson said that if these people were prepared to accept a deal to stabilise the company, a buyer might "pop out of the woodwork".

News of the Equitable moves coincided with an NAPF call for the government to reduce the "mass of red tape" making it difficult for employers to provide good quality company pension schemes.
