webTitle: Market forces: Lafarge powers up Blue Circle

fields.headline: Lafarge powers up Blue Circle
fields.standfirst:
Market forces

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Market forces.
fields.body:
There was no doubt about the topic of debate yesterday - the surprise rate cut from the US Federal Reserve. While analysts and traders were mulling over the implications, punters were concentrating on matters of a more speculative nature: in particular, the upward movement of Blue Circle's share price.

On a day when many defensive issues were heading south, Blue Circle stood out with a gain of 17p to 455p in good volume. Throughout the session there had been a specific rumour driving the stock higher - namely that Lafarge, the French building materials group, is coming back with a new bid, apparently at around 495p to 500p.

Last May, Lafarge made a 450p a share hostile bid for Blue Circle, which lapsed after the French group failed to attract enough acceptances for the deal to be unconditional. Although London's takeover rules prevent Lafarge from tabling another hostile bid until May it could, claim the gossips, strike an agreed deal and at the mooted price Blue Circle would probably accept.

Given its healthy financial position - it recently sold its paint and mortar interests for around £500m - and the fact that it controls 32.2% of Blue Circle's equity, most analysts reckon that it is a question of when, not if, Lafarge resumes its pursuit.

Unsurprisingly, the mood in the London market was brighter yesterday after the Federal Reserve's knight in shining armour performance.

All the main indices moved higher during the day, with technology, media and telecom stocks faring the best.

Underneath the market's euphoric response was more than a little disquiet.

Yes, the FTSE 100 had risen 145.7 points to 6,185.6, and the FTSE Techmark 100 had put on 115.26 to 2,459.87 - but in both cases, the gains did little more than mask the losses sustained on Wednesday.

Most did not know what to make of the Fed's action. On one hand it was clearly a good thing that the Fed had reacted to the slowing American economy, dealers said. But they pointed out that this rate cut - and any that follow - could take six months to filter through to the economy, in which time profits warnings will continue to roll in.

Moreover, some thought the move smacked of desperation and pointed out that the Fed rarely acts between meetings and when it does - 1998, for instance - it is usually because something, somewhere, has gone badly wrong.

Nonetheless, just about everything in the new technology world was heading higher. Colt Telecom was the pick of the bunch, rising 235p, or 18.22%, to £15.25. Other strong performers included Energis, 55p higher at 480p, Sage, up 33p to 300p, and Misys, 68.5p better at 623.5p.

Lower down the corporate ladder, the pattern was much the same, with Bookham, up 104p to 932p, and Psion, gaining 27p to 270p, among the day's winners.

Not that everything was going up, of course. Software group Autonomy fell 96p to £13.10, hit by a profits warning from Inktomi, a US software outfit often compared to Autonomy of which it is in fact a customer.

So-called defensive stocks were also having a rough time as investors rediscovered their appetite for risk. GlaxoSmithKline fell 121p to £17.36 and AstraZeneca lost 150p to £31.90. Elsewhere, tobacco company BAT surrendered 46p to 480p, Tesco slipped 17p to 257p and Scottish Power fell 24p to 490p.

Away from the leaders, a few leftovers from the pre-Christmas trading sessions were being reheated. Once again there was interest in rock crusher Aggregate Industries, up 1.5p to 80p, on speculation about a 95p bid on Monday.

Pub operator - and one of the Guardian's tips of the year - SFI rose 19.5p to 192.5p after a stock overhang of 3.5m shares was cleared. Apparently, two heavyweight institutions were the buyers.

webTitle: Is a pension more trouble than it's worth?

fields.headline: Is a pension more trouble than it's worth?
fields.trailText: In the wake of Equitable Life closing to new business and fears that at least one million of its policyholders will be short-changed, growing numbers of people are looking at alternatives to pensions.
fields.body:
In the wake of Equitable Life closing to new business and fears that at least one million of its policyholders will be short-changed, growing numbers of people are looking at alternatives to pensions.

Many are concerned about high charges, poor management and low returns. Beyond Equitable Life, the industry is tainted by the mis-selling scandal when thousands were coaxed out of company schemes into worse performing personal plans.

When it comes to pensions, timing is everything. If you have not started early enough, or are rich enough to stash away vast sums later in life, a pension could be a complete waste of money.

The huge rise in buy to let mortgages is partly fuelled by those who see property as a more reliable investment than a pension. Others are planning to rely on investments such as ISAs.

Legal & General, which expects to be one of the main providers of the new stakeholder pensions, says a 25-year-old, could expect a £12,000 annual pension for a contribution of £100 a month aged 60.

The cost of extra premiums needed to achieve this at a later age soon mounts up. A 40-year-old, for example, would need to pay an extra £214 and a 50-year-old would be paying an extra £800 a month.

"We recommend the earlier the better," says Legal & General's pensions marketing manager, Andy Agar. "If you are in your 40s it is almost too late."

He says he would recommend an ISA alongside a pension, but warns there is always a danger this could be spent too early.

Christine Hawkins, a partner with Horsham-based IFAs, Principles in Practice, says she is seeing an increasing number of women who have left it too start a pension.

"Some women I see, often in their 40s find themselves alone, perhaps through divorce. They realise they need a pension, but it is not always worth it. They would be better off putting money into investments such as ISAs where they have greater control and flexibility."

While no independent financial adviser (IFA) will say pensions are worthless, many admit that their clients are demanding alternatives.

Craig Wetton, marketing manager with Bath-based IFA Chartwell Investment Management, says: "The fact that pensions don't meet every need is something we've been conscious even before Equitable Life. He says there is anger among some clients of retirement age that annuity rates are often less than they expected.

Wetton says Chartwell favours clients investing in investment trusts alongside a pension. Investment trusts have low charges and in the past have tended to deliver better returns than many unit trusts. They often do not pay commission to salesmen, although this does not affect Chartwell, since it charges fees.

Outside of an ISA, other investments are taxed, while pensions do offer tax relief.

John Rutter, an IFA of Lancashire based Donald Rigg Insurance Brokers says: "The main benefit with a pension is the tax advantages, but those thinking about retirement need a holistic approach with other investments than just a pension."

While the pensions industry has been knocked for its high charges, the government believes stakeholder will be far more affordable and flexible. But, these plans, which are targeted at those earning between £9,500 and £21,600, are not without critics.

Rutter comments: "It is all very well the government saying they want to encourage people to make pension provision. But, a lot of these people will be spending all their earnings on the here and now and the amounts they could pay into a stakeholder plan will not make enough of a difference."

Others have criticised stakeholders for being misleading and confusing. There is uncertainty over the government's proposed pension credits, which are meant to give incentives for modest earners to save. But, it means people will have to take decisions without knowing the impact of these credits on their retirement income.

Decision trees - which are shown on official stakeholder literature - have also been slammed. Some feel these could produce unrealistic expectations and allow unqualified staff to advise on pensions.

fields.headline: Why oh why on why?
fields.standfirst: If you want to get ahead in the workplace learn to complain, says Judi James
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: If you want to get ahead in the workplace learn to complain, says Judi James.
fields.body:
Challenging authority is a bit of a sticky wicket. And yet it is becoming a cultural norm. Al Gore chose to question the US voting process. This would have been a very bad call in terms of image a few years ago, when politicians were expected to accept defeat with a gracious smile, like Nixon did under similar circumstances. Now we are into the era of the bad loser, when everyone questions everything and no-one goes down without a fight.

Companies are currently being warned to prepare for an influx of questioning workers. The next generation are learning to challenge and take personal control. They are part of the consumer generation and will see themselves as clients of the firms that employ them.

Which means the rest of us will be left looking like a herd of pliable wimps, unable to challenge our managers without the aid of a handful of Prozac and an industrial-strength nappy or two.

So how can we be more demanding without appearing feral? How to turn "Can Do!" and "No problem!" into "hang on a minute" and "are your sure you're being fair about that?" without sounding like a mutineer?

Strong leaders like Antarctic explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton had the answer to doubting Thomases. While he led his team hiking around the ice on a desperate bid for survival only one man stood up to disagree with his tactics. Evidently Shackleton would have been prepared to shoot him for the good of team dynamics. The guy eventually backed down.

Few modern bosses will be prepared to go that far, so the option of disagreement is one your can afford to consider.
 Begin honing your questioning techniques by building inner confidence. If you lack resolve you will back down quickly and merely look like a trouble-maker. A confident approach is vital.
Arm yourself with knowledge. Make sure you understand exactly what your boss or your company is asking you to do before you start to question it. Poor internal communications often lead to assumption on your part, which will scupper the validity of your viewpoint. Your boss probably knows everything about the point you are going to raise, and so should you.
 Try to eliminate the emotive side of your views. Stick to relevant facts.
 Avoid the use of emotive language. The word "Why" can sound confrontational in itself. Trying asking someone "Why do you do your hair like that?" without implied criticism. It's virtually impossible to do. There are better ways to question. "Can you explain" or "Can you clarify" might sound less confrontational.
 Use open questions to gain information and detail. Speaking to your boss in closed questions, like: "Did that pay rise get turned down?" will probably illicit one word answers, ie "Yes", rather than an explanation.
 Chose the time and place for your questioning carefully. Avoid chance meetings that may lead to a rushed response. Book appointments if the problem is important.
 You may use team briefings as an opportunity to question, and this can be formally encouraged in your firm. Plan your communication to sound like positive information-seeking, though. Never get labelled as the company whinger.
 Prepare for both outcomes - either agreement with your point or disagreement. Plan objectives but be prepared to negotiate. Question yourself before everything else: "Why am I raising this point? What do I want to achieve? What point do I want to make in response? Will there be anything to gain from asking this question? How will I respond if I don't get the answer I want?"
 Never get pushed into a corner through a negative response. Plan ahead. Otherwise you may find yourself flouncing out after threatening to hand in your notice.

webTitle: Jazz review: Ian Shaw/ Claire Martin

fields.headline: Ian Shaw/ Claire Martin
fields.standfirst:
Purcell Room
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Purcell Room
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Ian Shaw and Claire Martin have as formidable a capacity for deflationary humour as they do for spontaneous music-making. The two British jazz singers were presenting a compilation of the best bits from their own celebrations of the great pop songwriters, from Hoagy Carmichael to Burt Bacharach and Stevie Wonder. The only accompaniment was Shaw's piano, which may not be Keith Jarrett, but was all they needed.

In the first half, Shaw demonstrated how fiercely evocative his bluesy sound can be on a Ray Charlesian account of Carmichael's Georgia on My Mind. He then characteristically undermined any risk of self-importance with a hilarious imitation of a harmonica solo.

Martin's silky, low sonorities breathed their way round the room on The Nearness of You, and Shaw's eerie sliding falsetto resolved a delectably fragile reworking of Skylark. Shaw also risked a tangle with the much-sentimentalised Alfie in the second half, and gave the song a spine-tinglingly impassioned edge.

But the appeal of this pair's consistently engaging performances is in the balance between their consummate skill and the way they inhabit a stage with such unforced informality. In Queen Bee, Martin told the audience that Shaw would be uncorking an especially stratospheric high note, and distributed party-poppers to accompany the window-clattering blast. Stagecraft it might have been, but that did not reduce the exhilaration quotient.

fields.headline: Sgt Rock
fields.standfirst:
Camden Palace
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Camden Palace
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
A man wearing a giant styrofoam smiley face and a boilersuit throws shapes beneath a lurid green spotlight. A couple of numbers in, a masked wrestler emerges and trudges round the stage. Such cartoonish capers do not particularly faze or excite the young audience at this club gig; wacky surrealism has been de rigeur in dance music for so long that we have perhaps become visually desensitised. But at least everyone has retained their sense of rhythm, and the crowd moves cheerfully to a handful of numbers from Sgt Rock's debut album, Live the Dream (released on Wiiija last summer), a noisy, jocular swirl of big beat with squelchy acid-house effects.

Named after a DC comics army hero, Sgt Rock are the most recent project from Jim Burke, formerly of Collapsed Lung. With Burke the only musician actually on stage, tearing between his keyboards/sampler and bass guitar, Sgt Rock seem to encapsulate everything about live dance music that its detractors loathe. It's a messy performance, the vocals are perfunctory and even the scratch noises are sampled, which takes away some of the gig's edge.

But Sgt Rock counter such criticism with a wilful light-heartedness and gusto, and an ear for infectious, driving basslines. The instrumentals do tend to blur into one another, but they're essentially geared for dancefloor consumption.

What Sgt Rock can't overcome, however, is the fact that they are ultimately reminiscent of a dozen waggish acts that have gone before, from Altern-8 to Bentley Rhythm Ace and even Carter USM and the Happy Mondays. Acid house always was a pantomime; but "shall we take a trip" never referred to memory lane, and so Sgt Rock's nostalgia-drenched efforts divert rather than command our attention. Even the fresh-faced teenagers in the audience seem aware that rave already happened, and it was more happening than this.

fields.headline: ICI: talking the talk
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: It is probably fair to say that French stockbroker Credit Lyonnais Securities is not a prime mover of prices in London - unless, that is, the stock happens to be chemicals outfit ICI.
fields.body:
It is probably fair to say that French stockbroker Credit Lyonnais Securities is not a prime mover of prices in London - unless, that is, the stock happens to be chemicals outfit ICI.

When Martin Evans - the ICI analyst at Credit Lyonnais - talks, City fund managers tend to listen, and with good reason. After all, it was he who advised clients to buy ICI shares last October, when they were languishing at 350p. Last night, the stock closed at 540p.

After a recent meeting with the company and following the Federal Reserve's decision to cut rates, Mr Evans was again putting clients into ICI yesterday, expecting the shares to reach 650p to 700p in the short term.

Mr Evans thinks ICI is a good cyclical play. He reckons investors will be attracted by a weakening pound against the euro and, because ICI is still a heavily indebted company, the lower interest bill falling rates will bring.

webTitle: Notebook:  Lloyds , Abbey and the BoS

fields.headline: After the phoney bid, the phoney appeal
fields.standfirst:
Lloyds , Abbey and the BoS

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The radio silence over Lloyds TSB's phoney bid to take over its rival, Abbey National, should come to an end next week.
fields.body:
The radio silence over Lloyds TSB's phoney bid to take over its rival, Abbey National, should come to an end next week. Having seemingly strung out the matter for as long as possible, Lloyds will formally ask the office of fair trading how it might react to a deal that promises to scupper Abbey's planned marriage with Bank of Scotland and, in the process, destroy any threat to the high street cabal enjoyed by Britain's four biggest banks.

Outside of the magic money circle, Abbey and BoS have already begun the process and should hear back from the OFT by January 18.

Meanwhile, none of the parties can have been enthralled by the latest evidence of the way the competition authorities are thinking - given this week's decision to order the unwinding of Interbrew's purchase of Bass's brewing interests, which promised to give the Belgian group control over a third of the British brewing industry.

It is baffling that Lloyds, in claiming to be serious in its proposals to take over Abbey, did not formally approach the OFT six weeks ago.

Unless, of course, chief executive Peter Ellwood and his colleagues have really suspected all along that they are not going to get this bid through the competition commission and that their best bet therefore was to keep Abbey and BoS away from the altar long enough for BoS to get cold feet and slope off with an alternative, less threatening, partner.

It is also curious that the Lloyds camp persists with the quietly publicised line that it is ready and willing to launch a hostile bid if Abbey's management cannot be persuaded of the logic of their deal. Whatever the financial attractions of a takeover, few investment bank advisers would claim to be confident of delivering a big enough portion of the 40% or so retail investor base parked on Abbey's share register - from its days when it converted from building society status - to ensure a predatory move was successful.

Abbey, of course, should not be satisfied hiding behind its over-long share register. The big institutions would still like it to talk to Lloyds; they would like to see the numbers and the logic thoroughly discussed.

But as this affair trundles on, the impression remains that Lloyds is using every device available to avoid acting decisively and in the process block a competitive threat. Abbey and BoS are both hamstrung by a "non-bid" - a situation which the City's takeover rules are supposed to avoid. And, as ever, the victims are bank customers.

Mobile show

A good race is fun to watch, and there is real entertainment in witnessing the scramble for second slot in Britain's mobile phone market between Orange, which produced some excellent Christmas trading figures yesterday, and BT Cellnet, which should publish its own numbers next week.

For Orange, whose parent France Telecom is limbering up to float the business in two or three months' time, moving up the rankings would be a publicity coup in the eyes of would-be investors. And for Cellnet, whose parent BT has turned to selling part of its property portfolio to cut debt, the issue is just as acute.

But between watching these two trade blow and counter-blow, and setting aside a touch of bafflement over what makes a mobile such a desirable Christmas present, it is important to keep the big telecoms picture in focus.

For the latter part of last year, telecoms stocks were badly out of favour, largely due to the assumption that mobile firms had overpaid in the auctions for third generation licences in the UK and Germany.

As the markets' techno fever subsided, analysts raced back to the drawing board, redoing their sums on the costs of getting 3G services to customers - that is, the combination of new licences and rolling out new networks - and the impact on corporate balance sheets. Suddenly, questions were being asked about the speed with which money was flowing out - rapidly - and the rather slower rate at which revenues might flow back in.

But take a glance at yesterday's figures from Vodafone.

While admittedly choosing a horse for the course - the strongest mobile operator in Europe - it was able to announce new subscriber numbers which not only reflected last year's string of acquisitions but also demonstrated strong underlying growth. There is no evidence of faddish behaviour on behalf of consumers.

This is not to say all customers of all networks will be happy to take the additional services 3G can provide - and pay through the nose for the privilege. There are bound to be those who struggle. Further consolidation across the mobile industry still seems likely. But as the numbers grow, the mathematics of 3G are becoming less daunting than in the immediate, rather panicky, aftermath of the spectrum auctions.

fields.headline: Abstract art that's not a doodle
fields.standfirst:
John Hoyland
Graves Art Gallery
Sheffield
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
John Hoyland
Graves Art Gallery
Sheffield
Rating: ***
fields.body:
They are just coloured shapes on canvas, or acrylic on cotton duck as it says on the label. They could provide an aesthetic haven of almost spiritual dimensions amid the image rush of our multimedia world. On the other hand, they wouldn't look bad decorating the executive lounge of some multinational company.

This is the problem abstract painters face today. How to create a convincing other space that isn't just an escapist cop-out? John Hoyland has been struggling with this predicament for decades. Here he returns to the city of his birth to stage a mini-retrospective of work dating from the 1960s to November 2000. How taste changes in the fickle art world.

Hoyland was a massive figure in the 1960s and 1970s. In those days his intensely driven battle with the spatial push and pull of primal abstraction was accredited with heroic status. Now many might dismiss him as no more than an irrelevant dauber.

In the early works he stuck to the fundamental building blocks of purist abstraction - the rectangle, the stripe, the splotch, drip and wash. The titles refer simply to the date of the painting's completion, together with the acrylic and duck labelling of the medium. These are paintings whose subject is paint and content is paint.

One large-scale horizontal work, titled 28.2.69, consists of two rectangular blocks of red set against a slurred field of atmospheric orange. The narrow gap between the full-frontal walls of red is partially sealed with a vertical band of dazzling emerald. It's a marvellous work in which the liberating illusions of depth are made all the more captivating by being almost totally contradicted and blocked off.

Sometime in the mid 1980s Hoyland appears suddenly to have changed tactics and strayed away from the self-referential rigour of the work that had gained him such deserved recognition. The titles start to get fancy - The Yellow Boat, The Ocean Stream, Story from Nature. The marks go all organic and jazzy and suggest things other than a focus on paint. The Ark, from 1985, is a great dollop of crap brown accompanied by a fried-egg circle. The Hoyland of old would have been horrified by such fanciful allusions, and rightly so. The feeling that every element is placed to maintain an exquisite pictorial tension has gone.

Doodling takes over. But in the most recent work in the show, The Abyss 7.11.2000, the painter regains some of the old magic. The vertical bars hold in check an eternity of metallic turquoise. fields.bodyText: They are just coloured shapes on canvas, or acrylic on cotton duck as it says on the label. They could provide an aesthetic haven of almost spiritual dimensions amid the image rush of our multimedia world. On the other hand, they wouldn't look bad decorating the executive lounge of some multinational company. This is the problem abstract painters face today. How to create a convincing other space that isn't just an escapist cop-out? John Hoyland has been struggling with this predicament for decades. Here he returns to the city of his birth to stage a mini-retrospective of work dating from the 1960s to November 2000. How taste changes in the fickle art world. Hoyland was a massive figure in the 1960s and 1970s. In those days his intensely driven battle with the spatial push and pull of primal abstraction was accredited with heroic status. Now many might dismiss him as no more than an irrelevant dauber. In the early works he stuck to the fundamental building blocks of purist abstraction - the rectangle, the stripe, the splotch, drip and wash. The titles refer simply to the date of the painting's completion, together with the acrylic and duck labelling of the medium. These are paintings whose subject is paint and content is paint. One large-scale horizontal work, titled 28.2.69, consists of two rectangular blocks of red set against a slurred field of atmospheric orange. The narrow gap between the full-frontal walls of red is partially sealed with a vertical band of dazzling emerald. It's a marvellous work in which the liberating illusions of depth are made all the more captivating by being almost totally contradicted and blocked off. Sometime in the mid 1980s Hoyland appears suddenly to have changed tactics and strayed away from the self-referential rigour of the work that had gained him such deserved recognition. The titles start to get fancy - The Yellow Boat, The Ocean Stream, Story from Nature. The marks go all organic and jazzy and suggest things other than a focus on paint. The Ark, from 1985, is a great dollop of crap brown accompanied by a fried-egg circle. The Hoyland of old would have been horrified by such fanciful allusions, and rightly so. The feeling that every element is placed to maintain an exquisite pictorial tension has gone. Doodling takes over. But in the most recent work in the show, The Abyss 7.11.2000, the painter regains some of the old magic. The vertical bars hold in check an eternity of metallic turquoise. To the right there's a squiggle of red and yellow that seems just about to escape the cage of the picture surface, but not quite. Hoyland is still in there, trying to get out, then trying to get back in.  Until February 17. Details: 0114-278 2600.

fields.headline: Cinderella in a hot-air balloon
fields.standfirst:
The Glass Slipper
Southwark Playhouse
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
The Glass Slipper
Southwark Playhouse
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Charm is not always a virtue in the theatre, but Stephen Sharkey's variation on the Cinderella story combines charm with such keen intelligence that the result is a really delightful piece of theatre, rough and crinkly around the edges but all melting heart at its centre.

This is neither a pantomime nor a children's show, but a piece of grown-up theatre. Sharkey transposes the story to 18th-century London and the reign of George III, who is not yet mad but in Rupert Bates's lovely performance just deliciously dotty. Ella Humbleton's mother dies shortly after giving birth to her only daughter. Daughter grows up with a negligent father who spends his time shooting tigers in India, but when he marries for money, Ella finds her comfortable life transformed. She is forced to become the kitchen skivvy for the social climbing Lady Augusta and her daughters by her previous marriage, Charlotte and Euphronia Snifflewick. Or the Snifflers as they are better known.

Sharkey has some particularly nice touches that, together with the neat script, lift this story above the ordinary. The Snifflewick girls are no ugly stepsisters - they are hideous only on the inside and the younger, Charlotte (delightfully played by Melissa Collier), shows some signs of redemption. There is no fairy godmother either: Ella's transformation is wrought not by magic but through her long dead mother, who is haunting the Humbleton residence. Then there is that carriage.

In this version the pumpkin becomes a hot-air balloon that transports Ella to Vauxhall Pleasure Gardens where the king is giving a ball for his nephew, who is being forced to choose a wife. The rest is pretty much as you would both expect and desire, but the whole thing is executed in Erica Whyman's production with such flair that you can't help falling for it. All the performances are lovely but the production's trump card is Alison Pettitt's Ella, a tall, gawky girl with a smile so radiant she could melt an iceberg at a hundred paces. The prince falls for her, and so does every member of the audience.

 Until January 20. Box office: 020-7620 3494.

webTitle: Theatre review: Summer in the City

fields.headline: Edward Hopper takes to the stage
fields.standfirst:
Summer in the City
BAC
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Summer in the City
BAC
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Edward Hopper was greatly influenced by the theatre: one of his most famous paintings, Early Sunday Morning, was actually derived from a Broadway set by Jo Mielziner. In this hour-long play, Toby Farrow attempts to return the compliment by dramatising the events that lie contained within Hopper's celebrated 1949 canvas, Summer in the City. It seems an ingenious idea but the result locks the painting into a specific meaning and undercuts its mythic, open-ended suggestiveness.

In the Hopper, a woman in a red dress squats moodily on the edge of a bed while behind her a man in grey boxer shorts lies with head buried in the pillow. Transposing the image from the US to Britain, Farrow offers us three possible interpretations of the scene. In one, a seriously ailing man is enjoying a furtive assignation with his brother's wife. In another, the red-dressed figure turns out to be a transvestite landlord who wants slightly more than the rent from his disgusted but nervously compliant tenant. And in the third, a woman has come to reclaim her traumatised soldier-husband while strenuously denying him sex.

Last year Farrow wrote a highly promising play called Gringos - like this, seen at Bristol and BAC - based on his own backpacking experiences in South America. But here he has come up with a dryly conceptual play that, in deracinating Hopper, distorts him by imposing on him an alien gloom. In the words of Robert Hughes, the artist "sensed, but did not agonise over, a profound solitude that lay below American optimism".

As if the Hopper influence were not enough, Farrow also seems to be writing three short playlets in the manner, respectively, of Harold Pinter, Joe Orton and Sarah Kane. The only one that really works is the central one, in which the blond-wigged landlord squanders any chance of escape to distant parts for the sake of a bit of quick nookie with his tenant: clearly, a boy in the hand is worth two in the bush.

My conclusion is that paintings would be best left undramatised. The only time I remotely recall the process working was in David Pownall's Manet-inspired An Audience Called Edouard. Here, Martin Constantine's production for Lifetime Theatre does all it can to evoke memories of Hopper and there are decent performances from Grace Mattaka, Elizabeth Hurran and, not least, Danny Kerr as the draggy landlord. But the real place for Hopper's plangent, illuminated solitude is on gallery walls.

 Until January 20. Box office: 020-7223 2223.
